column4: येन क्षतायुषि मखे विमुखेन कोपा-न(न्न​)ष्टार्त्विजीनमुनिलोकविलुप्ततन्त्रे । दक्षस्य तत्क्षणविषादभुवा निजेन बाष्पह्रदेन पृथुनावभृथो विवव्रे ॥ १७ ॥
column5: yena kṣatāyuṣi makhe vimukhena kopā-nnaṣṭārtvijīnamunilokaviluptatantre | dakṣasya tatkṣaṇaviṣādabhuvā nijena bāṣpahradena pṛthunāvabhṛtho vivavre || 17 ||
column6: रोषवशाद्विमुखेन येन दक्षस्य यज्ञे नाशिते सति, अत एव नष्ट: पलायमान आर्त्विजीनोऽर्त्विकर्मापोहो (? न ऋत्विक्कर्मार्हो) मुनिलोको यत्र । अत एव विलुप्ततन्त्रे नष्टविधौ दक्षस्य दुःखजातेन स्वेनाश्रुपूरेण यज्ञान्तस्नानं सम्पादितम् । यज्ञान्ते हि स्नानमुचितम् । दक्षस्येश्वरेण नाशितयज्ञत्वाच्छोकाश्रुणैव स्नानमभूदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: When the officiating priests scurried away, Sacrifice was left in a lurch. And Shiva, unfavourably disposed towards it because of his anger, deprived it of its life. But Daksha still managed to finish the final ritual ablution in the vast lake of tears stemming that very moment from his sadness.
column8: The destruction of Sacrifice, personified as a deer, is narrated in the Vāmana Purāṇa (Chapter 5) – ‘When the fire was put out, Sacrifice assumed the form of a celestial deer and ran helter-skelter in the sky along with his wife Dakshina’ (‘agnau praṇaṣṭe yajño’pi bhūtvā divyavapurmṛgaḥ | dudrāva viklavagatirdakṣiṇāsahito’mbare’, 5.26) and Shiva killed it in anger with his arrow (‘trinetro yajñaṃ krodhānmārgaṇairājaghāna’, 5.43). The idea in the verse is this – The sacrificer takes a ritual bath when the sacrifice ends. In this case, the sacrifice ended with the very death of personified Sacrifice and Daksha, the sacrificer, took a ritual bath in his very own tears of sorrow.

column4: नृत्तोत्सवे स्फुरति यस्य स दण्डपादो यस्मिन्गते गगनसागरसेतुमुद्राम् । दूराध्वलङ्घनघनश्रमवारिबिन्दु- वृन्दप्रथां चिरमुडूनि कटाक्षयन्ति ॥ १८ ॥
column5: nṛttotsave sphurati yasya sa daṇḍapādo yasmingate gaganasāgarasetumudrām | dūrādhvalaṅghanaghanaśramavāribindu- vṛndaprathāṃ ciramuḍūni kaṭākṣayanti || 18 ||
column6: यस्मिन्व्योमसमुद्रस्य सेतुत्वं याते मार्गोल्लङ्घनजातधर्माम्बुकणसम्भावनां तारा लभन्ते । स दण्डाकारः पादो यस्य स्फुरति ॥
column7: When Shiva’s lively foot, lifted high up in the revelry of dance, becomes a bridge across the sea that is the sky, the stars mimic a closely packed cluster of sweat beads resulting from traversing the long distance

column4: पार्श्वोपविष्टहरिकेशपयोदयोगा-द्द्राग्विद्रुतं रथमरालकुलं विचेतुम् । आपृच्छ्य यं कमलभूः पृथुहंसयूथे ताम्यन्बहु भ्रमति रोधसि मानसस्य ॥ १९ ॥
column5: pārśvopaviṣṭaharikeśapayodayogā-ddrāgvidrutaṃ rathamarālakulaṃ vicetum | āpṛcchya yaṃ kamalabhūḥ pṛthuhaṃsayūthe tāmyanbahu bhramati rodhasi mānasasya || 19 ||
column6: पार्श्व उपविष्टस्य हरेः केशेषु पयोदा मेघास्तेषां सङ्गात्तूर्णमपसृतं वाहहंससमूहं गवेषयितुं यमापृच्छ्य ज्योत्कृत्य मानसतीरे ब्रह्मा बहु भ्रमति । यतो बहुहंसे ताम्यन्खिद्यमानः । यमापृच्छ्यान्वेष्टुमिति वा योज्यम् ॥
column7: The lotus-born Brahma takes leave of him (i.e., Shiva) and wanders on the banks of Lake Manasa, exhausted by endlessly searching among the many flocks of swans roosting there, his own chariot’s swans, which had flown away the very instant they came across the clouds on the tresses of Vishnu sitting close by (i.e., close to Brahma).
column8: The series of events described here is as follows – Brahma approaches Shiva on his swan-drawn chariot to offer respects to the latter; the swans chance upon the clouds on the tresses of Vishnu, who, also having arrived there to offer respects to Shiva, is sitting close by; unable to endure the sight of clouds on Vishnu’s tresses, the swans fly away to Lake Manasa (as they always do at the sight of monsoon clouds); Brahma reaches Lake Manasa expecting to find his swans there; since the bank of Lake Manasa is already populated by innumerable swans, Brahma is left endlessly searching for his own flock among them. JR explains ''āpṛcchya' ('taking leave off') with the less-known synonym 'jyotkṛtya'. See also footnote under 1.31

column4: गौरीमयैकवपुरर्धभृदात्तरागं केयूरकङ्कणफणीन्द्रमणिप्रभाभिः । सेर्ष्यं द्वितीयमपि भागमिवावरुद्धं यः सन्ध्यया सततवल्लभया बिभर्ति ॥ २० ॥
column5: gaurīmayaikavapurardhabhṛdāttarāgaṃ keyūrakaṅkaṇaphaṇīndramaṇiprabhābhiḥ | serṣyaṃ dvitīyamapi bhāgamivāvaruddhaṃ yaḥ sandhyayā satatavallabhayā bibharti || 20 ||
column6: अङ्गदरूपाणां फणीन्द्राणां मणिदीधितिभिरात्तरागं रक्तं द्वितीयमपि स्वशरीरार्धं नित्यप्रियया सन्ध्ययाक्षमापूर्वमवष्टब्धमिव बिभर्ति । यतो गौरीमयमेकं शरीरार्धं बिभ्रत् । अनेन प्रियायै गौर्यै शरीरार्धं दत्तम्, अहमप्यस्य प्रिया, अतो द्वितीयमर्धं रुणध्मीति रत्नांशुव्याजात्सन्ध्ययेवाक्रान्तमित्यर्थः॥
column7: Shiva – one half of whose body is Parvati – sports a second half, which is reddened by the lustre of the gems adorning the (hoods of) the serpent lords that have transformed into his armlets, as though Lady Twilight, his eternal sweetheart, had taken jealous possession of this second half too.
column8: "He has given away one half of his body to Parvati, his beloved. I too am his sweetheart, so let me occupy his other half" - thinking thus, Lady Twilight takes possession of Shiva's remaining half by masquerading as the red glow of the gems adorning the hoods of serpents (JR). See also footnote under 1.48.

column4: यश्चक्षुषः प्रकुपितस्य विकारशान्तिं चक्रे निजस्य बत पावकशोणभासः । कृत्वा स्मरस्य समवर्तिरसाधिरोहं तत्सुभ्रुवश्च विरचय्य घनाश्रुमोक्षम् ॥ २१ ॥
column5: yaścakṣuṣaḥ prakupitasya vikāraśāntiṃ cakre nijasya bata pāvakaśoṇabhāsaḥ | kṛtvā smarasya samavartirasādhirohaṃ tatsubhruvaśca viracayya ghanāśrumokṣam || 21 ||
column6: स्मरस्य समवर्तिरसायां यमभूमावधिरोहं कृत्वा । समवर्तिनो यमस्य रसे संहाराभिलाषे अधिरोहमिति वा । तत्सुभ्रुवो रतेर्घनमश्रुमोक्षं च कृत्वा यः पावकेनाग्निना शोणभासोऽरुणस्य । तृतीयस्येत्यर्थः । नेत्रस्य विकारशान्तिमसौम्यत्वनिवारणं चक्रे । अथ च समा सममात्रा । अविषमा वा । वर्तिस्तूलिका तया रसाधिरोहमन्यस्य कृत्वा । अन्यस्य च बाष्पमोक्षं अग्निरक्तस्य स्वनेत्रस्य विकारशान्तिकरणमद्भुतम् ॥
column7: How strange! Shiva relieved his angry/inflamed eye – red in hue due to the fire within/like fire – of its malefic change/aliment by subjecting Kama to Death’s passionate play/treatment with an appropriate quantity of salve dissolved in water and making his pretty-browed wife shed tears aplenty.
column8: There is an apparent incongruity, indicated through the exclamation 'bata' ('How strange!') in describing Shiva as overcoming the inflammation of his eye through procedures performed on Kama and Rati. 'Varti' is a medicinal preparation (in the form of salve or collyrium) that is used to treat eye disorders; it is dissolved in water or milk (e.g., 'ajākṣīreṇa piṣṭaṃ syādvartirvātākṣiroganut', 'vartiḥ piṣṭā divyena vāriṇā', Caraka Saṃhitā, 6.26.238, 239)

column4: धत्ते द्विजाधिपमुपर्यजिनावतारं स्वं गाहतेऽनवममूर्ध्वशयालुशेषः । भीमाङ्गदाविरहितां च भुजाग्रवीथीं पुष्णात्यपूर्वचरितः पुरुषोत्तमो यः ॥ २२ ॥
column5: dhatte dvijādhipamuparyajināvatāraṃ svaṃ gāhate'navamamūrdhvaśayāluśeṣaḥ | bhīmāṅgadāvirahitāṃ ca bhujāgravīthīṃ puṣṇātyapūrvacaritaḥ puruṣottamo yaḥ || 22 ||
column6: लोकोत्तरचरितो विपरीतस्वभावश्च, पुरुषोत्तमः पुरुषेषूत्तमः हरो हरिश्च, द्विजाधिपं चन्द्रं गरुडं चोपरि धत्ते, अनवममुत्तमं गजचर्माच्छादनम् । नवमं स्वात्मानमजिनस्य सुगतव्यतिरिक्तस्यावतारमुत्पत्तिं गाहते दधाति । तथोर्ध्वमुपरि शयालुर्निवसञ्शेषो यस्य तथा भीमेन फणिमयत्वादङ्गदेनाविरहितां सहिताम् । भीमां भयानकां गदया विरहितां च बाहुवीथीं पुष्णाति । हरेर्हि वाहो गरुडो नवमश्च बुद्धावतारः शेषे च शेते श्रीभोगार्हत्वात्कोमलान्सगदांश्चतुर्भुजान्धत्ते । अतो नारायणपक्षे विरोधः ॥
column7: Shiva is Vishnu himself, albeit of a different nature/Supreme Being, known for his wonderful ways:  He bears the Lord of birds/moon on his head; he assumes the ninth, non-Buddha, incarnation/is draped in a majestic elephant-hide; the Serpent Lord rests on him; and his hand is formidable and doesn’t wield a club/adorned with scary armlets (i.e., serpents).
column8: Vishnu is borne by the Lord of birds, assumes the ninth incarnation of Buddha, rests on the Serpent Lord, and carries a club, called Kaumodakī, in his hand. Shiva, on the other hand, is characterized by the opposite attributes, i.e., he bears the moon on his head, etc.The pun in the word 'puruṣottama' (Vishnu/Supreme Being) serves to equate Shiva with Vishnu whereas the other puns, such as 'dhatte dvijādhipamupari' ('He bears the Lord of birds/moon on his head'), bring out a contrast between them. The words 'ajināvatāram', 'anavamam', and 'bhīmāṅgadāvirahitāṃ' must be split in two ways: 'ajina+avatāram'/'a-jina-avatāram', 'an+avamam'/'a+navamam', and 'bhīma+aṅgada+avirahitām/bhīmāṃ, gadā+virahitām respectively. Buddha is also known as 'Jina' (Cf. 'buddho jinaḥ pātu vaḥ', Nāgānanda, 1.1)

column4: द्यामालिलिङ्ग मुखमाशु दिशां चुचुम्ब रुद्धाम्बरं शशिकलामलिखत्कराग्रैः । अन्तर्निमग्नचरपुष्पशरोऽतिपाता(?तापा)-त्किं किं चकार तरुणो न यदीक्षणाग्निः ॥ २३ ॥
column5: dyāmāliliṅga mukhamāśu diśāṃ cucumba ruddhāmbaraṃ śaśikalāmalikhatkarāgraiḥ | antarnimagnacarapuṣpaśaro'tipātā(?tāpā)-tkiṃ kiṃ cakāra taruṇo na yadīkṣaṇāgniḥ || 23 ||
column6: यन्नेत्राग्निर्द्यां दिवमालिलिङ्ग दिशां च मुखं चुचुम्ब । रुद्धमम्बरं नभो यत्रैवं कृत्वा कराग्रैश्चन्द्रकलामलिखत् । यतोऽन्तर्मध्ये निमग्नचरो दग्धपूर्वः पुष्पशरः कामो यस्य तथा तरुणो दीप्तः। अथ च तरुणो युवा हृदयस्थितकामः सन्किं किं न करोति । काञ्चिदालिङ्गति कासाञ्चिन्मुखं चुम्बति । रुद्धमम्बरं वस्त्रं यत्र काञ्चिन्नखैर्लिखति । इति शब्दशक्तिमूलो ध्वनिः ॥
column7: It embraced the Sky, eagerly kissed the faces of the Directions, and made marks on Lady Crescent with flame tips/nails after engulfing the firmament/seizing the garment; Was there anything which Shiva’s youthful Ocular Fire did not do in its intense heat after Kama/love entered it?
column8: Entered’ (‘nimagnacara’) is used both in its literal and metaphorical senses here. Mankha likens the fire to a love-struck youthful paramour who goes around embracing and kissing women. The Sanskrit words used for sky, directions, and crescent are all in the feminine gender so as to facilitate this idea. It is also possible to explain the compound ‘antarnimagnacarapuṣpaśara’ as ‘after Kama’s arrows entered its heart’. JR's commentary for 'atipātāt' is not available. The actual word here is probably 'atitāpāt', which, because of its dual meanings - 'intense heat' and 'intense passion' - is equally applicable to the fire and the youthful paramour. JR notes that the verse is an instance of suggestion based on the power of words ('śabdaśaktimūladhvani'), effected here by the word 'taruṇaḥ', which functions in the capacity of an adjective ('youthful', qualifying fire) and a noun ('youth') alike.

column4: यो मूर्ध्नि धारयति सान्द्रवलत्फणीन्द्र-फूत्कारधूमलहरि द्रुहिणस्य मुण्डम् । आवासतामरसगन्धलवानुवृत्ते-रद्यापि षट्पदकुलैरिव लिह्यमानम् ॥ २४ ॥
column5: yo mūrdhni dhārayati sāndravalatphaṇīndra-phūtkāradhūmalahari druhiṇasya muṇḍam | āvāsatāmarasagandhalavānuvṛtte-radyāpi ṣaṭpadakulairiva lihyamānam || 24 ||
column6: सान्द्रं यथा भवति तथा वलन्त्यः फणीन्द्रफूत्कारधूमलहर्यो यस्य तद्ब्रह्मणः कपालं धारयति । अतः सम्भाव्यते - ब्रह्मण आवासो यत्तामरसं पद्मं तत्सौरभकणानुवर्तनाद्भ्रमरैरिवास्वाद्यमानम् |गन्धलवानुवर्तनं ब्रह्मशिरसः साक्षादासनपद्मसम्पर्काभावात् ॥
column7: He wears on his crest Brahma’s skull – thickly enveloped by billowing coils of dark smoke emanating from the Serpent Lord’s breaths as if, on account of still carrying a small vestige of the lotus seat’s sweet scent, it were being kissed by swarms of bees.
column8: The ‘lotus seat’ refers here to Brahma’s seat. According to JR, Mankha employs the expression ‘gandhalavānuvṛtti’ (‘a small vestige of the sweet scent’) because Brahma’s skull can carry only a small bit of the lotus seat’s fragrance, given it (before Shiva lopped it off) was not in close contact (in comparison to his limbs) with the flower. See also footnote under 17.33

column4: रूढिं दृढामसमनेत्रतया विवृण्वं-ल्लोकत्रयाक्रमणशौण्डशुभैकपत्रः । आलोकवर्त्मधृतपुष्पवदुद्गमो यः स्थाणुर्गृहीतपरशुर्दुरितं छिनत्ति ॥ २५ ॥
column5: rūḍhiṃ dṛḍhāmasamanetratayā vivṛṇvaṃ-llokatrayākramaṇaśauṇḍaśubhaikapatraḥ | ālokavartmadhṛtapuṣpavadudgamo yaḥ sthāṇurgṛhītaparaśurduritaṃ chinatti || 25 ||
column6: असमानि त्रीणि नेत्राणि यस्य तद्भावेन प्रसिद्धिं प्रकटयन् । लोकत्रयस्याक्रमणे शौण्डं समर्थं शुभमेकं पत्रं वाहनं वृषभो यस्य । तथालोकवर्त्मनि दर्शनाश्रये नेत्रद्वये धृतः पुष्पवतोरर्केन्द्वोरुद्गमो येन। गृहीतः परशुरायुधविशेषो येन । स स्थाणुर्हरः पापं निवारयति । अथ च । असमानि नेत्राणि मूलानि यस्य तद्भावेन प्रसिद्धिं वहन् । स चैकपत्रः । आलोकवर्त्मनि दृश्ये विषये धृतः पुष्पवानुद्गमो येन । स स्थाणुर्मुण्डवृक्षश्च । गृहीतः परशु: काष्ठच्छेदको येन स च्छिनत्ति ॥
column7: He is Sthāṇu/a tree stump. Known widely for his odd-eyed nature/growing firmly on uneven roots, he/it possesses a vehicle/single leaf that can reach as far as the universe, has the sun and moon for his eyes/presents a floral feast to the eyes and carries an axe to cleave miseries apart.
column8: There is an apparent contradiction, effected by pun, in the description of a tree stump that grows firmly on uneven roots, possess a single leaf that reaches as far as the universe, presents a floral feast to the eye, and carries an axe. The contradiction is apparent because it can be solved by taking into consideration the alternative meanings of the words as applicable to Shiva. The use of the word ‘netra’ in the sense of ‘root’ is rare. Shiva wields an axe, wherefore he is known as ‘Khaṇḍaparaśu’ (‘Wielder of the split axe’).

column4: ते कुन्दकुड्मलसगोत्ररुचो मयूखा यस्यावचूलशशिनोऽनिशमुच्छ्वसन्ति । आसीदतां दिविषदां मुकुलीभवन्ति यद्वैभवादिव पुरः करपुष्कराणि ॥ २६ ॥
column5: te kundakuḍmalasagotraruco mayūkhā yasyāvacūlaśaśino'niśamucchvasanti | āsīdatāṃ diviṣadāṃ mukulībhavanti yadvaibhavādiva puraḥ karapuṣkarāṇi || 26 ||
column6: सेवार्थमुपसीदतां सुराणां करमुकुलानि येषां शशिरश्मीनां वैभवान्माहात्म्यादिव सङ्कुचन्ति, ते कुन्दकुड्मलानां सगोत्रा सदृशी रुग्यस्य हरमौलिचन्द्रस्य किरणा जयन्ति। सेवानिमित्तेऽञ्ज​लिबन्धे चन्द्रकरमाहात्म्यं निमित्तान्तरमुत्प्रेक्ष्यते ॥
column7: The continually expanding rays of the moon on his crest are akin to jasmine buds in their brightness. And the lotus-hands of the approaching celestials become cupped in his presence due, as it were, to the power of those rays.
column8: The gods fold their lotus-hands before Shiva in respectful service. Mankha attributes this folding of lotus-hands to the power of moonrays (JR).

column4: जूटाहिराजफणरत्नमरीचिपूरैः सीमन्तितं वदनरन्ध्रपथप्रवृत्तैः । यस्याचकास्ति नृकपालमतीत्य भाल- माग्नेयमन्यदिव लोचनमुज्जिहानम् ॥ २७ ॥
column5: jūṭāhirājaphaṇaratnamarīcipūraiḥ sīmantitaṃ vadanarandhrapathapravṛttaiḥ | yasyācakāsti nṛkapālamatītya bhāla- māgneyamanyadiva locanamujjihānam || 27 ||
column6: कपालसम्बन्धिना मुखरन्ध्रपथेन प्रवृत्तैर्जूटे फणिनां फणरत्नरश्मिकलापैः शोभितं नृकपालं नरमुण्डो यस्य भालमतीत्य ललाटादन्यत्रोत्तिष्ठदन्यन्नेत्रमिव शोभते । महानसे द्वारेभ्यो यथा शिखा निर्यान्ति तथा कपालस्य नेत्रादिभ्यो द्वारेभ्यः शिखा निर्गच्छन्ति । अतस्तृतीयनेत्रवच्चतुर्थमप्याग्नेयं नेत्रमुत्थितमिति सम्भाव्यते ॥
column7: A stream of rays emanating from the gems on the hoods of the snakes residing in Shiva’s matted locks passes through the hollow cavities in the human skull (which he wears on his crest) making it appear like yet another fiery eye, albeit beyond the forehead.
column8: The rays of gems escape through the holes in the skull just like the flames of fire escape through the doors of a kitchen. The blazing skull appears like a fourth eye of fire (JR).

column4: यस्याः परो न करपीडनकृन्न नीता या राहुणा विषयतां दशनक्षतानाम् । या दूषिता न शशशावकचुम्बनेन यस्तां सतीमधिशिरो वहतीन्दुलेखाम् ॥ २८ ॥
column5: yasyāḥ paro na karapīḍanakṛnna nītā yā rāhuṇā viṣayatāṃ daśanakṣatānām | yā dūṣitā na śaśaśāvakacumbanena yastāṃ satīmadhiśiro vahatīndulekhām || 28 ||
column6: यस्याः परोऽर्कादिः करैः रश्मिभिः कराणां रश्मीनां वा पीडनं व्यथां न करोति । दिवसेऽप्यम्लानरश्मिरित्यर्थः । राहुणा दन्तकर्तॄ(?र्तृका)णां क्षतानां घातानां स्थानतां न नीता। लेखामात्रत्वादिति हेतुः प्रत्येयः । अत एव मृगपोतकस्पर्शेन या न दूषिता तां सती शोभनां चन्द्रलेखां बिभर्ति । अथ च सती साध्वीं कश्चिद्वहति यस्याः परः करेण पीडनं कुचादिविमर्दं न करोति । अन्येन रतिदन्तव्रणानां स्थानतां न नीयते । परचुम्बनेन च या न दूषिता ॥
column7: He respectfully bears on his head chaste Lady Crescent – whose hand has never been taken in marriage by anyone/light has never been obscured by any other (celestial) object; on whom Rahu’s bite marks find no place; and whom Little Rabbit has never ever sullied with a kiss.
column8: Mankha compares the crescent moon to a chaste wife whom Shiva respectfully bears on his head. The demon Rahu is believed to swallow the moon during an eclipse; he cannot, however, bite the moon on Shiva's crest since it is in the form of a slender digit (JR). The black mark on the moon is likened to a rabbit, whereby the moon is also known as 'Śaśāṅka' ('Rabbit-marked'); the crescent moon on Shiva's head is too slender to display a black, hare-like mark. JR explains one of the meanings of 'yasyāḥ paro na karapīḍanakṛt' differently: there is no one else (other than her husband) who can compress her (breasts, etc.) with the hand ('yasyāḥ paraḥ kareṇa pīḍanaṃ kucādivimardaṃ na karoti')

column4: वक्रश्रियो गणपतेर्गतिविभ्रमे च देव्या विभाव्य हठचौरमसूययेव । यः कल्पितद्विपतनुं दनुजं चकार श्लिष्यन्मदक्षपणलोलशिलीमुखौघम् ॥ २९ ॥
column5: vakraśriyo gaṇapatergativibhrame ca devyā vibhāvya haṭhacauramasūyayeva | yaḥ kalpitadvipatanuṃ danujaṃ cakāra śliṣyanmadakṣapaṇalolaśilīmukhaugham || 29 ||
column6: गजमुखस्य गणपतेर्मुखशोभायां गौर्या गमनविलासे च लुण्ठाकं गजासुरं निश्चित्येव जातात्क्रोधाद्यः कल्पिता स्वेच्छया गृहीता हस्तिमूर्तिर्येन तं दनुजं गजासुरं श्लिष्यन्यो मदो दानवारि तस्य क्षपणं खण्डनं तेन हेतुना लोलाश्चटुला अन्यत्र गता भ्रमरा यस्मात्तं चकार । 'कृ विक्षेपे' इत्यस्य वा प्रयोगः । चकार विक्षिप्तवान् । तदा श्लिष्यन्मदक्षपणे दानास्वादने लम्पटभ्रमरसमूहं तमिति व्याख्येयम् । अथवा श्लिष्यतः सक्तस्य मदस्य दर्पस्य खण्डने लोलः शिलीमुखौधः शरसमूहो यस्येति व्याख्येयम् । चौरं च मदवारणार्थं निखातशरं कुर्वन्ति ॥
column7: Shiva made the Asura who assumed the form of an elephant the butt of a shower of pride-shattering arrows/disagreeable to swarms of bees by drying up his ichor, perhaps because he could not bear to see the Asura forcibly snatch away the beauty of Ganapati’s face and the graceful gait of Devi.
column8: The gait of beautiful women is often compared to that of elephants. See also foonote under 5.14.

column4: न क्षामतां त्यजति पुष्यति पाण्डिमानं हृद्रूढया परिणमद्विरहोऽङ्कलक्ष्म्या । यस्यामृतांशुरसमद्युसरित्तरङ्ग-शीतोपचारवति जूटतटे शयालुः ॥ ३० ॥
column5: na kṣāmatāṃ tyajati puṣyati pāṇḍimānaṃ hṛdrūḍhayā pariṇamadviraho'ṅkalakṣmyā | yasyāmṛtāṃśurasamadyusarittaraṅga-śītopacāravati jūṭataṭe śayāluḥ || 30 ||
column6: असमा महान्तो ये द्युसरित्तरङ्गा गङ्गालहर्यस्तैः शीतोपचारवति शीतले जूटे वर्तमानश्चन्द्रः क्षामतां कलात्वं न त्यजति । श्वेतत्वं धत्ते । हृदयस्थया कलङ्कलक्ष्म्या च प्राप्तविरहः । हृदयस्थितया च स्त्रिया विरहितः कृशः पाण्डुश्च भवति । शीतले नदीतटे शेते॥
column7: The Moon, separated from the pretty Mark that he cherished in his heart, rests on the slope of Shiva’s matted crest – cooled by the unparalleled waves of the Divine Stream. Assuming an ashen hue, he never abandons his emaciated look.
column8: The crescent moon on Shiva’s matted locks is not marked by a black spot. Mankha compares this moon to a lover who has been separated from his beloved, who, in this case, is the black spot ('aṅkalakṣmī', in the feminine gender). And since lovelorn individuals allay the heat of their separation by resting in cool places, the moon too rests on the slope of Shiva’s matted crest that is cooled by the waves of Ganga. Lovers in separation are characterized by paleness and an emaciated look – features shared by the thin sliver of the moon on Shiva’s crest (JR).

column4: भालस्थलादहरदग्निशिखानुषङ्गं चक्रे वलद्भुजगकङ्कणविप्रलोपम् । निःसर्वमङ्गलमथारचयच्छरीरं हर्तुं स्वसाम्यमिव योऽसुरसुन्दरीणाम् ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: bhālasthalādaharadagniśikhānuṣaṅgaṃ cakre valadbhujagakaṅkaṇavipralopam | niḥsarvamaṅgalamathāracayaccharīraṃ hartuṃ svasāmyamiva yo'surasundarīṇām || 31 ||
column6: असुरस्त्रीणामात्मसाम्यं निवारयितुमिव तासां ललाटादग्निशिखस्य कुङ्कुमस्यानुषङ्गमहरत् । वलन्तो भुजगा बाहुगता ये कङ्कणास्तेषां विप्रलोपं निवारणं चक्रे । तासां शरीरं सर्वमङ्गलेभ्यो निष्क्रान्तं कल्याणरहितं व्यधात् । ईश्वरस्य पुरस्त्रियां चाग्निशिखादिसम्बन्धाद्यत्साम्यमभूत्तद्वारणायेवाग्निशिखादिकमपाहरदित्यर्थः । ईश्वरो हि ललाटेऽग्निं वहति। भुजगाः सर्पास्त एव कङ्कणास्तान्वहति । सर्वमङ्गला गौरी तत्सहितं शरीरं वहति ॥
column7: Desirous, as it were, of putting an end to his semblance with the Tripura maidens, he took away the saffron mark/fire from their foreheads, rid them of the bracelets encircling their arms/armlets of encircling serpents, and deprived their bodies of all auspicious marks/Parvati.
column8: The poet employs pun to establish a semblance between Shiva and the Asura maidens and describes the Lord as ending this semblance by destroying the Asuras and making their wives widows, who, therefore, could no longer decorate themselves with saffron marks, bracelets, or other marks of auspiciousness.

column4: यस्यात्तदाशवपुषः सरुषः सिताश्वे भालस्थलं श्रमपयःप्रकरं ववर्ष । हव्याशनो विषमनेत्रपुटोपविष्टो यत्पातसम्भ्रमभियेव तिरोबभूव ॥ ३२ ॥
column5: yasyāttadāśavapuṣaḥ saruṣaḥ sitāśve bhālasthalaṃ śramapayaḥprakaraṃ vavarṣa | havyāśano viṣamanetrapuṭopaviṣṭo yatpātasambhramabhiyeva tirobabhūva || 32 ||
column6: आत्तमभिनीतं दाशवपुः किरातरूपं येन । सिताश्वेऽर्जुने सकोपस्य यस्य ललाटस्थलं कर्तृ घ​र्मजलप्रवाहं ववर्ष । यस्य घ​र्माम्बुनः पातस्तेन सम्भ्रमाद्भीत्येव विषमे तृतीये नेत्रपुट उपविष्टोऽग्निरन्तर्दधे । ईश्वरेण स्व​रूपस्य प्रकाशनाभावार्थं तृतीयं नेत्रं गोपितम् । तत्र घ​र्मजलपातभीतिर्निमित्तत्वेनोत्प्रेक्ष्यते ॥
column7: Profuse sweat rained from Shiva’s forehead when he was enraged at Arjuna in his hunter’s disguise. And afraid, as it were, of being suddenly put out by it (i.e., the sweat), the fire in the Lord’s third eye vanished out of sight.
column8: By not revealing his third eye, Shiva hid his true identity from Arjuna, the Pandava warrior, when he assumed the hunter's diguise. Mankha supplies a poetically fanciful reason for the missing eye. The story of Shiva testing Arjuna by assuming the form of a hunter and granting him the Pāśupata weapon is told in  Mahābhārata, 3, 40-41. 'Sitāśva' ('one, whose horses are white') is one of the names of Arjuna

column4: शश्वत्सहेलचरणार्पणमात्रकेण कुर्वञ्जगज्जनितनिर्भरजातरूपम् । क्लेशेन सप्तदिवसानि सुवर्णवर्षं यं क्लुप्तवन्तमपि वाहवृषोऽतिशेते ॥ ३३ ॥

column6: सहेलं चरणयोरर्पणं पादन्यासस्तावन्मात्रेण नित्यं जनितान्युत्पादितानि निर्भराणि बहूनि जातरूपाणि सुवर्णविशेषा यस्य तदीदृशं जगत्कुर्वन् । वाहवृषो यं कष्टेन सप्ताहानि सुवर्णं वर्षन्तं जयति। ईश्वरो हि सप्ताहानि सुवर्णं ववर्ष, वृषस्तु नित्यं वर्षति, अतो वाहवृषो जयति । स्व​भक्तान्स्वस्मादधिकान्करोतीत्याशयः ॥
column7: By merely meandering in a leisurely manner, Shiva’s bull continuously fills up the world with surplus gold, thus surpassing its master who, with much difficulty, managed to rain down gold just for one week.
column8: The purport is that Shiva makes his devotees superior even to himself (JR). See also footnote under 1.12.

column6: स्वर्लोके स्वर्गे पक्ष्मलदृशां स्त्रीणां नेत्रोत्पलेषु दृश्यं विषयं रोद्धुमकुण्ठशक्ति । स्वतो विस्तीर्णान्यप्यनिमिषस्त्रीणां नेत्रोत्पलानि विषभयात्सङ्कुचितान्यासन्नित्यर्थः । अत एव तत्काले मथनविषये सम्भ्रमवशाद्धठेन क्षुभितेन सता वम्यमानं धूममिव । धूमो हि दृष्टिपथं रुणद्धि । अत एव च मन्थाद्रिणा मन्दरेण घट्टनं घातस्तद्भयेन पातालतः पलायमानं चिरं राशीभूतमन्धकारमिव । तथोज्जिगमिषन्ती समुद्रादुद्गमिष्यन्तीति सम्भाव्यमाना या कमला श्रीस्तस्या निवासो गृहभूतं विकचं यत्पङ्कजं तस्य पुरःसराः प्रथमोत्थिता ये भ्रमरास्तेषां रीतेः शोभाया लुण्ठाकम् । तथा जगत्त्र​यस्य ग्लपनं हर्षक्षपणं तत्र दुर्ललितं व्यसनिनमत्युद्भटं कृत्वा समुद्रादुत्थितं गरलं विषं गले हारभूता ये फणीन्द्रास्त एवाच्छिदुराः शस्त्रशृङ्खलास्ताभिराहितं धाम स्थानं स्वकण्ठ एव कारागृहं बन्धनधाम तत्र बबन्ध । यश्च लुण्ठाकश्चौरः सर्वग्लपकश्च चपलमुदेति स शृङ्खलाभिः कारागृहे बध्यते ।
column7: 34) to 36) In the prison of his throat, furnished with iron fetters in the form of black cobras worn as garlands, Shiva held the ocean-born Poison captive. This fickle Poison, notorious for troubling the three worlds, blocked the path of vision of the heavenly maidens’ eyes – akin to blue lotuses – as if it were the smoke emitted by the submarine fire when the latter was forcefully stirred up in the frenzy of the on-going churning activity. It looked like some longstanding darkness that, fearful of being pulverized by the Churning Mountain’s rotations, was making a hasty escape from the nether world. And it stole the beauty of the bumblebees swarming before Shri’s blooming lotus abode as she emerged (from the ocean’s depths).
column8: Verses 34-36 constitute a ‘Tilaka’. Even the naturally elongated, unwinking eyes of the heavenly damsels closed in fear of the poison 'Hālāhala' (also called 'Kālakūṭa') as it emerged during the churning of the Milky Ocean; the Poison was guilty of blocking path (of vision), escaping (from the nether world), stealing (the lustre of bumblebees), and causing trouble (to the three worlds), all valid reasons for imprisoning it with chains (JR). JR explains 'āyasa' ('iron') with the synonym 'śastra'. Mankha's comparison of Kālakūṭa with smoke, darkness, and swarm of bees is based both on the shared dark colour and spreading shape.The story of the churnng of the ocean, as narrated in the Bhāgavata Purāṇa (8.7, 8.8), describes Shiva as gulping down the 'Hālāhala' poison after holding it in the hollow of his palm and the poison as causing his neck to turn blue ('tataḥ karatalīkṛtya vyāpi hālāhalaṃ viṣam | abhakṣayanmahādevaḥ - - - ||', 8.7.43; 'cakāra gale nīlaṃ - - - ||', 8.7.44); the appearance of Goddess Shri during the churning of the ocean was preceded, in that order, by the appearance of the celestial cow Havirdhānī, the celestial horse Uccaiśravas, the celestial elephants and their consorts, the celestial gem Kaustubha, the celestial tree Pārijāta, and the celestial women, called Apsarasas (8.8.1-9).

column4: तद्यस्य कैटभजिता घटितैक्यवृत्ते-र्वक्षः कटाक्षयति कञ्चन तुङ्गिमानम् । यस्मिन्परस्परसभाजनसौख्यमाप-देकोदरेण मणिना सह कालकूटः ॥ ३७ ॥
column5: tadyasya kaiṭabhajitā ghaṭitaikyavṛtte- rvakṣaḥ kaṭākṣayati kañcana tuṅgimānam | yasminparasparasabhājanasaukhyamāpa- dekodareṇa maṇinā saha kālakūṭaḥ || 37 ||
column6: एकं साधारणमुदरमुत्पत्तिस्थानं यस्य तेन मणिना कौस्तुभेन सह परस्परं सभाजनं प्रीतिदर्शनं तेन सौख्यं सुखं यत्र कालकूटः प्रापत् । नान्यत्र सङ्क्षिप्तत्वात् । क्वाप्येकत्र तौ नावसताम् । हरिहररूपस्य यस्य वक्षसि विस्तीर्णत्वात्समं वसत इत्यर्थः । कैटभजिता हरिणा घटितैक्यवृत्तिरद्वैतं येन यस्य वा । हरिहररूपस्येत्यर्थः । यस्य तद्वक्षः किमप्यौन्नत्यं दर्शयति । तुङ्ग उदारे च वसतोर्भ्रात्रोः सौहार्दं भवति । महद्भिः सह संयोगे महतां तुङ्गत्ववर्णनमुचितम् ॥
column7: The chest of Shiva, who (as Harihara) has become one in form with Vishnu, exhibits an unusual loftiness that allows the Kalakuta poison to enjoy a mutually respectful relationship with the Kaustubha gem, its sibling.
column8: The purport of the verse is that the Kālakūṭa poison and the Kaustubha gem, which never lived together despite being siblings because they never found a single place that could accomodate both, were able to do so on the lofty clhest of Harihara. People live in perfect harmony under someone who is lofty in character (JR). The Kālakūṭa poison and the Kaustubha gem are siblings since both were born from the ocean when it was being churned (see footnote under 5.36 above)

column4: गौर्या नतश्चरणयोर्दधदुत्तमाङ्गं सङ्क्रान्ततद्रथमृगेन्द्रमुखद्युसिन्धु । यः प्रौढिमेति गुरुगर्वशमाय विष्णो रूपं रसादनुसरन्निव नारसिंहम् ॥ ३८ ॥
column5: gauryā nataścaraṇayordadhaduttamāṅgaṃ saṅkrāntatadrathamṛgendramukhadyusindhu | yaḥ prauḍhimeti gurugarvaśamāya viṣṇo rūpaṃ rasādanusaranniva nārasiṃham || 38 ||
column6: यो गौर्याश्चरणयोर्नतः । अत एव सङ्क्रान्तं प्रतिमितं तद्रथमृगेन्द्रमुखं वाहसिंहमुखं यस्यां सा द्युसिन्धुर्गङ्गा यस्य तच्छिरो दधत् । प्रणामसमये हरशिरस्तिरोभूतं सिंहमुखं प्रतिबिम्बितम् , अतो नरसिंहरूपं वहन्निव हरेर्दर्पभङ्गाय सामर्थ्यमेति ॥
column7: When Shiva prostrates at the feet of Parvati, the face of the lion that is her vehicle is reflected in the Celestial River on his head; wherefore, he seems to eagerly imitate the Man-lion form to subdue Vishnu’s pompous pride.
column8: Men are often described in Sanskrit poetry as prostrating before their sweethearts to allay their love-anger. When Shiva bows down before Parvati, his real head becomes hidden under the reflected head of her lion (JR)

column4: यस्यासकृत्प्रणमतो धृतमन्तुतन्तु-र्नम्रानना गिरिसुताश्रुभिरञ्जनाङ्कैः । मौलौ नवं लिखति शीतरुचेः कलङ्कं पुष्णात्यकाण्डयमुनाप्रणयां च गङ्गाम् ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: yasyāsakṛtpraṇamato dhṛtamantutantu-rnamrānanā girisutāśrubhirañjanāṅkaiḥ | maulau navaṃ likhati śītaruceḥ kalaṅkaṃ puṣṇātyakāṇḍayamunāpraṇayāṃ ca gaṅgām || 39 ||
column6: रोषनिवृत्तये पुनः पुनः प्रणमतो यस्य सम्बन्धिनो मौलिचन्द्रस्यापूर्वं कलङ्कं गौरी साञ्जनैरश्रुभिर्लिखति । तथाकाण्डे प्रयागादन्यत्र यमुनायाः प्रणयः परिचयो यस्यास्तां गङ्गामञ्जनाश्रुभिः करोति । सापराधे भर्तरि प्रणमति स्त्रीणां रोषशमेनाश्रुपातः स्वभावतः। अतो गौर्याः पादयोरुपरि नमतो हरस्य मुकुटचन्द्रे पतिता गौरीबाष्पकणाः कलङ्कत्वेन सम्भाव्यन्ते, गङ्गायां च यमुनात्वेनेत्यर्थः ॥
column7: When Shiva bends down repeatedly before Parvati - her face downcast in unrelenting anger -  she paints, with her kohl-stained tears, a hitherto-unseen black mark on the moon over his crown and makes Ganga, who also dwells there, enjoy an unprecedented bond of friendship with Yamuna.
column8: Since Parvati’s face is downcast, her kohl-stained tears fall directly on Shiva's head as he prostrates before her. The kohl-stained tears (1) fabricate a hitherto-unseen black mark on Shiva’s crest moon ('hitherto-unseen', because, the slender moon on Shiva's head doesn't carry such a mark; see also footnote under 5.28  (2) mingle like the dark waters of Yamuna with the Ganga on his locks. 'Akāṇḍe' ('in an unprecedented way', 'unexpectedly') is described by JR as 'in a place other than the holy site of Prayāga (where the two rivers famously meet)' ('prayāgādanyatra').

column4: प्राङ्निग्रहं विरचयन्वपुषः स्व​रूपं पश्चादनुग्रहदृशा च दिशन्नशेषम् । यः सर्गसंहृतिविपञ्चनमक्रमेण चक्रे महानयविदां प्रथमः स्मरस्य ॥ ४० ॥
column5: prāṅnigrahaṃ viracayanvapuṣaḥ svarūpaṃ paścādanugrahadṛśā ca diśannaśeṣam | yaḥ sargasaṃhṛtivipañcanamakrameṇa cakre mahānayavidāṃ prathamaḥ smarasya || 40 ||
column6: पूर्वं कामस्य शरीरनाशं कुर्वंस्तदनु प्रसाददृष्ट्या विश्ववशीकरणलक्षणं रूपं कामस्य प्रतिपादयन्योऽक्रमेण संहारानन्तरसृष्टिलक्षणेन सर्गसंहृत्योः सृष्टिसंहारयोर्विस्तारणं चक्रे। यतो महानयविदां दर्शनज्ञानामाद्यः। तस्मिन्दर्शने हि संहारानन्तरं सृष्टिः ॥
column7: Shiva, the foremost among those who know the Mahanaya philosophy, first destroyed the body of Kama and then mercifully endowed him with a perfect form, thus turning the acts of creation and dissolution on their heads.
column8: Annihilation/withdrawal precedes creation in the 'Mahānaya' ('Great Way') philosophical system (JR). Mahānaya is a synonym of the Krama school of Śaiva Tantra. Commenting on this very use of the term 'Mahanaya' by Mankha, Rastogi (in 'Rastogi, N. (1996). The Krama Tantricism of Kashmir: Historical and General Sources. India: Motilal Banarsidass') observes that “the Krama system ardently adheres to the cyclical notion of Reality” (p.2) which can allow for the act of withdrawal to precede that of creation.

column4: सख्युः स्मरस्य नवकेतुकृते किरीट-स्वःसिन्धुवाहमकरं सहसेव हर्तुम् । यस्योत्तमाङ्गभुवि पुञ्जितमूर्तिरिन्दु-रास्ते नगेन्द्रतनयाननवर्णचौरः ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: sakhyuḥ smarasya navaketukṛte kirīṭa- svaḥsindhuvāhamakaraṃ sahaseva hartum | yasyottamāṅgabhuvi puñjitamūrtirindu- rāste nagendratanayānanavarṇacauraḥ || 41 ||
column6: स्वमित्रस्य कामस्य ध्वजकृते मौलिगङ्गाया वाहनभूतं मकरं हर्तुमिव चन्द्रो गौरीमुखकान्तिचौरः पुञ्जितमूर्तिः सङ्कुचितवपुरास्ते । कलामात्रत्वात्सङ्कुचितमूर्तित्वं मकरहरणार्थं सम्भाव्यते । चौरश्च हरणोद्यतः स्वगोपनार्थं सङ्कुचितमूर्तिर्भवति ॥
column7: Contracting his body, the Moon – robber of Parvati’s facial charm – waits on Shiva’s head to quickly catch, as it were, a crocodile, floating in the Celestial River adorning the Lord’s crest. for Kama, his friend, to fashion a new banner with it.
column8: Mankha picturises the moon as a thief waiting to catch a crocodile floating in river Ganga. The diminutive form of the crescent moon resembles the contracted body of the thief just as he gets ready to grab the crocodile (JR). The use of ‘caura’ (‘thief’) in the last line gives room for extending the metaphor of thief to the entire verse. One who robs one thing (Parvati’s facial charm) can also rob something else (crocodile). Kama’s banner is marked by the aquatic creature ‘makara’, often identified with the crocodile.

column4: यस्मिन्विनिर्मितवति प्रसभं प्रकोपा-दत्युग्रनिग्रहनवानुभवोपदेशम् । उद्धोष्यते ऋतुषु याज्ञिकतन्त्रविद्भि-रद्यापि पिष्टचरुभाजनमब्जबन्धुः ॥ ४२ ॥
column5: yasminvinirmitavati prasabhaṃ prakopā-datyugranigrahanavānubhavopadeśam | uddhoṣyate ṛtuṣu yājñikatantravidbhi-radyāpi piṣṭacarubhājanamabjabandhuḥ || 42 ||
column6: रोषवशाद्यस्मिन्नादित्यस्यातिदुःसहो यो निग्रहो दन्तभङ्गलक्षणस्तस्य नवो योऽनुभवस्तदुपदेशं कुर्वति सति पिष्टचरोः पुरोडाशस्य भाजनं भवन्नद्यापि याज्ञिकैरर्कः पुरोडाशपात्रं वर्ण्यते । यदुन्मूलितदन्तविषया हेतूत्प्रेक्षेयम् ॥
column7: Since Shiva, in his violent anger, taught the Sun god a lesson by inflicting severe punishment on him, the latter is declared even to this day by those well-versed in Vedic sacrificial rites as partaking the offering of Purodasha.
column8: According to a Puranic legend, Shiva broke the teeth of Surya/Pushan in anger when the latter laughed at him in the sacrificial hall of Daksha (pūṣṇo hyapātayaddantān - - - yo’hasaddarśayandataḥ; Bhagavata Purana, 4.5.21) and since then, the latter partakes of (easy-to-chew) cakes made of rice flour  (puroḍāśa/piṣṭacaru) in Vedic sacrifices. (JR).

column6: यस्य रश्मयः सकलोत्पलानां वैरकराः सोऽर्कः, तथा यः स्त्रीमुखेषूपमानेन बन्धुः परिचितः स चन्द्रः, तथा यज्ञेषु यो मन्त्रपूतामाहुतिं भुङ्क्ते सोऽग्निः, तथा यो विकसतां पुष्पाणां सौगन्ध्यस्य सार्थवाहः सोऽर्थाद्वायुः, तथा यच्छेषाहेराच्छादकत्वाच्छत्रमर्थाद्भूमिः, विधुरः पिपासितो मयूरो बर्हिणो मेघं यद्याचते तज्जलम् , यः शरीरं दीक्षाप्रवेशेन नियमेन तनु(नुं) बिभर्ति स यजमानशब्दव्यपदेश्यात्मा, यः सर्वेषां तारकाणां निरर्गलोऽनिकृष्टः पन्था अर्थादाकाशः, तन्मयीभिरादित्यादिमयीभिरष्टभिर्मूर्तिविवर्तनाभिः शरीरपरिणामैर्भुवनत्रयसामरस्यं व्यापकावस्थानं प्राप्य तिष्ठञ्जनिजरामरणानां जन्मजरामृत्यूनामनभिज्ञं पदं पुष्णञ्शास्त्रेषु वेदादिषु मतिमद्भिर्ब्रह्मादिभिर्यो भगवानष्टमूर्तिरविनाशिरूपोऽगादि गदितः । अपिर्विरोधद्योतकः । यो मूर्तीनामष्टकेन जगन्ति व्याप्नोति स कथमनष्टमूर्तिः । नाष्टौ मूर्तयो यस्येति तत्पक्षे वाक्यम् ॥
column7: 43) to 45) The sun, whose rays are inimical towards all white lilies; the moon, who befriends the faces of doe-eyed maidens by becoming their standard of comparison; the fire, which laps up oblations, offered in Vedic sacrifices to the accompaniment of potent hymns; the wind, which trades in the scent of freshly blooming flowers; the earth, an expansive parasol of Shesha, the lord of serpents; water,  which a tired peacock seeks from the cloud; the self, which assumes (in its role as the sacrificer) a body emaciated by the performance of obligatory rites; and space - a free highway for the movement of all celestial objects: Though Shiva exists in unison with the three worlds through as many transformations of his divine body as these, the scriptures declare him, who nurtures a state that knows no birth, decay, and death, as the one who does not possess eight different forms/whose form is indestructible.
column8: A Tilaka set of 3 verses, alluding to the eight forms of Shiva and ending in an apparent contradiction, made possible through the description of Shiva as ‘Aṣṭamūrti’ ('the Eight-formed one') and ‘an-aṣṭamūrti ('one who is not eight-formed')/'a-naṣṭamūrti ('one whose form is indestructible'). Mankha frequently employs the philosophically loaded word ‘sāmarasya’ in the sense of harmonious blending/unison – see also 8.32, 12.48, 14.28, 14.53, 14.57, 15.29, 15.33, and 20.38.

column5: ūrdhvaṃ vrajatkamalajākalitasphuliṅgaṃ liṅgaṃ tadagnimayamāviravībhavadyaḥ | gacchannadho'vadhididṛkṣutayā mukundo yatrāgrahīnmuhuravāṅmukhadhūmarekhām || 46 ||
column6: अग्निलिङ्गस्योर्ध्वावधिदर्शनेच्छयोर्ध्वं गच्छन्कमलजो ब्रह्मा स एवाकलितः स्फुलिङ्गो वह्निकणो यत्र । तथाधोऽवधिदर्शनेच्छयाधो गच्छन्नारायणोऽवाङ्मुखस्य बुध्नगामिनो धूमस्य भङ्गिमग्रहीत् । तदग्निमयं लिङ्गं यः प्रकटयामास । हरिब्रह्मणोर्धूमाग्निकणत्वारोपद्वारेण लिङ्गावधिभावः सूचितः । धूमस्फुलिङ्गयोरदूरगामित्वात् ॥
column7: When Shiva manifested as a pillar of fire – a Linga – Brahma and Vishnu, each desirous of ascertaining its limits, travelled upwards and downwards respectively; the former attained the state of its (i.e., the fiery pillar’s) spark and the latter took on the semblance of its downward-facing smoke.
column8: Since spark and smoke do not reach very far (away from fire), there is a suggestion that neither Brahma nor Vishnu could find out the limits of the Linga (JR). Brahma and Vishnu are compared to spark and smoke respectively because of their bodily hue. According to the Śiva Purāṇa, there arose a pillar of fire before Brahma and Vishnu, who were enaged in a dispute regarding their relative superiority to one another. Brahma and Vishnu assumed the forms of a swan and a wild boar and went upward and downward respectively to ascertain the limits of the blazing pillar, which they failed to even after spending an eon ('etasminnantare liṅgamabhavaccāvayoḥ puraḥ | vivādaśamanārthaṃ hi - - - || jvālāmālāsahasrāḍhyaṃ - - - || adho gamiṣyāmyanalastambhasy- - - || bhavānūrdhvaṃ - - - gantumarhasi - - || - - - viśvātmā svarūpamakarottadā | vārāhamahamapyāśu haṃsatvaṃ prāptavān - - - || kalpo babhūva - - - || nāpaśyadalpamapyasya mūlaṃ - - - ||' 2.1.7.47-61)

column4: यो वाहिनीं सुमनसां घटितार्धचन्द्रां कुर्वन्पुराणकवितुर्मुखभङ्गहेतुः । भोगैर्वपुः परिचरन्निजमेव चित्रं पुष्णाति सेव्यगुणसम्पदमद्वितीयाम् ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: yo vāhinīṃ sumanasāṃ ghaṭitārdhacandrāṃ kurvanpurāṇakaviturmukhabhaṅgahetuḥ | bhogairvapuḥ paricarannijameva citraṃ puṣṇāti sevyaguṇasampadamadvitīyām || 47 ||
column6: सुमनसां देवानां वाहिनीं नदीं गङ्गां घटितः सङ्क्रान्तोऽर्धचन्द्रो यस्यास्तां कुर्वन् । पुराणकवितुर्ब्रह्मणो मुखभङ्गस्य शिरश्छेदस्य हेतुः । भोगैः सर्पशरीरैरेव निजं वपुः परिचरन् । यः सेव्यस्य सेवनीयस्य राजादेर्गुणास्तेषां सम्पदमद्वितीयामसदृशीं धत्ते। चित्रशब्दो विरोधद्योतकः । यः समुनसां पण्डितानां गणं घटितोऽर्धचन्द्रः स्वलीकारार्थं गलहस्तिका यस्यास्तां करोति । पुराणस्य कवेर्मुखभङ्गेऽवमाने हेतुः । भोगैर्मृष्टान्नपानाद्यैर्निजमेव वपुः परिचरति स सेव्यगुणान्बिभर्तीति विरोधः ॥
column7: Shiva seizes learned men by their necks/makes the army of gods go through humiliation/binds the Celestial River and the crescent moon together. Thanks to him, an elderly poet/ Brahma experienced loss of face. He solely pampers his own body with materialistic comforts/adorns himself with the stretched-out coils of serpents. And strangely, in spite of this, he is still the unparalleled object of devotional service, thanks to all the noble qualities he possesses in rich abundance.
column8: An apparent contradiction, effected through pun, is presented between the first three lines of the verse (which describe some negative attributes in Shiva) and the last line (which praises Shiva as the unparalleled object of devotional service) . The word 'mukhabhaṅgahetu' ('loss of face') is used both in its literal and figurative senses (In connection with this, see also footnote under 17.33)

column4: द्राक्सन्धिष्विव पत्रिषु व्यवहृतिं सञ्चारयन्पञ्चसु व्यञ्जन्नारभटीं शनैरुपनमत्सर्वाङ्गहाराकुलैः(लः)। निर्वाह्य स्ववधाख्यनाटकविधिं मीनावचूलो विश- न्यन्नेत्राग्निशिखावलीजवनिकां तात्पर्यतोऽन्तर्दधे ॥ ४८ ॥

column6: मुखादिषु पश्चसु सन्धिष्विव तापनाद्येषु पञ्चसु शरेषु व्यवहारं लक्ष्यपातं दर्शयन् । आरभटीं संरम्भम् , रौद्रवृत्तिविशेषं च प्रकटयन् । उपनमतां सर्वाङ्गाणां दाहात्मकेन हारेणाकुलः, अङ्गहारैः करणविशेषैश्चाकुल: । स्ववधनामनाटकं सम्पाद्य यन्नेत्राग्नेर्ज्वालापङ्क्तिरेव तिरोधायकत्वाज्जवनिका तिरस्करिणी तां विशन्मीनावचूल: कामः, विशेषणसाम्यावच्छिन्नः शैलूषश्चान्तर्दधे ॥
column7: Kama exhibited a quick expertise in handling his five arrows as if they were the five divisions of a play; he displayed robustness of action/agitation; and zealously presented the Angahara movements, all of which unfolded in a gradual sequence/was perturbed by the loss, occurring one after the other, of all his limbs. In this manner, having put up the play titled “My destruction”, he entered behind the screen, namely, the thick sheet of flames emanating from Shiva’s eye, and finally disappeared.
column8: The five divisions (Sandhis) of a play’s plot are named Mukha, Pratimukha, Garbha, Avamarśa, and Nirvahaṇa. The five arrows of Kama are the flowers Aravinda, Aśoka, Cūta, Navamallikā, and Nīlotpala. JR refers to an alternative list of the five arrows, namely, Unmādana, Tāpana, Śoṣaṇa, Stambhana, and Sammohana. 'Ārabhaṭī' is one of the four modes (vṛtti) of dramatic action that is characterized by predominantly robust movements; a plot that is centered around deception, falsehood, hypocrisy, cheating, and aggression; and the portrayal of emotions such as courage, anger, and wonder ('samuddhataprāyaguṇā vīraraudrādbhutātmikā | kapaṭānṛtadambheṣu vañcanāskandayoḥ sthitā ||', Nāṭakalakṣaṇaratnakośa, 136). Aṅgahāra is a technical term for a specific class of dance movements. The Nāṭyaśāstra (chapter 4) describes 32 such movements, starting with Sthirahasta. The basic element constituting an Aṅgahāra is called Karaṇa, which involves the combined movements of the hand and the feet. Depending on the number of Karaṇas that combine, the Aṅgahāras are named variously as Mātṛkā (2 Karaṇas), kalāpa (3 Karaṇas), khaṇḍaka (4 Karaṇas) , saṅghāta (5 Karaṇas), and so on ('aṅgānāṃ savilāsaṃ yatpradeśamucitaṃ prati | prāpaṇaṃ karaṇotpannamaṅgahāraḥ sa ucyate || ubhābhyāṃ karaṇābhyāṃ syānmātṛkā karaṇaistribhiḥ | kalāpaḥ syāccaturbhiḥ syātkhaṇḍakaḥ pañcabhiḥ punaḥ || saṅghāta iti saṅghātasaṃjñābhedān pare jaguḥ |', quoted as Vipradasa's verses  by Ramakrishna Kavi in Bharatakoṣa, p.787). JR glosses ‘Aṅgahāra’ as a special type of Karaṇa (‘karaṇaviśeṣa’).

column6: यद्भालनेत्रान्तःस्थितस्य यमकाममुखानां प्लोषे दाहे शौटीर्यबन्धोर्धृष्टस्याग्नेस्तरलं कृत्वा विवलनाभिः स्पन्दैर्हेतुभिर्ज्वालामाला रक्तानां जयध्वजानां भङ्गिं बिभ्रति । बलिनो हि जयपताका उचिताः । अग्निश्च यमकामदाहाद्बली, अतो ज्वाला रक्तध्वजत्वेन संभाव्यन्ते॥
column7: Rows of undulating flames emitted by the fire within Shiva’s frontal eye take on the appearance of saffron-hued victory flags celebrating its (i.e., the fire’s) brave exploits such as the burning down of Yama and Kama.
column8: The exploit of burning down Yama relates to the story of Shveta (see footnote under 4.9). Though, according to Liṅga Purāṇa, Yama was deprived of his life merely by looking at Shiva (‘sasarja jīvitaṃ kṣaṇādbhavaṃ nirīkṣya vai bhayāt’, 1.30.21), the Haracaritacintāmaṇi of Jayadratha mentions that Shiva burnt him down with the fire of his eye (jāgrataṃ pāśahastaṃ ca nigirantamivāntakam | śvetānukampī netrāgnijvālayā sañjahāra yaḥ ||, 1.17).

column4: स प्रीतिं च कुतूहलं च जगतां पुष्णातु यस्य स्वयं वामार्धक्रमणोत्सवो गिरिजया यत्र क्षणं जायते । सम्भिन्नोभयवाहनाग्रिमखुरन्यासक्रियानिःसर- न्मुक्तादन्तुरजातरूपविपुलालङ्कारवत्युर्वरा ॥ ५० ॥

column6: यत्रोत्सवे गौरीश्वरावस्थायां स्वामिसम्भेदात्सम्भिन्ने एकीभूते ये उभे वाहने सिंहवृषभौ तयोर्यावग्रिमखुरौ तयोर्या न्यासक्रिया सञ्चरणं तेन निःसरन्ति निर्गलन्ति यानि मुक्तादन्तुराणि समौक्तिकानि जातरूपाणि । सिंहस्य करिकवाटपाटनान्मौक्तिकानि, हरवृषस्य वस्तुधर्मत्वात्काञ्चनानि, तान्येव विपुला अलङ्कारा विद्यन्ते यस्याः सा भूमिर्जायते । स गौर्या स्वयमप्रेरणया हरवामार्धाक्रमणमेवोत्सवो विश्वस्य प्रीतिम्, विचित्रत्वात्कौतुकं च वितनोतु । उत्सवे चालङ्कारधारणमुचितम् ॥
column7: May Shiva – the free appropriation of whose left half by Parvati is a festive event in which Maiden Earth flaunts her rich jewellery of interspersed gold and pearls, produced when their (i.e., Shiva’s and Parvati’s) individual mounts (i.e., the bull and the lion), which are also united, place their front hooves on the ground – fill the worlds with joy and amazement alike.
column8: The idea here is as follows: When Shiva and Parvati unite with one another, their mounts, the bull and the lion, also undergo a physical union. It is believed that Shiva’s bull can unearth gold wherever it places its foot on the ground. Likewise, it is believed that there are pearls found in the frontal globes of elephants which adhere to the blood-soaked claws of a lion when it pounces on them. Therefore, when the united bull-lion mount places its feet on the ground, gold and pearls alternatively fill the earth. According to JR, since the poet likens the union of Shiva and Partvati to a festival, there is poetic propriety in describing Maiden Earth as being richly adorned during this occasion. The poet’s benediction is also marked by propriety since the sight of gold and pearls elicits joy and the sight of a being that is partly bull and partly lion elicits amazement.

column4: नाट्यारम्भे क्षुभितमभितो यो दधानः शरीरं सर्वाङ्गेभ्यः प्रसभमुदयद्भास्मनं रेणुजालम् । पश्चाल्लोकत्रितयविपदां द्रागिवोत्सारितानां दिक्षु न्यस्यत्यनिभृतशिरःसिन्धुपाथःसनाथम् ॥ ५१ ॥
column5: nāṭyārambhe kṣubhitamabhito yo dadhānaḥ śarīraṃ sarvāṅgebhyaḥ prasabhamudayadbhāsmanaṃ reṇujālam | paścāllokatritayavipadāṃ drāgivotsāritānāṃ dikṣu nyasyatyanibhṛtaśiraḥsindhupāthaḥsanātham || 51 ||
column6: नृत्तारम्भे क्षुभितं लोलं शरीरं दधानः, अत एव समस्तावयवेभ्यस्तरसोत्तिष्ठत् । तथानिभृता या शिरःसिन्धुगङ्गा तस्याः पाथो जलं तेन सनाथं युक्तं भस्मरेणुजालं यो विपदामिव पश्चात्क्षिपति । यतो दिक्षु दिगन्तेषु निष्कालितानाम् । दुष्टस्य देशान्निष्कालितस्य पुनः प्रवेशाभावार्थं पश्चाद्भस्मजलं क्षिप्यत इत्याचारः ॥
column7: As he commences to dance, Shiva – his physical frame stirred into action on every side –  forcefully shakes off a mass of ashen dust from each and every limb, along with the roaring waters of the river on his crest, as if (he were scattering a mixture of ash and water all around) after quickly expelling the Miseries, which had been plaguing the triple worlds, to the farthest horizons.
column8: A mixture of ash and water is scattered all around to prevent the re-entry of a criminal who has been expelled from the kingdom (JR). The word 'niṣkālita' (JR) is a synonym of 'niṣkāsita' ('expelled').

column4: दन्तोदन्ततिलाञ्जलौ दिनपतेरम्भोजयोनेः शिरोदारिद्र्ये नयनोद्धतौ भगवतो लीढासुरेन्द्रायुषः । किं चाशेषवपुर्व्यये रतिपतेर्यः कारणत्वं भज-न्नप्यायाति न कुत्र नाम जगतः सर्वाङ्गसिद्ध्यङ्गताम् ॥ ५२ ॥
column5: dantodantatilāñjalau dinapaterambhojayoneḥ śirodāridrye nayanoddhatau bhagavato līḍhāsurendrāyuṣaḥ | kiṃ cāśeṣavapurvyaye ratipateryaḥ kāraṇatvaṃ bhaja-nnapyāyāti na kutra nāma jagataḥ sarvāṅgasiddhyaṅgatām || 52 ||
column6: दिनपतेः सूर्यस्य दन्तानामुदन्तः कथा तस्य तिलाञ्जलौ, वक्रोक्त्या निःशेषतयोन्मूलने । तथा ब्रह्मशिरोदारिद्र्ये मूर्धच्छेदे । तथा लीढं निगीर्णमसुरेन्द्रायुर्येन तस्य भगवतो हरेर्नेत्रोद्धरणे । कामस्य समस्तशरीरनाशे च हेतुभावं भजन्यः सर्वाङ्गायाः सम्पूर्णायाः सिद्धेरङ्गतां साधनत्वं कुत्र नायाति । अपिर्विरोधद्योतकः। यो दन्तादीनामङ्गानां भङ्गहेतुः स सर्वाङ्गानां सिद्धावङ्गतामायातीति चित्रम् ॥
column7: It was Shiva because of whom the Sun God bid farewell to his teeth, Brahma became poorer by one head, Vishnu – he that sucks life away from the Asuras – pulled out his (very own) eye, and Kama had to do away even with his whole body. In spite of all this, is there any place in the universe where he does not figure as the principal organ of perfect success?
column8: Though some gods lost their organs and Kama, even the entire body, on account of Shiva, it is surprising that he is the chief organ of success (i.e., every successful activity in the universe is on account of him). According to the Śiva Purāṇa, Vishnu offered one of his eyes to Shiva in the place of a lotus that went missing during worship (parīkṣārthaṃ viṣṇubhaktestadā vai śaṅkareṇa ha | kamalānāṃ sahasrāttu hṛtamekaṃ ca nīrajam ||, 4.34.20; tadaprāpya viśuddhātmā netramekamudāharat ||, 4.34.22). See also footnotes under 5.42, 17.33.

column4: स्व​यं बभ्रुर्बिभ्रद्विषमनयनस्थेन शिखिना द्रढीयः सौहार्दं सततमनुरुद्धौषधिपतिः। जटाजूटो यस्य त्रिभुवनमनःकौतुककृतः स धत्ते विश्रब्धावसथपथरीतिं फणभृताम् ॥ ५३ ॥
column5: svayaṃ babhrurbibhradviṣamanayanasthena śikhinā draḍhīyaḥ sauhārdaṃ satatamanuruddhauṣadhipatiḥ | jaṭājūṭo yasya tribhuvanamanaḥkautukakṛtaḥ sa dhatte viśrabdhāvasathapatharītiṃ phaṇabhṛtām || 53 ||
column6: स्वयं रागं विना कपिशः । विषमनयनस्थेन शिखिनाग्निना दृढतरं परिचयं बिभ्रत् । सदानुरुद्ध ओषधिपतिश्चन्द्रो येन । स त्रिजगदाश्चर्यकारिणो यस्य जटाजूटः सर्पाणामाश्वस्तावस्थानभङ्गिं धत्ते । अथ च यः स्वयं बभ्रुर्नकुलः । शिखिना मयूरेण यः सौहार्दं बिभर्ति । ओषधीनां नागदमनीप्रभृतीनां पतिर्येन धृतः स कथं सर्पाणामाश्वासस्थानम् । नकुलमयूरौषधिपतयो हि प्रत्येकं वैरिणः, किं पुनः समुदिता इति कौतुकम् ॥
column7: Itself tawny/a mongoose, the matted hair of Shiva – a source of surprise to the minds of everyone inhabiting the three worlds – is a close companion of the fire/peacock that resides in the third eye and is always favourably disposed towards the moon/physician, lord of herbs. (Strangely though,) it serves as the trusted abode of serpents.
column8: It is self-contradictory to describe a mongoose, which is an ally of a peacock and a physician, as providing shelter to serpents, because each one of the three - mongoose, peacock, and physician (specifically a toxicologist, who uses herbs such as 'Nāgadamanī' ) - is a separate threat to their existence (JR). The contradiction is only apparent, to be resolved by taking recourse to the alternative meanings of the punned words.. The Bhāvaprakāśanighaṇṭu describes the 'Nāgadamanī' herb as 'an antidote for all poisons' ('niśśeṣaviṣanāśinī', 4.299).

column4: द्वैधस्यान्तं व्यधित वपुषोर्यस्तमन्द्रीन्द्रपुत्र्या साकं स्थानं कुसुमधनुषोऽनुग्रहात्यादरस्य । सौन्दर्याख्यानवधिमदिरानिर्भरे यत्र नेत्रै-र्लेभे वृन्दारकमृगदृशां स्वैरमापानकेलिः ॥ ५४ ॥
column5: dvaidhasyāntaṃ vyadhita vapuṣoryastamandrīndraputryā sākaṃ sthānaṃ kusumadhanuṣo'nugrahātyādarasya | saundaryākhyānavadhimadirānirbhare yatra netrai-rlebhe vṛndārakamṛgadṛśāṃ svairamāpānakeliḥ || 54 ||
column6: स्व​सम्बन्धिनोः शरीरयोर्द्वैधस्य द्विरूपत्वस्यान्तमेकरूपतां यः शैलपुत्र्या सह चकार । कर्तृसाहित्यागौद्गौर्यप्यकरोदित्यर्थः । कुसुमधनुषः कामस्य योऽनुग्रहो दग्धस्याप्यनुष्ठेयाज्ञत्वं स एवास्यादरस्तस्य स्थानम् । स्त्रीपुंसयोः शरीरैक्यं हि कामाज्ञानुष्ठानलक्षणम् । सौन्दर्याख्या सौन्दर्यव्यपदेश्या, अनवधिः पीयमानत्वेऽप्यक्षया मदिरा तया निर्भरे यत्र शरीरैक्ये देवस्त्रीणां नेत्रैरापानक्रीडा प्राप्ता । गौरीश्वराभ्यां स्वशरीरैक्ये सम्पादिते सति देवस्त्रियः साभिलाषमवसन्नित्यर्थः। दृष्टेर्विस्तारान्मनसः सानुरागत्वाच्च मृगदृशामित्युपन्यस्तम् ॥
column7: Shiva put an end to the dualistic separation between his and Parvati’s body, which (i.e., the end of dualism) was a much esteemed favour he bestowed on the flower-bowed Kama. The glances of the celestial doe-eyed damsels revelled without restraint on this unified form of Shiva and Parvati – filled with the never-ending wine of beauty.
column8: By becoming one in form with Parvati and proving his commitment to love, Shiva complied with the order of Kama, whom he himself had burnt to ashes. Mankha describes this as a favour done by Shiva on Kama (JR)

column4: बिभ्रत्या प्रभुशक्तितां रतिपतेरेकत्र भागे कृत-प्रत्यादेशमगाधिराजसुतया यस्तद्वपुः पुष्यति । वामो यत्र कुचोर्ध्वविस्फुरदुरःशेषाहिरत्नान्तरे सङ्क्रान्तो नयतीव दक्षिणमपि प्रत्यक्षसंल​क्ष्यताम् ॥ ५५ ॥
column5: bibhratyā prabhuśaktitāṃ ratipaterekatra bhāge kṛta-pratyādeśamagādhirājasutayā yastadvapuḥ puṣyati | vāmo yatra kucordhvavisphuraduraḥśeṣāhiratnāntare saṅkrānto nayatīva dakṣiṇamapi pratyakṣasaṃlakṣyatām || 55 ||
column6: रतिपतेः कामस्य प्रभुशक्तितां दधत्या गौर्यैकत्र वामे भागे कृतः प्रत्यादेशः स्वयमाक्रमणेन निराकरणं यस्य तच्छरीरं बिभर्ति । प्रभुशक्तिमांश्च स्वयमाक्रामति । शरीरे यदर्धं सामर्थ्याद्दक्षिणं तत्र विस्फुरन्नुरःस्थो यः शेषाहिस्तद्रत्नमध्ये प्रतिबिम्बितो वामः स्तनो गुप्तमपि दक्षिणं स्तनं प्रत्यक्षं दृश्यतामिव नयति । दक्षिणार्धाभरणीभूतस्य फणिपतेः फणरत्नमध्ये वामस्तनः प्रतिबिम्बितो दक्षिणस्तनतया सम्भाव्यत इत्यर्थः ॥
column7: Shiva possesses a body whose one half is besieged by Parvati – the very personification of Kama’s regal power – and where the gem on the hood of the Serpent Lord, wriggling over the (right) chest, mirrors the left breast, manifesting, as it were, a breast on the right side too.
column8: The left breast, reflected on the serpent’s gem, appears like its right-side counterpart (JR).

column4: स्त्रीपुंसैकात्म्यकल्माषितगति घटयन्यो वपुस्तन्निमेष-क्लेशावेशान्न केषां सुचिरमुदहरत्पर्षदं लोचनानाम् । वामाङ्गोत्तंसगारुत्मतमणिकिरणापह्नुतार्धो रजन्या प्रेयस्या यत्र चूडाविधुरपि वहतीवार्धनारीश्वरत्वम् ॥ ५६ ॥
column5: strīpuṃsaikātmyakalmāṣitagati ghaṭayanyo vapustannimeṣa-kleśāveśānna keṣāṃ suciramudaharatparṣadaṃ locanānām | vāmāṅgottaṃsagārutmatamaṇikiraṇāpahnutārdho rajanyā preyasyā yatra cūḍāvidhurapi vahatīvārdhanārīśvaratvam || 56 ||
column6: यत्रैकीकृते वपुषि वामार्धस्योत्तंसो मूर्धाभरणं ये गारुत्मतमणयस्तेषां किरणैरपह्नुतं छादितमर्धं यस्य तथाविधः सन्मौलिचन्द्रो रात्र्या वल्लभया साह(सहा)र्धनारीश्वरत्वमिव प्राप्रोति। मरकतरत्नरश्मिभिरसितत्वाद्रात्रित्वेन सम्भावितैश्चन्द्रस्याच्छादितत्वादर्धनारीश्वरता सम्भाव्यत इत्यर्थः । स्त्रीपुंसयोरैकात्म्यमेकरूपतापादनं तेन कल्माषिता शबलिता गतिर्यस्य तद्वपुः सम्पादयन्केषां न नेत्रपङ्क्तिं निमेषत्वकर्तृकात्क्लेशादुदहरदुद्ध(द्धृ)तवान् । सर्व एव लोकोत्तरत्वाद्गौरीश्वररूपं निर्निमेषतयापश्यन्नित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Fashioning his (wondrous) form through the amalgamation of the male and the female (halves), Shiva forever frees the eyes of every being from the tiredness of blinking. In this form, one half of the Moon on the (right) crest is hidden by the dark glow of the sapphires adorning the tiara on the left side, so it seems even he has assumed the half-man, half-woman form along with Night, his beloved.
column8: Shiva forever frees the eyes of every being from the tiredness of blinking' is a roundabout way of saying that all beings behold the wondrous form of Shiva with unblinking eyes (JR). Servants often adopt the practices of their masters, so it is befitting that the Moon too should assume the half-man, half-woman form in the manner of Shiva, his master. Verse 19 from the Ardhanārīśvara Stotra, ascribed to Kalhana, plays on the same idea, though it is Parvati’s dark mane this is reflected in the moon here (premṇārdhaṃ vapuṣo vilokya militaṃ devyā samaṃ svāmino maulau yasya niśāpatirnagasutāveṇīniśāmāśritaḥ । āste svāmyanuvartanārthamiva tat kṛtvā vapuḥ khaṇḍitaṃ deyādadvayabhāvanāṃ sa bhagavān devo’rdhanārīśvaraḥ ॥).

column4: देहद्वन्द्वैकशेषं सममवनिभृतः कन्यया निर्मिमाणो यस्तं शस्तं प्रयुङ्क्ते प्रतिरजनिमुखं नाट्यलीलारहस्यम् । श्राम्यन्तो दक्षिणार्धाभरणफणभृतो यत्र फुल्लत्फणाग्रं क्लाम्यद्वामार्ध​निर्यत्सुरभिमुखमरुत्पानगोष्ठीं जुषन्ते ॥ ५७ ॥
column5: dehadvandvaikaśeṣaṃ samamavanibhṛtaḥ kanyayā nirmimāṇo yastaṃ śastaṃ prayuṅkte pratirajanimukhaṃ nāṭyalīlārahasyam | śrāmyanto dakṣiṇārdhābharaṇaphaṇabhṛto yatra phullatphaṇāgraṃ klāmyadvāmādthaniryatsurabhimukhamarutpānagoṣṭhīṃ juṣante || 57 ||
column6: नाट्यवशात्खिद्यमाना दक्षिणार्धाभरणं ये फणभृतः सर्पाः, अबलत्वात्क्लाम्यात्प्राप्तखेदं यद्वामार्धं ततो निर्यन्तो मुखमरुतस्तेषां पानार्थं गोष्ठीमासनबन्धनं फुल्लत्फणाग्रं व्यादीर्णफणं कृत्वा सेवन्ते तं देहद्वन्द्वस्यैकशेषं द्वितीयार्धेन निर्वृतिं गौर्या सह कुर्वाणो यः प्रदोषे नाट्योत्सवं कुरुते तमित्येकशेषविशेषणस्य यत्रेति प्रतिनिर्देशः । एकशेषनिर्देशेन गौरीश्वरयोः सरूपत्वं सूचितमिति भद्रम्॥
column7: Shiva – who has fashioned a single body out of two along with Parvati -  expounds the splendid secrets of the dancing art every twilight hour. And when he does so, the exhausted ornamental serpents on the right half expand their hoods and collectively feast on the fragrant breaths flowing out from the mouth of his fatigued left half (i.e., Parvati).
column8: Shiva dances every day at twilight, whereby he is also known as Sandhyānaṭa.

column4: इति श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराजाराजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये भगवद्वर्णनं नाम पञ्चमः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirājārājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye bhagavadvarṇanaṃ nāma pañcamaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Fifth Canto, named 'Description of the Lord' in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja.

column4: षष्ठः सर्गः ॥
column7: Sixth Canto

column4: अलिव्रजस्यानशनव्रतान्तो मानोग्रशापावधिरङ्गनानाम् । अथैकदानङ्गमदानुकूलः पुष्पावचूल: समयो जजृम्भे ॥ १ ॥
column5: alivrajasyānaśanavratānto mānograśāpāvadhiraṅganānām | athaikadānaṅgamadānukūlaḥ puṣpāvacūla: samayo jajṛmbhe || 1 ||
column6: अथ भगवतः कैलासाश्रयणादनन्तरम् । अथग्रहणं तत्रैवेति प्रतिपादनार्थम् । एकस्मिन्समये पुष्पावचूलः समयो वसन्तो जजृम्भ उल्ललास । शिशिरे पुष्पाभावाद्भ्रमरकुलस्यानशनं भोजनाभाव एव व्रतं तस्यान्तः समाप्तिः। वसन्ते मकरन्दोद्भवात् । स्त्रीणां मान एवोग्रः शापस्तस्यावधिः समाप्तिसङ्केतः। वसन्ते मानं वोढुमशक्तेः । अतोऽनङ्गस्य मदस्तस्यानुकूलः॥
column7: Then, once upon a time, the spring season – whose insignia are flowers – made a grand appearance. Swarms of honey bees ended their fast. The terrible curse of jealous anger was lifted off women. And Kama’s intoxicating pride got a boost.
column8: Then’ implies ‘After Shiva settled down on Mt. Kailasa’ (JR). Some of the features which poets ascribe to the spring season and which Mankha alludes to in this and the following two canto are as follows: Spring is Kama’s ally and abounds in flowers and nectar; mango trees put forth fresh sprouts in spring; there is excitement among cuckoos and bees; the cuckoos feast on mango sprouts and sing the Pañcama (‘pa’) note; women enjoy playing swing sports; trees and creepers that bloom in this season are Aśoka (bears red flowers), Kiṃśuka/Palāśa (flame of the forest, bears red flowers that are curved like the beak of a parrot), Kuravaka/Kurabaka (red amaranth), Karṇikāra (possesses flowers that are colourful but lack fragrance), Tilaka (bears fragrant flowers), Campaka (bears yellow flowers), Nālikera (coconut tree), Kanaka-ketaka (a variety of pandanus that bears fragrant, golden flowers; not to be confused with the Ketaka that has spiny leaves and puts forth flowers in the rainy season; Rajashekhara associates the Kanaka-ketaka with the summer season – ‘puṣpapradaḥ kāñcanaketakīnāṃ grīṣmaḥ’, kāvyamīmāṃsā, chapter 18), Vāsantikā/Atimukta/Mādhavī (types of white jasmine), Pāṭalī/Pāṭalā (trumpet flower), Bakula (bears fragrant flowers), Sindhuvāra/Sinduvāra and Tagara (bear white flowers), Vicakila (a type of jasmine), and Karavīra (fragrant oleander); women perform Dohada rituals to trees before they flower, as for example, kicking the Aśoka with their bedecked foot, hugging the Kuravaka, honouring the Tilaka with their glances, and spitting mouthfuls of wine on the Bakula; the white Kunda/Jāti flowers wither in spring; the southern breeze, bearing the fragrance of sandalwood, blows from Mt. Malaya in the Karṇāṭa, Kerala, and Siṃhala provinces; women cannot sustain their love-anger for long in this season, when factors that excite passion (such as the song of koels and the southern breeze) are all around; separated lovers go through intense suffering, even to the extent of dying; the sun travels to the northern direction; days grow longer; and the winter’s mist clears off, allowing the sun and the moon to shine brightly.

column4: क्रमादवाचीं मलयाद्रिबन्धुमुदीक्षमाणां पवनं युवानम् । उपोढतापं प्रथयञ्शरीरं प्रियोऽम्बुजिन्याः शिथिलीचकार ॥ २ ॥
column5: kramādavācīṃ malayādribandhumudīkṣamāṇāṃ pavanaṃ yuvānam | upoḍhatāpaṃ prathayañśarīraṃ priyo'mbujinyāḥ śithilīcakāra || 2 ||
column6: मलयाद्रेर्बन्धुं नववायुं प्रतीक्षमाणामवाचीं दक्षिणां दिशं नलिन्या नायकः सूर्यः क्रमादशिथिलयत्। वसन्ते सूर्यस्योत्तरदिग्गमनात् । मेघापायाद्देहस्य तापं वहन् । शिथिलीकरणोक्त्या वसन्तस्य प्रौढत्वं सूचितम् । अथ च विशेषणसाम्यावच्छिन्नत्वाक्षिप्तां नायिकां महतः कस्यचिद्बन्धुं तरुणमभिप्रायेणेक्षमाणामम्बुजिन्याः सखीत्वव्यवहृताया वल्लभः स्वदेहमीर्ष्यया तापेन युक्तं वहञ्शिथिलां करोति । अनुभूतस्नेहां चित्तादवरोहयतीत्यर्थः॥
column7: All heated up, the Sun – husband of the Lotus Plant - broke up with Lady South who was eagerly looking forward to meet the youthful Breeze – companion of Mt. Malaya.
column8: Though the contextual meaning pertains to certain happenings in the spring season, the non-contextual meaning relates to a lover (the sun) who breaks up with his girlfriend (the southern direction) in envy (scorching heat) on account of her fondness for another man (southern breeze) who is youthful and related to a certain powerful person (Mt. Malaya); the lotus plant stands for the girl friend's female confidant, whose husband the lover (i.e., the sun) is (JR).

column4: कश्मीरकान्ताननकिङ्कराणि पङ्केरुहाणि क्व न पल्वलेषु । अथाविरासन्सहसोपगन्तुं वसन्तलक्ष्म्या इव विष्टरत्वम् ॥ ३ ॥
column5: kaśmīrakāntānanakiṅkarāṇi paṅkeruhāṇi kva na palvaleṣu | athāvirāsansahasopagantuṃ vasantalakṣmyā iva viṣṭaratvam || 3 ||
column6: कश्मीरस्त्रीमुखानां किङ्कराणि पद्मानि तडागेषु क्व नाविरासन् । अत उत्प्रेक्ष्यते वसन्तलक्ष्म्या आसनत्वं गन्तुमिव । लक्ष्म्याः पद्मासनत्वात् । पद्मेष्वेव वसन्तलक्ष्मीरवसदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Lotuses – servants waiting upon the faces of Kashmira maidens – sprang up everywhere in lales  to instantly tranform, or so it seemed, into the seats of spring’s Fortune Goddess.
column8: Servants waiting upon the faces of Kashmira maidens' is an indirect way of saying that the faces of Kashmira maidens were lovelier than lotuses. Lakshmi, the goddess of fortune, resides in lotuses; 'lakṣmī' and  'śrī' are often added to insentient entities such as day (e.g., 'dinalakṣmī'), seasons (e.g., 'madhuśrī'), sky (e.g., 'vyomaśrī'), forest (e.g., 'vanalakṣmī'), etc. to personify them.

column4: अखण्डषाड्गुण्य​पथेषु विद्वान्वसन्त एको रसपार्थिवस्य । अन्यर्तवो मान्मथपुस्तकेषु न ग्रन्थिमुन्मोक्तुमपि क्षमन्ते ॥ ४ ॥
column5: akhaṇḍaṣāḍguṇypatheṣu vidvānvasanta eko rasapārthivasya | anyartavo mānmathapustakeṣu na granthimunmoktumapi kṣamante || 4 ||
column6: रसपार्थिवस्य कामस्याखण्डं यत्षाड्गुण्यं जगद्विषयः सन्धिविग्रहादिव्यवहारस्तन्मार्गेषु वसन्त एको विद्वान्बभूव । पार्थिवत्वात्षाड्गुण्योक्तिः । वसन्तादन्ये ऋतवो ग्रीष्मादय: कामतन्त्रेषु ग्रन्थिमात्रमपि निवारयितुं न शक्ताः । अपिशब्देन दण्डापूपिकया कामशास्त्रावबोधो दुष्कर इति सूचितम् । सौन्दर्यातिशयेन वसन्तो यथा कामकथान्तरङ्गो न तथा ग्रीष्माद्या इति कविना प्रौढोक्त्या वर्णितम् ॥
column7: Spring alone is knowledgeable about the nitty-gritties in the royal matters of Kama – passion’s monarch. Other seasons are incapable of disentangling even one little knotty detail in love’s corpus.
column8: The purport is that other seasons are not as conducive to love as spring is (JR).

column4: स्फुरत्पलाशोष्ठपुटो विलोलद्विरेफमालातरलीकृतभ्रूः । फुल्लाब्जनिःस्पन्ददृगास्त नूनं शृङ्गारकाव्योन्मुखधीर्वसन्तः ॥ ५ ॥
column5: sphuratpalāśoṣṭhapuṭo viloladvirephamālātaralīkṛtabhrūḥ | phullābjaniḥspandadṛgāsta nūnaṃ śṛṅgārakāvyonmukhadhīrvasantaḥ || 5 ||
column6: स्फुरन्ति चपलानि पलाशान्येवौष्ठपुटं यस्य । विलोलालिपङ्क्तिरेव कम्पिता भ्रूर्येन । फुल्लान्यब्जान्येव निःस्पन्दा दृग्यस्य । अतो नूनं मन्ये वसन्तः शृङ्गारकाव्ये कामवीर्यप्रबन्धे सम्मुखी धीर्यस्य स आस्त । सर्वाभिर्विच्छित्तिभिर्वसन्तः कामं प्रकाशितवानित्यर्थः । अन्यश्च काव्यं कुर्वन्नेवंविधो भवति ॥
column7: Spring seemed like he was desirous of composing a love poem: Palasha blossoms became his muttering lips, an undulating swarm of bees, his dancing brow, and steady, freshly bloomed lotuses, his fixed eyes.
column8: One exhibits mannerisms such as muttering to oneself when engaged in composing a poem; the overall purport of the verse is that the spring evoked love in each every way (JR).

column4: चिरानुभूतोष्णमयूखसख्यप्रवृद्धतापग्लपनेच्छयेव । दिग्दक्षिणा चन्दनसौरभार्द्रमरुत्तरङ्गप्रणयं पुपोष ॥ ६ ॥
column5: cirānubhūtoṣṇamayūkhasakhyapravṛddhatāpaglapanecchayeva | digdakṣiṇā candanasaurabhārdramaruttaraṅgapraṇayaṃ pupoṣa || 6 ||
column6: चिरमनुभूतं कृतानुभावं यदुष्णमयूखसख्यं दक्षिणायनकृतः सूर्यसंयोगस्तेन प्रवृद्धो यस्तापस्तस्य ग्लपनं खण्डनं तत्रेच्छयेव दक्षिणा दिक्चन्दनसौरभेणार्द्रस्तत्क्षणस्पृष्टो यो मरुत्तत्परिचयं पुपोष । वस्तुगत्या वसन्ते मलयमरुद्वहति । दक्षिणदिशस्तत्सेवनं तापनिवारणेच्छा निमित्तत्वेन सम्भाव्यते । उष्णमयूख इति साकूतम् । अन्योऽपि तापार्तश्चन्दनं पवनं च सेवते ॥
column7: Desirous, as it were, of allaying the excessive heat caused by her long-term association with the hot-rayed sun, the Southern Direction took a liking for the billowing breeze that was soaked in the fragrance of sandalwood.
column8: Cool breeze and sandalwood allay heat

column4: शनैः शनैर्मानवतीकवोष्णश्वासोर्मिभिः सार्धमवर्धताहः । निशीथिनी कार्श्य​दशां वियोगिजीवाशया सार्धमपि प्रपेदे ॥ ७ ॥
column5: śanaiḥ śanairmānavatīkavoṣṇaśvāsormibhiḥ sārdhamavardhatāhaḥ | niśīthinī kārśyadaśāṃ viyogijīvāśayā sārdhamapi prapede || 7 ||
column6: मानिनीनामतनुतापवशात्कवोष्णाः किञ्चिदुष्णा ये निःश्वासास्तैः सह क्रमेण दिनं ववृधे । दिनेषु वृद्धेषु विरहवशान्मानिन्यो बहून्निःश्वासानमुञ्चन्नित्यर्थः। विरहिणां जीवे जीवन आशया साकं रात्रिर्दुर्बलतामापत् । वसन्ते रात्रिष्वल्पीभूतासु विरहिणो जीवाशामत्यजन्नित्यर्थः ॥
column7: The day gradually grew longer along with the lukewarm sighs of women in love anger. And the night too dwindled away along with the lovelorn person’s hope for survival.
column8: The sighs are an indication of sadness brought about by separation.

column4: पलाशरक्तार्द्रनखे वसन्तकण्ठीरवे मानगजोऽङ्गनाभ्यः । भीतो ययौ साञ्जनबाष्पपङ्क्तिच्छलाद्विमुक्तायसशृङ्खलालिः ॥ ८ ॥
column5: palāśaraktārdranakhe vasantakaṇṭhīrave mānagajo'ṅganābhyaḥ | bhīto yayau sāñjanabāṣpapaṅkticchalādvimuktāyasaśṛṅkhalāliḥ || 8 ||
column6: वसन्त एव कण्ठीरवः सिंहः । पलाशानि किंशुकान्येव रक्तार्दा नखा यस्य तस्मिन्सति भीतो मान एव हस्ती स्त्रीभ्यः सकाशाद्ययौ पलायितः । साञ्जनाश्रुव्याजाद्विमुक्ता त्यक्तायसी लोहमयी शृङ्खलाङ्क्तिर्येन । सिंहे च पलाशे पलं मांसमश्नाति, अत एव रक्तार्द्रनखे सति भीरुश्छेदितशृङ्खलो गजोऽपसरति ॥
column7: In the presence of the spring season – a flesh-devouring lion, whose bloody claws are the red Palasha flowers – love anger, like a terrified elephant, ran far away from women, freeing itself from iron shackles disguised as lines of kohl-stained tears (shed by them).
column8: Palāśa also means ‘flesh-devouring’

column4: दिग्दक्षिणार्कं न शशाक हातुं तत्सङ्गतः सोऽपि सदाल्पतापः । परस्परं किं तु तयोस्तदानीं न वेद्मि कः पैशुनमाचचार ॥ ९ ॥
column5: digdakṣiṇārkaṃ na śaśāka hātuṃ tatsaṅgataḥ so'pi sadālpatāpaḥ | parasparaṃ kiṃ tu tayostadānīṃ na vedmi kaḥ paiśunamācacāra || 9 ||
column6: दक्षिणा दिगर्कं त्यक्तुं शक्ता नाभूत् । षण्मासान् रवेर्दक्षिणदिक्स्थत्वात् । तथा दक्षिणदिशासङ्गतः सङ्गच्छमानस्तत्सङ्गमाद्वा स रविश्च सदाल्पतापोऽभूत् । दक्षिणायने हिममयत्वात्। तयोरर्कदक्षिणदिशोरन्योन्यं भेदकं पैशुनमसत्यदोषारोपणं कश्चकारेति न जाने। लिङ्गविशेषाद्विशेषणसाम्याच्च दिगर्कयोः कामुकमिथुनव्यवहारप्रतीतिः । तत्पक्षे दक्षिणानुकूला ॥
column7: The amicable Southern Direction was (until now) incapable of forsaking the Sun. And he too was always soft-rayed/quite happy in her association. God knows whose malicious talk caused a drift between the two.
column8: Dakṣiṇā imeans both ‘southern’ and ‘amicable’ ('anukūlā'). The sun stays in the southern direction for six months in a year, a period known as 'Dakṣiṇāyana', which is characterized by increasing cold. The idea of a lover and his beloved is superimposed on the sun and the southern direction (JR)

column4: ये तस्थुरुद्यानपथेऽतिवेलमनेलमूकाः शिशिरेऽन्यपुष्टाः । ऋतुक्षितीशस्य त एव चित्रमास्थानविद्यापतयो बभूवुः ॥ १० ॥
column5: ye tasthurudyānapathe'tivelamanelamūkāḥ śiśire'nyapuṣṭāḥ | ṛtukṣitīśasya ta eva citramāsthānavidyāpatayo babhūvuḥ || 10 ||
column6: उद्यानान्तर्ये शिशिरेऽनेलमूका वक्तुं श्रोतुं चासमर्थास्तस्थुस्त एव कोकिला वसन्तस्यास्थाने विद्यापतयः पण्डिताश्चित्रं बभूवुः । राजानुगुणोक्तिरियम् । अनेलमूकाश्चान्यपुष्टा भवन्ति ॥
column7: How strange! Those very cuckoos (literally ‘reared by others’), which spent their winter in groves as thoroughly deaf and dumb creatures, transformed into highly learned pundits in the court of Spring – king among seasons.
column8: Cuckoos are silent during winter (udyānānāṃ mūkapuṃskokilatvaṃ --- hemante syāt, Kāvyamīmāṃsā, chapter 18). One of the words for cuckoo in Sanskrit is ‘anyapuṣṭa’ that means 'reared by a stranger (i.e., a crow)’. The deaf and the dumb too are often forsaken by their families and reared by kind strangers (JR).

column4: उद्यद्रजोभिर्घनपत्रशोभै रुन्धद्भिराशाः परपुष्टनादैः । अध्वन्यलोकः सुरभेर्बिभाय​ कन्दर्पसैन्यैरिव बालचूतैः ॥ ११ ॥
column5: udyadrajobhirghanapatraśobhai rundhadbhirāśāḥ parapuṣṭanādaiḥ | adhvanyalokaḥ surabherbibhāya kandarpasainyairiva bālacūtaiḥ || 11 ||
column6: उद्यद्यद्रजो मकरन्दः, धूलिश्च येषु । तथा घना पत्राणां [किसलयानाम्], वाहनानां च शोभा येषु । तथा परपुष्टनादैः पिकशब्दैः, परमत्यर्थं पुष्टैर्नादैश्च करणैराशा दिशः, जयाशाश्च रुन्धद्भिः । कामकटकैरिव चूतवृक्षैर्हेतुभिर्वसन्तात्पथिकलोको भीतो बभूव ॥
column7: Wayfarers feared the spring season because of its young mango trees that looked like Kama’s battalions: scattering pollen/dust; dazzling with densely packed leaves/chariots; and pervading the directions with the call of cuckoos/frustrating hopes (of winning) with their terrifying war cries.

column4: वियोगिभिः प्रोच्छ्वसदट्टहासवासन्तिकाशिक्षितसाहसानि । अकाण्डवैतण्डिककोकिलानि कैरप्यसह्यन्त न काननानि ॥ १२ ॥
column5: viyogibhiḥ procchvasadaṭṭahāsavāsantikāśikṣitasāhasāni | akāṇḍavaitaṇḍikakokilāni kairapyasahyanta na kānanāni || 12 ||
column6: प्रोच्छ्रसन्नट्टहासो विकासो यासां ता वासन्तिका माधव्यस्ताभिर्हेतुभिः शिक्षितं साहसं विरहिवधादिर्यैर्येषु वा । तथाकाण्डे रात्रावपि वैतण्डिता(का) बहुजल्पाकाः कोकिला येषु तानि वनानि कैरपि विरहिभिर्न सेहिरे ॥
column7: No lovelorn people could tolerate the woods where the boisterously laughing Vasantika bloom advocated thoughtless aggression and koels prattled continuously even at odd hours.
column8: Aggression’ here means ‘killing of lovelorn people, etc.' ('virahivadhādiḥ', JR).

column4: विवृण्वता सौरभरोरदोषं बन्दिव्रतं वर्णगुणैः स्पृशन्त्याः । विकस्वरे कस्य न कर्णिकारे घ्राणेन दृष्टेर्ववृधे विवादः ॥ १३ ॥
column5: vivṛṇvatā saurabharoradoṣaṃ bandivrataṃ varṇaguṇaiḥ spṛśantyāḥ | vikasvare kasya na karṇikāre ghrāṇena dṛṣṭervavṛdhe vivādaḥ || 13 ||
column6: कर्णिकारे सौरभरोरं सौगन्ध्याभाव एव दोषस्तं प्रकाशयता घ्राणेन सह दृष्टेर्विवादो ववृधे । यतः कर्णिकारवर्णगुणैर्हेतुभिः स्तुतिं कुर्वन्त्याः । दृष्टिनासिकयोः स्वविषये गुणदोषदर्शनात्तन्निराकरणसमर्थहेतूपन्याससामर्थ्याभावेन निर्णयरहिते विवादे समाप्तिर्नासीदित्यर्थः । कर्णिकारस्य वर्णसौभाग्यं सौगन्ध्याभावश्च कविना युक्त्या प्रतिपादित इति कर्णिकारम​ङ्ख इति प्रसिद्धिः॥
column7: When the Karnikara blossomed, the nose and the eye debated - "Poor in fragrance" declared the nose; "So colourful" praised the eye.
column8: Mankha is famed as ‘Karrṇikāra-Mankha’ on account of this verse. ‘Rora’ is a rare word that means ‘poor’/’wretched’; the footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition cites Kalhana's use of this word in Rājataraṅgiṇī, 5.15 ('pātreṣu roraśikhibhāgiṣu')

column4: शशाक नो यः किमपि ग्रहीतुमध्याप्यमानोऽपि वराङ्गनाभिः । उद्यानलीलान्यभृतस्तदानीं स सिद्धसारस्वततां प्रपेदे ॥ १४ ॥
column5: śaśāka no yaḥ kimapi grahītumadhyāpyamāno'pi varāṅganābhiḥ | udyānalīlānyabhṛtastadānīṃ sa siddhasārasvatatāṃ prapede || 14 ||
column6: वरा उत्तमा उपाध्यायकर्मणि निपुणा या अङ्गनास्ताभिः पाठ्यमानोऽपि यः कोकिल: किञ्चिदप्यध्येतुं नाशकत्, स तदानीं वसन्तकाले सिद्धं स्वयं निष्पन्नं न तु साध्यं सरस्व​तीसम्बन्धि वाग्भवकौशलं यस्य तद्भावं प्रपेदे । 'पुराङ्गनाभिः' इति वा पाठः । नगरस्त्रीभिः । न तु ग्राम्याभिरित्यर्थः । पुरेति भिन्नं पदं वा। समन्तादन्यदा पठने प्रेरितोऽपि जाड्यमेव योऽभजत्, स कोकिलो वसन्ते स्वयमुपाध्यायनिरपेक्षतया वाक्कौशलशाली बभूवेत्यर्थः॥
column7: Earlier, the sportive cuckoo in the pleasure grove couldn’t learn a thing even though it was taught by clever, city-bred women of the best kind. Presently (in the spring season), that very cuckoo transformed into a scholar of perfected eloquence
column8: JR provides  ‘purāṅganābhiḥ’ (‘city-bred lasses’) as an alternative reading for ‘varāṅganābhiḥ’ (‘best women’). Even clever, city-bred lasses, as contrasted with simple-minded, rustic women, could not teach a word to the cuckoo in the past. The word 'purāṅganābhiḥ' can also be split as 'purā' ('in the past') and 'aganābhiḥ'  ('by women') (JR). The translation incorporates all the different meanings noted above.

column4: व्यक्तानलोल्काकृतिमध्यमध्यसमुच्छलद्गुच्छगवाक्षिताङ्गी । कङ्केल्लिवल्लिस्तुहिनात्ययेऽपि बभावनङ्गस्य हसन्तिकेव ॥ १५ ॥
column5: vyaktānalolkākṛtimadhyamadhyasamucchaladgucchagavākṣitāṅgī | kaṅkellivallistuhinātyaye'pi babhāvanaṅgasya hasantikeva || 15 ||
column6: व्यक्ताः फुल्ला अनलोल्काकृतयोऽग्निज्वालारूपत्वेन व्यवस्थिता मध्यमध्य उत्पन्ना ये गुच्छाः स्तबकास्तैर्गवाक्षितानि जालयुक्तान्यङ्गानि यस्याः सा कङ्केल्लिवल्लिरशोकलता बभौ । अनङ्गस्य हिमाभावेऽपि [अङ्गार]शकटिकेव । हसन्तिका च जालयुक्ता शस्त्रमयी मग्नाग्निः ॥
column7: The young Ashoka tree – latticed by flame-like bunches of flowers bursting forth intermittently – shone like a Hasantika (ember basket) used by Kama even after the winter season had ended.
column8: See footnote under 3.29. The Hasantikā was used by Kashmiris to keep themselves warm in winter.

column4: स्वपक्षलीलालडितैरुपोढहेतौ स्मरे दर्शयतो विशेषम् । मानं निराकर्तुमशेषयूनां पिकस्य पाण्डित्यमखण्डमासीत् ॥ १६ ॥
column5: svapakṣalīlālaḍitairupoḍhahetau smare darśayato viśeṣam | mānaṃ nirākartumaśeṣayūnāṃ pikasya pāṇḍityamakhaṇḍamāsīt || 16 ||
column6: स्व आत्मीयः कोकिलस्य पक्षस्तल्लडितैरुपोढा हेतिरायुधं येन पिकपक्षविक्षेपैरेव कामस्य धनुष्कार्यसिद्धेः । कामे बलोपोद्वलनाद्विशेषमाधिक्यं दर्शयतः कोकिलस्य पाण्डित्यं ज्ञत्वं तरुणानां मानं वनितोपेक्षां निवारयितुमखण्डमभूत् । अथ च सिसाधयिषितधर्मविशिष्टो धर्मी पक्षः । हेतुः साधनोपन्यासः । हेतुबलेन स्वपक्षे परपक्षादुत्कर्षं दर्शयतः कस्यचित्पण्डितानां मानं प्रत्यक्षादि निराकर्तुं ज्ञत्वमस्ति ॥
column7: The cuckoo, which brought out the greatness in Kama by the graceful flappings of its wings/easy validations of its thesis that served the purpose of equipping him with a weapon/supplying him with logical reasons, was a complete genius in quashing every youth's self-righteous pride/proof.
column8: The pun in this verse is effected by the use of certain technical terms from Nyāya logic. Pakṣa is defined as ‘One of the two alternative views about a topic of contention’ (‘vipratipattyekakoṭiḥ’, Gautama Nyāya Sūtra, Vṛtti1.41). An example of such a contested topic would be the eternality or otherwise of sound. If one of the pakṣa is ‘sound is eternal’, its opposite pakṣa – the pratipakṣa – would be ‘sound is non-eternal’. Pakṣa is also the minor term in a syllogism. For example, in the syllogism ‘The mountain is fiery, because of smoke’, the minor term is mountain. It is qualified by the major term, i.e., fire, which needs to be established (‘sisādhayiṣādharmaviśiṣṭo dharmī’, JR). Hetu is the advancement of proof by providing logical reasons (‘sādhanopanyāso hetuḥ’, JR). Māna is the means of knowledge, such as direct perception or inference, by employing which one can prove one’s view about a topic of contention. To summarize the idea of this verse, the cuckoo energizes Kama by the flapping its wings (which is an excitant of love) and aids him in quashing the self-righteous pride of young men just as a scholar strengthens his side of a debate by supplying it with logical reasons, so the opponent's proof can be refuted.

column4: सिन्दूरितानङ्गमतङ्गजास्यं यद्व्यानशेऽशोकरजो जगन्ति । तन्मानिनीमानतमोऽङ्क(न्त)कारं बालातपाहङ्कृतिमारुरोह ॥ १७ ॥
column5: sindūritānaṅgamataṅgajāsyaṃ yadvyānaśe'śokarajo jaganti | tanmāninīmānatamo'ṅka(nta)kāraṃ bālātapāhaṅkṛtimāruroha || 17 ||
column6: सिन्दूरितं सिन्दूरवत्कृतं कामकरिमुखं येन तदशोकानां रजो जगन्ति व्यानशे व्याप्त्या जगृहे यत्ततो हेतोर्मानिनीनां मानतमसोऽङ्क(न्त)कारं विनाशकं बालातपस्पर्धामाप । यथा बालातपोऽन्धकारं निराकरोति तथाशोकरजो मानं निराचकारेत्यर्थः ॥
column7: The worlds were bathed in the pollen of Ashoka blossoms, which looked like vermilion marks on the face of the elephant named Kama and became the dawn’s crimson light in putting up a spirited fight against the pitch-black darkness of women’s’ love-pique.
column8: Mankha has employed the word 'aṅkakāra' elsewhere too (see also 1.43, 7.11)

column4: नीरन्ध्रनिर्यत्सुमनोनिकायकाषायपट्टप्रणयादशोकः। जग्राह भिक्षुव्रतमध्वगानां मनःसु शून्यत्वमिवोपदेष्टुम् ॥ १८ ॥
column5: nīrandhraniryatsumanonikāyakāṣāyapaṭṭapraṇayādaśokaḥ| jagrāha bhikṣuvratamadhvagānāṃ manaḥsu śūnyatvamivopadeṣṭum || 18 ||
column6: नीरन्ध्रं निर्विवरं कृत्वा निर्यन्नुद्भिद्यमानो यः सुमनोनिकायः पुष्पसमूहः स एव काषायपट्टस्तस्य प्रणयात्परिचयादशोको भिक्षुव्रतं शाक्यदर्शननिर्दिष्टमाचारमिव जग्राह। किं कर्तुम् । पान्थानां चेतःसु शून्यत्वं किङ्कर्तव्यतामूढत्वमुपदेष्टुम् । भिक्षवो हि काषायधारिणः शून्यत्वमनुपपद्यमानरूपत्वमुपदिशन्ति॥
column7: The Ashoka, by way of donning the ochre robe, namely, its red canopy of thickly blossomiing floral clusters, took the vow of a Buddhist mendicant tfor preaching the doctrine of emptiness to lovelorn wayfarers, or so it seemed.
column8: The doctrine of emptiness maintains that the existence of external forms cannot be proved (‘anupapadyamānarūpatvam'; JR); in the case of lovelorn travelllers, 'emptiness’ stands for 'an inability to decide what to do' (‘kiṅkartavyatāmūḍhatvam’, JR).

column4: वियोगिनीरोषकषायितेव नेत्रद्युतिर्विस्फुरिता स्मरस्य । प्राप्ता पलाशेषु बभौ शुकाग्रचञ्चुस्तुतिस्तेयनिरङ्कुशेषु ॥ १९ ॥
column5: viyoginīroṣakaṣāyiteva netradyutirvisphuritā smarasya | prāptā palāśeṣu babhau śukāgracañcustutisteyaniraṅkuśeṣu || 19 ||
column6: मानवशात्प्राप्तविरहासु यो रोषस्तेन कषायिता रक्ता कामस्य दृष्टिर्दीप्तिः पलाशेष्विव प्राप्ता शुशुभे । यतः शुकानामग्रचञ्चोश्चञ्च्व​ग्रस्य रक्तत्वेन या स्तुतिस्तस्याः स्तेयं हरणं तत्र निरङ्कुशेषु निरवग्रहेषु । पलाशानां नैसर्गिकं रक्तत्वं नास्ति, किं तु मानिनी क्रोधारुणा कामस्य दृष्टि: पलाशेषु पतिता । लोहितत्वात्स्मरोद्दीपकत्वाच्च सम्भावना । स्तेनेषु च क्रुद्धा राजदृष्टिः पतति ॥
column7: Kama, who was angry at lovelorn ladies, seemed to have cast his bloodshot glances on the Palasha flowers that were  involved in looting the crimson glory of parrot's beak.
column8: Loveorn ladies' = 'ladies seperated from their lovers because of pique' ('māninī'); the naturally red Kiṃśuka flowers are imagined by the poet as having become red by the angry glances of Kama (Kings cast  angry glances on robbers) (JR). .

column4: कामप्रशस्त्यक्षरसम्प्रदायो वियोगिहालाहलबीजमुष्टिः । द्विरेफराजी रुरुचे लतानां ग्रैवेयगारुत्मतरत्नमाला ॥ २० ॥
column5: kāmapraśastyakṣarasampradāyo viyogihālāhalabījamuṣṭiḥ | dvirepharājī ruruce latānāṃ graiveyagārutmataratnamālā || 20 ||
column6: कामस्य यशःप्रशस्तिस्तत्राक्षराणि तेषां सम्प्रदायः परम्परागतः क्रमः । कृष्णत्वान्मालारूपत्वाच्च । तथातएव विरहिणां विषबीजमुष्टिः । अथवा हालाहलशब्देन दुःखं लक्ष्यते। तथा लतानां ग्रैवेयं ग्रीवाभरणं चासौ गारुत्मतरत्नानां माला । लता अत्र नायिकास्थानीयाः ॥
column7: A line of bumblebees appeared like a sequence of characters engraved in Kama’s panegyric, a fistful of the deadliest poison’s seeds to the lovelorn, and a sapphire necklace to adorn Creepers.
column8: Hālāhala' has the metaphorical sense of 'sorrow'; the creepers personify amorous women (JR).

column4: सत्यं वसन्तक्रकचक्षतानां शल्कं निशानामलयो बभूवुः । न चेत्कथं पान्थनितम्बिनीनां व्यधुर्दृशोरान्ध्यनवोपदेशम् ॥ २१ ॥
column5: satyaṃ vasantakrakacakṣatānāṃ śalkaṃ niśānāmalayo babhūvuḥ | na cetkathaṃ pānthanitambinīnāṃ vyadhurdṛśorāndhyanavopadeśam || 21 ||
column6: वसन्तेन कर्त्रा क्रकचेनेव करणेन क्षतानां तनूकृतानां रात्रीणां शल्कं चूर्णं भ्रमरा नूनमभवन् । भ्रमराश्च शल्कं यदि नाभवंस्तत्कथं पान्थस्त्रीणां दृष्टेरन्धभावोपदेशमकार्षुः । चूर्णमेव हि दृष्टेरान्ध्यं करोति। आन्ध्यं हि विरहजनितं चूर्णकृतं च दृष्टिविघातार्थम् ॥
