column6: अहिमालि फणिधरं वपुर्बिभ्राणः । लुप्तः संसारिणां तापो येन स गौरीपतिः सकलगणैः सहिताम् । तथा आदिश्चासौ सारा च तां सभां दिवा प्रातरवापत् । आश्चर्यमित्यादिविरोधसूचकम् । अविद्यमाना हिमस्यालिः पङ्क्तिर्यस्य स लुप्तताप इत्याश्चर्यम् । गणैर्भ्वादिभिर्युक्तां दिवादिरेव धातुपाठच्छेदविशेषः सारो यस्या इत्यपूर्वत्वम् । दिवाशब्दोऽव्ययं प्रातर्वाचकम् । केचित्तु 'दिवादिसाराम्' इत्येकपदं कृत्वा एवं व्याचक्षते दिवादौ स्वर्गादौ सारामिति । तत्तु न लाक्षणिकं हृदयङ्गमम् । 'दिव उत्' इति दिवशब्दस्योत्वप्राप्तेः । यच्च दिवशब्दो समानोऽस्ति (?) तन्न तथा मतम्। दिवशब्दस्य महाकविभिरप्रयुक्तत्वात् ॥
column7: Possessed of a form which was not blanketed by thick snow/sported snakes and (yet) quelled the heat of agony, thereby accomplishing an astonishing feat, Parvati’s Dearest Partner entered the wondrous hall at daybreak, (hall) that was filled with the Ganas and stood foremost among all things valuable/comprised of all grammatical classes of verb roots and (yet) had (only) the class of verb roots starting with ‘div’ as its essence.
column8: An apparent contradiction effected by pun. JR contests the opinion of certain others  on the meaning of ‘divādisārām’. As against JR, who regards ‘divādisārām’ as a phrase formed by two different words, namely, the indeclinable ‘divā’ and the adjective ‘ādisārām’ (qualifying 'sabhām'), others explain it as a compound whose component words are ‘divādi’ and ‘sārām’ and means ‘eminent in the heaven etc. (i.e., in the three worlds, starting with heaven)’. According to JR, such an explanation is wrong on two accounts. Firstly, there is the word ‘div’, meaning ‘heaven’, which, if compounded with ‘ādi’ could become ‘divādi’. But such a possibility is checked by the rule ‘diva ut’ that specifies the transformation of ‘div’ into ‘dyu’. Therefore, ‘div’ cannot appear as it is when compounded with ‘ādi’. Secondly, although there exists an independent word ‘diva’ that also means ‘heaven’ and can be compounded with ‘ādi’ without the need to undergo any transformation, eminent poets (such as Mankha) do not employ it. The word 'ahimāli' can be split in two ways to derive two different meanings: 'ahi+māli' ('sporting snakes') and 'a+hima+āli' ('not blanketed by thick snow').

column4: नेत्राग्निज्वलनविलीयमानचूडाखण्डेन्दुस्रवदमृतोपजातजीवान् । भूयोऽपि प्रमुषितसम्पदो नृमुण्डान्कुर्वाणः श्वसितविषेण कङ्कणाहेः ॥ ७ ॥
column5: netrāgnijvalanavilīyamānacūḍākhaṇḍendusravadamṛtopajātajīvān | bhūyo'pi pramuṣitasampado nṛmuṇḍānkurvāṇaḥ śvasitaviṣeṇa kaṅkaṇāheḥ || 7 ||
column6: नेत्राग्रेर्ज्वलनं तेन विलीयमानाच्चूडाचन्द्राद्द्रवतामृतेनोपजातो जीवः प्राणो येषां तान्नृमुण्डान्कपालानि केयूराहिविषश्वासेन पुनरपि गतचेतनान्कुर्वाणः। प्रतिप्रसवालङ्कारः॥
column7: Shiva brought his ornamental human skulls back to life with the nectar of immortality trickling down from the crest-borne crescent, dissolving in the heat of the ocular fire, only to quickly rob them of their luck with the venomous breaths of the snakes forming his bracelets.
column8: The skulls that were brought to life by the flow of ambrosia were quickly deprived of it by the venomous breaths of the snakes. JR identifies the figure of speech in this verse as ‘pratiprasavālaṅkāra’, which is described by Shobhakara as ‘the recurrence of something that had ceased to exist’ (‘pratyāpattiḥ pratiprasavaḥ’, ‘nivṛttārthasya punaḥ prāptiḥ pratyāpattiḥ’, Alaṅkāraratnākara, sutra no. 85 and the explanation under it). In this verse, the skulls that were delivered from their lifeless state by the ambrosia were once again made lifeless by the venomous breaths of the serpents.

column4: चिन्वानो दृढतरमह्युपोढभारं पादाब्जद्वितयमिवोच्चजूटबन्धम् । ग्रीवाया वलयमिवान्वहं दधानो दोर्दण्डं श्रितविषमांसलस्वरूपम् ॥ ८ ॥
column5: cinvāno dṛḍhataramahyupoḍhabhāraṃ pādābjadvitayamivoccajūṭabandham | grīvāyā valayamivānvahaṃ dadhāno dordaṇḍaṃ śritaviṣamāṃsalasvarūpam || 8 ||
column6: दृढतरं कृत्वाहीनां सर्पणामुपोढो भारो येन तमुच्चमुन्नतं जूटबन्धं बिभ्राणः । पादपक्षे दृढतरमप्युपोढो भारो यस्य । श्रितं विषमांसलं पीवरं स्व​रूपं येन तं दोर्दण्डं दधानः । ग्रीवापक्षे श्रितविषं मांसलस्वरूपं यस्य ॥
column7: His pair of lotus-feet resembled his lofty matted hair since its weight was firmly borne by the earth/serpent (used as a hairband). And he possessed a shapely neck that forever appeared like his arm since it was sturdy and marked by poison/muscular with raised shoulders.
column8: The compound 'dṛḍhataramahyupoḍhabhāram' must be split in two different ways in order to get the two different meanings: 'dṛḍhataram+ahi+upoḍhabhāram' and 'dṛḍhatara+mahī+upoḍhabhāram'. JR’s commentary in the Kāvyamālā edition has  'dṛḍhataramapyupoḍho', which is a faulty reading and, as such, not useful in figuring out the punned meaning.

column4: व्यग्राणां चटुघटनासु वीक्षमाणो नेत्रान्तैर्वदनममर्त्यमागधानाम् । नाथोऽथ प्रमथसभां प्रपद्य तस्थावासीनः शिरसि विलासविष्टरस्य ॥ ९ ॥

column7: Ganesha plucked the crescent moon from the tip of his father’s matted crown and fixed it in the place of his other (broken) tusk. However, he only ended up breaking even his intact tusk, bathed as it was in mighty streams of moonlight.

JR describes this as a fact ('vastugati') and a species-specific occurance ('jātidharma'). Ganesha has a single tusk, whereby one of his names is ‘Ekadanta’.

column4: प्राविक्षन्नथ शनकैरकैतवेन व्यञ्जन्तो विनयविनम्रतां शिरोभिः । सर्वेऽपि त्रिदिवसदो निवेद्यमानाः सावज्ञं किमपि शिलादनन्दनेन ॥ १४ ॥

column7: And so all the gods, their heads bent in humility, entered quietly and unpretentiously in as Nandi announced something to them with disdain.
column8: With disdain’, because Nandi, being the attendant of Shiva, the lord of the universe, couldn’t care less for smaller gods. Nandi is the son of the sage Shilada (See footnote under 7.45)

column6: ते सुधा अन्धो भोजनं येषां ते संहत्य मिलित्वा भगवते प्रणतिं चक्रुः । संहत्येति भक्त्युद्रेकप्रतिपादनम् । यतस्तस्य भगवतः पादौ शिरसि कुर्वतां पुरुषाणां जगत्कर्तृ, स्वान्मौलीन्पादुकीकरोति पादपीठानि कुरुते ॥
column7: Thereafter, the gods, whose food is ambrosia, prostrated in unison before the triple-eyed Shiva from far. The world (i.e., humanity) undoubtedly makes its heads the footrests of those who place the Lord’s feet upon their heads.
column8: The idea in the second half of the verse is that people bow down before those who bow down to Shiva.

column6: अपिशब्दो भिन्नक्रमः पुररिपुशब्दात्परो द्रष्टव्यः । धामत्रयीप्रकृतयो भगवतापि निर्व्याजं न्यस्ता दृष्टिलेखा देवानां सन्तापं जाड्यं च निवारयामासुः । भगवद्दृष्टिपातमात्रेणैव तापजाड्यनिवृत्तिर्जातेत्यर्थः। बतेत्याश्चर्यसूचकम् । सूर्येन्द्वग्निभिस्तापजाड्यहरणं कथं भवतीत्यर्थः ॥

column8: Shiva enquired the gods about their welfare since it is a practice to do so when someone arrives from far and not because he needed their help (JR).

column4: विश्वेषां पुरि पुरि यत्सदैव शेषे विद्वद्भिः पुरुष इति प्रतीयसे तत् । किं धामत्रितयमयानपायदृष्टेस्तस्मात्ते जगति परोक्षमस्ति वस्तु ॥ १८ ॥
column5: viśveṣāṃ puri puri yatsadaiva śeṣe vidvadbhiḥ puruṣa iti pratīyase tat | kiṃ dhāmatritayamayānapāyadṛṣṭestasmātte jagati parokṣamasti vastu || 18 ||
column6: त्वं नित्यमेव पुरि पुरि यच्छेषे ततो विद्वद्भिस्त्वं पुरुष इति प्रतीयसे यथार्थः कथ्यसे । कदाचिन्महतामेव पुरि पुरीत्याह - विश्वेषामिति । ब्रह्मादिकीटान्तानाम् । तस्मात्पुरि पुरि निवासाद्धेतोर्धामत्रयरूपनिर्दोषदृष्टेस्ते जगति मध्ये किं वस्तु परोक्षमस्ति । सर्वमेव दृश्यमित्यर्थः । एवं वचनोपोद्धात एव युक्त्या विपत्सूचनम् ॥
column7: Since you constantly dwell in each and every body, the wise call you the body-dwelling ‘Purusha’. Therefore, is there anything in this world that is hidden from you, whose imperishable eyes are the three luminaries (i.e., the sun, moon, and fire)?
column8: The etymology of the word ‘puruṣa’ is ‘puri dehe śete’ (‘one who dwells in the body’). By praising Shiva as all-knowing, the gods hint at the very commencement of their speech that he is aware of their sad plight, caused by the Tripuaras (JR).

column4: नन्वेवं(कं) किमपि विनिर्मलं प्रकृत्या त्वद्रूपं सुरसरिदम्बुवत्पुनीते । स्रोतोभिस्त्रिभिरथ कारणात्मभिस्तद्विश्वात्मन्कृतकमपि व्यनक्ति भेदम् ॥
column5: nanvevaṃ(kaṃ) kimapi vinirmalaṃ prakṛtyā tvadrūpaṃ surasaridambuvatpunīte | srotobhistribhiratha kāraṇātmabhistadviśvātmankṛtakamapi vyanakti bhedam ||
column6: गङ्गाजलमिवैकं स्वभावेन निर्मलं च किमपि भवद्रूपं पवित्रयति । अथ कारणात्मभिर्हरिहरब्रह्माद्यैस्त्रिभिः स्रोतोभिस्त्वद्रूपं कर्तृ कृतकं स्वेच्छया कृतं भेदं प्रकाशयति। गङ्गाजलं च त्रिधा भिन्नम् ॥
column7: O Universal Self! It is indeed true that your form, which eludes description, is unitary and elementally pure like the water of Ganga; but it also exhibits an artificial division in to the three streams constituted by the forces of creation and the like (i.e., sustenance and annihilation).
column8: The naturally pure water of Ganga too is essentially one though it seemingly divides into three streams that nourish the triple world; 'tribhiḥ kāraṇātmabhiḥ srotobhiḥ' = Hari, Hara, and Brahma (JR).

column4: धिङ्मूढा वितथमुदासनस्वभावं भाषन्ते पुरुष तव त्रिलोकभर्तुः । कर्त्री चेत्प्रकृतिरियं करोतु किञ्चित्कैवल्यं भवदधिरोहमन्तरेण ॥ २० ॥
column5: dhiṅmūḍhā vitathamudāsanasvabhāvaṃ bhāṣante puruṣa tava trilokabhartuḥ | kartrī cetprakṛtiriyaṃ karotu kiñcitkaivalyaṃ bhavadadhirohamantareṇa || 20 ||
column6: धिङ् निन्दायाम् । मूढा मोहावृतचेतसः पुरुषाः । तवोदासीनस्वभावं ताटस्थ्यं वितथमसत्यं भाषन्ते । नन्द्यादित्वाल्ल्युः । यतस्तव त्रिलोकभर्तुः । अथ यदि पुरुषनिरपेक्षतया प्रकृतेरेव कर्तृत्वमारोप्यते तर्हि भवत्सम्बन्धं विना केवलत्वं प्रकृतिः किञ्चित्करोतु । त्रिलोककर्तृत्वं दूरतोऽस्तु, त्वां विना तृणाञ्चनमपि कर्तुमशक्तेति प्रतिपादनार्थं किञ्चिद्ग्रहणम् । एतेन साङ्ख्यमतं निराकृतम् । ते हि सत्त्वरजस्तमःसाम्यावस्थालक्षणायाः प्रकृतेः कर्तृत्वं मन्यन्ते ॥
column7: O Purusha - Conscious Being! Fie upon those deluded men who falsely claim that you, the lord of the three worlds, are characterized by aloofness. If Prakrti – Primeval Matter – is indeed an independent agent, let us see if she can somehow bring about a state of Kaivalya - absolute solitude - without associating with you.
column8: This verse attacks the Sāṅkhya doctrine of an active Prakṛti that is independent of Puruṣa, who is described as aloof. The gods ask: If material Prakṛti possesses independent agency, why doesn’t she liberate an individual from the cycle of birth and death all by herself, without the help of conscious Puruṣa? The overall purport is that matter’s apparent dynamism and agency result from its association with consciousness, which, in fact, is the actual agent. This line of thought is in keeping with the tenets of the Trika philosophy, according to which Universal Consciousness, as Shiva, uses it powers to both bind itself in and free itself from saṃsāra as part of its divine play. JR comments – ‘Prakṛti cannot even bend a blade of grass without you, what to speak of creating the three worlds’.

column4: किं मिथ्या हर महदादिषु प्रयुङ्क्ते लोकोऽयं विकृतिमयेषु तत्त्वशब्दम् । एकस्त्वं निरुपधि(निरवधि)रूपभृद्धि तथ्यं तत्तत्त्वं पुरुष बिभर्षि पञ्चविंशः ॥ २१ ॥
column5: kiṃ mithyā hara mahadādiṣu prayuṅkte loko'yaṃ vikṛtimayeṣu tattvaśabdam | ekastvaṃ nirupadhi(niravadhi)rūpabhṛddhi tathyaṃ tattattvaṃ puruṣa bibharṣi pañcaviṃśaḥ || 21 ||
column6: महदादि येषां तेषु तत्त्वमिति शब्दमयं लोकः किं प्रयुङ्क्ते। मा प्रयुङ्क्तादित्यर्थः । यतो विकृतिमयेषु विकाररूपेषु । निरवधि अवच्छेदोपरागरहितं रूपं बिभ्रत्त्वमेकस्तत्त्वशब्दं तथ्यं बिभर्षि । पञ्चविंशतेः पूरणं पञ्चविंशम् । महद्बुद्धितत्त्वम् । सञ्ज्ञाशब्दोऽयम्॥
column7: O Hara! Why does the world use the word ‘Tattva’ - ‘principle’-  in vain with respect to the intellect and the like that are all of the nature of modifications? O Purusha! It is you alone – the twenty-fifth (principle) – possessing a form that is pure and not subject to limitations, who truly merits the word ‘Tattva’.
column8: This is again directed at the Sāṅkhya doctrine, which recognizes 25 principles, of which 24 are part of the ever-changing Prakṛti and the 25th is the unchanging Puruṣa. According to the gods, the word ‘Tattva’ (‘principle’) is too very imbued with significance to be applied for entities that keep changing. It is only the unchanging Puruṣa, who merits to be called ‘Tattva’. 'Nirupadhi' = 'pure'; 'niravadhi' = 'free of limitations'.

column4: किं कर्तुं तव पुरतोऽथ किं नु वक्तुं शक्ष्यामः क्षितिधरराजमूर्धशायिन् । त्वं खण्डं क्वचिदपि नो पदं व्यनक्षि त्रैलोक्यं ध्वनिवपुषश्च ते विवर्तः॥ २२ ॥
column5: kiṃ kartuṃ tava purato'tha kiṃ nu vaktuṃ śakṣyāmaḥ kṣitidhararājamūrdhaśāyin | tvaṃ khaṇḍaṃ kvacidapi no padaṃ vyanakṣi trailokyaṃ dhvanivapuṣaśca te vivartaḥ|| 22 ||
column6: हे कैलासवासिन् , तवाग्रे वयं किं कर्तुं वक्तुं वा शक्ष्यामः । यतस्त्वमखण्डं पदं स्फोटरूपं प्रकटयसि । शब्दब्रह्मस्वरूपस्य च ते त्रिभुवनमसत्यः परिणामः। एवं च तयोरेककर्तृत्वयोः सिद्धयोस्तवाग्रे किमस्माकं कर्तृत्वं वेत्यर्थ: ॥
column7: O Lord, who dwells on the peak of the Mountain King! What power, may we ask, do we possess for doing or saying anything before you? For, it is you who takes the form of the unbroken word (‘Sphoṭa’) everywhere and the triple world is an apparent manifestation of you, whose body is constituted by sound (‘Dhvani’).
column8: This verse alludes to the Śābdika school of philosophy. Sphoṭa or Śabdabrahman is an eternal, all-pervading, and unmanifest word that becomes manifest through temporal and limited sound, called dhvani, and transforms into the non-real universe in the process. The purport of the verse is that Shiva is both the unmanifest sphoṭa and the dhvani that manifests it. The gods declare that they are rendered speechless and bereft of agency before Shiva because, as sphoṭa, he represents speech in its most fundamental form and as dhvani, he is the agent of the entire creation.

column4: कुत्रापि प्रतिहतिमेति नान्तरिक्षं शब्दस्तद्गुणपदवीं न चातिशेते । तन्मूर्तिस्त्वमसि च तद्विभो जगन्ति व्याप्नोषीत्ययमुपपत्तिसम्प्रदायः ॥ २३ ॥
column5: kutrāpi pratihatimeti nāntarikṣaṃ śabdastadguṇapadavīṃ na cātiśete | tanmūrtistvamasi ca tadvibho jaganti vyāpnoṣītyayamupapattisampradāyaḥ || 23 ||
column6: अन्तरिक्षं कर्तृ, प्रतिहतिं निरोधं नैति । शब्दस्तस्यान्तरिक्षस्य गुणत्वं नातिशेते । अनधिकत्वान्न त्यजति । एवं शब्दस्य गुणत्वे सिद्धे, गुणस्य च गुणिनि समवायाच्छब्दस्य जगद्व्यापकत्वं सिद्धम् । त्वं शब्दमूर्तिरसि। जगन्ति व्याप्नोषीत्ययमुपपत्तेर्न्यायस्य​ सम्प्रदायः॥
column7: All-pervading Lord! The thread of logical argumentation is as follows: Nowhere does space suffer restriction (i.e., it is all-pervasive); sound never ceases to be its (i.e., space’s) quality; and it (i.e., sound), in turn, is your form. Therefore, you pervade the worlds.
column8: It can be proved that Shiva is all-pervading through the Nyāya method of logical reasoning too. According to logicians, space is all-pervading and its distinguishing attribute is sound (‘śabdaguṇakamākāśam | taccaikaṃ vibhu nityaṃ ca’, Tarkasaṅgraha). Since sound exists in an inherent relationship (samavāyasambandha) with space, it too is all-pervading. And finally, Shiva himself is all-pervading because he is of the nature of sound. The use of the word ‘vibhu’ (all-pervading/master) for addressing Shiva is significant in the light of the above discussion.

column4: नो किञ्चिद्बहिरुपपत्तिमेति वस्तु ज्ञानात्तत्प्रसरति किन्तु चित्रवृत्ति । ज्ञानात्मा प्रभुरिति विश्वकर्तृभावो नो बौद्धैरपि भवतो बत व्यपास्त: ॥ २४ ॥
column5: no kiñcidbahirupapattimeti vastu jñānāttatprasarati kintu citravṛtti | jñānātmā prabhuriti viśvakartṛbhāvo no bauddhairapi bhavato bata vyapāstaḥ || 24 ||
column6: किञ्चिद्वस्तु कर्तृ, ज्ञानाद्बहिरुपपत्तिं नैति । चित्रवृत्ति अनेकरूपं ज्ञानात्प्रसरति । एवं ज्ञानस्यैव कर्तृत्वम् । भगवांश्च ज्ञानस्वरूपः । इति न्यायेन बौद्धैरपि विज्ञानवादिभिरपि जगत्कर्तृत्वं तव न निरस्तम् ॥
column7: There is no object that can be demonstrated as existing outside cognition. On the contrary, it (i.e., an object) itself proceeds from cognition in its myriad form. Given that the Lord is of the nature of cognition, even the Buddhists cannot negate your omnipotence. How strange!
column8: According to the Vijñānavāda school of Buddhist philosophy, cognition alone is real and the world of plurality proceeds from it. Since Shiva is of the nature of cognition, the Buddhists have no other option than to agree that he creates the universe (JR).

column4: शून्यं तैरकथि न तुच्छमेव रूपं मादृक्षानधिगमनीयवृत्ति किं तु । तादृक्षं तव च वपुस्तथा च बौद्धास्त्वामेव क्व न परमार्थतो गृणन्ति ॥ २५ ॥
column5: śūnyaṃ tairakathi na tucchameva rūpaṃ mādṛkṣānadhigamanīyavṛtti kiṃ tu | tādṛkṣaṃ tava ca vapustathā ca bauddhāstvāmeva kva na paramārthato gṛṇanti || 25 ||
column6: तैः शून्यवादिभिर्बौद्धैस्तुच्छमेव रूपं कर्मशून्यं नाकथि । किं तु मादृशैरल्पदृग्भिरनधिगमनीयाप्राप्या वृत्तिर्नानात्वं यस्य तच्छून्यं बौद्धैः कथितम् । भगवतश्च मूर्तिस्तादृक्षातिसूक्ष्मत्वाच्छून्येत्यर्थः । एवं सति शून्यवादिनो बौद्धास्त्वामेव, नान्यं परमार्थतः स्तुवन्ति॥
column7: What they (i.e., the Buddhists) mean by the word ‘Shunya’ is not an empty, unsubstantial form but one whose plurality of manifestation cannot be comprehended by people like us. And since your form fits this description, the Buddhists, truly speaking, have been glorifying you and you alone on every occasion.
column8: The Śūnyavāda school of Buddhist philosophy regards everything as empty and bereft of any essence. However, the gods turn this notion on its head by providing a novel interpretation of the word ‘śūnya’ as referring to something that is so subtle, its plurality of expression cannot be comprehended by those with limited vision. Since Shiva’s form fits this description aptly, the gods argue that the Śūnyavādins have been glorifying Shiva all along under the garb of declaring everything as empty.

column4: बोधात्मन्यनवधितां त्वयीह जानन्त्यन्यानि त्रिनयन सन्तु दर्शनानि । आत्मा त्वं तव च वपुस्त्रयोऽपि लोकास्तन्मानं त्वमिति च नार्हतोऽस्ति गर्हा॥ २६ ॥
column5: bodhātmanyanavadhitāṃ tvayīha jānantyanyāni trinayana santu darśanāni | ātmā tvaṃ tava ca vapustrayo'pi lokāstanmānaṃ tvamiti ca nārhato'sti garhā|| 26 ||
column6: बोधस्वरूपे त्वयि अनवधितां बोधस्वरूपादेवावधिरहितत्वं जानन्त्यन्यानि दर्शनानि सन्तु, नापास्यानि । भगवदेकनिलीनत्वात् । योऽपि देहप्रमाणमात्मानं मन्यते अर्हन् क्षपणकस्तेनापि त्रैलोक्यलक्षणं शरीरं प्रत्यात्मत्वाद्व्यापकत्वमङ्गीकृतम् । अव्यापकत्वाद्या गर्हा सा नास्तीत्यर्थः ॥
column7: O Lord with three eyes! Let there exist other philosophical schools that believe in your unboundedness on account of your nature as cognition. Even the Jaina deserves no condemnation (i.e., we must respect even the Jaina for admitting, albeit covertly, that you are all-pervasive) going by this (argument): you are the Self, your body is the triple world, and you are of the same size as it (i.e., the triple world).
column8: According to the Jainas, the size of the self is commensurate with the size of the body: the self of an ant is smaller compared to that of an elephant. Since Shiva is the Self of the universe, which is his body, even the Jainas must admit that he is all-pervading (JR).

column4: त्रैलोक्यं विभजति यो विचित्रतत्रं यस्माच्च प्रसरति सर्वजीवलोकः । चार्वाकास्तमिह वदन्ति यत्स्वभावं तद्भङ्ग्या त्वमसि शिवोररीकृतस्तैः ॥ २७ ॥
column5: trailokyaṃ vibhajati yo vicitratatraṃ yasmācca prasarati sarvajīvalokaḥ | cārvākāstamiha vadanti yatsvabhāvaṃ tadbhaṅgyā tvamasi śivorarīkṛtastaiḥ || 27 ||
column6: अनेकप्रकारं त्रिजगद्यो विभजति विभागेनावस्थापयति । तथा यस्मात्सर्वोऽपि जीवलोकः स्फुरति। तं विचित्रवस्तु निर्मातारं यत्स्वभावं वदन्ति । स्वभावमेव निर्मातारं वदन्तीत्यर्थः । तद्भङ्ग्या विचित्रवस्तुनिर्मातृस्वभावभङ्ग्या तैश्चार्वाकैस्त्वमेवाङ्गीकृतः ॥
column7: O Shiva! Since the Charvakas describe that, which differentiates the universe of myriad forms and that, from which all the living beings emanate, as ‘innate nature’, you have been accepted (even) by them in a roundabout way.
column8: What the Cārvākas designate as ‘svabhāva’(innate nature) is no different from Shiva because, like him, the former too is described as the creative force behind the world of plurality (JR).

column4: यं माया क्वचिदनिरुद्ध्यमानरूपा न स्प्रष्टुं प्रभवति नेति नेति सन्तः । यस्मिंश्च व्यवहृतिमाचरन्ति तं त्वां तात्पर्यादुपनिषदो विभो गृणन्ति ॥ २८ ॥
column5: yaṃ māyā kvacidaniruddhyamānarūpā na spraṣṭuṃ prabhavati neti neti santaḥ | yasmiṃśca vyavahṛtimācaranti taṃ tvāṃ tātparyādupaniṣado vibho gṛṇanti || 28 ||
column6: अनिरुध्यमानं रूपं यस्याः सा माया यं नैति । तथा यस्मिन्सन्तो नेति नेति 'नैवायं प्राणो नैव शरीरम्' इत्यादिक्रमेण व्यवहरन्ति । ते त्वामुपनिषदो वेदान्तास्त्वामेव तमिति तात्पर्याद्भजन्ति ॥
column7: All-pervading Lord! He, whom Maya – unrestrained by her nature – cannot approach from anywhere and about whom wise men speak in exclusionary terms such as “not this” and “not that” is, in summary, proclaimed by the Upanishads as being identical with you.
column8: This verse presents the viewpoint of Vedānta. He, whom the Upaniṣads speak about in exclusionary terms such as “He is not the vital breath”, “He is not the body”, and so on, is, in essence, none other than Shiva (JR).

column4: एकस्त्वं त्रिनयन दृश्यसेऽधिकर्तुं ज्ञातुं च त्रिभुवनमीश्वरः प्रकाशः । तादात्म्यं विवृतवती विमर्शशक्तिद्वैधेऽपि प्रथयति ते न भेददोषम् ॥ २९ ॥
column5: ekastvaṃ trinayana dṛśyase'dhikartuṃ jñātuṃ ca tribhuvanamīśvaraḥ prakāśaḥ | tādātmyaṃ vivṛtavatī vimarśaśaktidvaidhe'pi prathayati te na bhedadoṣam || 29 ||
column6: JR's commentary is not available for this verse.
column7: You alone, O three-eyed Master, are understood as the Light that is capable of acting on and knowing the three worlds. Despite there being duality, Reflective Power does not taint you with the blemish of difference since she is in unison with your form.
column8: According to the Trika school of philosophy, the Light of Supreme Consciousness (‘Prakāśa’) is always accompanied by the Power of Self-reflection (‘Vimarśaśakti’). The association of Consciousness with the Power of Self-reflection doesn’t engender duality just as it does not in the case of fire and its power to burn. JR’s commentary for this and the 4 verses that follow is not available.

column4: इच्छद्भिः शशिमुकुट क्रियैकरूपं वैवश्याप्रणयविधायिनं वि(नि)योगम् । निर्यूढश्रुतिकविकृत्य विश्वकर्ता त्वं हर्ताभ्युपगत एव वेदविद्भिः॥ ३० ॥
column5: icchadbhiḥ śaśimukuṭa kriyaikarūpaṃ vaivaśyāpraṇayavidhāyinaṃ vi(ni)yogam | niryūḍhaśrutikavikṛtya viśvakartā tvaṃ hartābhyupagata eva vedavidbhiḥ|| 30 ||
column6: JR's commentary is not available for this verse.
column7: O moon-crested Shiva, who has accomplished the duty of a poet as regards the Vedas (i.e., whose poetry are the Vedas)! You have indeed been (unwittingly) accepted as the doer of everything and the annihilator by the knowers of the Vedas (i.e., the Mimamsakas), according to whom Vedic command, which takes the sole form of action, enjoins relinquishment of (agential) control and freedom from desire.
column8: This verse is directed at the Mīmāṃsakas. If one must give up agency and desire while performing an action ordained by the Vedas, there must exist someone to whom they (agency and desire) can be attributed. This someone, according to the gods, is none other than Shiva, for he is the universal doer. ‘Viyoga’ must be read as ‘niyoga’. Niyoga is a technical term in Pūrvamīmāṃsā and refers to a Vedic command. Mankha uses this word elsewhere too in its technical sense (25.67). If ‘śrutikavi’ is taken to mean Brahma, as in verse 46, where he is similarly described as ‘śrutikavitā’, ‘nirvyūḍhaśrutikavikṛtya’ must be translated as ‘(O Shiva), who has accomplished the purpose of Brahma, the poet-composer of the Vedas’; since Shiva is the universal doer, he renders the Vedas, which enjoin the performance of certain actions, fruitful, thereby fulfilling the purpose of Brahma.

column4: यच्छायापृषदभिषेकतोऽपि सर्वे तात्पर्यादवसितजाड्यतां भजन्ते । तस्यात्मंस्तव जडतामुदीरयन्तः काणादा बत न कथञ्चन त्रपन्ते ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: yacchāyāpṛṣadabhiṣekato’pi sarve tātparyādavasitajāḍyatāṃ bhajante | tasyātmaṃstava jaḍatāmudīrayantaḥ kāṇādā bata na kathañcana trapante || 31 ||
column6: JR's commentary is not available for this verse.
column7: Everything springs to life, leaving behind its stupor, even when sprinkled with a mere drop of your effulgence. Alas! The followers of Kanada do not feel any shame in claiming that you, O Conscious Self, are inert.
column8: This verse targets the Vaiśeṣika  school of philosophy. According to this school, consciousness is not an essential quality of the self but emerges in the latter because of its contact with the mind (manas) (‘vaiśeṣikā āhuḥ - prāgaprakāśasya jaḍasyātmano manaḥsaṃyogājjñānākhyaḥ prakāśo jāyata iti’, Sāṅkhyapravacanabhāṣya, under sutra 145)

column4: क्वावत्स्यत्कथमजनिष्यत प्रकाशं प्राणिष्यत्कथमथवैष जीवलोकः । आ सर्गादखिलजगद्गरिष्ठ नो चेत्कारुण्यात्प्रभुरभविष्यदष्टमूर्तिः ॥ ३२ ॥

column4: वक्त्रेऽभूत्तव मुरजित्प्रतिग्रहीता त्वं ग्रीवां सरसिजजन्मनो व्यलावीः । इत्थं ते हिमकरशेखर प्रसादः कोपो वा क्व​चिदजनिष्ट नो महत्सु ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: vaktre’bhūttava murajitpratigrahītā tvaṃ grīvāṃ sarasijajanmano vyalāvīḥ | itthaṃ te himakaraśekhara prasādaḥ kopo vā kvacidajaniṣṭa no mahatsu || 33 ||

column7: Mura’s foe, Vishnu, got his face (back) because of you and you lopped the lotus-born Brahma’s neck off. O Lord, whose crest is adorned with the cool-rayed moon! You therefore exhibit neither favour nor anger while dealing with the great”.
column8: The story of Shiva plucking off Brahma’s head is well-known (ciccheda bahuśo devo brahmaṇaḥ pañcamaṃ śiraḥ’, Śivapurāṇa, 7.1.30.19). However, the story of Shiva granting a head to Vishnu is an obscure one. The Skandapurāṇa (Dharmāraṇyamāhātmya, chapter 15) describes the story of Vishnu, as the horse-headed Hayagrīva, getting back his original head by performing austerities at Dharmāraṇya, a holy site dedicated to Shiva in his form as Mokṣeśvara (‘tīrthasya mahimā rājanhayaśīrṣastadā hariḥ | śubhānano hi sañjātaḥ pūrveṇaivānanena tu ||, 15.49). Mankha probably alludes to this story. Alternatively, Mankha may be referring to the Harihara form in which Vishnu occupies one half of Shiva's body (Mankha refers frequently to this form; see verses 3.70, 5.37, and10.40)

column4: इत्यादिस्तुतिमुखरेषु निर्जरेषु प्रत्यग्रप्रसृतकृपारसातिरेकः। तानित्थं कथयितुमिन्दुखण्डचूडः प्रारेभे रभसवशंवदैर्वचोभिः ॥ ३४ ॥

column6: आपदेव गदो रोगः । विश्वस्यापद्गदभिषजो निवारका अपि भवन्तो विक्लवत्वदुःखदीनमुखाः किं स्थ भवथ । हे प्रत्यर्थिभिः प्रधनं युद्ध तत्र रसो येषां तेषामामन्त्रणम् । दैन्यमुल्लङ्घय वस्तेजो वाडवं तेजोऽनुकरोति । 'विलङ्घ्यदैन्यम्' इत्येकपदं वा ॥

column8: An alternative reading takes ‘vilaṅghyadainyam’ as a single word that qualifies ‘tejaḥ’ (JR). In that case, the translation would be ‘Your fiery valour, which can tide over despair’.

column6: ध्यानेन समाधिना ब्रह्मदृष्टौ स्तिमिततमत्वं चिन्तायाः परिचये सति नाधिकं धिनोति प्रीणयति । सहाधिभिश्चित्तपीडाभिर्वर्तते यस्तद्भावेन सहितम् । अपिर्विरोधद्योतकः । अधिकस्य भाव आधिक्यं तेन सहितमपि नाधिकम् ॥

column5: krāntābhiḥ pratidivasāstaśailasīdaccaṇḍāṃśudyutibhiriveśvaraḥ pratīcyāḥ | yastejo durabhibhavaṃ babhāra sadyaḥ svāṃ śaktiṃ dṛśi vidhṛtāmbhasi vyanakti || 43 ||
column6: क्रान्ताभिराक्रमणेन स्वीकृताभिः प्रत्यहमस्ताद्रौ सीदतः प्राप्तास्तमयस्य चण्डांशोर्द्युतिभिरिव यः प्रतीच्या ईश्वरो वरुणो दुरभिभवं तेजो बभार स विधृताम्भसि सबाष्पायां दृष्टौ स्वां शक्तिं प्रकटीकरोति । सबाष्पेण नेत्रेण वरुणशक्तिः प्रकाशितेत्यर्थः ॥
column7: The Lord of the West (i.e., Varuna, the god of waters), who used to boast of an indomitable radiance that resulted, as it were, from usurping the rays of the sun as the latter slid down the Setting Mountain every day, now exhibits his power (merely) through water-laden eyes.
column8: Varuna’s lordship over waters is now restricted to having watery eyes (JR).

column4: अन्येषां सवनलिहामपि प्रयातः स प्राच्यः क्व नु निजतेजसोऽतिरेकः । नीरन्ध्रप्रविसृमराननानिलौघैः किं लीढः कथमपि दीपवच्छमेन ॥ ४४ ॥
column5: anyeṣāṃ savanalihāmapi prayātaḥ sa prācyaḥ kva nu nijatejaso'tirekaḥ | nīrandhrapravisṛmarānanānilaughaiḥ kiṃ līḍhaḥ kathamapi dīpavacchamena || 44 ||
column6: मखभुजामपि स प्राच्यः प्राक्स्थितः स्वतेजोमहिमा क्व यातः । नीरन्ध्रं कृत्वा विसृमरैर्नि:श्वासैः स तेजोमहिमा दीपवत्किं लीढः(?शमेन लीढः) शमितः ॥
column7: As regards the other gods too, where, may I know, is their previously plentiful glow gone? Or has it somehow died out like a lamp, thanks to the sighing breaths that flow from their mouths in unbroken succession?”
column8: The sighing breaths are imagined as extinguishing the lamp of bodily glow.

column4: ईदृग्भिः स्मरमकरैकमान्त्रिकस्य व्याहारैरपहृतकल्पचित्तपीडाः । निर्वेदाद(न)भिमुखलोचनं कथञ्चित्प्रोत्क्षिप्य क्षणमवतस्थिरे मुखानि ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: īdṛgbhiḥ smaramakaraikamāntrikasya vyāhārairapahṛtakalpacittapīḍāḥ | nirvedāda(na)bhimukhalocanaṃ kathañcitprotkṣipya kṣaṇamavatasthire mukhāni || 41 ||
column6: स्मर एव मकरः स्मरस्य वा मकरस्तस्यैक[स्य] मान्त्रिकस्य प्रभावशमहेतोर्हरस्येदृग्भिः सस्नेहाभिरुक्तिभिर्निवारितकल्पचित्तचिन्ताः । अत एव निर्वेदेन दुःखेनानभिमुखानि लोचनानि यत्र । एवं कृत्वा कथञ्चिन्मुखान्युत्क्षिप्य क्षणं देवास्तस्थुः ॥
column7: The agony of their heart allayed somewhat by words such as these, uttered by Shiva, the sole magician who restrained the Makara sea monster that is Kama (also 'the Makara that is Kama's banner'), the gods stood still for a brief moment, holding their heads up somehow but avoiding eye contact due to their sorrow.
column8: Figuratively speaking, to restrain the Makara, which is Kama's banner, is to restrain the power of Kama himself.

column4: देवोऽथ श्रुतिकविता पयोदनादप्रत्यर्थिस्वनरचनाञ्चितैर्वचोभिः । हंसानां रथपथवर्तिनां मुहूर्तं तन्वानो भयमिति सादरं जगाद ॥ ४६ ॥
column5: devo'tha śrutikavitā payodanādapratyarthisvanaracanāñcitairvacobhiḥ | haṃsānāṃ rathapathavartināṃ muhūrtaṃ tanvāno bhayamiti sādaraṃ jagāda || 46 ||
column6: श्रुतिकविता देवो ब्रह्मा सादरं जगाद । पयोनादस्य स्तनितस्य प्रत्यर्थी स्पर्धाकरो यः शब्दस्तद्रचनया पूजितैर्वचोभिर्निजरथभूतानां हंसानां भीतिं कुर्वन् । हंसा हि मेघद्वेषिणः ॥
column7: Thereafter, Lord Brahma, the poet-composer of the Vedas, uttered the following words with respect in a voice that rivalled the thunder of clouds, causing thereby a momentary alarm in the swans pulling his chariot.
column8: The idea here is similar to the one in 16.30. According to the Sanskrit poetic convention, the sight of clouds upsets swans.

column4: सन्तापं किमपि विवृण्वते न केषां ये पादा इव दिविषन्मनोज्वरस्य । सन्त्यत्र त्रिनयन दुःसहप्रमेया दैतेयास्त्रिभुवनशत्रवस्त्रयस्ते ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: santāpaṃ kimapi vivṛṇvate na keṣāṃ ye pādā iva diviṣanmanojvarasya | santyatra trinayana duḥsahaprameyā daiteyāstribhuvanaśatravastrayaste || 47 ||
column6: दिविषदां देवानां यो मनोज्वरस्तस्य पादा इव ये केषां न सन्तापं प्रकाशयन्ति ते दैतेया दैत्यास्त्रिपुराख्यास्त्रयो दुःसहप्रमेया गहनस्वरूपास्त्रिभुवनवैरिणः सन्ति ।
column7: "Three-eyed Lord! Presently, there exist three Daityas, enemies of the three worlds, who, like the three limbs of the fever afflicting the minds of the gods, cause distress/elevated heat in everyone and escape reasoning.
column8: Fever is personified as a being with 3 legs and 3 heads that was born from the anger of Rudra (‘jvarastripādastriśirāḥ’, Harivaṃśa, 110.56; ‘dakṣāpamānasaṅkruddharudraniḥśvāsasambhavaḥ jvaraḥ’ Mādhavanidāna, 2.1)

column4: प्रागुद्यद्यमनियमादिमांसलाभिश्चेष्टाभिस्त्रिदिवमुनीन्विलङ्घयन्तः । संहत्य स्थिरतरनिश्चयेन ते मामाराद्धुं निरवधि तेपिरे तपांसि ॥ ४८ ॥
column5: prāgudyadyamaniyamādimāṃsalābhiśceṣṭābhistridivamunīnvilaṅghayantaḥ | saṃhatya sthirataraniścayena te māmārāddhuṃ niravadhi tepire tapāṃsi || 48  ||
column6: प्रथममुद्यद्भिर्यमैरहिंसादिभिर्निवृत्तिरूपैर्नियमैः शौचादिभिर्मांसलाभिर्घनाभिश्चेष्टाभिः कर्मभिर्देवर्षीञ्जयन्तस्ते दैत्याः संहत्य मिलित्वा स्थिरनिश्चयेन मां सेवितुं निरवधि निष्परिच्छेदं तपांसि तेपिरे चक्रुः । तपःकर्मकस्यैव कर्मवद्भावादात्मनेपदम् ॥
column7: Overthrowing the Celestial Sages through their actions that were initially replete with practices such as the control of the mind and the body, they came together and performed penance without a break, having taken a firm decision to please me.
column8: Control of the body is called ‘yama’, which includes practices such as cleanliness; control of the mind is ‘niyama’, incorporating practices such as non-violence (JR).

column4: त्रैलोक्यं तपसि विशङ्कमेव तेषां कल्पान्तज्वलननयेन बाधमाने । निर्व्याजक्रममथ दर्शनं पुरस्तात्तेभ्योऽहं व्यतरमनुत्तरानुरोधः ॥ ४९ ॥

column6: कल्पान्ताग्निन्यायेन तेषां तपसि त्रिभुवनं बाधमाने सति जातानुरोधोऽहं निष्कपटं तेभ्यो दर्शनमदाम् ॥

column6: तीक्ष्णया तपोरूपया वास्या कुब्जिकया सर्वोऽपि भवतामङ्गप्रपञ्चस्तनूकृतः। अहमिष्टं वरं भवद्भ्यो दास्यामि । तस्माद्व्रतानि विरचय्य कृत्वा खल्वलम् । व्रतेभ्यो निवर्तध्वमित्यर्थः । 'अलं खल्वोः' इति क्त्वाप्रत्ययः ॥
column7: "Dear sons! Your physical frames have been completely trimmed down by the sharp blade that is this uniquely arduous form of penance. There is no need to practice vows (any further), for I am ready to grant you your cherished boon.
column8: khalu’ is used here along with the ktvānta indeclinable ‘viracayya’ (vi+rac+ktvā) in the sense of  prohibition according to the rule ‘alaṅkhalvoḥ pratiṣedhayoḥ prācāṃ ktvā’ (JP). 'Vāsī' = 'kubjikā' (JR) = sharp blade.

column7: Having obtained this powerful boon from me in order to cleverly evade Yama’s plans, they actively engaged in fresh efforts to attack the three worlds one by one.
column8: N/A

column4: तत्तत्त्वमान्तरमवेत्य ततः सुवर्ण-दुर्वर्णलोहघटनाविकटैः प्रकारैः । तेभ्यः पृथक्त्रिषु जगत्सु पुरीरनल्प-शिल्पाविकल्पसमयः स मयश्चकार ॥ ५८ ॥
column5: tattattvamāntaramavetya tataḥ suvarṇa-durvarṇalohaghaṭanāvikaṭaiḥ prakāraiḥ | tebhyaḥ pṛthaktriṣu jagatsu purīranalpa-śilpāvikalpasamayaḥ sa mayaścakāra || 58 ||
column6: तत्त्रिजगदाक्रमणलक्षणमान्तरमप्रतिभिन्नमपि तत्त्वमवेत्य ज्ञात्वा भयवशात्सेवावधानेनेङ्गितादिभिर्लक्षिताभिप्रायत्वात् । सुवर्णरौप्यलोहमयघटनया विकटैर्विस्तीर्णैः प्राकारैः पुरीर्न​गरीस्त्रिषु भुवनेषु तेभ्यो दैत्येभ्यः स मयो विश्वकर्मपुत्रः कृतवान् । अनल्पशिल्पेऽविकल्पो निष्कम्पः समयो मर्यादा यस्य । आन्तरं तपःप्रयुक्तवरलक्ष्यमिति व्याख्येयम् ॥
column7: Thereafter, having grasped the unified import of their minds, Maya, whose immense knowledge in the domain of artisanship is unshakeable, constructed (three) separate cities for them in the three worlds, (cities) whose vast expanse was (separately) fashioned with gold, silver, and iron.
column8: Unified import' refers to the common intention of the Asuras to attack the three worlds; Maya is the son of  Vishvakarma, the architect of the gods (JR).

column4: अरुणमणिगरीयोगोपुरप्रोज्जिहान-द्युतिनिवहनवीनोदृङ्कितामेयवप्रम् । पुरवरमथ हैमं दैत्यनारीकटाक्षैः कुवलयितगवाक्षं तारकाक्षोऽध्यरुक्षत् ॥ ५९ ॥
column5: aruṇamaṇigarīyogopuraprojjihāna- dyutinivahanavīnodṛṅkitāmeyavapram | puravaramatha haimaṃ daityanārīkaṭākṣaiḥ kuvalayitagavākṣaṃ tārakākṣo'dhyarukṣat || 59 ||
column6: पद्मरागमयगुरुतरपुरद्वारप्रसृतांशुभरसम्पादितनवाग्निमयप्राकारम् । तथा दैत्यस्त्रीदृष्टिभिः सञ्जातोत्पलाः कृता गवाक्षा यस्य तत्सौवर्णं नगरं तारकाक्षो दैत्योऽधिरूढवान् । वक्ष्यमाणयोर्नगरयोर्द्यावापृथिव्यधिकरणत्वात्पारिशेष्यात्सौवर्णनगरस्य पाताले विधिः ॥
column7: And so, Tarakasha occupied the magnificent city made of gold, which, by dint of the copious rays radiating from its grand, ruby-studded towers, seemed to be surrounded by a newly erected rampart of fire and whose latticed windows seemed to be adorned with blue lilies, thanks to the side-glances of the Daitya damsels (peeping through them).
column8: Tarakaksha’s golden city occupied the nether region of Pātāla (JR).

column4: धवलभवनयोगादाप्तपर्याप्तसाम्य-श्रिणि नभसि हसन्त्यामुल्लसद्भिर्मयूखैः । पुरि परिकरमाधाद्राजतोल्लासबन्धौ स्वक इव कमलाक्षः प्रक्रमो विक्रमस्य ॥ ६० ॥
column5: dhavalabhavanayogādāptaparyāptasāmya-śriṇi nabhasi hasantyāmullasadbhirmayūkhaiḥ | puri parikaramādhādrājatollāsabandhau svaka iva kamalākṣaḥ prakramo vikramasya || 60 ||
column6: धवलानि सुधास्नातानि भवनानि गृहाणि भानां नक्षत्राणां वनानि कुलानि तद्योगात्सदृशे व्योम्नि रश्मिभिर्हसन्त्याम् । तथा राजतो रौप्यमयो यत्रोल्लास: । राजता राजभावश्च । तदुल्लासस्य बन्धौ परिचितायां नगर्याम् । अत एव निजपौरुषोल्लास इव कमलाक्षो दैत्यः परिकरं चकार । पुर्या यन्नभसः साम्यश्रीः प्राप्ता तदधिकरणा पूरिति व्याख्येयम् ॥
column7: Kamalaksha established his dominion in a different city, which, by way of the bright rays beaming from it, seemed to be smiling in the sky – remarkably similar to its (i.e., the city’s) own self because of the white cluster of stars/mansions adorning it – and which, like the exuberance of his heroism, laid claim to a silvery glow/royal glory.
column8: Kamalaksha’s silver city occupied the celestial region. The poet employs pun to compare this city with the sky and the Asura Kamalaksha’s royal glory.

column4: भरत्रुट्यत्क्षोणीतलविसृतपातालतिमिर-स्थिरासङ्गेनेव स्फुरदसितनिःशेषवपुषम् । नृणां लोके कालायसमयमया(य​)त्नाज्ज​नपदं ततो विद्युन्मालीत्यसिसलिलधाराभिरसिचत् ॥ ६१ ॥
column5: bharatruṭyatkṣoṇītalavisṛtapātālatimira- sthirāsaṅgeneva sphuradasitaniḥśeṣavapuṣam | nṛṇāṃ loke kālāyasamayamayā(ya)tnājanapadaṃ tato vidyunmālītyasisaliladhārābhirasicat || 61 ||
column6: भरेण बृहत्त्वान्नगरभरेण त्रुट्यतः स्फुटतः क्षोणीतलान्निर्गतं यत्पातालान्धकारं तत्सम्बन्धी स्थिरो यः सम्पर्कस्तेनेव कृष्णप्रकृति कालायसमयं कृष्णायोजातिकृतं जनपदं विद्युन्मालीति दैत्योऽसीनां सुलिलं प्रभाविशेषस्तत्प्रधानाभिर्धाराभिरसिचद्व्यापत् । विद्युन्माली मेघश्च जलधाराभिः सिञ्चति ॥
column7: Thereafter, Vidyunmali/a cloud wreathed in lighting, freely bathed a provincial city in the world of mortals with a stream of water flowing from his sword’s sparkling edge; (a city) which, on account of being fashioned from dark iron, seemed to have turned black by coming into close contact with the darkness springing forth from the nether world when the earth’s surface gave way under its weight.
column8: Vidyunmali’s iron city occupied the world of mortals. The sparkle of a sword’s edge is often equated with water in the Sanskrit poetic tradition.

column4: ते प्राप्य त्रिपुरप्रथामथ पृथग्लोकान् रुजन्तः स्थिता दिव्यान्यब्दशतायुतान्युपनमद्विश्वापमृत्युश्रियः । यन्नाम्नाप्यधिरोहता श्रुतिपदं गीर्वाणवामभ्रुवां गाहन्ते तनवोऽतिवेलपवनोद्वेल्लल्लतासौहृदम् ॥ ६२ ॥
column5: te prāpya tripuraprathāmatha pṛthaglokān rujantaḥ sthitā divyānyabdaśatāyutānyupanamadviśvāpamṛtyuśriyaḥ | yannāmnāpyadhirohatā śrutipadaṃ gīrvāṇavāmabhruvāṃ gāhante tanavo'tivelapavanodvellallatāsauhṛdam || 62 ||
column6: अथ भुवनत्रये राजधानीकरणादनन्तरं त्रिपुराणीति प्रसिद्धिं प्राप्य दिव्यानि वर्षशतायुतानि वर्षदशसाहस्रीः पृथग्भुवनानि बाधमानाः स्थिताः । श्रुतेन येषां नाम्नापि देवाङ्गनानां तनवः सवेगवायुकम्पमानलताकान्तिं श्रयन्ति । नामापि श्रुत्वा कम्पन्त इत्यर्थः ॥
column7: Famed as “Tripura”, they stayed put for hundreds of thousands of divine years, tormenting the worlds, each separately, like some universal untimely death. Merely on hearing their name, the limbs of celestial ladies attain similitude with creepers that tremble in strong winds.
column8: Tripura’ stands for the cities as well as their Asura lords taken together.

column4: तापं रुचिक्षतिमथो विविधाश्च पीडा विश्वस्य धातव इवोत्कुपितास्त्रयस्ते । आतन्वते सपदि दुःसहसन्निपाते तस्मिन्भिषक्तु यदि भर्ग भवत्प्रसादः ॥ ६३ ॥
column5: tāpaṃ rucikṣatimatho vividhāśca pīḍā viśvasya dhātava ivotkupitāstrayaste | ātanvate sapadi duḥsahasannipāte tasminbhiṣaktu yadi bharga bhavatprasādaḥ || 63 ||
column6: तापं दुःखम्, पित्तसन्तापं च । रुचिक्षतिं विच्छायतामोजोभङ्गात् , अन्नविषयाभिलाष​निवृत्तिं श्लेष्मकृतां च । पीडा जनोपद्रवात्, वातकृताः पीडाश्च । ये कुपिता ईर्ष्यालवः, स्वप्रमाणातिरिक्ताश्च । धातवश्च वातपित्तकफा इव विकुर्वते । तस्मिन्दुःसहे सन्निपाते दुःसहानां सन्निपाते वा वातादिकोपे च भवतः प्रसादो भिषगगदङ्कारो भवति ॥
column7: Like the three incensed bodily humours, they presently cause sorrow/ fever, loss of splendour/appetite, and different types of pain to the world. O Bharga! If at all there is a physician who can deal with this morbid emergency, that physician is none other than your grace.
column8: The 3 bodily humours are known as ‘vāta’, ‘pitta’, and ‘kapha’. Though they are commonly known as ‘doṣa’, the word ‘dhātu’ can also be used for them (‘vātapittakaphā ete trayo doṣā iti smṛtāḥ || te dhātavo'pi vidvadbhirgaditā dehadhāraṇāt |’, Bhāvaprakāśa, 1.1.3.100-101). Their combined aggravation is known as ‘sannipāta’. Fever, loss of appetite, and pain are attributable to the aggravation of pitta, kapha, and vāta respectively.

column4: याः क्रीडद्विबुधावरोधनपरिष्कारार्ककान्तानल-ज्वालातापलवावलेहमपि नो मध्येदिनं सेहिरे । ताः सन्तानकवीरुधो विधुनितास्तत्सैनिकैः साम्प्रतं दावाग्निर्यदि नाम रक्षति ततो नीचावमानज्वरात् ॥ ६४ ॥
column5: yāḥ krīḍadvibudhāvarodhanapariṣkārārkakāntānala- jvālātāpalavāvalehamapi no madhyedinaṃ sehire | tāḥ santānakavīrudho vidhunitāstatsainikaiḥ sāmprataṃ dāvāgniryadi nāma rakṣati tato nīcāvamānajvarāt || 64 ||
column6: क्रीडन्ति यानि विबुधावरोधनानि देववध्वस्तासां परिष्कारार्थं भूषणार्थमर्ककान्तास्तदग्निसन्तापस्पर्शमपि या न सेहिरे ताः सन्तानकलतास्तच्चमूचरैर्व्यथिताः । नीचावमान एव ज्वरस्तस्माद्दावाग्निर्यदि रक्षति । दावाग्निर्वरम्, न तु दैत्यावमान इत्यर्थः॥
column7: The heavenly Santanaka creepers, which could not tolerate being licked even by the lukewarm flames of the fire emanating at midday from the sunstone ornaments adorning the wives of gods, are so tossed around at present by their (i.e., the Tripura's) soldiers that even a wild fire could perchance protect them from this insufferable shame.
column8: Santānaka is the name of one of the 5 heavenly creepers (see footnote under 12.41). These soft creepers regard even a wild fire as soothing in comparison to the assault of the Asuras (JR). The footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition quotes the following verse from Mentha’s Hayagrīvavadha (quoted, in turn, in Sāhityadarpaṇa) for comparison – ‘spṛṣṭāstā nandane śacyā keśasambhogalālitāḥ | sāvajñaṃ pārijātasya mañjaryo yasya sainikaiḥ ||’ (‘The Asura’s soldiers touched with disrespect the floral clusters of the heavenly Pārijāta tree, which Shaci, Indra’s wife, used to honour by wearing on her tresses’)

column4: पाशैर्बद्धशिरोधराः फणिमयैरुत्खातनाकिद्रुम-स्कन्धालानतलेषु दानसलिलावग्राहिणो दिग्द्विपाः । नीतास्तैरजिरेषु यामगजतां स्रस्तेऽपि विश्वम्भरा-भारे व्रीडनिपीडनेन दधते दूरावनम्रं शिरः ॥ ६५ ॥
column5: pāśairbaddhaśirodharāḥ phaṇimayairutkhātanākidruma- skandhālānataleṣu dānasalilāvagrāhiṇo digdvipāḥ | nītāstairajireṣu yāmagajatāṃ sraste'pi viśvambharā-bhāre vrīḍanipīḍanena dadhate dūrāvanamraṃ śiraḥ || 65 ||
column6: उत्खातानां देववृक्षाणां स्कन्धा एवालानानि तत्तलेषु सर्पमयैः पाशैर्बद्धग्रीवाः । तेषां मदजलस्यावग्राहः शोषोऽस्ति येषां दुःखवशात् । दैत्यैरङ्गनेषु प्रहरहस्तितां प्रापिता दिग्दन्तिनो भूभारेऽसत्यपि शिरो दूरनतं वहन्ति । यतो लज्जया नम्रम् ॥
column7: Their necks bound with serpents doubling up as ropes and their flow of ichor dried up, the Quarter Elephants stand under the trunks of uprooted celestial trees that serve the purpose of tying posts. Put to work in the Asuras’ courtyards during the different shifts of the day, they keep their heads bent very low in painful shame though the burden of the all-bearing earth has been lifted off them.
column8: The elephants (Airāvata, etc.) of the various directions are described as bearing the earth’s burden. Since they are stripped off their position and put to work in the courtyards of the Asuras, they bend their heads in shame and not because of carrying the load of the earth. The footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition quotes the following hemistich from Magha’s Śiśupālavadha (1.57) for comparison - hṛte'pi bhāre mahatastrapābharāduvāha duḥkhena bhṛśānataṃ śiraḥ | (The rest of this verse is as follows: paretabharturmahiṣo'munā dhanurvidhātumutkhātaviṣāṇamaṇḍalaḥ). In this verse, Yama’s buffalo is described as bending its head low in shame though the burden of its bent horns has been removed by Ravana, who has uprooted them to fashion his bow.

column4: किं वान्यत्ते तथाद्य त्रिनयन विनयातिक्रमाक्रान्तविश्वा निःश्वासौघेन दीर्घीकृतचमरमरुड्डम्बराः स्वर्वधूभिः । सर्वं निर्वीरमुर्वीतलमथ निलयं नाकिनां मन्यमानाः कर्तारो नूनमस्मत्परिकरमचिरान्नाममात्रावशेषम् ॥ ६६ ॥
column5: kiṃ vānyatte tathādya trinayana vinayātikramākrāntaviśvā niḥśvāsaughena dīrghīkṛtacamaramaruḍḍambarāḥ svarvadhūbhiḥ | sarvaṃ nirvīramurvītalamatha nilayaṃ nākināṃ manyamānāḥ kartāro nūnamasmatparikaramacirānnāmamātrāvaśeṣam || 66 ||
column6: अन्यत्किमिव वर्णयामः । अविनयेन जितविश्वा बन्दीकृताभिर्नाकनारीभिर्निःश्वासबहुलीकृतचमरवायवस्ते दैत्या भूतलं देवावासं च वीररहितं मन्यमाना निश्चितमस्मत्सामग्रीं नामैकशेषां करिष्यन्ति ॥
column7: O Lord with a triad of eyes! What more can I say? Thus do they attack the universe without control, the steady breeze of their royal flywhisks augmented by the (sorrowful) sighs of celestial maidens, that they regard the terrestrial and celestial regions as devoid of heroes and will surely reduce our realm to a mere nominal existence very soon”.
column8: N/A

column4: इत्थं प्रस्तावनायै विवृतवति वचः पद्मभूसूत्रधारे तूर्णं वक्त्रप्रसादप्रसरजवनिकामग्रतोऽपास्य दूरम् । क्रोधाख्यः पर्षदानां विदधदधिमनोरङ्गपीठप्रवेशं शैलूषो दृष्टहस्ताद्यसमविकृतिभिः सङ्गमङ्गीचकार ॥ ६७ ॥
column5: itthaṃ prastāvanāyai vivṛtavati vacaḥ padmabhūsūtradhāre tūrṇaṃ vaktraprasādaprasarajavanikāmagrato'pāsya dūram | krodhākhyaḥ parṣadānāṃ vidadhadadhimanoraṅgapīṭhapraveśaṃ śailūṣo dṛṣṭahastādyasamavikṛtibhiḥ saṅgamaṅgīcakāra || 67 ||
column6: प्रस्तावना आमुखे भाविवस्तूपक्षेपस्तदर्थं ब्रह्मण्येव सूचनात्सूत्रधारे वचो वहति वक्त्रप्रसाद एव प्रसरणाज्जवनिका तां तूर्णं निवार्य क्रोधप्रवेशात्पर्षदानां गणानां मन एव रङ्गपीठं तत्र प्रवेशं कुर्वन्क्रोधाख्यः शैलूषो दृष्टिहस्तादीनामसमाभिर्विकृतिभिर्विकारैः सङ्गमङ्गीचकारेति भद्रम् ॥
column7: In this way, as Brahma, the director, finished uttering these introductory words, the actor called “Anger” entered the stage, namely, the heart of the assembled Ganas, after hastily tossing the curtain of their calm countenance far aside and exhibited an extraordinary repertoire of gestures – of the hands and so on.
column8: A well-developed metaphor in which Brahma, anger, heart of the Ganas, and calm countenance stand for the director of a play, actor, stage, and curtain respectively. Since anger exhibits a rich repertoire of gestures, it is apt to compare it with an actor.

column4: इति श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराजराजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये परमेश्वरदेवसमागमवर्णनं नाम सप्तदशः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirājarājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye parameśvaradevasamāgamavarṇanaṃ nāma saptadaśaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Seventeenth Canto, named 'Description of the Meeting between the Supreme Lord Shiva and the Gods' in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja.

column4: अष्टादशः सर्गः ॥
column7: Eighteenth Canto

column4: दैत्योदयासवरसं श्रवणानुतर्ष-मार्गेण ते गणगणा विनिपीतवन्तः । रज्यद्विलोचनकपोलतलाः स्खलद्भि-र्वाक्यैर्विलोलवलितभ्रु विकारमूहुः ॥ १ ॥
column5: daityodayāsavarasaṃ śravaṇānutarṣa-mārgeṇa te gaṇagaṇā vinipītavantaḥ | rajyadvilocanakapolatalāḥ skhaladbhi-rvākyairvilolavalitabhru vikāramūhuḥ || 1 ||
column6: श्रवण एवानुतर्षश्चषकस्तत्पथेन दैत्योदयमेवासवरसं पीतवन्तः । अत एव रज्यन्ति सरागाणि सम्पद्यमानानि नेत्रगण्डतलानि येषां ते [गण्डसमूहाः][?गणसमूहाः] स्खलद्भिः किञ्चिन्निःसरद्भिर्वचनैर्विलोलवलिते भ्रुवौ यत्र । एवं कृत्वा विकारं प्रतिभेदमूहुर्बभ्रुः । मधुपानेन च नेत्रादिरागसम्भवः ॥
column7: Having imbibed the wine, namely, the news of the Daityas’ advent, with the goblet of their ears, Shiva’s attendants, their eyes and cheeks reddening, words faltering, and eyebrows frowning and fluttering, exhibited varied mannerisms.
column8: The verse’s idea is based on the similarity between the bodily responses resulting from anger and drunkenness (JR).

column4: तेऽक्षिभ्रुवभ्रमिकरालतरालिकाग्र-माजघ्निरे करतलैर्घनमंसकूटम् । यत्सम्भ्रमेण विदलत्कनकोर्मिकोत्थं चक्रे रजः पृथुविलोचनकूणितानि ॥ २ ॥
column5: te'kṣibhruvabhramikarālatarālikāgra-mājaghnire karatalairghanamaṃsakūṭam | yatsambhrameṇa vidalatkanakormikotthaṃ cakre rajaḥ pṛthuvilocanakūṇitāni || 2 ||
column6: अक्षिणी च भ्रुवौ च तदक्षिभ्रुवम् । 'अचतुर-' इति साधुः । तस्य भ्रमिर्भ्रमणं तया दुर्दर्शं ललाटं ते गणा निजस्कन्धं हस्तैराजाघ्निरे । 'स्वाङ्गकर्मका-' इत्यात्मनेपदम् । यस्मिन्नाहनने सम्भ्रमेण विदलन्त्यो या: कनकोर्मिकाः स्व​र्णबालिकास्तदुत्थं रजः पृथूनां नेत्राणां कूणितानि किञ्चिन्निमीलनानि चक्रे। 'पृथु' इति वा भिन्नं पदम् । यच्छब्दश्च भिन्नपदीकृत्य यथार्थं वा व्याख्येयः । तदुक्तं त्रिलोचनपङ्क्ति(ञ्जि)कायाम्- 'निपाताश्चोपसर्गाश्च धातवश्चेति ते त्रयः । अनेकार्था भवन्त्येवं पाठस्तेषां निदर्शनम्'॥
column7: Their lower foreheads rendered hideous by the twirling of eyebrows and the spinning of eyeballs, they patted their sturdy shoulders with the palm of their hands, pulverizing the golden finger rings and releasing a cloud of dust that caused (their) bulging eyes to shut.
column8: An alternative reading suggested by JR takes ‘pṛthu’ as an independent word qualifying ‘rajaḥ’. In that case, ‘cloud of dust’ must be replaced by ‘thick cloud of dust’ and ‘bulging’ must be dropped from the translation. The Dvandva compound ‘akṣibhruva’ ('akṣiṇī ca bhruvau ca') is irregularly formed by adding the affix 'ac' according to the rule ‘acaturavicaturasucatura----akṣibhruva---’; the ātmanepada in 'ājaghnire' is according to the Vārtika 'svāṅgakarmakācca' for the rule 'āṅo yamahanaḥ' (JR). JR explains 'ūrmikā' ('finger ring') as 'bālikā'

column4: प्राथम्यतः प्रमथवीरजनः सकोप-निष्पिष्यमाणविविधाभरणाग्रचूर्णैः । उद्दामदानवजनरस्य पुरन्ध्रिदृष्टे-रश्रुप्रथार्थमिव धूलिभरं पुपोष ॥ ३ ॥
column5: prāthamyataḥ pramathavīrajanaḥ sakopa-niṣpiṣyamāṇavividhābharaṇāgracūrṇaiḥ | uddāmadānavajanarasya purandhridṛṣṭe-raśruprathārthamiva dhūlibharaṃ pupoṣa || 3 ||
column6: सकोपं कृत्वा निष्पिष्यमाणानां विविधानामाभरणानामग्रचूर्णैः सकललोको(?)(?प्रमथलोको) ​रजोभरमुत्थितवान्। प्राथम्यतो युद्धात्पूर्वमेव दैत्यस्त्रीलोकस्य बाष्पजननार्थमिवेति सम्भावनम् ॥
column7: With the minute powder scattering from the edges of their numerous ornaments, which they broke in a fit of anger, the Pramatha warriors seemed to keep ready beforehand a cloud of dust for making the wives of the unruly Danavas shed copious tears (of widowhood, in the future).
column8: Beforehand’ = ‘even before the battle began’. Dust provokes tears.

column4: साटोपपाणिमृदितस्वविलासहार-तारेन्द्रनीलनिबिरीसरजश्छटाभिः । व्यानञ्ज कश्चन पुरोन्तरदीप्यमान-कोपप्रदीपगलदञ्जनधूलिपुञ्जम् ॥ ४ ॥
column5: sāṭopapāṇimṛditasvavilāsahāra-tārendranīlanibirīsarajaśchaṭābhiḥ | vyānañja kaścana purontaradīpyamāna-kopapradīpagaladañjanadhūlipuñjam || 4 ||
column6: साटोपं ससंरम्भं पाणिभ्यां मृदितः कोपवशात्पिष्टो यः स्वविलासहारस्तत्र तारा ये इन्द्रनीलास्तेषां निबिरीसाभिर्घनाभी रेणुच्छटाभिर्हेतुभिः कोऽपि अन्तरेऽन्तर्दीप्यमानस्य कोपप्रदीपस्य सम्बन्धी पुरो गलन्योऽञ्जनपुञ्जः कज्जलराशिस्तं व्यानञ्ज । पिष्टानां रत्नानां धूलि: कोपदीपकज्जलमिति सम्भावना ॥
column7: Through the thick showers of dust raining down from the dazzling sapphires of the fancy necklace, which he squeezed hard in his palm, a certain attendant displayed (or so it seemed) a mass of powdery soot dripping from the lamp of fiery anger burning within his heart.
column8: Soot, like powdered sapphire, is black in colour.

column4: अन्योन्यमर्दनरयादुदितासमोष्म-ताम्रीभवद्विधृतधूमशिखोद्गमं च । कस्यापि पाणियुगलं स्वभुजप्रताप-वह्नेर्विनिर्गमनमार्गमिवाचचक्षे ॥ ५ ॥
column5: anyonyamardanarayāduditāsamoṣma-tāmrībhavadvidhṛtadhūmaśikhodgamaṃ ca | kasyāpi pāṇiyugalaṃ svabhujapratāpa-vahnervinirgamanamārgamivācacakṣe || 5 ||
column6: मिथोमथनाज्जाततापम्, तथा रक्तीभवत्, तथा प्रकाशितधूमोत्पत्ति च कस्यापि करद्वयं निजभुजप्रतापाग्रेर्निर्गममिव सूचितवत्। अग्निनिर्गमस्य च तापारुणत्वधूमा लिङ्गम्॥
column7: Reddened by the intense heat, produced when rubbed together violently, and emitting a smoky trail, the palms of another Pramatha seemed to betray the path taken by the fire of his prowess to escape out (of his body).
column8: Redness, heat, and smoke characterize the trail of fire (JR).

column4: केनाप्यभज्यत तथा पृथुपद्मराग-चूडामणिर्निबिडपाणिविघट्टनाभिः । नासीद्यथोल्लसति तद्रजसि प्रसक्त-रोषारुणाननरुचः परभागलाभः ॥ ६ ॥
column5: kenāpyabhajyata tathā pṛthupadmarāga-cūḍāmaṇirnibiḍapāṇivighaṭṭanābhiḥ | nāsīdyathollasati tadrajasi prasakta-roṣāruṇānanarucaḥ parabhāgalābhaḥ || 6 ||
column6: निबिडं कृत्वा पाणिना घट्टनाभिः करणभूताभिः केनापि महापद्मरागमणिस्तथा भग्नो यथा तस्य रजसि स्फुरति रोषलोहिताया मुखशोभायाः परभागलाभो नासीत् । वर्णान्तरसन्निकर्षे परभागलाभस्य सद्भावात् ॥
column7: Thus did one warrior shatter a large ruby crest jewel by pounding it heavily with the fist that his angry-red countenance did not stand out prominently in the midst of the raining ruby dust.
column8: The angry red face went unnoticed amidst the raining red dust of rubies.

column4: कश्चिद्विशङ्कटपटुभ्रुकुटीकराल-भालस्थलः किमपि घोरतरं बभाषे । नीतो रुषा कलुषतां स हठात्प्रवीरो वाचां कथं त्वपरुषं प्रसरं व्यनक्तु ॥ ७ ॥
column5: kaścidviśaṅkaṭapaṭubhrukuṭīkarāla-bhālasthalaḥ kimapi ghorataraṃ babhāṣe | nīto ruṣā kaluṣatāṃ sa haṭhātpravīro vācāṃ kathaṃ tvaparuṣaṃ prasaraṃ vyanaktu || 7 ||
column6: भ्रुकुटिदुर्दर्शललाटतटः कोऽपि कठोरमवदत् । कश्चिदिति निर्दिष्टस्य स इति परामर्शः। रुषा कलुषतामप्रसादं नीतः स वाचामुल्लासमपरुषं सुकुमारमरोषं च कथं व्यनक्तु । विरोधच्छायापक्षे कार्यस्य कारणानुगुण्यं हेतुः ॥
column7: Another Pramatha, his broad forehead marked with deep, menacing frowns, spoke something very harsh. How could a great warrior like him, sullied by sudden anger, utter words that are soft/purged of anger?
column8: The word ‘aparuṣam’ is used in the dual senses of ‘soft’ (a+paruṣam) and ‘purged of anger’ (apa+ruṣam).

column4: कस्यापि तत्समयसम्भ्रमदूरदीर्ण-जीर्णव्रणप्रणयिनी तनुराबभासे । द्रष्टुं भ्रुवोरसमलास्यरहस्यदीक्षां वीरश्रिया कृतगवाक्षपरम्परेव ॥ ८ ॥
column5: kasyāpi tatsamayasambhramadūradīrṇa-jīrṇavraṇapraṇayinī tanurābabhāse | draṣṭuṃ bhruvorasamalāsyarahasyadīkṣāṃ vīraśriyā kṛtagavākṣaparampareva || 8 ||
column6: तत्काले सम्भ्रमेण दूरं दीर्णाः स्फुटिता जीर्णाः पुराणा व्रणाः शरप्रवेशखातानि तेषां प्रणयिनी परिचिता तनुः शुशुभे । अतः सम्भाव्यते - भ्रुवोः कोपवशान्नाट्यरहस्ये दीक्षा नियमेन ग्रहणं वीक्षितुं वीरलक्ष्म्या विरचिता जालपङ्क्तिरिव । राज्ञी च जालान्तरेण नाट्यादि वीक्षते ॥
column7: Its old wounds gaping widely in the frenzy of the moment, the body of a certain warrior seemed to sport a row of latticed windows for the indwelling Lady Courage to watch the marvellous and mystical dance of his Brows.
column8: Queens watch dance performances from latticed windows (JR). Mankha describes gaping wounds also in 18.9, 18.37, and 22.12

column4: क्रोधानुबन्धघनघर्मविकीर्यमाण-विस्तीर्णदीर्णजरठव्रणविभ्रमेण । कूपावलीर्विपुलवीररसाः प्रतापं हर्तुं द्विषामिव च कश्चन सञ्चिकाय ॥ ९ ॥
column5: krodhānubandhaghanagharmavikīryamāṇa-vistīrṇadīrṇajaraṭhavraṇavibhrameṇa | kūpāvalīrvipulavīrarasāḥ pratāpaṃ hartuṃ dviṣāmiva ca kaścana sañcikāya || 9 ||
column6: क्रोधव्यसनेन घनो यो घर्मस्तेन पूर्यमाणानि विस्तीर्णानि दीर्णानि स्फुटितानि व्रणानि तद्व्याजेन घनवीररसाः कूपपङ्क्तीः शत्रूणां प्रतापं शमितुमिव सञ्चितवान् ॥
column7: By way of his large, gaping old wounds, filled with profuse sweat that poured out in the unrelenting anger, yet another warrior seemed to keep ready many a row of wells, overflowing with bravery’s liquid essence, so he could supress the burning heat of the enemy’s prowess.
column8: One allays heat by pouring water.

column4: व्यालोलतारकगतिर्विकसत्सरोज-श्रीसख्यवत्यरुणतामवलम्बमाना । कस्यापि चित्रमहह प्रमथाधिपस्य दृष्टिर्निशातमसिडम्बरमेव भेजे ॥ १० ॥
column5: vyālolatārakagatirvikasatsaroja-śrīsakhyavatyaruṇatāmavalambamānā | kasyāpi citramahaha pramathādhipasya dṛṣṭirniśātamasiḍambarameva bheje || 10 ||
column6: व्यालोलतारकयोः कनीनिकयोस्तारकाणामुडूनां च गतिर्यस्याः । तथा प्रफुल्लया पद्मश्रिया सख्यं सादृश्यं परिचयश्च तद्वती । तथारुणतां शोणत्वमरुणभावं च गृह्णती कस्यापि दृष्टिर्निशितं तीक्ष्णमसिडम्बरं खड्गप्रपञ्चमेव सेवितवती । अथ च निशायास्तमसि निशातमसि दृष्टिर्डम्बरं विषयग्रहणसामर्थ्यं भजते ॥
column7: How very strange! The eyes of a certain Pramatha chief, which were characterized by the tremulousness/fraility of pupils/stars; had befriended the beauty of lotuses in bloom; and were sporting a red glow; landed on a majestic display of sharp swords/attained glory in nocturnal darkness.
column8: An apparent contradiction based on pun. Anything characterized by fraility of stars, friendship with lotuses, and a red glow cannot attain glory in nocturnal darkness (that is characterized by the opposite, namely, brightness of stars, enmity towards lotuses, and blackness). ‘Niśātamasiḍambaram’ must be split in two different ways to get the punned meanings: ‘niśā+tamasi, ḍambaram’ and ‘niśātam, asi+ḍambaram’

column4: संरूढरीढमरुणीभवदीक्षणान्त-कान्तिच्छटाघटनया क्षणमीक्षमाणः । आसन्नसङ्गरमहोत्सवशंसनाय सिन्दूरपूरमिव कोऽप्यकिरत्कृपाणे ॥ ११ ॥
column5: saṃrūḍharīḍhamaruṇībhavadīkṣaṇānta-kānticchaṭāghaṭanayā kṣaṇamīkṣamāṇaḥ | āsannasaṅgaramahotsavaśaṃsanāya sindūrapūramiva ko'pyakiratkṛpāṇe || 11 ||
column6: संरूढा रीढा मदमन्थरत्वेनावज्ञा यत्र । एवं कृत्वा क्षणमर्थात्खङ्गं वीक्षमाणः कोपरोषारुणनेत्रकान्तिसम्पर्केण हेतुना सङ्ग्रामोत्सवसूचनाय खड्गे सिन्दूरमिवाक्षिपत् । उत्सवे च सिन्दूरक्षेपो युक्तः ॥
column7: Casting a careless momentary glance on his sword, another warrior seemed to scatter a heap of vermilion dust on it with the reddening glow of his eye corner to announce the forthcoming festival of war .
column8: Vermilion dust is scattered during festive occasions (JR).

column4: दुःशिक्षिताखिलविपक्षदिधक्षयान्त-र्नेत्रेषु सङ्घटितपाटलिमोद्गमेषु । माहात्म्यतोऽन्तकरिपोरखिलास्तदोद्य-दाग्नेयदृष्टय इव प्रमथा बभुवुः ॥ १२ ॥
column5: duḥśikṣitākhilavipakṣadidhakṣayānta-rnetreṣu saṅghaṭitapāṭalimodgameṣu | māhātmyato'ntakariporakhilāstadodya-dāgneyadṛṣṭaya iva pramathā babhuvuḥ || 12 ||
column6: रोषवशान्नेत्रेष्वन्तर्घटितः पाटलिमोद्गमः शोणत्वं येषां तेषु सत्सु दुःशिक्षितानामवस्तुशिक्षितानामखिलानां विपक्षाणां दिधक्षया दग्धुमिच्छया भगवतः प्रभावात्प्रमथाः प्रकटीभवदग्निमयदृष्टय इवाभूवन् । अन्तकरिपोरिति प्रकृतानुगुणमभिधानम् । भगवताग्नेयदृशा यमस्य दाहात् ॥
column7: Their eyes flushed red in the desire to burn down every unruly foe, it seemed as if all the Pramathas had turned fire-eyed by the power of Shiva, Death's enemy.
column8: The word ‘antakaripu’ (‘Death's enemy’) is significant since Shiva burnt down the god of death with his fire-bearing eye (JR) (see footnote under 5.49). By imagining the Pramathas as fire-eyed, the poet suggests they too have the power to defy death.

column4: कश्चिन्निनाय पटुपाटलिमावमृष्टा दृष्टिच्छटास्तत इतः सुचिरं विमुञ्चन् । वक्तुं पुरः प्रतिभुवामशुभान्यनभ्र-विद्युद्घ​टाजटिलतामिव दिङ्मुखानि ॥ १३ ॥
column5: kaścinnināya paṭupāṭalimāvamṛṣṭā dṛṣṭicchaṭāstata itaḥ suciraṃ vimuñcan | vaktuṃ puraḥ pratibhuvāmaśubhānyanabhra-vidyudghaṭājaṭilatāmiva diṅmukhāni || 13 ||
column6: पटुना पाटलिम्ना शोणत्वेनावमृष्टाः स्पृष्टा दृष्टिच्छटा इतस्ततः क्षिपन्कश्चिद्वैरिणामशुभानि सूचयितुं दिङ्मुखानि अनभ्राया(भ्रा या) विद्युतस्ताभिर्जटिलतामिवानयात् । रोषारुणदृष्टयो वर्णधर्मकायैर्विद्युत्त्वेन सम्भाविताः। 'पटु' इति वा भिन्नं पदम् ॥
column7: Letting his bright red gaze float around for a long time, a certain warrior streaked the directions with a mosaic of cloudless lightning bolts to herald, as it were, the misfortune of his enemies.
column8: Lightning bolts are an ominous sign in the absence of clouds JR gives an alternative reading that takes ‘paṭu’ as a separate word – an adverb, meaning ‘cleverly’, which qualifies the verb ‘nināya’ (In that case, the translation would necessitate removing ‘bright’ and adding ‘cleverly’ before ‘streaked’).

column4: धुन्वन्परः परुषरोषतयोत्तमाङ्गं प्रेङ्खोलकेलिमणिकुण्डलयुग्मभङ्ग्या । निन्ये निनर्तिषति वैरिकबन्धलोके सन्नद्धतालपुटतामिध वक्त्रचन्द्रम् ॥ १४ ॥
column5: dhunvanparaḥ paruṣaroṣatayottamāṅgaṃ preṅkholakelimaṇikuṇḍalayugmabhaṅgyā | ninye ninartiṣati vairikabandhaloke sannaddhatālapuṭatāmidha vaktracandram || 14 ||
column6: क्रूररोषभावेन शिरः कम्पयन्कश्चित्कम्पमानक्रीडारत्नकुण्डलव्याजेन दैत्यकबन्धवर्गे निनर्तिषति सति मुखचन्द्रं सतालयुगलतामिवानैषीत् । सन्निवेशकार्याभ्यां कुण्डलयोस्तालत्वसम्भावनम् ॥
column7: As another Pramatha shook his head in intense anger, it appeared as if he had fitted his moon-like face with cymbal plates, masquerading as the swinging, gem-studded circular earrings adorning it, in anticipation of the dance of his enemy’s headless trunks.
column8: The description of headless trunks dancing on battlegrounds is commonplace in Sanskrit poetry. The earrings resemble cymbals both by their (round) appearance and (sound-producing/swinging) action (JR). ‘Ninartiṣati’ is a desiderative verb that is used here to denote future (i.e., in the sense of ‘nartiṣyati’). Cymbals are used as accompaniment for dance.

column4: आघट्टयन्करतलेन घनाभ्यसूयः कश्चिन्महीमुदितनूतनरन्ध्रयुक्त्या । सद्योऽतनोदिव मदाग्र्यधुराश्रितानां द्वारं विकस्वरमधोगतये परेषाम् ॥ १५ ॥
column5: āghaṭṭayankaratalena ghanābhyasūyaḥ kaścinmahīmuditanūtanarandhrayuktyā | sadyo'tanodiva madāgryadhurāśritānāṃ dvāraṃ vikasvaramadhogataye pareṣām || 15 ||
column6: घनरोषतः पाणिना भूमिं घट्टयन्कश्चिज्जातनवच्छिद्रयोगेण परेषामधोगतये किञ्चिद्द्वारं विवृतमकरोत्। यतो मदस्याग्रधुरं श्रितानाम् । पतनान्ताः समुच्छ्रया भवन्ति ॥
column7: By hitting the floor with the face of his palm and creating a freshly gaping hole to emerge therein, yet another deeply outraged warrior instantly inaugurated, as it were, a yawning opening for his enemies, who were standing at the very pinnacle of pride, to tumble down.
column8: One who reaches a pinnacle must end up falling – ‘patanāntaḥ samucchraya bhavanti’ (JR).  Mankha frequently describes the slamming of the fist against the ground as an anger-related behaviour (see 18.19, 29, 50, 52, 55, 56; and 20.8).

column4: वीरोऽपरस्त्रिनयनानुचरः सरोषं मृद्नँल्ललाटफलकं करपङ्कजेन । दग्धुं रिपूननलमाशु ततो न्वियेष निर्मथ्य लब्धुमिव नेत्रदशाधिरूढम् ॥ १६ ॥
column5: vīro'parastrinayanānucaraḥ saroṣaṃ mṛdna~llalāṭaphalakaṃ karapaṅkajena | dagdhuṃ ripūnanalamāśu tato nviyeṣa nirmathya labdhumiva netradaśādhirūḍham || 16 ||
column6: हस्तेन भालस्थलं मथ्नंस्त्रिनेत्रसेवकः कश्चिच्छत्रून्दग्धुं नेत्रावस्थया स्थितमग्निं मथित्वा लब्धुमिवानुससार । त्रिनयनानुचर इति साकूतम् ॥
column7: Desirous, as it were, of churning an ocular fire to quickly burn down the enemies, another Pramatha, attendant of the Three-eyed Lord, rubbed his lotus-hand hard against his broad forehead.
column8: The expression ‘attendant of the Three-eyed Lord’ (‘trinayanānucara’) is significant (JR); since Shiva sports fire in his forehead eye, his attendant's attempt to produce fire from his own forehead is not out of place.

column4: आकर्ण्य निर्णयमरातिमतप्रथाना-मारोहतोऽभिनवदुःसहरोषकोटिम् । चित्तेऽनवाप्य धृतिरुद्ध इवावकाशं कस्याप्यभूदधर एव दृढः प्रकम्पः ॥ १७ ॥
column5: ākarṇya nirṇayamarātimataprathānā-mārohato'bhinavaduḥsaharoṣakoṭim | citte'navāpya dhṛtiruddha ivāvakāśaṃ kasyāpyabhūdadhara eva dṛḍhaḥ prakampaḥ || 17 ||
column6: शत्रूणां सङ्ग्रामोद्योगरूपाणां मतानां निश्चयं पक्षान्तरनिरासेन स्थापनं श्रुत्वा रोषमारोहतः कस्यापि चित्ते धैर्येण रुद्धे आवृते, अतोऽवकाशमलब्ध्वेवौष्ठ​ एव कम्पो दृढोऽभूत् । तदा कस्यापि रोषवशादोष्ठ एव चकम्पे, न तु भयवशाद्धृदयमित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Listening to the consensus reached by the enemies after considering various options, a certain Pramatha scaled the peak of fresh, irresistible rage, wherefore, trepidation gained a strong foothold on his lips, unable to find any room in his heart that was pervaded with courage.
column8: His lips trembled in anger, not his heart in fear (JR).

column4: धूमच्छटाप्रविकटभ्रुकुटीपुटस्य कस्यापि वेपथुसखोऽधरपल्लवोऽभूत् । उग्रोग्रनिःश्वसितमारुतघट्टनाभिः कोपानलस्य वलमान इव स्फुलिङ्गः ॥ १८ ॥
column5: dhūmacchaṭāpravikaṭabhrukuṭīpuṭasya kasyāpi vepathusakho'dharapallavo'bhūt | ugrograniḥśvasitamārutaghaṭṭanābhiḥ kopānalasya valamāna iva sphuliṅgaḥ || 18 ||
column6: धूमरेखावद्भीषणभ्रूभङ्गस्य कस्यापि कम्पमान ओष्ठपल्लवो निःश्वासवाताहननैः कम्पमानकोपाग्निस्फुलिङ्ग इवाभवत् ॥
column7: The quivering sprout-like lower lip of a third warrior, whose frightening frowns  resembled columns of smoke, appeared like the spark of anger’s fire, shaken up by the windy gale of hurried breathing.
column8: The quivering of lower lip, frowning, and hurried breathing accompany anger.

column4: वर्षन्नजस्रमसमश्रमवारिबिन्दू-नाताम्रलोलनयनान्ततडित्कडारः । कश्चित्प्रनर्तयितुमुग्रकबन्धकेकि-लोकं स्पृहां व्यधित दिव्यधनुर्ग्रहाय ॥ १९ ॥
column5: varṣannajasramasamaśramavāribindū-nātāmralolanayanāntataḍitkaḍāraḥ | kaścitpranartayitumugrakabandhakeki-lokaṃ spṛhāṃ vyadhita divyadhanurgrahāya || 19 ||
column6: घनघर्मजलकणान्वर्षन्नरुणनेत्रान्ता एव विद्युतस्ताभिः कपिशः कश्चित्कबन्धा एव केकिनो मयूरास्तेषां लोकं नर्तयितुं दिव्यधनुषो लोकोत्तरस्य चापस्येन्द्रचापस्य च ग्रहणायाभिलाषमकरोत् । सेन्द्रचापो मेघो मयूरान्नर्तयति ॥
column7: Continuously raining down plentiful droplets of sweat and tinged tawny by the lightning bolts, namely, the corners of his bloodshot eyes, another warrior readily grasped a celestial bow to make the wild, headless torsos (of the enemies) dance in the manner of peacocks..
column8: Mankha likens the Pramatha to a cloud without literally saying so.The celestial bow is the rainbow.

column4: कस्यापि कोपधुतमूर्धविलोलमौलि-माल्योत्पतन्मधुपशावशतच्छलेन । घर्माम्बुतिम्यदलकस्थलरूढलोल-भ्रूवल्लरीनवफलावलिराविरासीत् ॥ २० ॥
column5: kasyāpi kopadhutamūrdhavilolamauli-mālyotpatanmadhupaśāvaśatacchalena | gharmāmbutimyadalakasthalarūḍhalola-bhrūvallarīnavaphalāvalirāvirāsīt || 20 ||
column6: कोपेन हेतुना धुतो यो मूर्धा तत्र विलोलं यन्मौलिमाल्यं ततो भयवशादुत्पतन्तो ये मधुपशावा भ्रमरकास्तद्व्याजेन घ​र्माम्बुना तिम्यदार्द्रीभवद्यदलिकस्थलं तत्र जाता या भ्रूवल्लरी भ्रूलता तत्सम्बन्धिनां फलानामावलिः पङ्क्तिराविरासीत् । अत्र भ्रमराणां भ्रूलताफलत्वेन सम्भावनम् ॥
column7: Disguised as hundreds of baby bees rising up from the chaplet that swung to and fro when a certain warrior shook his head in anger, it appeared as if his eyebrows, spread like a creeper across the surface of his forehead and watered with perspiration, had put forth a fresh bounty of fruits.
column8: The bees are likened to the fruits put forth by the creeper in the form of the eyebrow (JR).

column4: मथ्नन्मिथः करयुगं पृथुमन्युरन्यो भग्नोर्मिकारुणमणेः शकलैर्ववर्ष । निर्व्यूढगाढतरमत्सरनिर्जिहान-हव्याशनव्यवधिभाज इव स्फुलिङ्गान् ॥ २१ ॥
column5: mathnanmithaḥ karayugaṃ pṛthumanyuranyo bhagnormikāruṇamaṇeḥ śakalairvavarṣa | nirvyūḍhagāḍhataramatsaranirjihāna-havyāśanavyavadhibhāja iva sphuliṅgān || 21 ||
column6: बहुरोषतो हस्तद्वयमन्योन्यं मथ्नन्नन्यो भग्नवालिकापद्मरागरत्नस्य खण्डैर्हेतुभिर्मत्सर एव निर्जिहानो निर्गच्छन्यो हव्याशनोऽग्निस्तस्याव्यवधानमव्यवहितत्वं भजन्ते ये तान्स्फुलिङ्गानिव ववर्ष । हस्तमर्दभग्नवालिकापद्मरागखण्डा रोषाग्निस्फुलिङ्गत्वेन सम्भाव्यन्ते ॥
column7: Through the pieces of a ruby-studded finger ring that broke when he rubbed his palms against each other, one angry Pramatha seemed to rain down the closely-set, intervening sparks of the blazing fire, namely, his fully grown jealous wrath.
column8: The scattering ruby pieces appeared like sparks emanating from the fire of his anger (JR). JR reads 'vyavadhibhājaḥ' ('intervening') as 'avyavadhibhājaḥ' ('avyadhānam avyavahitatvaṃ bhajante'; 'closely-set'); the translation takes both meanings into account.

column4: सन्ध्येव गण्डतलपाटलिमा परस्य प्रागाविरास्त तदनु भ्रुकुटीतमिस्रम् । पश्चात्ततोऽपि विचकास नवाट्टहास-ज्योत्स्ना विपक्षमुखपद्मनिरासहेतुः ॥ २२ ॥
column5: sandhyeva gaṇḍatalapāṭalimā parasya prāgāvirāsta tadanu bhrukuṭītamisram | paścāttato'pi vicakāsa navāṭṭahāsa-jyotsnā vipakṣamukhapadmanirāsahetuḥ || 22 ||
column6: कस्यचित्कपोलयोः पाटलिमारुणत्वं पूर्वसन्ध्येवाविरासीत् । अथ भ्रुकुट्येव तमिस्रं तम आसीत्। अतोऽपि पश्चान्नवाट्टहास एव ज्योत्स्ना विचकास। विपक्षाणां दैत्यानां मुखपद्मानि तेषां निरासहेतु: सङ्कोचकारिणी ॥
column7: At first, the cheeks of a certain warrior turned red like evening, then his frowning eyebrows emitted dense darkness, and finally, his boisterous laughter bloomed afresh like moonlight, which caused the lotus-faces of the enemies to wither away.
column8: A temporal sequence is described here – of evening, followed by darkness, then moonlight, and finally, the withering away of lotuses.

column4: ऐक्षन्त वक्षसि नवश्रमवारिबिन्दू-नन्यस्य सम्भ्रमविशेषभुवो भुजिष्याः । कोपश्रियोऽतिचतुरं हृदये विशन्त्या मुक्तामणीनिव जवक्षतहारसूत्रान् ॥ २३ ॥
column5: aikṣanta vakṣasi navaśramavāribindū-nanyasya sambhramaviśeṣabhuvo bhujiṣyāḥ | kopaśriyo'ticaturaṃ hṛdaye viśantyā muktāmaṇīniva javakṣatahārasūtrān || 23 ||
column6: सम्भ्रमेण विशेषेण भूरुत्पत्तिर्येषां तान्घर्मकणान्कस्यचिद्वक्षसि दासा ददृशुः । अतः सम्भाव्यते - हृदयं विशन्त्याः कोपलक्ष्म्याः सम्भ्रमच्छिन्नहारसूत्राणि मुक्तारत्नानीव । अत्र घ​​र्मकणानां मुक्ताफलोत्प्रेक्षया स्थौल्यं प्रतिपादितम् । अत एव मुक्तानामन्तःप्रवेशाभावः । 'हारसूतात्' इति वा पाठः । हारेण सूतानुत्पादितान् ॥
column7: Shiva’s attendants beheld the fresh beads of perspiration, sprouting on the chest of a certain warrior in a state of heightened agitation, as if they were the pearls fallen off from his necklace, which broke all of a sudden when Lady Anger entered his heart in haste.
column8: JR provides ‘(kṣata)hārasūtān’ (‘produced by the necklace that broke off’).as an alternative reading for ‘hārasūtrān’

column4: कश्चिद्बभार पुनरुक्तविपञ्च्यमान-रोमाञ्चसूचिसचिवं प्रमथप्रवीरः । तत्तत्समीकशतपीतचरारिखड्ग-खण्डोत्करोद्वमनसज्जमिवाङ्गमङ्गम् ॥ २४ ॥
column5: kaścidbabhāra punaruktavipañcyamāna-romāñcasūcisacivaṃ pramathapravīraḥ | tattatsamīkaśatapītacarārikhaḍga-khaṇḍotkarodvamanasajjamivāṅgamaṅgam || 24 ||
column6: पुनरुक्तमत्यर्थं विपश्यमाना जायमाना ये रोमाञ्चास्त एव तीक्ष्णतया सूचयस्तत्सचिवमेकैकमङ्गं कश्चिदवहत् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - तेषु तेषु समीकशतेष्वनेकरणेषु पीतचराः पूर्वं निगीर्णा येऽरिखड्गखण्डोत्करास्तेषामुद्वमने सज्जमिव । अत्र रोमाञ्चाः खड्गखण्डत्वेन सम्भाविताः ॥
column7: Covered in wildly bristling, needle-like hair, every limb of a Pramatha hero seemed all prepared to emit out a pile of the enemy’s broken sword blades, which had got entrenched into it during several battles in the past.
column8: The Pramatha described here had imbibed pieces of swords while fighting in bygone battles; the hairs standing on end are those very pieces being emitted out at present (JR).

column4: कस्यापि पाणिकमले तरवारिलेखा भ्रूवल्लरी च सुमहत्यलिके चकम्पे । मालिन्यभूश्च कुटिला च मतिः परेषा-मुद्भूष्णुकम्पकलनास्त तयोस्तृतीया ॥ २५ ॥
column5: kasyāpi pāṇikamale taravārilekhā bhrūvallarī ca sumahatyalike cakampe | mālinyabhūśca kuṭilā ca matiḥ pareṣā-mudbhūṣṇukampakalanāsta tayostṛtīyā || 25 ||
column6: कस्यापि हस्ते करट्टिका ललाटे च भ्रूलता चकम्पे । तयोः करट्टिकाभ्रुवोस्तृतीया शत्रूणां मतिरासीत् । यत उद्भूष्णु: कम्पकलना यस्याः । मालिन्यभूरित्यादि तिसॄणां विशेषणम् ॥
column7: A dagger trembled in the lotus-hand of a warrior and a creeper-like eyebrow trembled on his broad forehead. The third in this series - the equally dark and crooked mind of the enemies - started trembling too.
column8: Taravārilekhā' = 'karaṭṭikā' (JR); the correct word seems to be 'kaṭṭarikā', see commentary under 18.49.

column4: आत्तः क्रुधा मृधविधानधृतानुबन्ध-मुद्वेपथुः पृथुरुचिभ्रुकुटीजटालः । केयूरलौहितकभाभिरगाहतेव खड्गोऽपि कस्यचन कोपविपाटलत्वम् ॥ २६ ॥
column5: āttaḥ krudhā mṛdhavidhānadhṛtānubandha-mudvepathuḥ pṛthurucibhrukuṭījaṭālaḥ | keyūralauhitakabhābhiragāhateva khaḍgo'pi kasyacana kopavipāṭalatvam || 26 ||
column6: मृधविधाने रणकरणे धृतोऽनुबन्धो व्यसनं यत्र । एवं कृत्वा गृहीतः । तथोद्वेपथुः। आधारभूतस्य हस्तस्य सकम्पत्वात्कम्पमानः । अथवा पाणिनर्तनात् । तथा रुचिरेव भ्रुकुटी तया जटाल: कस्यापि खड्गोऽप्यङ्गदपद्मरागांशुभिः कोपारुणत्वमिवाभजत् । कुपितस्य कम्पादिसम्भवः ॥
column7: A certain hero’s shaking sword, which was gripped by him in/with the angry desire to take part in the battle and whose dazzlingly dense glow resembled a frown, turned red in wrath, or so it seemed, because of the spreading radiance of the rubies set in his armlet.
column8: The sword is itself described as overcome with anger. ‘Lauhitaka’ is ruby.

column4: द्राङ्निप्रहन्तुमितरः समरे रिपूणां चक्रं चिरं चलयति स्म कराम्बुजेन । आवर्तमूर्तिरुदटङ्कि भुजोत्तरङ्ग-सङ्गस्य येन नवशौर्यमहार्णवस्य ॥ २७ ॥
column5: drāṅniprahantumitaraḥ samare ripūṇāṃ cakraṃ ciraṃ calayati sma karāmbujena | āvartamūrtirudaṭaṅki bhujottaraṅga-saṅgasya yena navaśauryamahārṇavasya || 27 ||
column6: रिपूणां निप्रहन्तुं कश्चित्करेण चक्रमभ्रमयत् । भुजाभ्यामुद्गतेन तरङ्गेण सङ्गो यस्य तस्य शौर्योदधेरावर्तरूपं टङ्कितम् ॥
column7: All set to injure the enemies in battle, one Pramatha kept spinning a discus with his lotus-hand, (discus) which became a whirlpool in the ocean of his unmatched valour, his arm standing for its lofty wave.
column8: The use of the genitive ‘ripūṇām’ with ‘niprahantum’ is according to the rule ‘jāsiniprahaṇanāṭakrāthapiṣāṃ himsāyāṃ’

column4: धाराजलह्रदपथाभिनवप्ररूढ-रक्तोत्पलव्यतिकरेव कृपाणलेखा । केनाप्यमन्थरमरच्यत मुच्यमान-रोषारुणारुणनिरङ्कुशदृष्टिपातैः ॥ २८ ॥
column5: dhārājalahradapathābhinavaprarūḍha- raktotpalavyatikareva kṛpāṇalekhā | kenāpyamantharamaracyata mucyamāna- roṣāruṇāruṇaniraṅkuśadṛṣṭipātaiḥ || 28 ||
column6: द्रुतं क्षिप्यमाणा रोषातिरक्ता अनियन्त्रणा ये दृष्टिपातास्तैर्हेतुभिः केनापि खड्गलेखा धाराजलमग्नि(?)(सि)गतस्निग्धप्रभाविशेषस्तदेव जलत्वेनाध्यवसितं तदेव ह्रदस्तत्पथेऽभिनवः प्ररूढो जातो रक्तोत्पलानां व्यतिकरोऽस्याः सेवारच्यत कृता । रोषरक्ता दृष्टिपाता रक्तोत्पलत्वेन सम्भाविताः ॥
column7: Another warrior seemed to freely furnish the blade of his sword with crimson lotuses, springing afresh in the stream of its shimmering edge, by quickly casting his unrestrained, angry red glances (on it).
column8: The angry red glances are compared to crimson lotuses (JR)

column4: कश्चित्तथाप्रथितरोषभरं करेण वेगोद्धतं व्यधित कुट्टिमघट्टनानि । सद्यो यथा प्रथितनूतनरन्ध्रयोगा-त्त्रासेन भग्नहृदयेव धरापि जज्ञे ॥ २९ ॥
column5: kaścittathāprathitaroṣabharaṃ kareṇa vegoddhataṃ vyadhita kuṭṭimaghaṭṭanāni | sadyo yathā prathitanūtanarandhrayogā-ttrāsena bhagnahṛdayeva dharāpi jajñe || 29 ||
column6: प्रथितो रोषभरो यत्र । एवं कृत्वा । तथा वेगेनोद्धतं कृत्वा कश्चित्कुट्टिमानां घट्टनानि तथाकार्षीद्यथा सद्यः सम्पन्ननवच्छिद्रयोगाद्भूमिरपि भीत्या स्फुटितहृदयेव जज्ञे जाता ॥
column7: Thus did an enraged Pramatha slam his fist against the ground with great force that even Maiden Earth’s heart broke asunder in fear, or so it seemed, by way of the gaping hole that was newly formed.
column8: N/A

column4: कस्यापि वक्त्रमुदयात्परिपाटलश्रि मिश्रीकृतार्धमसिदीधितिधोरणीभिः । नाशैकपैशुनकृते द्विषतामकाण्ड-राहूपरागमिव कन्दलयाञ्चकार ॥ ३० ॥
column5: kasyāpi vaktramudayātparipāṭalaśri miśrīkṛtārdhamasidīdhitidhoraṇībhiḥ | nāśaikapaiśunakṛte dviṣatāmakāṇḍa-rāhūparāgamiva kandalayāñcakāra || 30 ||
column6: रोषवशादुदयन्ती परिपाटला श्रीर्यस्य । तथासिदीधितिधोरणीभिः खड्गप्रभापङ्क्तिभिर्मिश्रीकृतमर्धं यस्य तत्कस्यापि वक्त्रं नाशद्योतनायाकाण्डे दिनादौ राहूपरागमिव प्रकाशयामास ॥
column7: Another Pramatha’s dark red face, suffused on one side with swathes of lustre streaming forth from his (dark) sword, seemed to conjure up an untimely (solar) eclipse that signalled the enemy’s utter ruin.
column8: Untimely = at daybreak (JR). An untimely eclipse forebodes misfortune.

column4: आक्रन्दमावहदिवाविरतान्तराल-पारिप्लवभ्रमरसंहतिझाङ्कृतेन । प्रत्यर्थिवीरकमलागृहशङ्कयेव कश्चिद्बभञ्ज निजविभ्रमपुण्डरीकम् ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: ākrandamāvahadivāviratāntarāla- pāriplavabhramarasaṃhatijhāṅkṛtena | pratyarthivīrakamalāgṛhaśaṅkayeva kaścidbabhañja nijavibhramapuṇḍarīkam || 31 ||
column6: रोषवशात्कश्चितस्वविलासपद्ममस्फोटयत् ॥ अतः सम्भाव्यते- प्रत्यर्थिनो वैरिणो ये वीरास्तेषां कमला श्रीस्तस्या गृहमावास इति शङ्कया सम्भावनयेव । अत एव चान्तराले पारिप्लवा चश्चला या भ्रमरसंहतिस्तस्या झाङ्कृतं रुतं तेन हेतुनाक्रन्दं विह्वलं शब्दं बिभ्रदिव॥
column7: When a warrior tore his play-lotus apart in the belief that it was the abode of the enemy’s Fortune Goddess, it appeared to let out a wail through the hum of the bees swarming agitatedly within.
column8: N/A

column4: कोऽपि प्रकोपितमतिः परकिंवदन्त्या दन्त्याहवप्रसरसम्भृतसिंहवीर्यः । अङ्गैः समीकशतपीतचरारिखड्ग- धाराम्बु धर्मभरविभ्रमतो ववाम ॥ ३२ ॥
column5: ko'pi prakopitamatiḥ parakiṃvadantyā dantyāhavaprasarasambhṛtasiṃhavīryaḥ | aṅgaiḥ samīkaśatapītacarārikhaḍga- dhārāmbu dharmabharavibhramato vavāma || 32 ||
column6: परेषां किंवदन्ती वार्ता तया प्रकोपिता मतिर्यस्य सः । दन्त्याह​वं हस्तियुद्धं तत्प्रसरे सम्भृतं सिंहवीर्यं यस्य स कोऽपि घर्मजलव्याजात्सङ्ग्रामेषु पूर्वपीतं यदरिखड्गधाराम्बु ववामोदवमत् ॥
column7: Enraged by the news of his enemies, a certain Pramatha, who possessed the strength of a lion in his long-drawn fights with elephants, seemed to release all the water that was imbibed by him from the shimmering edges of the enemy’s swords in several foregone battles by disguising it as an outpour of sweat.
column8: Idea similar to verse 24 above. While verse 24 talks about pieces of swords, this verse talks about the water-like shimmering edge of the swords. A similar idea is repeated once again in 18.58

column4: कश्चित्पुरो विकिरति स्म विमृद्यमान-हस्तोर्मिकोत्करगलत्तपनीयचूर्णैः । उन्मूल्यमानपरिपन्थिरमानिकेत-पङ्केरुहप्रकरकेसररेणुपुञ्जम् ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: kaścitpuro vikirati sma vimṛdyamāna-hastormikotkaragalattapanīyacūrṇaiḥ | unmūlyamānaparipanthiramāniketa-paṅkeruhaprakarakesarareṇupuñjam || 33 ||
column6: विमृद्यमानो भज्यमानो यो हस्तोर्मिकोत्करस्तस्माद्गलन्ति तपनीयचूर्णानि सुवर्णरेणवस्तैर्हेतुभिः कोपत उन्मूल्यमान उत्खातमूलो य: परिपन्थिरमानिकेतपङ्केरुहप्रकरो वैरिलक्ष्मीनिवासपद्मसमूहस्तस्य केसरास्त एव [तदीय]रेणुपुञ्जं व्यानञ्ज । हस्तवालिकासुवर्णचूर्णानि पद्मपरागत्वेन सम्भावितानि ॥
column7: After uprooting the lotus abodes of his enemy’s Lady Fortune, yet another soldier scattered their plentiful pollen by disguising it as the golden dust rained down by a row of pulverized finger rings.
column8: The golden dust is likened to the pollen of lotuses (JR).

column4: कस्याप्यवेपत वपुः पुनरुक्तकोपा-टोपाकुलं गलदनर्गलघ​​र्मवारि । आसन्नसङ्गररसव्यसनानुषङ्गा-द्वीरश्रियेव हठतः परिरभ्यमाणम् ॥ ३४ ॥
column5: kasyāpyavepata vapuḥ punaruktakopā-ṭopākulaṃ galadanargalagharmavāri | āsannasaṅgararasavyasanānuṣaṅgā-dvīraśriyeva haṭhataḥ parirabhyamāṇam || 34 ||
column6: पुनरुक्तो यः कोपाटोपस्तेनाकुलं कस्यापि वपुर्गलदनर्गलं निर्निरोधं घ​​र्मवारि यत्र । एवं कृत्वाकम्पत । आसन्नो यः सङ्गरः सङ्ग्रामः स एव चर्व्यमाणत्वाद्रसस्तत्र व्यसनेनानुषङ्गाद्धेतोर्वीरश्रिया स्त्रीत्वान्नायिकात्वेन व्यवहृतयालिङ्ग्यमानमिव । योषितालिङ्ग्यमानश्च गलद्घ​र्मजल: कम्पते ॥
column7: Dripping with a steady flow of sweat, a certain Pramatha’s body trembled in repetitive wrath, embraced tightly, as it were, by Lady Courage due to his relentless desire for savouring the mood of the upcoming battle.
column8: A man sweats and trembles in ecstasy when embraced by a maiden (JR).

column4: श्यामोद्भ्रमद्भ्रुकुटि पाण्डुतराट्टहास-मुल्लासिशोणिमसखं च मुखं परस्य । कोपश्रियः सममिवारभतैणनाभि-नासीरपीतनरसैरनुलेपकेलिम् ॥ ३५ ॥
column5: śyāmodbhramadbhrukuṭi pāṇḍutarāṭṭahāsa-mullāsiśoṇimasakhaṃ ca mukhaṃ parasya | kopaśriyaḥ samamivārabhataiṇanābhi-nāsīrapītanarasairanulepakelim || 35 ||
column6: श्यामोद्भ्रमन्ती भृकुटिर्यस्य । तथाविच्छिन्नत्वाच्छुभ्राट्टहासम् । तथोल्लासिनः शोणिम्नोऽरुणत्वस्य सखं परिचितं चान्यस्य मुखं समं मिश्रैः कस्तूरीकर्पूरकुङ्कुमरसैः कोपश्रियो वीरलक्ष्म्या अङ्गरागसिद्धिमिवारब्धवत् ॥
column7: Yet another Pramatha’s face seemed to engage in the sport of simultaneously smearing Maiden Anger with a mixture of musk, camphor, and saffron through its dark, animated frowns, bright boisterous laughter, and the spreading glow of flushed redness in that order.
column8: Nāsīra' is a rare Sanskrit synonym for 'camphor'

column4: दूरं प्रसार्य भुजदण्डयुगं मुखं च व्यादाय कश्चिदथ जृम्भणविभ्रमेषु । आकृष्य दिग्वलयतोऽखिलवैरिलोका-न्द्रागत्तुमारभत भैरवशिक्षयेव ॥ ३६ ॥
column5: dūraṃ prasārya bhujadaṇḍayugaṃ mukhaṃ ca vyādāya kaścidatha jṛmbhaṇavibhrameṣu | ākṛṣya digvalayato'khilavairilokā-ndrāgattumārabhata bhairavaśikṣayeva || 36 ||
column6: जृम्भाविलासेषु भुजद्वयं प्रसार्य मुखं च व्यादाय विकास्य कश्चिद्दिगन्तराद्वैरिवर्गमाकृष्य महाकालोपदेशेन भोक्तुमिवारब्धवान् ॥
column7: His mouth agape in careless yawns, one warrior stretched his arms afar, as if, with Bhairava’s training, he was beginning to devour his enemies greedily by grabbing them from each and every direction.
column8: Bhairava, also known as Mahākāla, is a fierce form of Shiva.
