column4: गर्वादथर्वाय रथाङ्गरक्षस्तस्यैकपार्श्वे प्रणयं बबन्ध । पुराभिचाराय महोमयेऽग्नौ कुर्वन्निवापाङ्गरुचासहोमम् ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: garvādatharvāya rathāṅgarakṣastasyaikapārśve praṇayaṃ babandha | purābhicārāya mahomaye'gnau kurvannivāpāṅgarucāsahomam || 33 ||
column6: अथर्वा आभिचारिककर्मप्रधानो वेदविशेषः, तस्य रथस्यैकपार्श्वे प्रणयं परिचयं चकार । महस्तेजस्तन्मयेऽग्नौ पुराभिचाराय दैत्योच्चाटनायास्रहोमं कुर्वन्निव । अभिचारे रक्तहोम उचितः॥
column7: Offering, as it were, a bloody oblation of his (angry red) side glances in the fire of heroism so as to cast an evil spell on the Puras, Atharvan stood proudly by the side of the chariot as its guard.
column8: The Atharva Veda deals with rituals aimed at causing harm (such as death) to one’s enemy through the use of spells (abhicārakarma). Offering blood as oblation is part of such rituals (JR).

column4: तस्येतरच्चक्रमरक्षि तेन पुरःसरेणाङ्गिरसा मुनीनाम् । सुरद्रुहामैन्द्रपदाधिरोहे सदैव यत्सन्ततिरन्तरायः ॥ ३४ ॥
column5: tasyetaraccakramarakṣi tena puraḥsareṇāṅgirasā munīnām | suradruhāmaindrapadādhirohe sadaiva yatsantatirantarāyaḥ || 34 ||
column6: सुरद्रुहामसुराणामैन्द्रपद इन्द्रत्वेऽधिरोहस्तत्र यत्सन्ततिर्बृहस्पतिरन्तरायो विघ्नभूतः। बृहस्पतेर्देवगुरुवात् । तेन मुनीनां पुरःसरेणाङ्गिरसा द्वितीयं चक्रं रक्षितम् ॥
column7: Its other wheel was protected by Angiras, the foremost of sages, whose progeny (i.e., Brhaspati) is a constant obstacle to the god-hating Asuras in reaching Indrahood.
column8: Angiras is one of the ten sons of Brahma, born from his mouth (‘athābhidhyāyataḥ sargaṃ daśa putrāḥ prajajñire | - - - aṅgirā mukhataḥ ||’, Bhāgavata Purāṇa, 3.12.21, 24). His wife, Shraddha, gave birth to four daughters, named Sinivali, Kuhu, Raka, and Anumati (see footnote under 20.24 above) and two sons, Utathya and Brihaspati (‘śraddhā tvaaṅgirasaḥ patnī catasro’sūta kanyakāḥ | sinīvālī kuhū rākā caturthyanumatistathā || tatputrāvaparāvāstāṃ - - - utathyo - - - brahmiṣṭhaśca bṛhaspaiḥ ||, Bhāgavata Purāṇa, 4.1.34, 35)

column4: पुरः पुराणैः सह सार्धमृग्भिः सामान्यसामान्यजवं ववल्गुः। विलोकयन्त्यास्पदसंस्तवेन वक्त्राणि यन्तृत्वभृतो विधातुः ॥ ३५ ॥
column5: puraḥ purāṇaiḥ saha sārdhamṛgbhiḥ sāmānyasāmānyajavaṃ vavalguḥ| vilokayantyāspadasaṃstavena vaktrāṇi yantṛtvabhṛto vidhātuḥ || 35 ||
column6: ऋग्भिः ऋग्वेदेन सार्धम्, तथा पुराणैः पञ्चलक्षणैः सह सामानि रथस्याग्रेऽसामान्यजवं बहुवेगं ववल्गुः पुस्फुरुः । यन्तृत्वभृतः सूतभूतस्य ब्रह्मणो मुखानि प्रतिष्ठापरिचयेन पश्यन्ति । वेदा हि ब्रह्ममुखान्निरासन् ॥
column7: Beholding their naturally familiar abode - the faces of Brahma, who was the charioteer - the Samans, accompanied by the Puranas and the Rks, marched forward with unmatched speed.
column8: The Vedas were born from the mouths of Brahma (JR). The repetition of ‘sā’, ‘mā’, and ‘nya’ in the second line of the verse is an instance of the sound-based trope Yamaka.

column4: सहेतिहासैश्च सहेतिहासैर्यजूंषि सोद्रेकवलद्वपूंषि । पृष्ठे प्रतिष्ठामतिशय्य तस्य रक्षाभरक्षान्तिसखत्वमूहुः ॥ ३६ ॥
column5: sahetihāsaiśca sahetihāsairyajūṃṣi sodrekavaladvapūṃṣi | pṛṣṭhe pratiṣṭhāmatiśayya tasya rakṣābharakṣāntisakhatvamūhuḥ || 36 ||
column6: हेतीनामायुधानां हासः स्फुरणम् । सहेतिहासेन वर्तन्ते ये तैरितिहासैः पुरावृत्तैः सह तस्य पृष्ठे प्रतिष्ठामाश्रित्य स्थित्वा यजूंषि रक्षालक्षणे भरे या क्षान्तिस्तत्सखत्वमवहन् । सोद्रेकं सोत्कर्षं वलत्स्फुरद्वपुर्येषाम् । एतेन तेषां निर्भयत्वं प्रतिपादितम् ॥
column7: The particularly lively-limbed Yajus hymns, along with the Itihasas that wielded sparkling weapons, occupied its rear end and readily took charge of protecting it.
column8: Another example (see 20.35 above) of Yamaka, effected through the repetition of ‘sa’, ‘he’, ‘ti’, ‘hā’, and ‘saiḥ’; the string of syllables must be read in two different ways: ‘sa-heti-hāsaiḥ’ and  ‘saha’ + ‘itihāsaiḥ’.

column4: यासां शरीरं पदमन्तरात्मा वाक्यं प्रमाणं परिकर्ममार्गः । विद्वन्मुखालङ्करणं गिरस्ताः सिषेविरे तत्परिपार्श्ववृत्तिम् ॥ ३७ ॥
column5: yāsāṃ śarīraṃ padamantarātmā vākyaṃ pramāṇaṃ parikarmamārgaḥ | vidvanmukhālaṅkaraṇaṃ girastāḥ siṣevire tatparipārśvavṛttim || 37 ||
column6: पदं यासां शरीरम् । पदस्य प्रथमोपलक्ष्यमाणत्वाच्छरीरत्वम् । वाक्यं यासामन्तरात्मा । वाक्यस्य शरीरभूतैः पदैर्व्यज्यमानत्वात्प्राधान्याच्चान्तरात्मत्वम् । प्रमाणं यासां परिकर्ममार्गः । तस्य विचारहेतुत्वात् । विद्वन्मुखेऽलङ्करणभूतास्ता वाचस्तत्पार्श्वे वृत्तिमभजन् ॥
column7: The Utterances whose body is the word; heart, the sentence; and the manner of attire, the valid means of knowledge; and which adorn the scholar’s mouth served the chariot in the capacity of an accompanying retinue.
column8: The word is compared to the body because it is the first to be perceived; the sentence is compared to the heart because it is understood through the word and holds primacy; the valid means of knowledge is compared to the manner of attire since, like the latter, it is a product of deliberation (JR).

column4: तत्कर्मसाहायकसामरस्यं सारस्वतस्यावधयो रसस्य । अदुर्दशां तत्र चतुर्दशापि प्रपद्य हृद्या विदधुश्च विद्याः ॥ ३८ ॥
column5: tatkarmasāhāyakasāmarasyaṃ sārasvatasyāvadhayo rasasya | adurdaśāṃ tatra caturdaśāpi prapadya hṛdyā vidadhuśca vidyāḥ || 38 ||
column6: सारस्वतस्य रसस्य चर्व्य​माणत्वात्प्रसरस्यावधयः पर्यन्तभूमयश्चतुर्दशविद्या अदुर्दशां प्रपद्य । तदा वीतविघ्नैर्मुनिभिरुपास्यमानत्वात् । तत्कर्मणि साहायकं तत्र सामरस्यं तुल्यां वृत्तिं चक्रुः । 'अङ्गानि वेदाश्चत्वारो मीमांसा न्यायविस्तरः । पुराणं धर्मशास्त्रं च विद्या ह्येताश्चतुर्दश ॥
column7: Attaining blessedness, the fourteenfold, cherished Knowledge Domains – farthest boundaries of scholarship’s sweet stream – came together as one in aiding its function.
column8: The fourteenfold knowledge domains include the four Vedas, the six Vedāngas, and four Śāstras (Purāṇa, Ānvīkṣikī, Mīmāṃsā, and Smṛtitantra (‘caturdaśa vidyāsthānāni, yaduta vidyāścatvāraḥ, ṣaḍangāni, catvāri śāstrāṇi ityācāryāḥ’, Kāvyamīmāṃsā, chapter 1; also ‘angāni vedāścatvāro mīmāṃsā nyāyavistaraḥ | purāṇaṃ dharmaśāstraṃ ca vidyā hyetāścaturdaśa’, quoted by JR)

column4: पद्मं च सिन्धुं च महीधरं च मुक्त्वा किलैकत्र सदा घटन्ते । यस्मिन्मिथः स्त्री(थस्त्री)ण्यपि कारणानि ययौ स तस्य प्रणवो मुखत्वम् ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: padmaṃ ca sindhuṃ ca mahīdharaṃ ca muktvā kilaikatra sadā ghaṭante | yasminmithaḥ strī(thastrī)ṇyapi kāraṇāni yayau sa tasya praṇavo mukhatvam || 39 ||
column6: पद्मं समुद्रं महीधरमत्र कैलासं त्यक्त्वा यस्मिन्नेकस्मिंस्त्रीण्यपि कारणानि ब्रह्मादयो मिथोऽन्योन्यं घटन्ते स प्रणवस्तस्य रथस्य मुखभावं गतः । अस्य ह्यकारोकारमकारलक्षणास्तिस्रो मात्रा ब्रह्मादिरूपाः॥
column7: The divine syllable Om – in which the three Causes, dismissing (their individual abodes, namely) the lotus, ocean, and mountain, merge with one another in perpetual unity – became its forepart.
column8: The three Causes are Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva, whose respective abodes are lotus, ocean, and mountain, and who represent the sounds ‘a’, ‘u’, and ‘m’ respectively in the divine syllable 'Om' (JR).

column4: सितासितानर्गलपक्षजालक्रमेण रोहज्जवतारतम्यः । पृषत्कवत्सन्निदधे हि चापे संवत्सरो मत्सरिणः पुरेषु ॥ ४० ॥
column5: sitāsitānargalapakṣajālakrameṇa rohajjavatāratamyaḥ | pṛṣatkavatsannidadhe hi cāpe saṃvatsaro matsariṇaḥ pureṣu || 40 ||
column6: शुक्लकृष्णावनर्गलौ यौ पक्षौ दिनपञ्चदशकरूपौ कालिकविशेषौ पक्षाः पत्राणि च तेषां जालं तत्क्रमेण रोहदुत्पद्यमानं जवतारतम्यं यस्य संवत्सरस्य । गत्वरत्वात् । पृषत्कवच्छर इव संवत्सरः पुरारेश्चापे सन्निहितः ॥
column7: The Year was fixed on the bow of Pura’s Foe like an arrow. Its speed grew in stages, thanks to the unimpeded advance of the numerous bright and dark halves of the month/feathers (attached to it).
column8: The year is likened to Shiva’s arrow and the bright and dark halves of the month to the feathers attached to it.

column4: चापे तदध्यासनतो हिमर्तुग्रीष्मश्रियो भीष्मतया गुणस्य । प्रागेव सेवां व्यधितेव भाविपृषत्कसोमज्वलनप्रभावः ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: cāpe tadadhyāsanato himartugrīṣmaśriyo bhīṣmatayā guṇasya | prāgeva sevāṃ vyadhiteva bhāvipṛṣatkasomajvalanaprabhāvaḥ || 41 ||
column6: धनुषि विषये तस्य संवत्सरस्याध्यासनत आश्रयणाद्धिमर्तुग्रीष्मसम्बन्धिनो गुणस्य शीतोष्णलक्षणस्य भीष्मतया व्यक्तत्वेन भाविनौ भविष्यन्तौ पृषत्के शरे सोमज्वलनौ तयोः प्रभावः शीतोष्णलक्षणः पूर्वमेव सेवामकरोत् ॥
column7: Because of the placement of the Year (transformed into an arrow) on the bow, the bowstring – having come in contact with the winter and summer seasons – was so rendered intolerable it seemed as if the effect (i.e., cold and heat) of the moon and the fire in the arrow-to-be had already become manifest.
column8: See verse 20.45 below for the role played by Soma w.r.t Shiva’s arrow.

column4: श्रीनायकः सायकतामकाण्डचण्डक्रुधः खण्डशशाङ्कमौलेः । प्रागेव वाहाण्डजपक्षवेगगत्यां चिराभ्यस्त इवाललम्बे ॥ ४२ ॥
column5: śrīnāyakaḥ sāyakatāmakāṇḍacaṇḍakrudhaḥ khaṇḍaśaśāṅkamauleḥ | prāgeva vāhāṇḍajapakṣavegagatyāṃ cirābhyasta ivālalambe || 42 ||
column6: अकाण्डे तपःक्षयाभावेऽपि चण्डक्रुधोऽतिक्रुद्धस्य हरस्य विष्णुः शरभावमग्रहीत् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - पूर्वमेव वाहो योऽण्डजो गरुडस्तस्य पक्षैश्च वेगेन गतिर्गमनं तत्र चिराभ्यस्त इव । शरश्च हि पक्षवेगेन गच्छति । अकाण्डग्रहणाद्धरस्य स्वातन्त्र्यं प्रतिपादितम् ॥
column7: Seemingly in view of the long-drawn training he already had in flying fast on the wings of the bird (i.e., Garuda) that is his mount, Vishnu became the arrow of the crescent-crested Lord, whose furious anger grew all of a sudden.
column8: An arrow’s speed is also aided by the feathers attached to it; 'all of a sudden' = 'even before the  Asuras exhausted all the merits which they had earned from their penance' (JR)

column4: शौरिः शरीभूततनुः पुरस्तान्निमग्नमग्निं बिभराञ्चकार । विनिह्नुतस्यापि हठात्स्फुरन्तं भरं प्रभाणामिव कौस्तुभस्य ॥ ४३ ॥
column5: śauriḥ śarībhūtatanuḥ purastānnimagnamagniṃ bibharāñcakāra | vinihnutasyāpi haṭhātsphurantaṃ bharaṃ prabhāṇāmiva kaustubhasya || 43 ||
column6: शरः सम्पद्यमानो विष्णुरग्रे निक्षिप्तमूलं वर्तमानमग्निं दधे । स्वात्मगोपनार्थं गोपितस्यापि कौस्तुभस्य बलान्निर्यान्तं दीप्तिभरमिव ॥
column7: Having transformed into an arrow, Vishnu flaunted the fire enshrined before him as if it were the dense lustre of the Kaustubha gem which, though kept hidden from view (in his transformed state), was shining forth spontaneously.
column8: Though Vishnu had kept the Kaustubha gem hidden from view in his transformed state as Shiva’s arrow, its irrepressible glow manifested as the arrow’s fiery radiance.

column4: स्फुरन्पुरस्ताच्छतशः शरस्य स्वाहाकुटुम्बः पटलैः शिखानाम् । यात्राप्रसङ्गे व्यधितेव शम्भोरव्याजनीराजनचेष्टितानि ॥ ४४ ॥
column5: sphuranpurastācchataśaḥ śarasya svāhākuṭumbaḥ paṭalaiḥ śikhānām | yātrāprasaṅge vyadhiteva śambhoravyājanīrājanaceṣṭitāni || 44 ||
column6: शतशः शतसङ्ख्यैर्ज्वालाकदम्बैः स्फुरन्नग्निर्यात्रावसरे नीराजनचेष्टितानि शान्तिकर्माणीवाकरोत् ॥
column7: Blazing brightly at the arrow’s tip with masses of flames in their hundreds, Swaha’s Spouse seemed to readily perform a lamp-waving ritual on the occasion of Shiva’s military march.
column8: Swāhā’s Spouse is Agni, the fire god..

column4: सोमोऽपि सोमार्धभृतः शरस्य प्रोट्टङ्कयामास निवासमग्नौ । विलायिताभिः सविधाग्निधाम्ना सुधाभिराप्यायितजीवलोकः ॥ ४५ ॥
column5: somo'pi somārdhabhṛtaḥ śarasya proṭṭaṅkayāmāsa nivāsamagnau | vilāyitābhiḥ savidhāgnidhāmnā sudhābhirāpyāyitajīvalokaḥ || 45 ||
column7: The Moon too made the fire of the Moon-crested Lord’s arrow his abode, nourishing the world of beings with his ambrosia that melted away in the heat of the fire at hand.
column8: JR’s commentary for this verse is not available.

column4: सवह्निमह्नाय विवर्धमानमग्रे विवृण्वन्नवलीढसोमः । नेतुं शरः शूलकरस्य मन्यौ पुराणि पूर्णाहुतितामियेष ॥ ४६ ॥
column5: savahnimahnāya vivardhamānamagre vivṛṇvannavalīḍhasomaḥ | netuṃ śaraḥ śūlakarasya manyau purāṇi pūrṇāhutitāmiyeṣa || 46 ||
column6: अग्निमग्रे धारयन्नवलीढो धृतः सोमश्चन्द्रो येन स शूलिनः शरो रोषे पुराणि दैत्यविशेषान्पूर्णाहुतिभावं नेतुमैच्छत् । अथ चाग्निं बिभ्रदवलीढः सोमस्तृणविशेषो येन स मन्यौ यज्ञे पूर्णाहुतिं ददाति ॥
column7: Sporting a steadily surging fire in its tip/ahead, the moon-/Soma-bearing Arrow desired to make the Cities its final offering in the Trident-handed God’s fury/sacrifice.
column8: The arrow is personified as a Vedic sacrificer, carrying the Soma herb and making a final oblation of the Tripuras in the fire of Shiva’s fury (JR).

column4: विधुः स्वयं सायकतामियेष विधुश्च तस्याथ पुरो निलिल्ये । अस्तानि ताभ्यां न कथं पुराणि विध्वस्ततासंस्तवमाप्नुवन्तु ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: vidhuḥ svayaṃ sāyakatāmiyeṣa vidhuśca tasyātha puro nililye | astāni tābhyāṃ na kathaṃ purāṇi vidhvastatāsaṃstavamāpnuvantu || 47 ||
column6: विधुर्विष्णुः स्वयमप्रेरितः शरभावं काङ्कितवान् । विधुश्चन्द्रस्तदग्रे निलीनः । ताभ्यां विधुभ्यां नारायणेन्दुभ्यामस्तान्यवगणितानि पुराणि विध्वस्तताया विध्वंसस्य विधुभ्यामस्तत्वस्य च संस्तवं कथं नाप्नुवन्तु । यो विधुभ्यामस्तः स विध्वस्तः कथं न भवति ॥
column7: When Vidhu (Vishnu) himself desired to become the arrow and Vidhu (the moon) too was present in front of him, how could the Cities, which were vanquished by the two, not be termed ‘vanquished by the Vidhus’/meet with their ruin?
column8: The verse plays on the words ‘vidhu’ (Vishnu/moon) and ‘vidhvasta’ (‘ruined’/‘vanquished by Vishnu and moon’) (JR).

column4: सर्गप्रसङ्गे जगदेकजिष्णोर्विष्णोः स्थितिः कर्म किल प्रणीतम् । अहो पुराणां चरितं तु तेषु यत्सोऽपि संहारपुरःसरोऽभूत् ॥ ४८ ॥
column5: sargaprasaṅge jagadekajiṣṇorviṣṇoḥ sthitiḥ karma kila praṇītam | aho purāṇāṃ caritaṃ tu teṣu yatso'pi saṃhārapuraḥsaro'bhūt || 48 ||
column6: किलेत्यागमे । सृष्ट्यारम्भ एव हरेः स्थितिः कर्म व्याख्यातम् । पुराणां चरितं पुनरहो अद्भुतम् । सोऽपि स्थितिकार्यपि हरिस्तेषु संहारार्थमग्रणीरभूत् ॥
column7: It was clearly established at the very beginning of creation that sustenance is the duty of Vishnu, the sole conqueror of the world. Strange is the saga of the Puras, in whose case even he took the lead to carry out the task of annihilation.
column8: It was Vishnu, who in the form of Shiva’s arrow, brought about the destruction of theTripuras.

column4: यस्यास्ति वैकुण्ठतया प्रसिद्धिस्तस्मिञ्शरे पञ्चशरान्तकस्य । चक्रे शशाङ्केन हुताशतप्ते पानक्रियेव स्वसुधारसेन ॥ ४९ ॥
column5: yasyāsti vaikuṇṭhatayā prasiddhistasmiñśare pañcaśarāntakasya | cakre śaśāṅkena hutāśatapte pānakriyeva svasudhārasena || 49 ||
column6: यस्य शरस्य वैकुण्ठतया वैकुण्ठभावेन विकुण्ठोऽतीक्ष्णस्तद्भावेन च प्रसिद्धिः । तस्मिन्हरस्य शरे चन्द्रेण कर्त्रा निजामृतरसेन करणेन पानक्रियेव चक्रे । [तप्तस्य] जले ब्रोडनं पानक्रिया । कुण्ठस्य च शरादेरग्नितापनात्पूर्वं पानक्रिया युक्ता । वैशब्दः प्रसिद्ध्यर्थः ॥
column7: Since it is widely known that the arrow of Shiva, destroyer of the five-arrowed Kama, is Vishnu/blunt, the moon seemed to quench it in its ambrosial fluid after the fire had heated it up.
column8: Pānakriyā’ is the process of dipping a heated object in water. Blunt metallic objects are sharpened by this process (JR).

column4: अद्वैतमूर्तेर्विशिखेन शम्भोः प्रत्युप्तशीतांशुहुताशनेन । अतन्यतान्योन्यविरोधभाजोरेकत्र शीतातपयोर्निवेशः ॥ ५० ॥
column5: advaitamūrterviśikhena śambhoḥ pratyuptaśītāṃśuhutāśanena | atanyatānyonyavirodhabhājorekatra śītātapayorniveśaḥ || 50 ||
column6: अद्वैता निर्द्वन्द्वा मूर्तिर्यस्य । विश्वमयस्येत्यर्थः । हरस्य बाणेन परस्परविरुद्धयोः शीतातपयोर्निवेश एकस्मिन्स्थाने कृतः । यतः प्रत्युप्तौ निवेशितौ चन्द्राग्नी यत्र ॥
column7: Furnished with the moon and the fire, the arrow of the all-encompassing Shiva, who is without a second, brought together in one place the mutually opposed attributes of cold and heat.
column8: The qualifier ‘advaitamūrti’ (explained by JR as ‘nirdvandva’ and ‘viśvamaya’, which mean ‘secondless’ and ‘all-encompassing’) is significant; Shiva, being himself all-encompassing and secondless, could easily bring about a reconciliation of mutually opposed attributes.

column4: यस्यासिताश्रीरधिकण्ठपीठमाभाति मूर्धा च धृतार्धचन्द्रः। ऊर्ध्वाक्षिरोहद्बहुहेति तस्य विभोः किमस्त्रान्तरदुर्ग्रहेण ॥ ५१ ॥
column5: yasyāsitāśrīradhikaṇṭhapīṭhamābhāti mūrdhā ca dhṛtārdhacandraḥ | ūrdhvākṣirohadbahuheti tasya vibhoḥ kimastrāntaradurgraheṇa || 51 ||
column6: असिता श्रीः श्यामा शोभा, असेः खड्गस्य भावोऽसिता तया श्रीर्यस्य कण्ठपीठे भवति । मूर्धा च धृतोऽर्धचन्द्रः शरविशेषोऽपि येन स आभाति । तथा ऊर्ध्वाक्षि तृतीयं नेत्रं रोहन्त्यो बहवो हेतयो ज्वाला आयुधानि च यस्य तद्भवति । तस्य विभोरन्यास्त्राध्यासनेन किम् ॥
column7: Why must the Lord, whose handsome neck is home to a dark blue glow/the splendour of swordness, over whose head lies the crescent moon/crescent-tipped arrow, and from whose third eye emanate plentiful flames/weapons wield other weapons in vain?
column8: Through the use of pun, the poet describes Shiva as intrinsically possessing various weapons and therefore not in need of them without. The word ‘asitā’ must be taken as an adjective (meaning ‘dark blue’) of ‘śrīḥ’ (‘glow’) in one sense and as an abstract noun (meaning ‘swordness’) in the other.

column4: इत्थं मुकुन्दं च हविर्भुजं च विभावरीशं च विधाय शस्त्रम् । मूर्त्यन्तरैरेव निजैस्तथासावक्रीडदाद्यः पुरुषोऽष्टमूर्तिः ॥ ५२ ॥
column5: itthaṃ mukundaṃ ca havirbhujaṃ ca vibhāvarīśaṃ ca vidhāya śastram | mūrtyantaraireva nijaistathāsāvakrīḍadādyaḥ puruṣo'ṣṭamūrtiḥ || 52 ||
column6: इदानीं कविर्भगवतः स्तुत्यर्थं स्वतन्त्र्यमाह - एवं नारायणादीनस्त्रीकृत्य स्वैरेव मूर्त्यन्तरैर्निजाभिरेव मूर्तिभिः सोऽक्रीडत् । यत आद्यः पुरुषोऽष्टमूर्तिः ॥
column7: In this way, having made Vishnu, fire, and moon his missile, the eight-formed Primeval Being amused himself by playing with his very own varied forms.
column8: The fire and moon are included among the eight forms of Shiva; Vishnu and Shiva are often regarded as inseparable in form and essence (e.g., ‘śivāya viṣṇurūpāya viṣṇave śivarūpiṇe’, Padma Purāṇa, 6.138.14).

column4: कालं च कामं च यदा प्रसह्य काक्षेक्षितैरेव तिरश्चकार । एकस्य लोकत्रितयस्य जेतुरस्त्रं तदानीं कतरद्बभूव ॥ ५३ ॥
column5: kālaṃ ca kāmaṃ ca yadā prasahya kākṣekṣitaireva tiraścakāra | ekasya lokatritayasya jeturastraṃ tadānīṃ kataradbabhūva || 53 ||
column6: अक्षश्चक्षुरिन्द्रियं तस्येक्षितानि रोषरूक्षेक्षितानि काक्षेक्षितानि । ईषदर्थे कादेशः । काणाक्षपातमात्रैरित्यर्थः । कालं च कामं च यस्तिरश्चकार जितवांस्तस्य कतरदस्त्रम् । न किञ्चिदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Since Shiva, the sole conqueror of the three worlds, had thoroughly routed out even Death and Desire with his side-glances alone, what was it that could become his weapon at that time (i.e., during the destruction of the Tripuras)?
column8: The purport is that there was nothing in the world that could truly serve as Shiva’s weapon; the weapons (bow and arrow) wielded by Shiva while destroying the Tripuras functioned merely as appendages; it was his very own indomitable spirit that was the true cause of victory.

column4: यस्यासकृद्भैरवविग्रहस्य लोकत्रयग्रासरसोऽवहेला । तिस्रः पुरस्तस्य पुरोऽपकर्तुं को नाम संरम्भधुराधिरोहः ॥ ५४ ॥
column5: yasyāsakṛdbhairavavigrahasya lokatrayagrāsaraso'vahelā | tisraḥ purastasya puro'pakartuṃ ko nāma saṃrambhadhurādhirohaḥ || 54 ||
column6: महाकालरूपस्य यस्य विश्वग्रासोऽवहेला हेलासाध्यस्तस्य तिस्रः पुरो दैत्यविशेषान्नगरीश्च जेतुं कः संरम्भः । न कश्चिदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: In his form as Bhairava, he repeatedly devours the three worlds like it is some child’s play. So what great excitement could he possibly have in destroying the three (trivial) cities before him?
column8: N/A

column4: शिरो विरिञ्चस्य नखाञ्चलेन मृणाललावं किल यो लुलाव । चिक्रीड स स्यन्दनवारवाणबाणादितन्त्रक्रियया पुरेषु ॥ ५५ ॥
column5: śiro viriñcasya nakhāñcalena mṛṇālalāvaṃ kila yo lulāva | cikrīḍa sa syandanavāravāṇabāṇāditantrakriyayā pureṣu || 55 ||
column6: मृणालमूलमिव ब्रह्मणः शिरो यो नखाग्रेण लूनवान्स वारबाणं वर्म बाणास्तदादिकरणेन पुरेषु दैत्येष्वक्रीडत् । दण्डापूपिकया पुरदाहस्य सिद्धेः ॥
column7: That very Shiva, who had plucked off Brahma’s head with the tip of his fingernail as if he were tearing a lotus stalk, entertained himself with paraphernalia such as chariot, armor, and arrow in the case of the Puras.
column8: Refer footnote under 17.33; Cf ‘rathaḥ kṣoṇī yantā - - - tripuratṛṇamāḍambaravidhiḥ’, Śivamahimnaḥ stotra, 18). The purport of the verse is this: Given Shiva had plucked off even the Creator's head, there is no way he would not destroy the Tripuras (JR).

column4: अध्यासीनो रथमवितथस्तोत्रतन्त्रप्रयोग-व्यग्राशेषत्रिदशवदनन्यस्तनेत्रत्रिभागः । देवो रेजे तदनु दनुजध्वंसदीक्षकसत्त्री तस्मिन्काले शिशुकुमुदिनीकान्तलेखावचूलः ॥ ५६ ॥
column5: adhyāsīno rathamavitathastotratantraprayoga- vyagrāśeṣatridaśavadananyastanetratribhāgaḥ | devo reje tadanu danujadhvaṃsadīkṣakasattrī tasminkāle śiśukumudinīkāntalekhāvacūlaḥ || 56 ||
column6: रथमारोहंस्तथा अवितथः सत्यो यः स्तोत्रतन्त्रप्रधान: प्रयोगस्तस्मिन्व्यग्राः संरव्धा ये अशेषत्रिदशास्तेषां वदनेषु न्यस्तो नेत्रत्रिभागोऽनुग्रहसूचकः कटाक्षपातो येन । तथा दनुजध्वंस एव दीक्षा तस्य एकसस्त्री अनवरतदाता चन्द्रमौलिर्दिदीपे ॥
column7: And then, letting his side-glance fall on the faces of all the gods, who were busy singing his praises wholeheartedly, Lord Shiva – adorned with the crest-ornament of the baby moon’s digit - looked splendid as he stood on his chariot, having vowed to carry out the Yajna of Asura massacre all by himself.

column4: भक्त्या नित्याहितहठनतिस्तत्क्षणं मार्गणत्व-स्वीकारेण प्रसृतवितताकाण्डसारल्ययोगः । शंसन्नद्रेर्नियतनमनं चापदण्डत्वमग्रे मन्ये तस्य त्रिभुवनगुरोः शार्ङ्गपाणिर्ललज्जे ॥ ५७ ॥
column5: bhaktyā nityāhitahaṭhanatistatkṣaṇaṃ mārgaṇatva-svīkāreṇa prasṛtavitatākāṇḍasāralyayogaḥ | śaṃsannadrerniyatanamanaṃ cāpadaṇḍatvamagre manye tasya tribhuvanaguroḥ śārṅgapāṇirlalajje || 57 ||
column6: अहं मन्ये - तस्य त्रिभुवनगुरोरग्रे हरिर्ललज्जे । यतो भक्त्या नित्यमाहिता हठनतिर्दण्डप्रणामो येन। तत्क्षणं मार्गणत्वस्य शरभावस्य याचकत्वस्य च स्वीकारेण ग्रहणेन प्रसृतो विततोऽकाण्डे सारल्येन ऋजुत्वेनानम्रत्वेन च योगो यस्य । यतो नित्यं नमनं तत्र तदद्रेर्धनुर्दण्डत्वं शंसन्स्तुवन् । मन्दरः शिलामयो नमति, मया तु मार्गणरूपेण नित्यभक्तेन च न नम्यते, किं त्वकाण्डे स्तब्धता धार्यते इति हरेर्लज्जा । त्रिभुवनगुरोरिति साकूतमभिधानम् ॥
column7: I believe the Sharnga-wielding Vishnu, who bends down readily and regularly in reverential devotion, must have felt embarrassed before the Master of the three worlds, because of being suddenly stretched straight in the process of becoming an arrow/a supplicant, all the while praising the mountain’s predicament as the bow that is destined to bend (in the near future).
column8: Vishnu’s embarrassment is due to the fact that he can no longer bend down before Shiva after transforming into his arrow (by pun, also ‘even after transforming into his supplicant’). He praises Mt. Mandara because it has the good fortune of bending before Shiva after becoming his bow (in spite of being a mountain, and therefore, naturally rigid). The poet’s use of the word ‘Śārṅgapāṇi’ (‘Wielder of the Śārṅga bow’) for Vishnu is significant. An apparent contradiction is brought out by describing the wielder of a bow as transforming into an arrow. The word ‘tribhuvanaguru’ (‘Master of the three worlds’), used for Shiva, indicates that he is worthy of being bowed down to.

column4: अग्रे कूबरिचक्रयोर्दिनकरश्यामाभुजङ्गौ शरे ज्वालालाञ्छनमित्युवाह भगवानादृत्य धामत्रयम् । यत्तत्रापि पुरत्रयस्य कदनादैच्छत्स लब्धास्पदं त्रैलोक्येऽपि निजं यशो रचयितुं सोऽभूद्विचित्रः क्रमः॥ ५८ ॥
column5: agre kūbaricakrayordinakaraśyāmābhujaṅgau śarejvālālāñchanamityuvāha bhagavānādṛtya dhāmatrayam | yattatrāpi puratrayasya kadanādaicchatsa labdhāspadaṃ trailokye'pi nijaṃ yaśo racayituṃ so'bhūdvicitraḥ kramaḥ|| 58 ||
column6: कूबरिणो रथस्य चक्रयोः पुरः सूर्येन्दू, तथा शरे ज्वालालाञ्छनोऽग्निः, इति धामत्रयं तेन स्वयं स्थानत्रयं चादृत्य भगवान्यदवहत्तत्रापि पुरत्रयस्य दैत्यत्रयस्य नगरत्रयस्य च नाशात्स्वयशस्त्रिभुवने प्राप्तस्थानं कर्तुमैच्छदिति क्रमोऽद्धृतः। य आत्मनि धामत्रयं वहति स पुरत्रयनाशात्त्रिजगत्स्थायि स्वयशः कर्तुं कथमि[च्छती]ति वैचित्र्यम् ॥
column7: The Lord flaunted a triad of luminaries/mansions: the sun and the moon in front of his chariot wheels and the flaming fire in his arrow. What was surprising, however, is that, by doing so, he wished to destroy the three Puras/cities and thereby firmly establish his fame in the three worlds.
column8: The cause of surprise is the fact that someone who owns three mansions (‘dhāma’) aims to destroy three cities ('pura') and establish his fame in the three worlds (JR). The apparent contradiction in this description must be resolved by considering the alternative meanings of ‘dhāma’ and 'pura' as 'luminaries' and 'Tripuras' respectively.

column4: देवः स्यन्दनमिन्दुशेखरमणिस्तं सोऽध्यरुक्षत्ततः सर्वाङ्गीणभुजङ्गमण्डनकृतायःकङ्कटोट्टङ्कनः । त्वङ्गत्तुङ्गतरङ्गसङ्गतशिखागङ्गाम्बुपूराहित- प्रादुर्भूतशिरस्त्रभङ्गिरधिकप्रक्रान्तवीरव्रतः ॥ ५९ ॥
column5: devaḥ syandanaminduśekharamaṇistaṃ so'dhyarukṣattataḥ sarvāṅgīṇabhujaṅgamaṇḍanakṛtāyaḥkaṅkaṭoṭṭaṅkanaḥ | tvaṅgattuṅgataraṅgasaṅgataśikhāgaṅgāmbupūrāhita- prādurbhūtaśirastrabhaṅgiradhikaprakrāntavīravrataḥ || 59 ||
column6: सर्वाङ्गीणाः सर्वाङ्गव्यापिनो ये भुजङ्गास्त एव मण्डनानि भूषणानि तैः कृतमयःकङ्कटस्य लोहकवचस्योट्टङ्कनं भङ्गिर्यस्य । तथा त्वङ्गत्तुङ्गतरङ्गसङ्गतो यः शिखागङ्गाम्बुपूरस्तेनाहितो निर्मितः प्रादुर्भूतस्य प्रकटस्य शिरस्त्रस्य शिरस्त्राणस्य भङ्गिष्टङ्को यस्य । यतोऽधिकं प्रक्रान्तमारब्धं वीरव्रतं येन स चन्द्रशिखारत्नो रथमधिरूढवान् ॥
column7: And then, the moon-crested Lord, who was fully prepared to discharge the hero’s vow, ascended the chariot,  the snakes clinging to his each and every limb giving the appearance of an iron armor and the stream of Ganga on his head, with its tumultuous waves rising high, conjuring up a crown.
column8: The snakes are compared to iron armours because they are dark in colour and adhere closely to the limbs. The waves of Ganga, some tall and some short, can put on the semblance of a crown, which is multitiered with rows of peaks arranged one above another.

column4: आरूढस्य दृढाभिमानगरिमप्रस्यन्दतः स्यन्दनं बाणेनाग्निमयात्मना रचयितुं नामावशेषान्द्विषः । दर्शंदर्शमदर्शदाश्रितजनस्तं कालकूटं गले लौहोरश्छदशङ्कया धृतनवोद्रेकं पुरद्रोहिणः ॥ ६० ॥
column5: ārūḍhasya dṛḍhābhimānagarimaprasyandataḥ syandanaṃ bāṇenāgnimayātmanā racayituṃ nāmāvaśeṣāndviṣaḥ | darśrśaṃdarśamadarśadāśritajanastaṃ kālakūṭaṃ gale lauhoraśchadaśaṅkayā dhṛtanavodrekaṃ puradrohiṇaḥ || 60 ||
column6: दृढो योऽभिमानगरिमा तदुल्लासाद्धेतोः आग्नेयस्वभावेन शरेण शत्रून्नाममात्रावशेषान्कर्तुं रथमारूढवतः पुरजितः कण्ठे कालकूटविषं दृष्ट्वा दृष्ट्वा सेवकजनोऽद्राक्षीत् । लौहोरश्छद इति शङ्कया । नायं कालकूटः, अपि त्वायस उरश्छद इत्यद्राक्षीत् । अदर्शदिति लुङ्यङि गुणे च कृते रूपम् ॥
column7: As the Foe of the Puras, who was eager to grant the enemies a mere nominal existence by employing his fiery-natured arrow, climbed the chariot with an outpouring of steady, surplus courage, his attendants kept gazing and gazing with renewed curiosity at the Kalakuta poison on his throat, mistaking it for an iron chest guard.
column8: The comparison of the poison Kālakūta with an iron chest guard is due to their shared black colour; it is possible to imagine the poison’s dark glow as extending beyond the neck to pervade the chest below, thereby lending further propreity to the comparison. The phrase ‘racayituṃ nāmāvaśeṣān dviṣaḥ’ - ‘to leave the enemies with nothing more than their names’ - is a roundabout way of saying ‘to kill the enemies’.

column4: अक्षैरक्षतधुर्यवृत्तिर(?म​)धिकावाप्तोग्ररश्मिग्रहा-दासीदन्निबिडश्रियं हृतदृशं प्रोद्यद्रजोडम्बरैः । यः पद्मं विधृतप्रथं रथमिवाध्यास्ते सदा सूततां सूते कूबरिणि प्रभोः समतनोत्सोऽथ श्रुतीनां कविः ॥ ६१ ॥
column5: akṣairakṣatadhuryavṛttira(?ma)dhikāvāptograraśmigrahā-dāsīdannibiḍaśriyaṃ hṛtadṛśaṃ prodyadrajoḍambaraiḥ | yaḥ padmaṃ vidhṛtaprathaṃ rathamivādhyāste sadā sūtatāṃ sūte kūbariṇi prabhoḥ samatanotso'tha śrutīnāṃ kaviḥ || 61 ||
column6: यो ब्रह्मा सदा पद्मं रथमिवाश्रयति स श्रुतीनां कविः [ब्रह्मा] सुष्ठु उते सम्बद्धे तस्मिन्हररथे सारथिभावमकरोत् । अक्षैर्बीजैरखण्डिता धुर्या सर्वपद्मेभ्यो ज्यायसी वृत्तिर्यस्य । तथा अधिकमवाप्त उग्ररश्मौ सूर्ये ग्रहो येन तस्मात् । आसीदन्ती निबिडा श्रीर्ल​क्ष्मीर्यस्य । तथा प्रोद्यन्तो ये रजोडम्बरा रेणुप्रबन्धास्तैर्हता आवर्जिता दृग्येन । इति पद्मपक्षे । रथपक्षे तु - अक्षै रथाङ्गैरक्षता धुर्याणां वाहानां वृत्तिर्यत्र । श्रीः शोभा । रजो मकरन्दः ॥
column7: Brahma, the poet whose compositions are the Vedas and who is forever seated in a famed, chariot-like lotus – characterized by absolute supremacy (among lotuses) because of its (preeminent) seeds/axles that facilitate the pace of horses; specially favored by the sun and therefore approached by Lakshmi in all her glory/appearing majestic on account of being specially furnished with strong reins, and captivating the eyes with its flow of nectar/blinding the sight with vast clouds of dust – became the charioteer in the Lord’s well-harnessed chariot.
column8: This punning verse likens Shiva’s chariot to Brahma’s lotus abode so as to poetically establish that Brahma felt at home with his new office as Shiva’s charioteer. The word ‘sūte’ must be split as ‘su’+‘ūte’ (‘in the well-harnessed’) (JR). JR explains the word ‘rajaḥ’/‘parāga’ (‘pollen dust’) as ‘makaranda’ (‘floral nectar’) in some places (see also 6.12, 10.32); JR's explanation of 'rajaḥ’ as 'makaranda' in the context of the chariot ('rathapakṣe') seems out of place; furthermore, the commentary, as published in the Kāvyamālā edition, doesn't comment on the meaning of 'raśmi' as related to the chariot.

column4: कौतूहलं मनसि कस्य न स व्यधत्त यस्मिन्पुरो भगवतः पुरशासनस्य । गर्वं चतुर्वदनताधिगमेन धुर्य-पालीव सारथिरपि प्रथयाञ्चकार ॥ ६२ ॥
column5: kautūhalaṃ manasi kasya na sa vyadhatta yasminpuro bhagavataḥ puraśāsanasya | garvaṃ caturvadanatādhigamena dhurya- pālīva sārathirapi prathayāñcakāra || 62 ||
column6: स रथो मनसि कौतूहलं कस्य न व्यधत्त । सर्वेषामेवाश्चर्यमकरोदित्यर्थः । यस्मिन्हरस्य रथे धुर्यपाली चतुःसङ्ख्याकाश्वश्रेणीव सारथिर्ब्रह्मा चतुर्मुखतासम्बन्धि दर्पमवहत् ॥
column7: Even its charioteer, like its row of horses, beamed with pride before the Blessed Lord – Chastiser of the Puras – due to the attainment of four-facedness. Was there anyone in whose heart such a chariot as this did not evoke curiosity?
column8: Since the number of horses tied to the chariot is four, the row of horses is four-faced; Brahma, the charioteer, is four-faced too. The resemblance of the charioteer to the horses is the cause for surprise

column4: मित्रेणारिदशान्वभावि जगृहे बाणारिणा बाणता प्राप्याग्रेसरतामथाभिववृते दण्डक्रिया सामभिः । नासीरत्वपरिग्रहेऽभिनवता लेभे पुराणैरहो तस्मिन्विस्मयवेधसो भगवतः पत्रे पुराणां रिपोः ॥ ६३ ॥
column5: mitreṇāridaśānvabhāvi jagṛhe bāṇāriṇā bāṇatā prāpyāgresaratāmathābhivavṛte daṇḍakriyā sāmabhiḥ | nāsīratvaparigrahe'bhinavatā lebhe purāṇairaho tasminvismayavedhaso bhagavataḥ patre purāṇāṃ ripoḥ || 63 ||
column6: मित्रेणादित्येन सुहृदा च अरिदशा चक्रावस्था शत्रुत्वं च प्राप्ता । बाणस्य बलिसुतस्य शरस्य च अरिणा बाणता शरभावो गृहीता। अग्रवर्तित्वं प्राप्य सामभिः प्रथमोपायैर्वेदैश्च दण्डक्रिया चतुरङ्गबलकर्म तुर्योपायविधिश्च प्रारब्धा । पुराणैः पञ्चलक्षणैः जीर्णैश्च नासीरत्वस्याग्रेसरत्वस्य ग्रहणे सामग्री लब्धा । पुराणां रिपोः पत्रे रथे इति सर्ववाक्येषु योज्यम् । एवं सति विस्मयवेधस इत्युचितम्॥
column7: As regards the car of the Lord, who is the enemy of the Puras and a creator of miracles, the friend/sun attained the state of a foe/wheel, Bana’s foe (i.e., Vishnu) became Bana/an arrow, the expedient of appeasement/Sama Veda marched in the forefront and began discharging punishment/the duty of an army, and the old/Puranas gained vitality by occupying the vanguard position.
column8: The qualifier ‘creator of miracles’ (‘vismayavedhāḥ’) used for Shiva is significant since it provides an explanation for the contradictions in the rest of the verse (such as the friend turning into a foe, Bana’s foe transforming into Bana, and the expedient of appeasement discharging punishment) (JR). It is only a ‘creator of miracles’ who can synthesise mutually contradictory elements. From a poetic perspective, the contradictions are only apparent and can be otherwise resolved by taking recourse to the alternative meanings of words such as ‘ari’ (enemy/wheel), ‘bāṇa’ (the Asura Bana/arrow), ‘sāma’ (appeasement/Sāma Veda), and ‘daṇḍa’ (punishment/army).

column4: कोपात्पाटलिमा कपोलयुगले यः प्रादुरासीद्विभोः स व्यक्तिं न जगाम धामनि घने भालाग्निनेत्रार्चिषाम् । उष्णीषासितदन्दशूककुटिलस्फूर्जत्फणासञ्चयैः किं चान्यत्प्रकटोत्कटा भ्रुकुटयः सामान्यमानिन्यिरे ॥ ६४ ॥
column5: kopātpāṭalimā kapolayugale yaḥ prādurāsīdvibhoḥ sa vyaktiṃ na jagāma dhāmani ghane bhālāgninetrārciṣām | uṣṇīṣāsitadandaśūkakuṭilasphūrjatphaṇāsañcayaiḥ kiṃ cānyatprakaṭotkaṭā bhrukuṭayaḥ sāmānyamāninyire || 64 ||
column6: हरस्य गण्डयोः क्रोधवशाल्लोहितत्वं यदुत्पन्नं तल्ललाटाग्निमयनेत्रदीप्तीनां घने तेजसि सति व्यक्तिं नागतम् । किं चान्यत् - भ्रुकुटयो भ्रूभङ्गा उष्णीषभूताः शिरोवेष्टनभूता असिताः कृष्णा ये दन्दशूकाः सर्पास्तेषां सम्बन्धि कुटिलं कृत्वा स्फूर्जदुन्नमद्यत्फणामण्डलं तैः सामान्यं सादृश्यमानिन्युः । पूर्वत्र वर्णमात्रम् , उत्तरत्र वर्णसन्निवेशावव्यञ्जनकारणम् ॥
column7: The angry redness of the Lord’s cheeks was scarcely visible amidst the bright glow of the flames emanating from his fiery frontal eye. And his evidently scary eyebrows too were simulated by a multitude of swaying, outstretched hoods of the black cobras adorning his crown.
column8: In the first part of the verse, it is the shared colour (redness) that is responsible for the semblance; in the second part, it is colour and shape (JR).

column4: अग्रे निवर्त्य संवर्तकसलिलमुचः स्पन्दनं स्यन्दनस्य प्रस्थाने विश्वभर्तुर्विधुरपुरपरिप्लोषरोषग्रहेण । श्लिष्यत्सौवर्णकोणप्रतिभटतडितस्तत्क्षणाद्धन्यमानाः क्षुभ्यद्गम्भीरभेरीपरिकरकरणेरन्तरङ्गीबभूवुः ॥ ६५ ॥
column5: agre nivartya saṃvartakasalilamucaḥ spandanaṃ syandanasya prasthāne viśvabharturvidhurapurapariploṣaroṣagraheṇa | śliṣyatsauvarṇakoṇapratibhaṭataḍitastatkṣaṇāddhanyamānāḥ kṣubhyadgambhīrabherīparikarakaraṇerantaraṅgībabhūvuḥ || 65 ||
column6: संवर्तके प्रलये सलिलमुचो मेघास्तत्क्षणे प्रस्थानावसर आहन्यमाना अत एव क्षुभ्यन्त्यः शब्दायमाना गम्भीरा भेर्यः पटहास्तेषां परिकरः प्रबन्धस्तस्य करणिः सादृश्यं तस्यान्तरङ्गीबभूवुः । मेघाः पटहाः सम्भाविता इत्यर्थः । किं कृत्वा । विधुराणि सुजेयानि पुराणि दैत्यास्तेषां प्लोषार्थं दाहार्थं रोषग्रहस्तेन हेतुना हरस्य प्रस्थाने रथस्याग्रे स्पन्दनं चलनं कृत्वा । तथा श्लिष्यन्त्यः सौवर्णकोणप्रतिभटाः सुवर्णमयपटहवादनलगुडिकासमास्तडितो येषां ते । एतेन वक्ष्यमाणार्थोपक्षेप: कृत इति भद्रम् ॥
column7: As the Lord of the Universe, gripped by a wrathful desire to burn down the trifling Puras, set out on his military expedition, the apocalyptic Samvartaka clouds, drifting in front of the chariot, resembled an orchestra of deeply resonating drums that were beaten on the occasion, the lightning bolts adhering to them rivalling golden sticks.
column8: The clouds resemble military drums and the lightning streaks, the sticks for beating them.

column4: इति श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराज- राजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये रथबन्धनं नाम विंशः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirāja- rājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye rathabandhanaṃ nāma viṃśaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Twenteeth Canto, named 'Description of the Binding of the Chariot' in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja.

column4: एकविंशः सर्गः ॥
column7: Twenty-first Canto

column4: अथाभ्यमित्रीणमवेक्ष्य शर्वरीकुटुम्बलेखाभरणं गणावली । इतस्ततः सन्नहनोद्यमक्रमादनर्गलव्यापृततामगाहत ॥ १ ॥
column5: athābhyamitrīṇamavekṣya śarvarīkuṭumbalekhābharaṇaṃ gaṇāvalī | itastataḥ sannahanodyamakramādanargalavyāpṛtatāmagāhata || 1 ||
column6: अथ हरममित्राञ्शत्रून्गच्छन्तं दृष्ट्वा सन्नहने सन्नद्धत्वे उद्यम उत्साहस्तत्क्रमाद्गणपङ्क्तिरितस्ततोऽनर्गलं निर्विलम्बं व्यापृततां व्यापारमभजत् ॥
column7: Thereafter, seeing the moon-crested Lord set out against his enemies, the army of the Ganas bustled with activity in every nook and corner as it went about preparing for the battle.
column8: N/A

column4: न कौतुकं तद्विदलय्य वैरिणो भवस्य वीरैर्यदवापि मङ्गलम् । वरूथिनी तस्य हि सा जगत्पतेः सवीरभद्रादित एव पप्रथे ॥ २ ॥
column5: na kautukaṃ tadvidalayya vairiṇo bhavasya vīrairyadavāpi maṅgalam | varūthinī tasya hi sā jagatpateḥ savīrabhadrādita eva paprathe || 2 ||
column6: भवस्य वीरैर्भटैः शत्रूञ्जित्वा मङ्ग​लं प्राप्तं यत्तन्नाश्चर्यम् । हिर्यस्मादर्थे । प्रभोः सा सेना आदितो वैरिदलनात्पूर्वमेव वीरभद्राख्यगणसहिता वीराणां भद्रं मङ्गलं तद्युक्ता [च] प्रथिता । यः पूर्वमेव वीरभद्रसहितस्तस्य शत्रुजयेन वीरभद्रप्राप्तिः किमुच्यत इत्यर्थः ॥
column7: It is not surprising that Shiva’s warriors attained glory by routing out the enemies since the army of the Universal Master was accompanied by Virabhadra/sported the warrior’s glory from the very start.
column8: Virabhadra is one among the attendants of Shiva (See footnote under 18.49). The verse plays on the pun in the word ‘vīrabhadra’, which also means ‘warrior’s glory’.

column4: परानपेक्षो विजयः पिनाकिनस्तथापि संवर्मयति स्म तच्चमूः । तमोंऽशुमात्रेण विनिघ्नतो रवेः पुरोऽर्ककान्तैरपि किं न दीप्यते ॥ ३ ॥
column5: parānapekṣo vijayaḥ pinākinastathāpi saṃvarmayati sma taccamūḥ | tamoṃ'śumātreṇa vinighnato raveḥ puro'rkakāntairapi kiṃ na dīpyate || 3 ||
column6: हरस्य विजयो यद्यप्यन्यं नैवापेक्षते । सर्वेभ्योऽधिकबलत्वात् । तथापि हरसेना वर्मणा सन्नह्य​ति स्म । 'सत्यापपाशरूप-' इत्यादिना णिच् । रश्मिमात्रेणान्धकारं वारयतः सूर्यस्याग्रे सूर्यकान्तैरपि किं न दीप्यते । अपि तु दीप्यत इत्यर्थः । पिनाकिन इति विजयानुगुणमभिधानम् ॥
column7: Even though the Pinaka-holder’s victory is not dependent on others, his army still got ready for the battle by putting on armours. Don’t tsunstones too glow before the sun as he sets about suppressing darkness with a mere ray?
column8: The description of Shiva as ‘Pināka-holder’ is appropriate to the context of his victory expedition. The verb‘saṃvarmayati’ is formed by adding the affix ‘ṇic’ after ‘varma’ according to the rule ‘satyāpapāśa - - - varma - - - ādibhyo ṇic’.

column4: असेर्म​यूखैरथ लोहवर्मणा गणो महाकाल इतीन्दुलक्ष्मणः । विशङ्कटभ्रूकुटिकान्तिभिश्च स त्विषं स्वनाम्नोऽप्यधिकाधिकां दधौ ॥ ४ ॥
column5: asermayūkhairatha lohavarmaṇā gaṇo mahākāla itīndulakṣmaṇaḥ | viśaṅkaṭabhrūkuṭikāntibhiśca sa tviṣaṃ svanāmno'pyadhikādhikāṃ dadhau || 4 ||
column6: खड्गरश्मिभिस्तथा आयसेन कवचेन तथा विशङ्कटा वक्रा या भ्रुकुटयस्तासामंशुभिश्च महाकाल इत्यन्वर्थान्नाम्नोऽप्यधिकां दीप्तिं महाकालो नाम हरस्य गणोऽवहत् ॥
column7: One of the Ganas of Shiva called Mahakala (literally ‘very dark’) wore a complexion that went far beyond his name, thanks to the lustre of his sword, his iron armour, and the radiant glow of his angrily contorted eyebrows.
column8: The Gaṇas Mahakala and Bhrngi were born from Shiva’s seed. Shiva appointed both as his doorkeepers. Mahakala is known for his pitch-black complexion (‘tataḥ - - - svaṃ reto - - - | utsasarja - - - || - - - sambhūtau śaṅkarātmajau | - - - nāma bhṛṅgīti cākarot || mahākṛṣṇaikarūpasya mahākāleti - - - || - - - kramādgaṇeśau kṛtvā tau haro dvāri nyayojayat || (Kālikā Purāṇa, 46.61-66)

column4: प्रायेण भेरीरणितैर्घनस्वनैः स्फुटोर्मिभिर्नृत्यति वाहबर्हिणि । उपोढदार्ढ्यः शरभूरवोचत स्वमासनस्थैर्यविशेषकौशलम् ॥ ५ ॥
column5: prāyeṇa bherīraṇitairghanasvanaiḥ sphuṭormibhirnṛtyati vāhabarhiṇi | upoḍhadārḍhyaḥ śarabhūravocata svamāsanasthairyaviśeṣakauśalam || 5 ||
column6: स्तनितसमैः प्रस्थानानकशब्दैर्वाहमयूरे नृत्यं कुर्वति सति धृतदार्ढ्योऽविचल: शरभूः कुमारो निजमासने स्थैर्यविशेषस्तत्र कौशलमदर्शयत् ॥
column7: Kumara exhibited an extraordinary skill in maintaining his posture by stabilizing himself when his peacock-mount danced to the war drum’s rippling roar that resembled the rumbling of clouds.
column8: Avocata’ (‘spoke’) is used here in sense of ‘adarśayat’ (‘exhibited’) (JR).

column4: कृतप्रयाणोऽग्र​त एव गच्छतामभूदनर्थाय मतङ्गजाननः । प्रचस्खलुस्ते हि पदे पदे गलत्तदीयदानहृदपङ्किले पथि ॥ ६ ॥
column5: kṛtaprayāṇo'grata eva gacchatāmabhūdanarthāya mataṅgajānanaḥ | pracaskhaluste hi pade pade galattadīyadānahṛdapaṅkile pathi || 6 ||
column6: युद्धार्थं गच्छतामग्रे निर्भयत्वात्कृतप्रस्थानः करिमुखो गणपतिरनर्थायाभूत् । हिर्यस्मादर्थे । तदीयो गजमुखसम्बन्धी यो दानहृदो मदप्रवाहस्तेन पङ्कवति मार्गे गच्छन्तः स्खलितवन्तः ॥
column7: Marching right in the front, the elephant-faced Ganesha upset those walking behind him since they skid and fell at every step along the way that was made slushy by the trickling stream of his ichor.
column8: N/A

column4: तमस्यदीने पृतनारजोपमे प्रभोः स गच्छन्सुरसिन्धुनन्दनः । स कु(सकु)म्भसिन्दूररदाङ्कुरच्छलादभूदिवाग्रे धृतहस्तदीपकः ॥ ७ ॥
column5: tamasyadīne pṛtanārajopame prabhoḥ sa gacchansurasindhunandanaḥ | sa ku(saku)mbhasindūraradāṅkuracchalādabhūdivāgre dhṛtahastadīpakaḥ || 7 ||
column6: प्रभोरग्रे गच्छन्स गाङ्गेयः कटसिन्दूरपूरितदशनाग्र​व्याजाद्धृतो हस्तदीपको मार्गसन्दर्शनार्थं गृह्यमाणो दीपो येन स इवासीत् । तमस्यदीने घने सति सेनारजोपमे ॥
column7: As he strode ahead of the Lord in the dense, dusty darkness of the army, Ganesha – the Celestial River’s son – seemed to be carrying a hand-held lamp masquerading as his sharp tusk, which was covered with the red vermillion adorning his temples.
column8: The tusk, tinged with vermillion, is likened to a blazing lamp; one carries a hand-held lamp while walking in darkness; ‘hasta’ stands here for both ‘trunk’ and ‘hand’. The story of how Ganesha came to be known as 'Gāṅgeya' ('son of Ganga') is told in the Matsya Purāṇa (‘putretyuvāca taṃ devī putretyūce ca jāhnavī || gāṅgeya iti devaistu pūjito'bhūdgajānanaḥ |’ 154.504, 505). ‘Pṛtanārajopame’ is not a happy expression from the view of grammar and meaning; 'pṛtanārajomaye' or 'pṛtanārajobhare' seems to be a better alternative.

column4: वहन्विलोलश्रुतितालवृन्ततां समक्षमुक्षन्वमथूदबिन्दुभिः । बभूव भूम्ना धुसरित्सुतो यतां पथि प्रयाणश्रमवैशसच्छिदे ॥ ८ ॥
column5: vahanvilolaśrutitālavṛntatāṃ samakṣamukṣanvamathūdabindubhiḥ | babhūva bhūmnā dhusaritsuto yatāṃ pathi prayāṇaśramavaiśasacchide || 8 ||
column6: श्रुती कर्णौ ते एव विस्तारदैर्घ्याभ्यां तालवृन्ते वीजिते विधूतकम्पिते येन तद्भावं बिभ्रत् । तथा वमथुः करसीकरस्तज्जलकणैः समक्षं सम्यगुक्षन्सिञ्च​न् । गाङ्गेयो यतां गच्छतां भूम्नातिशयेन प्रस्थानखेदच्छेदायाभूत् । जलसेकव्यजनयोस्तापप्रतिपक्षत्वात् ॥
column7: Flapping his ears in the manner of palmyra fans and spraying the surroundings with water droplets emitted from his trunk, Ganesha greatly allayed the journeying troop’s extreme exhaustion all along the way.
column8: N/A

column4: विलोलकर्णाञ्चलमारुतोद्धतस्वकुम्भसिन्दूररजोविकूणिते । स वीक्षितुं वर्त्म तदान्तरान्तरा कथञ्चिदुन्मीलयति स्म लोचने ॥ ९ ॥
column5: vilolakarṇāñcalamārutoddhatasvakumbhasindūrarajovikūṇite | sa vīkṣituṃ vartma tadāntarāntarā kathañcidunmīlayati sma locane || 9 ||
column6: स्वभावाद्विलोलश्चपलो यः कर्णाञ्चलस्तेन मारुतस्तेनोद्धूतं यत्स्वकुम्भसिन्दूररजस्तेन सञ्कुचिते नेत्रे गजमुखो मार्गे मध्ये मध्ये उदमीलयत् । निम्नसम्भावनया पतनभयादित्यर्थः॥
column7: Shaken up by gusts of wind springing from the flapping of his ears, the powdered vermilion smeared over Ganesha’s temples made him shut his eyes; he only opened them grudgingly once in a while to catch a glimpse of the road ahead.
column8: N/A

column4: करे गणानां करवालवल्लरीततिः परेषामदिशद्विषव्यथाम् । उपेयुषी जङ्गमतां तरङ्गिता हरस्य कण्ठादिव रश्मिसंहतिः ॥ १० ॥
column5: kare gaṇānāṃ karavālavallarītatiḥ pareṣāmadiśadviṣavyathām | upeyuṣī jaṅgamatāṃ taraṅgitā harasya kaṇṭhādiva raśmisaṃhatiḥ || 10 ||
column6: गणानां हस्ते खड्गलतापङ्क्तिः शत्रूणां विषवद्व्यथामदात् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - जङ्गमत्वात्स्थावरत्वं प्राप्तवती हरकण्ठनिर्गता रश्मिमालेव । अथवा हरस्य कण्ठान्निर्गतांशुपङ्क्तिर्विषव्यथामिव शत्रूणामदात् । येन विषं जीर्णं तस्य वयं किं कुर्म इत्यर्थः । जङ्गमतां प्राप्ता गणानां हस्ते खड्गपङ्क्तिरित्यारोपः॥
column7: The multitude of slender swords which the Ganas held in their hands wrought poisonous affliction on the enemies as if it were a moving mass of radiant rays rippling forth from Shiva’s throat.
column8: The swords of the Ganas resemble the Kālakūṭa poison in their colour and deadliness alike; they are therefore compared to the rays rippling forth from Shiva’s throat that is the abode of that poison.

column4: अनीककोलाहलकेलिविस्तरप्रतिश्रुता काहलतां जगाहिरे। अपास्तमौनाः पुरतः पुरद्विषो दिशः प्रयाणोत्सवमङ्गलैरिव ॥ ११ ॥
column5: anīkakolāhalakelivistarapratiśrutā kāhalatāṃ jagāhire| apāstamaunāḥ purataḥ puradviṣo diśaḥ prayāṇotsavamaṅgalairiva || 11 ||
column6: सैन्यकलकलक्रीडाप्रबन्धप्रतिशब्देन हेतुना दिश: काहलतां शब्दायमानत्वमापुः । अतः सम्भाव्यते - हरस्य प्रस्थानोत्सवगीतैर्हेतुभिस्त्यक्तमौना इव । दानवभयात्स्त्रीत्व​व्यवहारावच्छेदात्पूर्वं तासां मौनमासीत् । राजप्रस्थाने च वारनारीगीतस्योचितत्वात् ॥
column7: The Directions reverberated with the echo of the army’s cheerful outcry as if, abandoning their silence, they were singing auspicious songs before Pura’s Foe on the festive occasion of his military march.
column8: Courtesans sing songs when a king sets out on his military march; the directions had hitherto maintained silence due to their fear of the Tripuras and in keeping with their feminine nature ( the word ‘dik’, meaning ‘direction', is in the feminine gender) (JR).

column4: प्रयाणलीलावसरे पिनाकिनो विवृण्वती वेगनिरङ्कुशां दशाम् । पुरश्च मौलौ च सुपर्ववाहिनी विनिद्रकोलाहलतामगाहत ॥ १२ ॥
column5: prayāṇalīlāvasare pinākino vivṛṇvatī veganiraṅkuśāṃ daśām | puraśca maulau ca suparvavāhinī vinidrakolāhalatāmagāhata || 12 ||
column6: पिनाकिनः प्रस्थानावसरे सवेगामवस्थां प्रकाशयन्ती सुपर्ववाहिनी देवसेना गङ्गा च पुरो मुकुटे चासङ्कुचितकलकलतामभजत् ॥
column7: Unhindered in its speed, the celestial army/river made a lot of noise, both in front of Shiva and on his head, at the time of his glorious march.
column8: N/A

column4: विलासपङ्केरुहसौरभापतद्विशालभृङ्गावलिभिर्विरेजिरे । क्व सैन्यसारङ्गदृशोऽपि नोच्छ्वसत्कृपाणरेखैरिव पाणिपल्लवैः ॥ १३ ॥
column5: vilāsapaṅkeruhasaurabhāpatadviśālabhṛṅgāvalibhirvirejire | kva sainyasāraṅgadṛśo'pi nocchvasatkṛpāṇarekhairiva pāṇipallavaiḥ || 13 ||
column6: लीलापद्मे सौगन्ध्येनागच्छन्तीभिर्विस्तीर्णाभिर्भ्रमरपङ्क्तिभिर्हेतुभूताभिः सखड्गैरिव हस्तैः सैन्यस्त्रियोऽपि क्व नादीप्यन्त ॥
column7: Thanks to the long-drawn rows of bees rushing towards them due to the fragrance of their sportive lotuses, even the deer-eyed women accompanying the army appeared to be holding outstretched swords in their soft, sprout-like hands.
column8: N/A

column4: पदं चुचुम्ब प्रतिबिम्बिता विभोर्वरूथिनी सा स्फटिकाद्रिसानुषु । श्रयन्त्यरातिक्षतितारतम्यतः प्रभावतोऽनेकशरीरतामिव ॥ १४ ॥
column5: padaṃ cucumba pratibimbitā vibhorvarūthinī sā sphaṭikādrisānuṣu | śrayantyarātikṣatitāratamyataḥ prabhāvato'nekaśarīratāmiva || 14 ||
column6: स्फटिकाद्रिशिखरेषु प्रतिबिम्बिता सा प्रभोः सेना पदं चुचुम्ब सादरं पस्पर्श । अतः सम्भाव्यते - अरातीनां शत्रूणां क्षतिर्हननं तत्र तारतम्यमतिवाञ्छा ततो हेतोः प्रभाववशाद्बहुमूर्तितामिव सेवमाना ॥
column7: The Lord’s army gained a foothold on the peaks of the Crystal Mountain by being reflected on them, thus assuming, as it were, a plurality of bodies in its strong desire for exterminating the enemies.
column8: N/A

column4: निनाय माद्यन्सुरसिन्धुनन्दनो बत स्वसेनामपि दौस्थ्यपद्धतिम् । तदीयमाघ्राय हि दानसौरभं गजो विदद्रौ क न कस्य योधिनः॥ १५ ॥
column5: nināya mādyansurasindhunandano bata svasenāmapi dausthyapaddhatim | tadīyamāghrāya hi dānasaurabhaṃ gajo vidadrau ka na kasya yodhinaḥ|| 15 ||
column6: माद्यन्मदमयो गजमुखः स्वसेनामपि दुरवस्थत्वमनैषीत् । हिर्यस्मादर्थे । कस्य न योधिनः सर्वेषामेव योधानां गजो हस्ती गजेन्द्रमदसौगन्ध्यं घ्रात्वा क्व न विदद्रौ । सर्वत्रैव पलायितः । गजजातेर्गजान्तरगन्धोद्विग्नत्वात् ॥
column7: Ganesha, who was intoxicated in rut, put his very own army into disarray because every warrior’s elephant went berserk all over the place after smelling the odour of his ichor.
column8: Elephants cannot tolerate the smell of each other's ichor (JR).

column4: रवेण भेर्या घननादबन्धुना शिखी विशाखस्य नटत्वमादधे । अवाप्य शिक्षामिव तत्क्षणं यतो द्विषत्कबन्धा अपि नृत्तमादधुः ॥ १६ ॥
column5: raveṇa bheryā ghananādabandhunā śikhī viśākhasya naṭatvamādadhe | avāpya śikṣāmiva tatkṣaṇaṃ yato dviṣatkabandhā api nṛttamādadhuḥ || 16 ||
column6: स्तनितसदृशेन पटहशब्देन विशाखस्य कुमारस्य शिखी मयूरो नटत्वमादधेऽनृत्यत् । यतः शिखिनः शिक्षामिव प्राप्य द्विषतां कबन्धा अपि नृत्तमादधुर्ननृतुः ॥
column7: Listening to the roar of the war drums, which resembled the thunder of clouds, Kumara’s peacock began to dance. Instructed, as it were, by it, the headless trunks of the enemies took to dancing too.
column8: N/A

column4: धृता रथाङ्गैः स्फटिकारुणोपलप्रभाविभागातिथिभिर्नगाध्वसु । रथाः परेषामपि तत्र भेजिरे विनिद्रचन्द्रार्कमयारितामिव ॥ १७ ॥
column5: dhṛtā rathāṅgaiḥ sphaṭikāruṇopalaprabhāvibhāgātithibhirnagādhvasu | rathāḥ pareṣāmapi tatra bhejire vinidracandrārkamayāritāmiva || 17 ||
column6: हरादन्येषामपि रथा विनिद्रावुदितौ  यौ चन्द्रार्कौ तन्मयमरि चक्रं यस्य तद्भावमिव दधुः । यतो रथाङ्गैश्चक्रैरूढाः । स्फटिकानि चारुणोपलाः पद्मरागास्तेषां प्रभास्तासां विभागस्यातिथिभिः परिचितैः । स्फटिकचक्रत्वाच्चन्द्रत्वं पद्मरागचक्रत्वादर्कत्वमिति प्रभाणां विभागः॥
column7: Supported on mountainous terrains by wheels that each sparkled with the sheen of inlaid crystals and rubies, the chariots of others too seemed to possess the moon and the sun for their wheels.
column8: The wheels inlaid with crystals and rubies resemble the moon and the sun respectively. ‘Others’ = ‘those other than Shiva’ (JR).

column4: अहो महो दैत्यजनाभिषेणने तदीश्वरस्यानुपमश्रि पप्रथे । रथाङ्गमूर्ती दिनकृन्निशाकरौ विसृत्वरे यत्प्रसरे ममज्जतुः ॥ १८ ॥
column5: aho maho daityajanābhiṣeṇane tadīśvarasyānupamaśri paprathe | rathāṅgamūrtī dinakṛnniśākarau visṛtvare yatprasare mamajjatuḥ || 18 ||
column6: त्रिपुरयात्रायां हरस्य तेजोऽनुपमा साम्यरहिता श्रीर्यस्य तत्पप्रथे । विसरणशीले यत्प्रसरे तेज:स्फारे चन्द्रार्कौ मग्नौ ॥
column7: Matchless was the magnificent glow of Shiva as he marched against the Asura tribe; a glow, in whose spreading expanse, the sun and the moon, disguised as chariot wheels, vanished without a trace!
column8: N/A

column4: उपर्यहीन्द्रो गिरिशस्य भूषणं बभौ रथात्मा तदधो वसुन्धरा । अथास्त तत्पाददशेन्दुसूर्ययोरहो तदा विश्वविपर्ययोऽभवत् ॥ १९ ॥
column5: uparyahīndro giriśasya bhūṣaṇaṃ babhau rathātmā tadadho vasundharā | athāsta tatpādadaśendusūryayoraho tadā viśvaviparyayo'bhavat || 19 ||
column6: अहो तदा विश्वस्य विपर्यासोऽभूत् । यत उपरिष्टाच्छेष आसीत् । यतो हरस्यालङ्कारः। तस्य शेषस्याधो रथरूपा भूमिः । चन्द्रार्कयोस्तत्पाददशा रथचरणत्वम् । सदा शेषोऽधः, तदृर्ध्वे भूः, तदुपरि चन्द्रार्कौ । तदा न तथेति विश्वविपर्ययः ॥
column7: The universe turned topsy-turvy at that time! For, the Serpent Lord, who is Shiva’s ornament, occupied the very top; the earth, which assumed the form of a chariot, shone beneath him; and the sun and the moon were reduced to the state of the chariot’s wheels.
column8: Shesha, the lord of serpents, lies bottommost; above him, supported on his hoods, is the earth; and higher up are the moon and the sun. In this case, however, the order was reversed (JR).

column4: हठाद्विनिर्यन्नथ कोऽपि मत्सरात्कराद्विकृष्यैणदृशोंऽशुकाञ्चलम् । जवेन गत्वापि मनाग्बतावशो बभूव वीप्सावलितार्धकन्धरः ॥ २० ॥
column5: haṭhādviniryannatha ko'pi matsarātkarādvikṛṣyaiṇadṛśo'ṃ'śukāñcalam | javena gatvāpi manāgbatāvaśo babhūva vīpsāvalitārdhakandharaḥ || 20 ||
column6: सङ्ग्रामगमनमनिच्छन्त्या योषितो हस्तात्स्ववस्त्रान्तं नीत्वा हठान्निर्गच्छन्कश्चित्ततो वेगेन किञ्चिद्गत्वा वीप्सया पौनःपुन्येन वलिता तिर्यक्कृतार्धकन्धरा येन सोऽभूत् । यतोऽवशो गन्तुमशक्तः । स्नेहस्मरणेन स्वातन्त्र्यनिरोधात् ॥
column7: How very sad! Freeing the hem of his robe from the hand of his deer-eyed beloved hesitantly, a certain warrior, who left in a hurry, could barely stop himself from turning back a little every now and then just after taking a few quick steps.
column8: The lover’s freedom was restricted by memories of love (JR).

column4: हठोत्कया कश्चन कान्तया रहः कृतावगूहः प्रतिमुक्तिसिद्धये । निमज्ज्य तत्स्पर्शरसामृतह्रदे बतोत्तरीतुं सहसैव नाशकत् ॥ २१ ॥
column5: haṭhotkayā kaścana kāntayā rahaḥ kṛtāvagūhaḥ pratimuktisiddhaye | nimajjya tatsparśarasāmṛtahrade batottarītuṃ sahasaiva nāśakat || 21 ||
column6: हठेनात्यर्थमुत्कोत्कण्ठा तया हेतुभूतया प्रतिमोचनार्थं स्त्रिया कृतालिङ्गनः कश्चित्तस्याः स्पर्शरस एवामृतह्रदस्तत्र निमज्ज्य सहसोत्तरीतुं नाशकत् । सहसैवेति वचनं क्षणान्तरे उत्तरणप्रतिपादनार्थम् ॥
column7: Having received a secret embrace from his unrelentingly anxious sweetheart as she bid him farewell, another warrior, who plunged into the ambrosial lake of her affectionate touch, could not emerge out of it readily.
column8: The word ‘sahasā’ (‘readily’) implies that the warrior described here did not get struck in the passionate experience but came back to his senses the very next moment (JR).

column4: चचाल कश्चित्परितोषविह्वलैः पदैः प्रवीरो धृतधैर्यविप्रुषः । स्ववल्लभाया निबिडावगूहनामवाप्य पाथेयमिवाधरामृतम् ॥ २२ ॥
column5: cacāla kaścitparitoṣavihvalaiḥ padaiḥ pravīro dhṛtadhairyavipruṣaḥ | svavallabhāyā nibiḍāvagūhanāmavāpya pātheyamivādharāmṛtam || 22 ||
column6: धृता धैर्यस्य विप्रुट् अंशो यया तस्याः स्ववल्लभाया निबिडं कृत्वालिङ्गनात्पाथेयं श्रमहरमिवौष्ठामृतं प्राप्य आनन्दसम्भ्रान्तैः पदैः कश्चिद्रणाय चलितः ॥
column7: A third warrior walked with steps that faltered in joy after he received from his somewhat strong-hearted beloved the provisions for his journey - the ambrosia of her lips - by hugging her tightly.
column8: N/A

column4: विजित्वरः सत्वरमेषि चेच्छिवं न चेत्पुनर्नो त्रिदिवेऽस्तु संस्तवः । इतीरयित्वा तरलायितेक्षणा कथञ्चिदाप्रष्टुमियेष वल्लभम् ॥ २३ ॥
column5: vijitvaraḥ satvarameṣi cecchivaṃ na cetpunarno tridive'stu saṃstavaḥ | itīrayitvā taralāyitekṣaṇā kathañcidāpraṣṭumiyeṣa vallabham || 23 ||
column6: प्राप्तविजयस्त्वं यद्येषि तदा मङ्गलम् । न चेत्सङ्ग्रामादेषि तदावयोः स्वर्गे सङ्गमः । अनेन मरणव्यवसायः सूचितः । इत्युक्त्वा काचित्कथञ्चित्प्रियं प्रतिमोक्तुमैच्छत् ॥
column7: "Everything will be fine if you quickly return back victorious. Otherwise, we shall meet again in heaven” – so saying, a maiden with roving eyes tried to somehow bid her lover farewell.
column8: The maiden’s words indicate a resolve to die if the lover didn't come back (JR).The adjective ‘taralāyitekṣaṇā’ (‘with roving eyes’) hints at the anxiety and helplessnes of the lady described here.

column4: प्रपद्य नाकं करवालवर्मना सुपर्वनारीः परिरब्धुमिच्छसि । न तत्सहे तेऽहमिति प्रियोऽन्यया न्यरुध्यतेर्ष्याकलुषाक्षरैः पदैः ॥ २४ ॥
column5: prapadya nākaṃ karavālavarmanā suparvanārīḥ parirabdhumicchasi | na tatsahe te'hamiti priyo'nyayā nyarudhyaterṣyākaluṣākṣaraiḥ padaiḥ || 24 ||
column6: खड्गमार्गेण स्वर्गं प्राप्य देवस्त्रीरालिङ्गितुमिच्छसि । तद्देवयोषिदालिङ्गनं न सहे । इतीर्ष्यया मत्सरेण कलुषाणि रूक्षाण्यक्षराणि येषां तैः पदैः करणभूतैरन्यया कथञ्चिन्निरुद्धः ॥
column7: "You (evidently) long to embrace the divine damsels after reaching heaven by taking the (hero’s) path of the sword. But I don’t approve of it” – another lady stopped her lover in this manner with words that were marred by harsh-sounding, jealousy-ridden letters.
column8: Heroes who die fighting in battle are believed to reach heaven (cf. ‘hato vā prāpsyasi svargam’, Bhagavadgītā, 2.37). Since the lady described here is the wife of a Gana warrior (and not of a Deva), there is no contradiction in her words, i.e., in claiming that her husband wants to visit heaven.

column4: रुरोध काचिद्दयितं ततोऽश्रभिः पिधीयमानाकुललोचनाभवत् । उपांशु निर्गत्य य​यौ स संयुगे तदन्तरे वीररसैककिङ्करः ॥ २५ ॥
column5: rurodha kāciddayitaṃ tato'śrabhiḥ pidhīyamānākulalocanābhavat | upāṃśu nirgatya yayau sa saṃyuge tadantare vīrarasaikakiṅkaraḥ || 25 ||
column6: काचित्प्रियमरुणत् । ततो बाष्पैराच्छाद्यमानव्याकुलनेत्रा साभूत् । तदन्तरे तच्छिद्रकाले उपांशु शनैर्निर्गत्य सङ्ग्रामाय गतः । यतो वीररसस्यैककिङ्करः । अस्यामश्रुच्छादितनेत्रायां गन्तुं मम समय इति विचार्य गतः ॥
column7: Yet another woman stood in the way of her lover. The next moment, her agitated eyes were blinded by tears. And in that brief interval, the lover, subservient solely to his warrior spirit, stealthily left for the battle.
column8: N/A

column4: हठात्प्रयान्तं प्रियमङ्गनेतरा विमुञ्चती दैन्यसखे विलोचने । सितासितापाङ्गतरङ्गितांशुभिर्जुगोप रक्तेव नवेन वर्मणा ॥ २६ ॥
column5: haṭhātprayāntaṃ priyamaṅganetarā vimuñcatī dainyasakhe vilocane | sitāsitāpāṅgataraṅgitāṃśubhirjugopa rakteva navena varmaṇā || 26 ||
column6: प्रियगमनेन सदैन्ये नेत्रे भर्तरि स्नेहवशात्किरन्ती काचिद्धठाद्गच्छन्तं वल्लभं नवेन कवचेनेव जुगोप ररक्ष । सितासिता अपाङ्गतरङ्गिता येंऽशवस्तैः । यतो रक्ता सानुरागा। कटाक्षकान्तिव्याजादायसं कवचमिव पर्यधापयदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Letting a pair of sorrowful eyes fall on the lover, who was taking leave of her in a hurry, a certain lady seemed to drape him affectionately in a brand new armour with the rippling rays of her black and white side-glances.
column8: The armour described here is made of iron (‘āyasaṃ kavacam’, JR), probably with white stripes adorning it.

column4: अशक्नुवन्त्यस्तरसेतराः प्रियान्विमोक्तुमिन्दीवरदीर्घदृष्टयः । प्रतुष्टुवुः साध्वसगद्गदैः पदैः कथाश्चिरायानुपयोगिनीरपि ॥ २७ ॥
column5: aśaknuvantyastarasetarāḥ priyānvimoktumindīvaradīrghadṛṣṭayaḥ | pratuṣṭuvuḥ sādhvasagadgadaiḥ padaiḥ kathāścirāyānupayoginīrapi || 27 ||
column6: वल्लभान्सहसा प्रतिमोक्तुमसमर्था अन्या भयवशेन श्लिष्टैः पदैः सङ्ग्रामप्रस्तावानुचिताः कथाः प्रारेभिरे । विलम्बनार्थमिति भावः ॥
column7: Unable to let go of their lovers readily, other women, with long eyes that resembled blue lotuses, carried on pointless conversations for a long time in words shaken by fear.
column8: The women carried on pointless conversations in order to delay their lovers (JR).

column4: परः प्रियायाः प्रतिमुक्तिलालनाकृते स्थितोऽग्रे मुहुरार्तचेतसः । सरूपमुत्खातकृपाणरश्मिभिर्द(र्दृ)शोरुवापेव वियोगजं तमः ॥ २८ ॥
column5: paraḥ priyāyāḥ pratimuktilālanākṛte sthito'gre muhurārtacetasaḥ | sarūpamutkhātakṛpāṇaraśmibhirda(rdṛ)śoruvāpeva viyogajaṃ tamaḥ || 28 ||
column6: विरहभयाद्दीनचित्ताया वल्लभाया प्रतिमोचने लालनायाः करणार्थं पुरः स्थितः कश्चिदुत्खातस्य कोषान्निष्कृष्टस्य रश्मिभिर्हेतुभिः सरूपं रूपसहितं विरहजमन्धकारमिवोप्तवान् । अत्र खड्गप्रभास्तमस्त्वेन सम्भाविताः॥
column7: A certain man, standing before his distressed beloved to bid her an affectionate farewell, seemed to continuously sow, through the gleam of his drawn-out sword, the similarly hued darkness of sorrowful separation in her eyes.
column8: Swords are generally described as black in Sanskrit literature

column4: विलिप्यमानाननमोजसः कणैर्जयश्रियः संवननौषधैरिव । स्थिरानुरागव्र​ततत्पराः पराः स्वयं प्रियं वामदृशोऽनुवव्रजुः ॥ २९ ॥
column5: vilipyamānānanamojasaḥ kaṇairjayaśriyaḥ saṃvananauṣadhairiva | sthirānurāgavratatatparāḥ parāḥ svayaṃ priyaṃ vāmadṛśo'nuvavrajuḥ || 29 ||
column6: जयलक्ष्म्या वशीकरणौषधैरिवौजसः कणैर्विलिप्यमानमुखं प्रियं दृढानुरागव्रते तत्पराः सक्ताः काश्चिस्त्रियः स्व​यं वल्लभमनुजग्मुः ॥
column7: Established firmly in the practice of love’s vow,  some pretty-eyed maidens voluntarily followed their lovers, whose faces were besmeared with specks of brilliance as if with magical ointments for charming Lady Victory.
column8: N/A

column4: सितातपत्रैः शबलं विदिद्युते विकोषसैन्यासिविसृत्वरं महः । रथीभवन्त्यां भुवि शेषमूर्धभिः सहैव पातालतमः समुद्गतम् ॥ ३० ॥
column5: sitātapatraiḥ śabalaṃ vididyute vikoṣasainyāsivisṛtvaraṃ mahaḥ | rathībhavantyāṃ bhuvi śeṣamūrdhabhiḥ sahaiva pātālatamaḥ samudgatam || 30 ||
column6: आकृष्टेभ्यः खड्गेभ्यो निर्गच्छंस्तथा श्वेतातपत्रैश्चित्रं तेजो दिद्युते । सम्भाव्यते - भुवि रथरूपायां सत्यां शेषफणाभिः सहोत्थितं पातालान्धकारमिव ॥
column7: Interspersed with white parasols, the spreading glow of the army’s unsheathed swords appeared like the nether world’s dense darkness tossed up along with Shesha’s hoods when the earth was transforming into a chariot.
column8: Shesha, the lord of serpents, resides in the nether world of Pātāla, and is an epitome of whiteness.The circle of white parasols correspond to Shesha’s hoods and the glow of swords, to the darkness of Pātāla.

column4: अनीकिनीवीरुषि गुच्छविभ्रमो भवस्य बभ्रे धवलोष्णवारणैः । अनेकनिस्त्रिंशगभस्तिसंस्तवादकाण्डविस्तारितषट्पदैरिव ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: anīkinīvīruṣi gucchavibhramo bhavasya babhre dhavaloṣṇavāraṇaiḥ | anekanistriṃśagabhastisaṃstavādakāṇḍavistāritaṣaṭpadairiva || 31 ||
column6: भवस्य सम्बन्धिनी अनीकिनी सेना सैव वीरुल्लता तस्यां सितच्छत्रैः स्तबकभावः प्राप्तः । बहुखड्गप्रभासङ्गाद्धृतभ्रमरैरिव । गुच्छेषु हि भ्रमरैर्भाव्यम् ।
column7: In the creeping vine of Shiva’s battalion, the white parasols put on the semblance of flower clusters teeming with bees, or so it seemed, thanks to the sheen of the army’s numerous swords alighting on them.
column8: N/A

column4: प्रभोः पुरो दिव्यवचोऽधिदैवतव्रतप्रथामात्तवतः पिनाकिनः । गणैर्विवव्रे बहुधातुलक्षणप्रकर्ष एवानवधिक्रियात्मभिः ॥ ३२ ॥
column5: prabhoḥ puro divyavaco'dhidaivatavrataprathāmāttavataḥ pinākinaḥ | gaṇairvivavre bahudhātulakṣaṇaprakarṣa evānavadhikriyātmabhiḥ || 32 ||
column6: दिव्यं वचः संस्कृतवाणी तत्राधिदैवतव्रतप्रथामधिष्ठातृत्वं गृहीतवतो भगवतोऽग्रे गणैरतुलस्योत्साहप्रधानत्वादनन्यसदृशस्य सेवाक्षणस्य प्रकर्षो बहुधा बहुभिः प्रकारैर्विवव्रे धृतः । अनवधिरियत्तारहिता क्रिया रणानुगुणो व्यापारो यस्य स आत्मा येषां तैः । अथ च गणैर्भूप्रभृतिभिर्बहूनां धातूनां यल्लक्षणं धर्मस्तत्प्रकर्षो विव्रियते । क्रिया साध्यमानैकरूपा सा येषां तैः । दिव्यानां दिवि निवसतां वचसि दैवतभावं गृहीतवत इति वा मुख्यार्थे व्याख्येयम् ॥
column7: In front of Lord Shiva, who had attained prestigious lordship over the speech of the Devas/Sanskrit language, the Ganas/verb classes, characterized by boundless activity/the ability to evolve innumerable derivatives, exhibited a peerless abundance of festive joy in so many ways/sophistication in the definition of diverse root words.
column8: Bahudhātulakṣaṇaprakarṣa’ must be split as ‘bahudhā+atula+kṣaṇa+prakarṣa’ and ‘bahu+dhatu+lakṣaṇa+prakarṣa’ in its contextual (narrative-related) and non-contextual (grammar-related) meanings respectively. ‘Divyaṃ vacaḥ’ (‘divine speech’) = ‘saṃskṛtavāṇī’ ('Saṃskṛta language') (JR).

column4: नवान्तकभ्रूकुटिभङ्गिसङ्गिभिर्व्यलोकि सेना तरवारिडम्बरैः । विचेष्टितं पत्युरवेत्य बिभ्रती विभूषणं कालभुजङ्गमैरिव ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: navāntakabhrūkuṭibhaṅgisaṅgibhirvyaloki senā taravāriḍambaraiḥ | viceṣṭitaṃ patyuravetya bibhratī vibhūṣaṇaṃ kālabhujaṅgamairiva || 33 ||
column6: यमभ्रूभङ्गसदृशैरेकधारखड्गप्रपञ्चैर्हेतुभिः स्वामिनोऽभिप्रायं बुद्धा कृष्णसर्पैर्भूषणमिव कुर्वती सेना जनेन दृष्टा । अत्र तरवारीणां भुजङ्गमत्वेनोत्प्रेक्षणम् ॥
column7: Through an exuberant display of swords that resembled Death’s darkly knit eyebrows, the Army seemed to bedeck itself with black cobras by taking cue from the behaviour of its master (i.e., Shiva).
column8: The black swords are compared to darkly knit eyebrows and snakes.

column4: मृगाङ्कमौलेर्व्रजतो वसत्यधो रथाङ्गताभाजि पतङ्गमण्डले । प्रसृत्य तद्रश्मिभिरुष्णवारणं प्रपञ्चितच्छायमुपर्युपर्यभूत् ॥ ३४ ॥
column5: mṛgāṅkamaulervrajato vasatyadho rathāṅgatābhāji pataṅgamaṇḍale | prasṛtya tadraśmibhiruṣṇavāraṇaṃ prapañcitacchāyamuparyuparyabhūt || 34 ||
column6: चक्ररूपेऽर्कबिम्बेऽधोगते सति तत्प्रभाभिर्हरस्यच्छत्रमुपर्युपरि कृतच्छायमभूत् । बुध्नेऽर्कोंशुसङ्गाच्छायाया उपरिवर्तित्वम् ॥
column7: As the moon-crested Lord marched ahead, the sun’s orb, which had assumed the role of a chariot wheel, took its position beneath him, whereby his parasol, spread over by sunrays, cast its shadow higher and higher up.
column8: Since the parasol is above and the sun below, the former casts its shadow high up (JR)

column4: जगत्प्रभोः पाण्डुरमुष्णवारणं कचत्किरीटादुपरि प्रतिष्ठया । अदर्शि बद्धेर्ष्यतयोपगत्वरद्वितीयपूर्णेन्दुधिया शिखेन्दुना ॥ ३५ ॥
column5: jagatprabhoḥ pāṇḍuramuṣṇavāraṇaṃ kacatkirīṭādupari pratiṣṭhayā | adarśi baddherṣyatayopagatvaradvitīyapūrṇendudhiyā śikhendunā || 35 ||
column6: मुकुटादुपरिस्थित्या दीप्यमानं तथा श्वेतं छत्रं चन्द्रेणागच्छदपरचन्द्रभ्रान्त्या समत्सरमदर्शि । 'किलेन्दुना' इति पाठः । 'शिखेन्दुना' इति पाठे द्वितीयपूर्णेन्दुशब्दस्यासङ्गतिः स्यात् ॥
column7: The moon that adorns the crest of the Lord of the Universe gazed at the resplendent white parasol raised above his crown with envy, mistaking it for a second, and full-orbed, moon approaching it.
column8: JR gives ‘kilendunā’ as the correct reading instead of ‘śikhendunā’. Since the moon on Shiva’s head is a crescent, it is not logical to say that it was envious at the sight of the parasol, which it fancied as a second full-moon, i.e., if the moon on Shiva’s head were to be the full-moon (which is not the case), it makes sense to describe the parasol as the second full-moon. If we accept the reading ‘kilendunā’ as correct, the verse must be understood differently. In that case, the moon is not the half-moon on Shiva’s head but the full-moon transformed into one of his chariot wheels. Such an understanding renders the description of the parasol as the second full-moon and the envy of the first moon (i.e., the full-moon in the role of the chariot wheel) meaningful.

column4: ख​रांशुचन्द्रौ समसप्तकस्थितौ रथेऽवधार्याधिकगर्वदुर्धरः। शरीभवन्मूर्तिमवेक्ष्य शार्ङ्गिणं विधुन्तुदोऽभूत्पुनरुद्भवद्भयः ॥ ३६ ॥
column5: kharāṃśucandrau samasaptakasthitau rathe'vadhāryādhikagarvadurdharaḥ| śarībhavanmūrtimavekṣya śārṅgiṇaṃ vidhuntudo'bhūtpunarudbhavadbhayaḥ || 36 ||
column6: सूर्येन्दू रथचक्रतालक्षणतुल्यकार्यकरणात्परस्परं सम्मुखतया स्थितौ दृष्ट्वा राहुर्बहुगर्वेण दुर्घरोऽभूत्। समसप्तकस्थितयोरर्केन्द्वोरुपरागसम्भवात् । विष्णुं बाणरूपं दृष्ट्वा राहुः पुनरुद्भवद्भयं यस्य सोऽभूत् । विष्णोरेव राहोर्भयं युक्तम् । विशेषेण शररूपात् ॥
column7: Rahu was beside himself with intense elation on seeing the sun and the moon occupying a Samasaptaka position, facing one another in the chariot. But his fear resurfaced when he beheld Vishnu transform into Shiva’s arrow.
column8: The sun and the moon face each other in the ‘samasaptaka’ position (‘parasparaṃ sammukhatayā sthitau’, JR), as they are in their present roles of chariot wheels. The samasaptaka position presents the possibility of an eclipse (‘samasaptakasthitayorarkendvoruparāgasambhavāt, JR), wherefore Rahu, who is believed to cause eclipse, was overjoyed. His joy, however, was short-lived because Vishnu, who had cut off his head in the past, was also present nearby, having transformed himself into Shiva’s arrow (see footnote under 2.2)

column4: रथः पथा नाकसदां स्यदाकुलं प्रतिष्ठमानः स पिनाकधन्वनः । चकार चक्रत्वजुषोऽप्यहो मुहुर्नियोगशून्यं न पदं विवखतः ॥ ३७ ॥
column5: rathaḥ pathā nākasadāṃ syadākulaṃ pratiṣṭhamānaḥ sa pinākadhanvanaḥ | cakāra cakratvajuṣo'pyaho muhurniyogaśūnyaṃ na padaṃ vivakhataḥ || 37 ||
column6: स्यदेन वेगेनाकुलं कृत्वा आकाशेन प्रस्थानं कुर्वन्स हरस्य रथश्चक्ररूपस्यापि सूर्यस्य नियोगेनाधिकारेण रहितं पदमाकाशं नाकरोत् । चक्ररूपस्याप्यर्कस्याकाशेनैव गमनात् ॥
column7: As it travelled with immense speed along the path of the celestials, Shiva’s chariot still allowed the Sun to preside over his realm (i.e., the sky) even though he was transformed into a wheel at present.
column8: N/A

column4: अरिष्टमन्यत्किमतोऽपि मृग्यतां सुरद्विषां यद्गगनाग्रसङ्गिनि । रथे विभोरात्तरथाङ्गरूपयोः सहोदयोऽभूत्तपनैणलक्ष्मणोः ॥ ३८ ॥
column5: ariṣṭamanyatkimato'pi mṛgyatāṃ suradviṣāṃ yadgaganāgrasaṅgini | rathe vibhorāttarathāṅgarūpayoḥ sahodayo'bhūttapanaiṇalakṣmaṇoḥ || 38 ||
column6: जनेन दैत्यानामन्यदमङ्गलं किमन्विष्यताम् । नभः सक्ते रथे गृहीतचक्ररूपयोः सूर्येन्द्रोः सहोदयो यदभूत् ॥
column7: When the Lord’s chariot hit the skies, the sun and the moon, having assumed the form of its wheels, rose simultaneously. Could the Asuras ask for a worse omen than this?
column8: N/A

column4: तदा स्यदः स्यन्दनमिन्दुलक्ष्मणस्तथाध्यशेतानवधौ दिवः पथि । यथा गणानां रणतारतम्यतो मनोऽपि पश्चाच्चरतामशिश्रियत् ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: tadā syadaḥ syandanamindulakṣmaṇastathādhyaśetānavadhau divaḥ pathi | yathā gaṇānāṃ raṇatāratamyato mano'pi paścāccaratāmaśiśriyat || 39 ||
column6: अनवधावियतारहिते आकाशे हररथो वेगं तथाश्रयत्, यथा युद्धश्रद्धाधरमपि गणानां चेतः पश्चादगमत् । मनसोऽप्याशु रथोऽगमदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Thus sped the moon-crested God’s chariot across the endless celestial path that even the war-obsessed minds of the Gana hordes were left far behind.
column8: The chariot travelled faster than the mind (JR).

column4: रथाङ्गचन्द्रार्ककराग्रसङ्ग्रहप्रसक्तशीतातपदैन्यहानये । गणाङ्गनानां हरपत्रपार्श्वयोः सपौनरुक्त्याः परिवृत्तयोऽभवन् ॥ ४० ॥
column5: rathāṅgacandrārkakarāgrasaṅgrahaprasaktaśītātapadainyahānaye | gaṇāṅganānāṃ harapatrapārśvayoḥ sapaunaruktyāḥ parivṛttayo'bhavan || 40 ||
column6: चक्ररूपयोश्चन्द्रार्कयो रश्मीनां योगेन हेतुना प्रसक्तौ यौ शीतातपौ ताभ्यां दैन्यं तन्निवारणाय हररथपार्श्वयोः परिवर्तनानि गणस्त्रीणां पुनःपुनरभवन् । एकत्र पार्श्वे तापे लग्ने सति गणस्त्रियोऽन्यं पार्श्वमगमन्, शैत्यदैन्यात्ततोऽप्यर्कान्तिकमित्यर्थः ॥
column7: The wives of the Ganas, marching on either sides of Shiva’s chariot, repeatedly exchanged their positions to overcome the discomfort, caused by the cold and heat resulting, respectively, from an accumulation of the rays of the sun and the moon, transformed presently into wheels.
column8: N/A

column4: अकाण्डनैबिड्यनिपीडनस्फुटद्विलासमुक्तासररत्नरेणुभिः । मरुद्विकीर्णैः कटकैणचक्षुषां रजोऽसृजद्व्योमगतापि सा चमूः ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: akāṇḍanaibiḍyanipīḍanasphuṭadvilāsamuktāsararatnareṇubhiḥ | marudvikīrṇaiḥ kaṭakaiṇacakṣuṣāṃ rajo'sṛjadvyomagatāpi sā camūḥ || 41 ||
column6: अकाण्डेऽकाले नैबिड्येन सङ्कटत्वेन स्फुटञ्चूर्णीभवन्यो विलासमुक्तासरो लीलामुक्तादाम तद्रजोभिर्हेतुभिराकाशस्थापि सेना रजोऽसृजत् ॥
column7: Though it was marching in the sky, the army threw up much dust, thanks to the wind-blown powder of the fancy pearl necklaces of the battalion’s doe-eyed beauties that were pulverized by rubbing against one another in the suddenly surging crowd.
column8: N/A

column4: सा सोमार्धशिरोमणेरगणितैः शार्ङ्गैः कृतालिङ्गना भङ्गिं प्राप पताकिनी रिपुजनीवैधव्यवैक्लव्यभूः । आरूढैररिवीरलोककदनानन्ताभियोगान्तक- क्रीडावाहलुलायसंहतिहठाभिव्यक्तशृङ्गश्रियम् ॥ ४२ ॥
column5: sā somārdhaśiromaṇeragaṇitaiḥ śārṅgaiḥ kṛtāliṅganā bhaṅgiṃ prāpa patākinī ripujanīvaidhavyavaiklavyabhūḥ | ārūḍhairarivīralokakadanānantābhiyogāntaka- krīḍāvāhalulāyasaṃhatihaṭhābhivyaktaśṛṅgaśriyam || 42 ||
column6: अरिवीरलोकस्य कदनं मारणं तत्रानन्ताभियोगेऽभ्युद्यतो योऽन्तको यमस्तस्य क्रीडावाहभूता लुलायसंहतिर्महिषपङ्क्तिस्तस्या हठेनाभिव्यक्तानां शृङ्गाणां श्रियमारूढैः । महिषशृङ्गसमैरित्यर्थः । शार्ङ्गैः कोदण्डैः कृतास्पदा हरस्य सेना शोभां प्रापत् । रिपुजनीनां शत्रुवधूनां वैधव्येन भर्तृवधेन वैक्लव्यस्य भूः स्थानम् ॥
column7: Shiva’s army, the very bedrock of woeful widowhood to the enemy’s womenfolk, was equipped with countless horn-made bows that appeared like the horns, displayed in aggression, by the herd of Death’s sportive buffalo mounts as he (i.e., Death) strove endlessly towards the extermination of the enemy warriors.
column8: N/A

column4: द्राक्कर्तास्मि स्मयरसजुषामद्य शान्तिं पुराणा-मेवं सन्धामनुसृतवतस्तर्जनीवान्तकस्य । तत्रैकैको गिरिशकटके पार्षदानां करेषु प्रासस्त्रासव्यसनगुरुतामाससाद द्विषत्सु ॥ ४३ ॥
column5: drākkartāsmi smayarasajuṣāmadya śāntiṃ purāṇā- mevaṃ sandhāmanusṛtavatastarjanīvāntakasya | tatraikaiko giriśakaṭake pārṣadānāṃ kareṣu prāsastrāsavyasanagurutāmāsasāda dviṣatsu || 43 ||
column6: तत्र हरसैन्ये गणानां हस्तेष्वेकैकः प्रास आयुधविशेषो रिपुत्रासव्यसने गुरुतामुपदेशकतां प्राप । भयदुःखे कृतवानित्यर्थः। अतः सम्भाव्यते- स्मयरसं दर्पं धारयतां त्रिपुराणामद्य तूर्णं शान्तिं निर्वाणं कर्तास्मीत्येवं सन्धां प्रतिज्ञां कुर्वतो यमस्य तर्जनी प्रदेशिन्यङ्गुली । तर्जनीति प्रकृतानुगुणमभिधानम् । प्रासान्दृष्ट्वैवारयो मुमुहुरित्यर्थः ॥
column7: As if it were the threatening index finger of Death, who took this resolve “I shall quickly quash the arrogant Puras”, each and every spear that the soldiers in Shiva’s army held in their hands became an instructor to the enemies in the agonizing experience of fear.
column8: Resolve is expressed by sticking out the index finger. Since the index finger is also used to threaten others, the word ‘tarjanī’ (‘the threatening finger’) is a contextually appropriate usage.

column4: नासीरपार्षदभटेषु ततः प्रतोलीं लोलीकृतासिषु हठादधिरूढवत्सु । वामभ्रुवः पुरपुरेष्वभवन्नकाण्डे मग्ना भियेव निजबाष्पजलह्रदेषु ॥ ४४ ॥
column5: nāsīrapārṣadabhaṭeṣu tataḥ pratolīṃ lolīkṛtāsiṣu haṭhādadhirūḍhavatsu | vāmabhruvaḥ purapureṣvabhavannakāṇḍe magnā bhiyeva nijabāṣpajalahradeṣu || 44 ||
column6: नासीरः सेनामुखं तत्र ये पार्षदभटा गणयोधास्तेषु हठाद्बलेन प्रतोलीं रथ्यामाश्रितवत्सु सत्सु भीत्येव त्रिपुरनगरेषु स्त्रियो निजाश्रुप्रवाहमग्ना अभवन् । एते वीरा अस्मदीयभर्तॄन्हनिष्यन्तीति पुरस्त्रियोऽरुदन्नित्यर्थः ॥
column7: No sooner did the brave Ganas in the vanguard rush to the highway brandishing their swords than the pretty-browed women in the citadels of Tripura readily drowned in a flooding stream of tears due to panic, or so it seemed.
column8: Drowning in a stream of tears is likened here to suicide by drowning

column4: वीरैस्तस्य प्रकृतिचपलैर्विश्वजैत्रस्य शम्भो-र्विस्रम्भासूत्रितनवनवोपप्लवेष्वन्तिकेषु । द्वारश्लिष्टाररपुटतया ताः पुराणां पुराणां पत्न्यो मीलद्दृश इव बभुर्भीतिमोहग्रहेण ॥ ४५ ॥
column5: vīraistasya prakṛticapalairviśvajaitrasya śambho- rvisrambhāsūtritanavanavopaplaveṣvantikeṣu | dvāraśliṣṭārarapuṭatayā tāḥ purāṇāṃ purāṇāṃ patnyo mīladdṛśa iva babhurbhītimohagraheṇa || 45 ||
column6: विश्वजैत्रस्य सर्वजेतुः शम्भोः सम्बन्धिभिर्वीरैर्विस्रम्भेण निर्भयमासूत्रिताः कृता नवनवा उपप्लवा उपद्रवा येषु तेष्वन्तिकेषु निकटस्थानेषु सत्सु द्वारश्लिष्टानि पिहितान्यररपुटानि द्वाःपट्टानि यस्य तद्भावेन हेतुना नगर्यो भीतिमूर्छापातेन सङ्कुचद्दृष्टय इव बभुः । विस्रम्भासूत्रितेति यतिभङ्गोऽनुप्रासानुरोधादङ्गीकृतः॥
column7: As the naturally sprightly soldiers of Shiva, conqueror of the universe, wreaked one havoc after another in the vicinity of the Asura cities, it seemed as if the latter, gripped by overwhelming fear, had shut their eyes under the pretext of their locked gates.
column8: Cf. ‘vinirgataṃ mānadamātmamandirāt - - - sasambhramendradrutapātitārgalā nimīlitākṣīva bhiyāmarāvatī’ (from Mankha’s ‘Hayagrīvavadha’, quoted in Kāvyaprakāśa, chapter 1). There is a breach of caesura after the fourth syllable of the second line, which JR substatiates as necessitated by the 'anuprāsa' ('alliteration') in 'śambhoḥ' and 'visrambhā'. The word 'patnyo' seems to be a faulty reading since JR's commentary says nothing about it and its contextual importance is unclear. A possible alternative reading for 'purāṇāṃ patnyo' could be 'purāṇāḥ puryo' ('ancient cities')

column4: आक्रामत्सु भटेषु बालशशभृन्मौलेर्बलादन्तिकं त्रासोद्भ्रान्तपिधीयमानविकटद्वाराग्रपट्टस्वनैः । दूरोत्क्षिप्तभुजायमानतनुभिः सीमन्त्यमाना ध्वजै-रब्रह्मण्यमुदैरयन्निव पुरस्ता नाकसद्वैरिणाम् ॥ ४६ ॥
column5: ākrāmatsu bhaṭeṣu bālaśaśabhṛnmaulerbalādantikaṃ trāsoddhrāntapidhīyamānavikaṭadvārāgrapaṭṭasvanaiḥ | dūrotkṣiptabhujāyamānatanubhiḥ sīmantyamānā dhvajai- rabrahmaṇyamudairayanniva purastā nākasadvairiṇām || 46 ||
column6: हरस्य योधेषु हठात्समीपं जयत्सु सत्सु त्रासोद्भ्रान्त्या भयचकितत्वेन पिधीयमानानि श्लिष्यमाणानि विकटानि यानि द्वाराग्रपट्टानि तेषां शब्दैर्हेतुभिर्देवद्विषां नगर्योऽब्रह्मण्यमुपद्रवनिवेदकं शब्दमुदैरयन्नकुर्वन् । दूरमुत्क्षिप्ता अत एव भुजायमाना भुजसमास्तनवो मूर्तयो येषां तैर्ध्वजैः सीमन्त्यमाना विभक्तीक्रियमाणाः । वलिनाक्रम्यमाणश्चोत्क्षिप्तभुजं पूत्करोति ॥
column7: Their row of flag-arms flung high in the air, the cities of the Asuras seemed to cry out “Help! Help!” through the loud bang caused by the frantic closure of their gates as the soldiers of Shiva forcefully besieged their precincts.
column8: Abrahmaṇyam’ is an exclamation that expresses trouble (‘upadravanivedakam’, JR)

column4: विशति शशिकलाशिखस्य सैन्ये त्रिपुरपुरेषु भयैकदन्तुरेषु । ध्वजसिचयचयोऽपि वातधूतो रभसमिवाध्यवसत्पलायनाय ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: viśati śaśikalāśikhasya sainye tripurapureṣu bhayaikadantureṣu | dhvajasicayacayo'pi vātadhūto rabhasamivādhyavasatpalāyanāya || 47 ||
column6: हरस्य कटके प्रविशति सति त्रिपुरनगरेषु भयैकव्याप्तेषु सत्सु ध्वजवस्त्रसमूहोऽपि पलायनार्थमिव त्वरामाश्रयत् । यतो वातधूतो वायुकम्पितः । एतेनाप्यसुराणामनिमित्तं सूचितम् । 'उपान्वध्याङ्वसः' इति सकर्मत्वम् ॥
column7: When Shiva’s army entered the utterly terrified cities of the three Puras, even their cluster of cloth banners, shaken by winds, seemed all prepared to run away.
column8: N/A

column4: शम्भोः सेनापटहरणिताडम्बरः कम्पसम्प-त्स​म्पर्कायाजनि स तुहिनप्रक्रियामाददानः । यस्मिन्नन्तर्विशति दितिजप्रेयसीनां न भूयः कर्णे रूढिप्रणयमपुषञ्शेखरेन्दीवराणि ॥ ४८ ॥
column5: śambhoḥ senāpaṭaharaṇitāḍambaraḥ kampasampa-tsamparkāyājani sa tuhinaprakriyāmādadānaḥ | yasminnantarviśati ditijapreyasīnāṃ na bhūyaḥ karṇe rūḍhipraṇayamapuṣañśekharendīvarāṇi || 48 ||
column6: हरस्य सेनायाः पटहरटितस्यानकध्वनेराडम्बरः कम्पसम्पदः सम्पर्कायाजनि जातः । अत एव हिमसमकार्यकारित्वं गृह्णन् । यस्मिन्पटहशब्दप्रबन्धेऽन्तर्विशति सति दैत्यस्त्रीणां कर्णे रूढत्वं भूषणकर्णोत्पलानि नागमन् । हेमन्ते चोत्पलानां प्ररोहाभावः ॥
column7: Like snowfall in its effect, the loud bang of Shiva’s battalion drums caused continuous shivering. No sooner did it gain entry into the hearts of the Asura maidens than their ears were forever deprived of their friendship with the blue lotuses adorning them.
column8: Snowfall causes shivering as well as the withering of lotuses. The phrase 'ears were forever deprived of their friendship with the blue lotuses adorning them' is a roundabout way of saying that the Asura maidens were rendered widows.

column4: विशद्गिरिशसैनिकप्रवरपाणिहेलावल-त्कृपाणकिरणच्छटापिहितसङ्कुचन्मूर्तयः । पुरः सुरविरोधिनां रुरुधिरे चिरेणाननं स्पृशन्त्य इव तत्क्षणं व्यतिकरेण कालस्य ताः ॥ ४९ ॥
column5: viśadgiriśasainikapravarapāṇihelāvala-tkṛpāṇakiraṇacchaṭāpihitasaṅkucanmūrtayaḥ | puraḥ suravirodhināṃ rurudhire cireṇānanaṃ spṛśantya iva tatkṣaṇaṃ vyatikareṇa kālasya tāḥ || 49 ||
column6: विशन्तो ये हरसेनाचरास्तेषां पाणिषु वलन्तो वल्गन्तो ये कृपाणाः खड्गास्तेषां किरणच्छटाभिः पिहिताश्छादिता सङ्कुचन्ती मूर्तिर्यासां ता दैत्यानां नगर्यस्तत्क्षणं वृत्तान्तेन यमस्य मुखं विशन्त्य इवारोचन्त । कालस्येति प्रकृतानुगुणम् । खड्गांशुसम्पर्को यममुखप्रवेशरूपत्वेनोत्प्रेक्षितः ॥
column7: Their outlines disappearing in the (dark) glow of the swords brandished bravely by Shiva’s invading warriors, the cities seemed at that moment to slowly enter the mouth of Death.
column8: N/A

column4: सस्रंसे श्रवणोत्पलं विजघटे कण्ठादथैकावली श्रोत्राभ्यां मणिकेलिकुण्डलयुगं विभ्रश्य दूरं ययौ । इत्थं दानवसुभ्रुवां हरचमूनादश्रुतौ पप्रथे त्रासेनैव भविष्यदक्षतबृहद्वैधव्ययोग्यः क्रमः ॥ ५० ॥
column5: sasraṃse śravaṇotpalaṃ vijaghaṭe kaṇṭhādathaikāvalī śrotrābhyāṃ maṇikelikuṇḍalayugaṃ vibhraśya dūraṃ yayau | itthaṃ dānavasubhruvāṃ haracamūnādaśrutau paprathe trāsenaiva bhaviṣyadakṣatabṛhadvaidhavyayogyaḥ kramaḥ || 50 ||
column6: दैत्यस्त्रीणां कर्णोत्पलं सस्तम् । कण्ठादेकावली मुक्तासरो विजघटे च्युतः । रत्नकुण्डलद्वयं कर्णाभ्यां पतित्वा दूरमगमत् । एवं हरसेनासिंहनादाकर्णने दानवस्त्रीणां भयेनैव भाव्यक्षतं सम्पूर्णं यद्वैधव्यं तत्र योग्यः क्रमोऽवस्था पप्रथे सम्पन्नः । वैधव्ये हि स्त्रियः कर्णोत्पलादि परिहरन्ति ॥
column7: The blue lotuses tucked behind their ears slipped down; pearl necklaces snapped off their necks; and bejewelled pendants came loose and fell far away from their ears: In this way, due merely to the panic resulting from hearing the shout of Shiva's army, the Asura women went through an experience that was consistent with their imminent, absolute widowhood.
column8: Widowed women do not wear ornaments on their person (JR).

column4: बाणीभूतसुरारिवैरिणि लसत्सारथ्यपथ्यस्थिति-ब्रह्मण्यागतवत्युपोढसुदृढाटोपं पुरद्वेषिणि । आसन्ने तदनीकिनीपरिकरे सद्मामरद्रोहिणां क्षुभ्यत्सत्त्वमुदस्तदुःसहरजो रोहत्तमश्चाभवत् ॥ ५१ ॥
column5: bāṇībhūtasurārivairiṇi lasatsārathyapathyasthiti-brahmaṇyāgatavatyupoḍhasudṛḍhāṭopaṃ puradveṣiṇi | āsanne tadanīkinīparikare sadmāmaradrohiṇāṃ kṣubhyatsattvamudastaduḥsaharajo rohattamaścābhavat || 51 ||
column6: बाणीभूतः शररूपः सम्पन्न: सुरारिवैरी नारायणो यस्य । तथा लसन्ती सारथ्यपथ्या सारथिभावपथानपेता स्थितिर्यस्य स ब्रह्मा यस्य । तस्मिन्हरे धृतस्थिराडम्बरमागतवति सति तस्य हरस्यानीकिनीपरिकरे सेनाडम्बर आसन्ने सति, असुराणां स्थानं क्षुभ्यन्ति सत्त्वानि प्राणिनः सत्त्वं च गुणो यत्र, तथा उदस्तमुत्थितं रजः पांसुर्गुणश्च, तथा रोहत्तमोऽन्धकारो गुणश्च यत्र तदभवत् । हरिब्रह्मसम्बन्धात्सत्त्वाद्युक्तिसङ्गतिः ॥
column7: No sooner did Tripura’s Foe – with Vishnu transformed into his arrow and Brahma shining in the befitting role of his charioteer – arrive and his well-equipped army draw near than the mansions of the Asuras betrayed perturbed inmates/Sattva, intolerable dust storms/Rajas, and dense darkness/Tamas.
