column8: Sattva, Rajas, and Tamas refer to the three elements (guṇas) that constitute matter (prakṛti); they are presided over by Vishnu, Brahma, and Rudra (a fierce form of Shiva, associated with the annihilation of the universe) respectively (‘rajoguṇamayaṃ cānyadrūpaṃ - - - || caturmukhaḥ - - - || sattvaṃ guṇamupāśritya viṣṇuḥ - - - ||’, Kūrma Purāṇa, 4.50-52; ‘ayaṃ hi bhagavān rudraḥ sarvaṃ jagadidaṃ śivaḥ | tamoguṇaṃ samāśritya kalpānte saṃharetprabhuḥ ||’, ibid. 22.31).

column4: उद्गच्छदच्छिदुरकच्छपकेतुवैरि-दुर्वारसैन्यजरजःपरिरम्भणेन । गण्डस्थलीषु पुरविष्टपसुन्दरीणां जज्ञेतरां विरहपाण्डिमपूर्वरङ्गः ॥ ५२ ॥
column5: udgacchadacchidurakacchapaketuvairi-durvārasainyajarajaḥparirambhaṇena | gaṇḍasthalīṣu puraviṣṭapasundarīṇāṃ jajñetarāṃ virahapāṇḍimapūrvaraṅgaḥ || 52 ||
column6: कच्छपो मीनः स ध्वजो यस्य स कामस्तस्य वैरी हरस्तस्य दुर्वारं यत्सैन्यं तस्माज्जातमुद्गच्छदुत्तिष्ठद्यद्रजस्तत्सन्निपातेन पुरस्त्रीणां कपोलेषु विरहेण पाण्डुत्वस्य पूर्वरङ्गो जातः ॥
column7: The impenetrable dust that was raised by Shiva’s unstoppable army kissed the Asura women’s cheeks, thus setting the stage for the pallor of widowhood’s separation to manifest on them.
column8: Kacchapa’ is generally used in the sense of ‘tortoise’; here, however, it means ‘fish’ (JR); 'Kacchapaketu' = 'the Fish-bannered One' (i.e., Kama).

column4: इत्थं सैन्ये धरित्रीधरवरदुहितृप्राणनाथस्य तस्मि-न्नासन्ने दानवानां पुरि परिचिततामाससाद प्रसा(?मा)दः । येनाकाण्डप्रकम्पाकुलिततनुलताः पौरपारिप्लवाक्ष्य-स्त्रासेनेवोपभुक्ता दधुरधिकतरस्वेदरोमाञ्चचर्चाम् ॥ ५३ ॥
column5: itthaṃ sainye dharitrīdharavaraduhitṛprāṇanāthasya tasmi-nnāsanne dānavānāṃ puri paricitatāmāsasāda prasā(?mā)daḥ | yenākāṇḍaprakampākulitatanulatāḥ paurapāriplavākṣya-strāsenevopabhuktā dadhuradhikatarasvedaromāñcacarcām || 53 ||
column6: गौरीपतेः कटके एवं निकटं प्राप्ते सति प्रसादोऽभावः (?) परिचयं प्रापत् । येन हेतुना त्रासेन भयेनेवोपभुक्ताः सर्वाङ्गव्याप्ता नायकव्यवहारसमारोपात्कम्पिताश्च कम्पव्याकुलदेहाः पौरस्त्रियोऽधिकयोः स्वेदरोमाञ्चयोश्चर्चां दधुरधारयन् । कृतोपभोगाश्च स्त्रियः कम्परोमाञ्चयुक्ता भवन्तीति भद्रम् ॥
column7: And so, when the army of Shiva, sweetheart of the Mountain Lord’s daughter, drew closer to the Cities, danger drew closer too, wherefore the fickle-eyed Asura lasses, their lithe bodies trembling, displayed profuse sweating and intense goosebumps as if Fear itself had made love to them.
column8: Prasāda’ seems to be a faulty reading; one possible alternative reading for it is ‘pramāda’ (danger)

column4: इति श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराजराजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये गणप्रस्थानवर्णनं नामैकविंशः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirājarājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye gaṇaprasthānavarṇanaṃ nāmaikaviṃśaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Twenty-first Canto, named 'Description of the Military March of the Ganas' in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja.

column4: द्वाविंशः सर्गः ॥
column7: Twenty-second Canto

column4: तन्निशम्य पुरवैरिणो बलं सर्वतोऽप्यभिसरत्पुरः पुरीः । मन्दिरेषु सहसैव जज्ञिरे गाढरोषपरुषाः सुरद्विषः ॥ १ ॥
column5: tanniśamya puravairiṇo balaṃ sarvato'pyabhisaratpuraḥ purīḥ | mandireṣu sahasaiva jajñire gāḍharoṣaparuṣāḥ suradviṣaḥ || 1 ||
column6: पुरवैरिणो हरस्य तद्बलं सर्वतोऽपि पुरीर्नगरी: स्त्रीलिङ्गत्वान्नायिकाव्यवहारयोग्या अभिसरद्गच्छद्दृष्ट्वा स्वगृहेष्वसुरा गाढकोपेन परुषा उल्बणा जाताः ॥
column7: Seeing that the army of Shiva was approaching their cities from all sides, the Asuras were suddenly filled with intense anger in their mansions.
column8: The non-contextual meaning relates to lovers who get angry when others approach their beloved women (JR).

column4: अप्रयुक्तवति चन्द्रशेखरे बाणमग्निमयमप्यनर्गलम् । पूर्वमेव दितिजा निजक्रुधा दह्यमानतनवोऽवतस्थिरे ॥ २ ॥
column5: aprayuktavati candraśekhare bāṇamagnimayamapyanargalam | pūrvameva ditijā nijakrudhā dahyamānatanavo'vatasthire || 2 ||
column6: हरे आग्नेयं शरमक्षिपत्यपि सति प्रागेव दैत्या दह्यमानवपुषः क्रुधासन् ॥
column7: Though the Moon-crested Lord had not yet discharged his unbridled arrow of fire, Diti’s sons were already burning with anger within.
column8: N/A

column4: पश्यतां स्मयरसेन दोर्युगं बिम्बिता भ्रुकुटयोंऽसवर्त्मनि । स्वर्द्रुहां हठगलग्रहोच्छ्वसत्कालपाशकरणिं प्रपेदिरे ॥ ३ ॥
column5: paśyatāṃ smayarasena doryugaṃ bimbitā bhrukuṭayoṃ'savartmani | svardruhāṃ haṭhagalagrahocchvasatkālapāśakaraṇiṃ prapedire || 3 ||
column6: दर्परसेन हेतुना भुजद्वयं वीक्षमाणानां स्वर्द्रुहामसुराणामंसेषु प्रतिबिम्बिता भ्रूभङ्गा हठेन कण्ठरोधार्थमुच्छ्वसतां यमपाशसर्पाणां साम्यमापुः । उपमोपक्रमोत्प्रेक्षेयम् ॥
column7: The dark frowns of the Asuras, which were reflected on their shoulders when they gazed at their arms in arrogant pride, took on the appearance of Death’s (serpentine) noose expanding to tighten around their necks.
column8: Kālapāśakaraṇim’ = ‘yamapāśasarpāṇāṃ sāmyam’ (‘semblance of the serpents that form Yama’s noose’) (JR)

column4: जृम्भमाणकटुकोपदारुणास्तेऽरुणारुणमुखत्विषोऽभवन् । कल्पितैर्हरशराग्निभीतितो रक्तचन्दनविलेपनैरिव ॥ ४ ॥
column5: jṛmbhamāṇakaṭukopadāruṇāste'ruṇāruṇamukhatviṣo'bhavan | kalpitairharaśarāgnibhītito raktacandanavilepanairiva || 4 ||
column6: जृम्भमाणः कटुर्दुःसहो यः कोपस्तेन दारुणास्ते दैत्या अरुणवदरुणा मुखत्विड्येषां तेऽभवन् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - हरशराग्निभयात्कल्पितै रक्तचन्दनाङ्गरागैरिव । चन्दनं हि शीतवीर्यम् ॥
column7: As the countenance of the Asuras, who looked frightening in their harsh, explosive anger, got redder and redder, it appeared as if they had been smeared with a paste of red sandalwood in anticipation of Shiva’s fire-bearing shaft.
column8: Sandalwood paste is cold in potency (‘candanaṃ hi śītavīryam’, JR)

column4: तैः कृतान्तकरपाशपन्नगस्फारितस्फुटफणागणात्मसु । शोणकान्तिकृतवह्निवृष्टयो दृष्टयो मुमुचिरेऽसियष्टिषु ॥ ५ ॥
column5: taiḥ kṛtāntakarapāśapannagasphāritasphuṭaphaṇāgaṇātmasu | śoṇakāntikṛtavahnivṛṣṭayo dṛṣṭayo mumucire'siyaṣṭiṣu || 5 ||
column6: तैरसियष्टिषु दृष्टयो मुमुचिरे मुक्ताः । शोणकान्त्या कृता वह्निवृष्टिर्याभिस्ताः । अग्निवद्दुःसहा इत्याशयः । कृतान्तस्य करे पाशपन्नगास्तैः स्फारितो योऽसौ फणागणः स आत्मा यासामिति प्रहर्तृभावत्वानुगुण्यादतिशयभीषणत्वं प्रतिपादितम् ॥
column7: They let their glance, which seemed to spew fire with its red glow, fall on their sword blades that resembled numerous expanded hoods of the serpent-noose in Death’s hand.

column4: निर्गमोन्मुखरमाकुलीभवद्विष्टराम्बुरुहचुम्बिता इव । बिम्बितारुणविलोचनास्तदा तैरवाहिषत खड्गयष्टयः ॥ ६ ॥
column5: nirgamonmukharamākulībhavadviṣṭarāmburuhacumbitā iva | bimbitāruṇavilocanāstadā tairavāhiṣata khaḍgayaṣṭayaḥ || 6 ||
column6: निर्मलत्वाद्विम्बितान्यरुणानि विलोचनानि यासु ताः खड्गयष्टयस्तैरसुरैरवाहिषत । अतः सम्भाव्यते - निर्गमे उन्मुखी या रमा तस्या आकुलीभवद्यद्विष्टराम्बुरुहमासनपद्मं तेन चुम्बिता इव । लक्ष्म्या निर्गमोन्मुखत्वं भाविनाश्रयनाशेन भयात् ॥
column7: The swords, which the Asuras presently took hold of, mirrored their bloodshot glances, thus appearing to be kissed goodbye by Lakshmi's perturbed lotus-abode as she prepared to take leave of them.
column8: The lotus-seated Lakshmi is supposed to dwell in the warrior’s sword. Since the Asuras will be killed very soon, she decides to abandon their swords (JR). As she prepares to leave, her lotus-abode kisses goodbye to the swords. The bloodshot glances reflected in the swords resemble kisses.

column4: भ्रूकुटीपरिणतेरुपागता निर्जिहानबहुशाखतामिव । वर्धमानहठरोषदुर्धरैस्तैः क्रुधा दुधुविरेऽसिवीरुधः ॥ ७ ॥
column5: bhrūkuṭīpariṇaterupāgatā nirjihānabahuśākhatāmiva | vardhamānahaṭharoṣadurdharaistaiḥ krudhā dudhuvire'sivīrudhaḥ || 7 ||
column6: भ्रूभङ्गप्रतिबिम्बनान्निर्जिहाना उत्पन्ना बहवः शाखा यस्य तद्भावमिवोपगतास्तैः क्रुधा खड्गलताः कम्पिताः । वर्धमानेन हठरोषेण दुस्तरैः ॥
column7: Unstoppable in their ever-growing temper, they brandished their creeper-like swords that seemed to sprout so many branches through the dark frowns reflected on them.
column8: N/A

column4: कस्यचित्करविघट्टनस्फुटत्कुट्टिमाग्रविवरं वरक्रुधः । तत्क्षणग्रसनलालसान्तकव्यात्तवक्त्रकुहरायितं दधौ ॥ ८ ॥
column5: kasyacitkaravighaṭṭanasphuṭatkuṭṭimāgravivaraṃ varakrudhaḥ | tatkṣaṇagrasanalālasāntakavyāttavaktrakuharāyitaṃ dadhau || 8 ||
column6: वरक्रुधः कस्यचित्करविघट्टनेन स्फुटद्यत्कुटिमाग्रविवरं कर्तृ तत्क्षणं ग्रसने लालसो योऽन्तकस्तेन व्यात्तमुद्घाटितं वक्त्रकुहरं तद्वदाचरितं दधौ ॥
column7: A hole that opened up when a certain deeply enraged Asura stomped his hand on the floor mimicked the gaping, cave-like mouth of Death, all set to devour him then and there.
column8: N/A

column4: कोऽपि कोपतरलाग्रपाणिना घट्टयन्नसकृदंसमण्डलम् । गन्तुमन्तकपुरं पुरः स्वयं निर्ममे पटहताडनामिव ॥ ९ ॥
column5: ko'pi kopataralāgrapāṇinā ghaṭṭayannasakṛdaṃsamaṇḍalam | gantumantakapuraṃ puraḥ svayaṃ nirmame paṭahatāḍanāmiva || 9 ||
column6: कोपेन तरलश्चपलो योऽग्रपाणिस्तेन पुनः पुनः स्कन्धमण्डलं घट्टयन्कोऽपि पटहताडनामानकध्वनिमिव स्वयमकरोत् । अन्तकपुरं यमनगरं गन्तुम् । अन्तकपुरगमनसमये पुरः पटहस्ताड्यत इत्याचारः ॥
column7: Another Asura repeatedly patted his round shoulder with the front of his angrily brisk palm as if he were beating in advance the drum of his own departure to Death’s capital.
column8: People announce a dead person’s journey to the other world by beating drums (JR).

column4: नर्तयन्नरि करेण कश्चन व्रश्चनाय परिपन्थिनां बभौ । आत्मनो यमपथप्रवृत्तये सज्जयन्नवरथक्रियामिव ॥ १० ॥
column5: nartayannari kareṇa kaścana vraścanāya paripanthināṃ babhau | ātmano yamapathapravṛttaye sajjayannavarathakriyāmiva || 10 ||
column6: परिपन्थिनां वैरिणां व्रश्चनायच्छेदार्थमरि चक्रं करेण नर्तयन्कश्चिद्बभौ । अतः सम्भाव्यते - यमपथे प्रवृत्तिस्तदर्थमात्मनो नवरथक्रियां सज्जयन्सज्जीकुर्वन्निव ॥
column7: A third Asura, who kept spinning a discus/wheel with his hand in order to chop the enemies down, appeared as though he were fashioning a brand new chariot to embark on a journey along Death’s highway.
column8: The Asura seemed to be fashioning a new chariot for his own journey to the other world (JR).

column4: मृद्न​तः करयुगं मिथोऽग्रतस्तद्भुवा विततधूमरेखया । प्रापि कस्यचन बन्धनोन्मुखप्रेतराट्प्रहितशृङ्खलालिपिः ॥ ११ ॥
column5: mṛdnataḥ karayugaṃ mitho'gratastadbhuvā vitatadhūmarekhayā | prāpi kasyacana bandhanonmukhapretarāṭprahitaśṛṅkhalālipiḥ || 11 ||
column6: क्रुधा मिथः करयुग्मं मृद्न​तो मथ्नतः कस्यचित्तद्भुवा मथनजातया धूमरेखया बन्धनोन्मुखेन प्रेतराजा यमेन प्रहिता या शृङ्खला तद्भ्रमः प्रापि प्राप्तः । यमशृङ्खलावद्भयङ्करी धूमरेखासीदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: A continuous trail of smoke that arose before an Asura when he rubbed his palms together wore the semblance of a chain hurled by Death for binding him.
column8: A trail of smoke resembles an iron chain in  colour and appearance alike.

column4: कस्यचिद्वपुषि तत्क्षणस्फुटद्रूढपूर्वजरठव्र​णस्रजः । सत्वरापसृतिसिद्धये बहुद्वारविभ्रममबिभ्रत श्रियः ॥ १२ ॥
column5: kasyacidvapuṣi tatkṣaṇasphuṭadrūḍhapūrvajaraṭhavraṇasrajaḥ | satvarāpasṛtisiddhaye bahudvāravibhramamabibhrata śriyaḥ || 12 ||
column6: कस्यापि शरीरे तत्क्षणं स्फुटन्त्यो रूढपूर्वा जरठा [या] व्रणस्रजो बहुद्वाराणां [टङ्कं] सादृश्यमधारयन् । द्वारवद्व्रणानां विवृतत्वमभूदित्यर्थः । श्रियो लक्ष्म्याः सत्वरमपसरणसिद्ध्यर्थमित्युत्प्रेक्षणम् । व्रणानां स्फुटितत्वं वीररसपूरितत्वेनाङ्गानां विकासात् ॥
column7: A row of old, already healed wounds burst open all of a sudden on the person of another Asura as if it were a series of doors thrown wide for Lady Fortune to make a quick exit.
column8: The Asura’s limbs were filled with a burst of new energy, thereby causing them to expand and the wounds on them to break open (JR).

column4: मण्डलाग्रमुरुकोषकोटरात्केनचिद्रणरसेन कर्षता । कालसूत्रघटनेव सर्वतस्तन्मरीचिभिररच्यतात्मनः ॥ १३ ॥
column5: maṇḍalāgramurukoṣakoṭarātkenacidraṇarasena karṣatā | kālasūtraghaṭaneva sarvatastanmarīcibhiraracyatātmanaḥ || 13 ||
column6: उरोर्महतः कोषकोटरात्परिवारान्मण्डलाग्रं खड्गं कर्षता केनचित्खड्गांशुभिः करणैरात्मनः कालसूत्रघटनेव यमसूत्रपात इव कृतः । खड्गरश्मयो यमवास्तुसूत्रत्वेन सम्भाविता इत्यर्थः ॥
column7: As he pulled out a sword from the hollow of its scabbard, yet another Asura appeared to bind himself all around in the dark/deadly net of its thread-like rays.
column8: The dark rays radiating from the sword are imagined as threads used for marking measuring lines during the construction of Death’s mansion (‘khaḍgaraśmayo yamavāstusūtratvena sambhāvitāḥ’, JR). Architects trace the outline of a shape by dropping a thread that is smeared with soot, chalk, etc. (‘śilpinaśca kimapi lekhituṃ varddhayituṃ cālikhyamānasya varddhyamānasya cākāravakrimaparihārāya maṣīkhaṭikādyupaliptasūtrābhighātena rekhāpatanaṃ kurvanti’, Narayana’s commentary on Naiṣadhacarita, 15.34). The dark rays described here can be regarded as representing threads smeared with soot.

column4: केचिदुच्छ्वसितघर्ममार्जितैरङ्गरागघुसृणैरितस्ततः । उच्छलद्भिरचिराद्गलिष्यतां पूर्वरङ्गमसृजामिवासृजन् ॥ १४ ॥
column5: keciducchvasitagharmamārjitairaṅgarāgaghusṛṇairitastataḥ | ucchaladbhiracirādgaliṣyatāṃ pūrvaraṅgamasṛjāmivāsṛjan || 14 ||
column6: स्वेदगलितैरङ्गरागैर्हेतुभिः पतिष्यतां रुधिराणां पूर्वरङ्गमिव केचिदसृजन् ॥
column7: Washed away by the spreading sweat, an application of saffron powder dripped here and there from the limbs of some Asuras, who, therefore, seemed to be setting the stage for the impending bloodshed.
column8: N/A

column4: कोऽपि पाणिधृतखड्गतेजसां निर्झरैः क्षणविनिह्नु​ताननः । सिंहिकासुतकबन्धशङ्कया भास्वतः कृतभयो व्यभाव्यत ॥ १५ ॥
column5: ko'pi pāṇidhṛtakhaḍgatejasāṃ nirjharaiḥ kṣaṇavinihnutānanaḥ | siṃhikāsutakabandhaśaṅkayā bhāsvataḥ kṛtabhayo vyabhāvyata || 15 ||
column6: पाणिना धृतो यः खड्गस्तत्तेजसां निर्झरैः प्रवाहैः क्षणं छादितमुखः कोऽपि सिंहिकासुतस्य राहोः कबन्धः शिरोरहितकायस्तत्सम्भावनया भास्वतः सूर्यस्य कृतभयो व्यभाव्यत ॥
column7: A certain Asura, his face hidden temporarily from view by the flooding lustre of a hand-held sword, was seen to cause fear in the Sun, who mistook him for the headless trunk of Rahu.
column8: The sun fears being swallowed and digested by Rahu if his head and body reunite.

column4: कोपपाटलिमसंविभक्ततां नीयमान इव गण्डरेखया। कस्यचिद्वदनतः श्रमाम्बुनो डम्बरः सघुसृणोद्गमोऽगलत् ॥ १६ ॥
column5: kopapāṭalimasaṃvibhaktatāṃ nīyamāna iva gaṇḍarekhayā| kasyacidvadanataḥ śramāmbuno ḍambaraḥ saghusṛṇodgamo'galat || 16 ||
column6: कस्यापि मुखात्सकुङ्कुमः स्वेदजलप्रबन्धोऽगलत् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - गण्डरेखया कोपारुणत्वसंविभागं नीयमान इव । गण्डरेखया स्त्रीलिङ्गत्वान्नायिकास्थानीयया संविभक्तः। कृतोपभोग इति च लेशतोऽर्थः ॥
column7: Profuse sweat, mingled with saffron, dripped from the face of another Asura, making it appear as if his cheek had shared a part of its angry red flush with it.
column8: Since ‘gaṇḍalekhā’ (‘cheek’) and ‘kopapāṭalimā’ (‘redness caused by anger’) are in the feminine and masculine genders respectively, the two can be imagined as standing in the mutual relation of a lady and her lover with the word ‘shared’ (‘samvibhakta’) taking the overtone of ‘enjoyed’ (‘kṛtopabhoga’) (JR).

column4: ते ततो वपुषि लोहनिर्मितैर्वर्म​भिः प्रकृतिमेचका बभुः । नूतनाम्बुधररञ्जिताञ्जनक्ष्माधरभ्रमविधानबन्धवः ॥ १७ ॥
column5: te tato vapuṣi lohanirmitairvarmabhiḥ prakṛtimecakā babhuḥ | nūtanāmbudhararañjitāñjanakṣmādharabhramavidhānabandhavaḥ || 17 ||
column6: प्रकृत्या मेचकाः कृष्णास्ते लोहकङ्कटैर्बभुः । नूतनैः सजलैरम्बुधरैर्मेघै रञ्जितो योऽञ्ज​नाद्रिस्तद्भ्रमकारिणः ॥
column7: Thanks to the iron armours covering their bodies, the Asuras, who are naturally jet-black in complexion, were mistaken for the Collyrium Mountain, dotted with dark, newly formed clouds.
column8: The Asuras and their iron armours resemble Collyrium Mountain and dark clouds respectively.

column4: कल्पितश्चिरमयोमयोऽप्यहो स्वर्द्रुहां समरचेलसञ्चयः । कोपपाटलविलोचनत्विषा मङ्क्षु वध्यपटतामिवापठत् ॥ १८ ॥
column5: kalpitaściramayomayo'pyaho svardruhāṃ samaracelasañcayaḥ | kopapāṭalavilocanatviṣā maṅkṣu vadhyapaṭatāmivāpaṭhat || 18 ||
column6: स्वर्द्रुहां दैत्यानां शस्त्रमयोऽपि कल्पितः समरचेलानां रणवस्त्राणां सञ्चयः कोपपाटला रोषारुणा या विलोचनत्विट् नेत्रप्रभा तया हेतुभूतया वध्यपट​ताभावमिवापठद्व्यञ्जितवान्। रक्तपटावृतो वध्यो हन्यत इत्याचारः ॥
column7: The iron battle armours, which the Asuras donned slowly and carefully, transformed instantly into red robes of execution due to the angry glow of their bloodshot  eyes.
column8: To-be-executed criminals are dressed up in crimson robes (JR).

column4: मृत्युवाहमहिषस्य शृङ्गयोर्वप्रकेलिघनकर्दमैरिव । लिप्यमानवपुषश्चकाशिरे ते तदायसतनुत्ररश्मिभिः ॥ १९ ॥
column5: mṛtyuvāhamahiṣasya śṛṅgayorvaprakelighanakardamairiva | lipyamānavapuṣaścakāśire te tadāyasatanutraraśmibhiḥ || 19 ||
column6: यमवाहमहिषस्य शृङ्गयोस्तटाघातपङ्कैर्लोहकङ्कटांशुभिर्लिप्यमानाङ्गा इव ते बभुः ॥
column7: The Asuras looked dazzling in the spreading radiance of their iron coats as if their bodies had been smeared with the thick black slush stuck to the horns of Yama’s buffalo-mount during its playful butting.
column8: The playful butting of buffaloes (as well as elephants and bulls) against a bank or bund is called ‘vaprakrīḍā’ or ‘taṭāghāta’; it is frequently described in Sanskrit poetry. The overall purport of the verse is that the Asuras were facing imminent death.

column4: नूतनाभ्ररुचयो निसर्गतः सङ्गता निभृतलोहवर्मभिः । जज्ञिरेऽसिमहसा सुरद्विषां मूर्तयस्त्रिगुणितासितत्विषः ॥ २० ॥
column5: nūtanābhrarucayo nisargataḥ saṅgatā nibhṛtalohavarmabhiḥ | jajñire'simahasā suradviṣāṃ mūrtayastriguṇitāsitatviṣaḥ || 20 ||
column6: निभृतैर्निश्चलैर्लोहकङ्कटैः सङ्गताः, तथा नवमेघश्यामा दैत्यानामाकृतयः, असिमहसा त्रिगुणकृष्णाभा जाताः ॥
column7: The Asuras’ bodies, which naturally resembled fresh clouds in their complexion and sported tightly fitting iron armours, saw a trebling of blackness when dark swords flashed forth.
column8: The trebling is due to their naturally black complexion combined with the blackness of iron armours and the glow of their black swords (JR).

column4: निःसरत्सु दनुजेषु संयते संयतेद्धकवचेषु भूमिषु । भाविनीं सुवसतिं स्वविष्टपे मन्यते स्म तनयो विवस्वतः ॥ २१ ॥
column5: niḥsaratsu danujeṣu saṃyate saṃyateddhakavaceṣu bhūmiṣu | bhāvinīṃ suvasatiṃ svaviṣṭape manyate sma tanayo vivasvataḥ || 21 ||
column6: संयतानि बद्धानीद्धानि कवचानि यैस्तेषु संयते सङ्ग्रामाय निःसरत्सु निर्गच्छत्सु यमः स्वभवने सुवसतिं वसद्बहुलजनत्वममन्यत ॥
column7: When the Asuras, clad in blazing armours, came out in large numbers for the battle, Death foresaw an immanent increase in the population of his realm.
column8: N/A

column4: आतपत्रमुपरि प्रपेदिरे भेजिरे च चमराञ्चलानिलम् । यत्सुरारिपतयस्तदास्त तत्केवलं विकसदूष्मशान्तये ॥ २२ ॥
column5: ātapatramupari prapedire bhejire ca camarāñcalānilam | yatsurāripatayastadāsta tatkevalaṃ vikasadūṣmaśāntaye || 22 ||
column6: दैत्या यच्छत्रं दधुः यच्च चमरवायुं भेजुः, तत्केवलं तापशमनायैव, न तु विभूतिव्यञ्जनार्थम् । तस्या अचिरेण नाशात् ॥
column7: The royal parasols, which the Asura chieftains flaunted over their heads, and the breeze, which they enjoyed from the tips of flywhisks, served the sole purpose of alleviating the soaring heat of their anxiety.
column8: The parasols and flywhisks served the purpose of alleviating the burning anxiety of the Asuras and not of communicating their royal status, which they would soon be deprived of (JR).

column4: उच्छ्रितैरुपरि नाकवैरिणां रत्नखण्डखचितैरचुम्ब्यत । कालमण्डलितपाशपन्नगश्रीरजस्रमसितोष्णवारणैः ॥ २३ ॥
column5: ucchritairupari nākavairiṇāṃ ratnakhaṇḍakhacitairacumbyata | kālamaṇḍalitapāśapannagaśrīrajasramasitoṣṇavāraṇaiḥ || 23 ||
column6: दैत्यानामुपर्युन्नतैः कृष्णच्छ​त्रैः कालस्य मण्डलिता ये पाशसर्पास्तच्छोभा दधे । रत्नखण्डखचितत्वेनाहिफणारत्नधर्मत्वमाक्षिप्तम् ॥
column7: The gem-studded black parasols that were raised over the heads of the Asuras put on the steady semblance of Death’s coiled-up serpent noose.
column8: The gem-studded black parasols resembled coiled-up snakes carrying gems on their hoods (JR).

column4: जज्ञिरे त्रिपुरदानवाः शिरोरत्नबिम्बितवलक्षचामरैः । शाम्भवाशुगहुताशसंस्तवात्प्रागिव प्रसितभास्मनोर्मयः ॥ २४ ॥
column5: jajñire tripuradānavāḥ śiroratnabimbitavalakṣacāmaraiḥ | śāmbhavāśugahutāśasaṃstavātprāgiva prasitabhāsmanormayaḥ || 24 ||
column6: शिरोरत्नेषु प्रतिबिम्बितैः शुभ्रचामरैर्हेतुभिर्दैत्या हरशरपातात्पूर्वमेव जातभस्मवीचय इव जाताः । जानातेर्वा लिटि कर्मणि रूपम् ॥
column7: Owing to the reflection of the white flywhisks in their crest gems, the Asuras of the Triple City seemed to sprout ripples of ash on their person even before coming in contact with Shiva’s fire missile.
column8: The word ‘jajñire’ may either mean ‘(they) were (covered in ripples of ash)’ or ‘(they were) perceived (as covered in ripples of ash’), depending on whether it is derived from the verb root ‘jan’ (in which case ‘jajñire’ is the liṭ-lakāra, third person, plural form in the active voice) or from the verb root ‘jñā’ (in which case ‘jajñire’ is the liṭ-lakāra, third person, plural form in the passive voice).

column4: सान्द्रतूर्यनिनदा विपाण्डुरच्छत्रसंहतिमती पताकिनी । निर्जरप्रतिभुवां तदा बभावन्तकाट्टहसिताञ्चितेव सा ॥ २६ ॥
column5: sāndratūryaninadā vipāṇḍuracchatrasaṃhatimatī patākinī | nirjarapratibhuvāṃ tadā babhāvantakāṭṭahasitāñciteva sā || 26 ||
column6: N/A
column7: Due to the continuous blare of war trumpets and the closely packed rows of pure white parasols, the Asura army seemed to be suffused with Death’s boisterous laughter.
column8: The whiteness of the parasols and the blare of trumpets stand respectively for the whiteness of laughter and the loud sound accompanying it. JR’s commentary for this verse is not available.

column4: कोणबाहुभिरुरःस्थलश्रियस्ताडयन्त्यलसमन्द्रदुन्दुभीन् । सा ध्वजिन्यतत तूर्यनिःस्वनक्रन्दितान्युपनमत्प्रभुक्षतिः ॥ २७ ॥
column5: koṇabāhubhiruraḥsthalaśriyastāḍayantyalasamandradundubhīn | sā dhvajinyatata tūryaniḥsvanakranditānyupanamatprabhukṣatiḥ || 27 ||
column6: वक्षःस्थलशोभान्पटहान्दुन्दुभिपटलवादनदण्डभुजैस्ताडयन्ती सा सेना तूर्यनि:स्वना एव ऋन्दितानि व्यधात् । यत उपनमन्ती प्रभुक्षतिः स्वामिक्षतिर्यस्याः । ध्वजिन्यत्र नायिकास्थानीया ॥
column7: As its lord’s death drew near, the Army, beating its deeply resonant chest-like drums with sticks resembling arms, cried aloud by way of the clarion’s shrill blast.
column8: The army is imagined as a lady crying at the imminent death of her Asura lord (JR).

column4: कर्णतालवलनान्यनारतं तद्गजा विदधिरे मदोद्धताः । व्यञ्जयन्त इव दन्तसंसरत्सन्निधेश्चपलतां प्रभुश्रियः ॥ २८ ॥
column5: karṇatālavalanānyanārataṃ tadgajā vidadhire madoddhatāḥ | vyañjayanta iva dantasaṃsaratsannidheścapalatāṃ prabhuśriyaḥ || 28 ||
column6: दैत्यदन्तिन: कर्णतालकम्पांश्चक्रुः । अतः सम्भाव्यते - तद्दन्तेषु संसरन्नुल्लसन्सन्निधिर्यस्याः श्रियश्चापलं ख्यापयन्त इव । पूर्वं दन्तिनां दन्तद्वारेण श्रीरधो गतासीदितीतिहासः । तालो वाद्यभाण्डविशेषः ॥
column7: Through the incessant flapping of their ears, the army’s elephants, maddened with rut, seemed to announce the fickleness of Royal Glory, who was dwelling in the vicinity of their tusks.
column8: Royal Glory, identified with Goddess Lakshmi, is believed to have descended down by taking the path of elephants' tusks (JR). JR explains the word ‘tāla’ also as 'drum'; the flapping of ears is equated, through pun, with the beating of drums to announce the fickleness of Royal Glory.

column4: दन्तिनां श्रुतिपुटैरनेकशो नर्त्यमानतनुभिर्व्यतन्यत । क्लाम्यतो द्रुततरागतिश्रमादन्तकस्य नवतालवृन्तता ॥ २९ ॥
column5: dantināṃ śrutipuṭairanekaśo nartyamānatanubhirvyatanyata | klāmyato drutatarāgatiśramādantakasya navatālavṛntatā || 29 ||
column6: मदवशात्कम्प्यमानैर्हस्तिनां कर्णपुटैर्यमस्य नवव्यजनभावो गृहीतः । यतः कार्यगौरवात्तूर्णमागमनेन जातखेदस्य ॥
column7: The continuously flapping, outstretched ears of elephants became the brand new palmyra fans of Death, who was exhausted by the exertion of his hurried arrival.
column8: N/A

column4: वाजिभिर्निकटविप्लवार्जितैः प्रेषितैर्गगनवर्त्महेषितैः । द्रागदूरयमवाहसैरिभत्रासवैशसमिवाभ्यधीयत ॥ ३० ॥
column5: vājibhirnikaṭaviplavārjitaiḥ preṣitairgaganavartmaheṣitaiḥ | drāgadūrayamavāhasairibhatrāsavaiśasamivābhyadhīyata || 30 ||
column6: दर्पवशादाकाशवर्त्मविसृष्टैर्हेषितैः करणैर्वाजिभिः कर्तृभिरदूरे यमवाहमहिषास्त्रासस्तेन वैशसमिवोक्तम् । अश्वानां महिषैः सह शाश्वतिकविरोधात्त्रासवैशसम् ॥
column7: Through their neighing noises, stemming from a sense of the lurking danger, the horses that were let loose in the celestial path seemed to readily betray their intense fear of Yama’s approaching buffalo mount.
column8: The buffalo is regarded as a natural enemy of the horse (‘aśvānāṃ mahiṣaiḥ saha śāśvatikvirodhāttrāsavaiśasam, JR; see also 20.20).

column4: दीर्घकाञ्चनखलीनदीधितिप्रोतमाननमवाहि वाजिभिः । आन्तरस्य महसो निरेष्यतश्चुम्ब्यमानमिव वीचिडम्बरैः ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: dīrghakāñcanakhalīnadīdhitiprotamānanamavāhi vājibhiḥ | āntarasya mahaso nireṣyataścumbyamānamiva vīciḍambaraiḥ || 31 ||
column6: वाजिभिराननं दीर्घाणां काञ्चनखलीनानां कविकानां रश्मिभिः सम्बद्धमवाहि धृतम् । अतः सम्भाव्यते - आन्तरस्यान्तर्वर्तिनो महसस्तेजसो जीवरूपस्य वीचिस्फारैः स्पृश्यमानमिव । यतो निरेष्यतोऽभ्यन्तरान्निर्गमिष्यतः । वाजिनां मरणेनाश्रयाभावात् ॥
column7: The mouths of the horses were bathed in the lustre of their long, golden bridles as if kissed by a swelling surge of life’s energy that was about to depart in the near future.
column8: The poet imagines personified life energy as kissing the horses goodbye before taking leave of them.

column4: वक्त्र​निर्यदनलार्चिषां मिषादन्तकाय धृतहस्तदीपकाः । अग्रतः पिशुनिताशिवाः शिवा वाशितानि दिवसेऽपि तेनिरे ॥ ३२ ॥
column5: vaktraniryadanalārciṣāṃ miṣādantakāya dhṛtahastadīpakāḥ | agrataḥ piśunitāśivāḥ śivā vāśitāni divase'pi tenire || 32 ||
column6: दिनेऽपि शिवा रटितानि चक्रुः । यतः सूचितामङ्गलाः । वाशन्तीनां शिवानां मुखादग्निज्वाला निर्गच्छतीति वस्तुगतिः। अतः सम्भाव्यते - मुखनिर्गच्छदग्निज्वालानां व्याजाद्यमाय धृता हस्तदीपिका याभिस्ताः । रजोन्धकारे स्फुरति मार्गदर्शनात् ॥
column7: Carrying portable lamps to lead Death from the front, or so it seemed, through the fiery flames blazing forth from their mouths, female jackals portended evil by howling even in the daytime .
column8: Female jackals are believed to emit flames from their mouth when they howl (‘vāśantīnāṃ śivānāṃ mukhādagnijvālā nirgacchantīti vastugatiḥ’, JR). The jackals are imagined as carrying lamps so Death can see his way in the dense darkness created by the dust of the battle (JR).

column4: पप्रथे यमवरूथिनीपृथुच्छत्रपङ्क्तिभिरिव क्षतातपा । दूरविस्तृतपतत्रमेचकैः पेचकैः परिचिता नभःस्थली ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: paprathe yamavarūthinīpṛthucchatrapaṅktibhiriva kṣatātapā| dūravistṛtapatatramecakaiḥ pecakaiḥ paricitā nabhaḥsthalī || 33 ||
column6: दूरे विस्तृतानि पतत्राणि पक्षास्तैर्मेचकैः कृष्णैः पेचकैरुलूकैर्हेतुभिर्नभःस्थली वारितातपा सम्पन्ना । अतः सम्भाव्यते - यमवरूथिन्याः पृथुभिश्छत्रपङ्क्तिभिरिव ॥
column7: Spreading their dark wings wide, owls covered the sky and shut off all sunlight like they were a row of large parasols in Death’s battalion.
column8: N/A

column4: सा तदा त्रिदशलोकवैरिणां स्वैरिणां प्रचलिता पताकिनी । विन्ध्यहास्तिकवदास्त विस्तृतप्रस्फुरत्करटवाशिताञ्चिता ॥ ३४ ॥
column5: sā tadā tridaśalokavairiṇāṃ svairiṇāṃ pracalitā patākinī | vindhyahāstikavadāsta vistṛtaprasphuratkaraṭavāśitāñcitā || 34 ||
column6: स्वैरिणां स्वतन्त्राणां दैत्यानां सा सेना करटानां काकानां वाशितं रटितं विस्तृतं स्फुरितं तेन व्याप्तासीत् । विन्ध्यहस्तिसमूहवत् । तत्पक्षे स्फुरन्तः करटा गण्डा यासां ता वाशिताः करिण्यस्ताभिरञ्चिता । हास्तिकमिति 'अचित्तहस्तिधेनोष्ठक्'॥
column7: Marching at that moment, the army of the self-indulgent Asuras appeared like Mt. Vindhya’s elephant herd – resounding with the long-drawn cry of flittering ravens/distinguished by she-elephants with large, splendid frontal globes.
column8: The word ‘hāstika’ (‘herd of elephants’) is derived from ‘hasti’ by the rule ‘acittahastidhenoṣṭak’ (JR).

column4: नर्तितोड्डमरमृत्युदेवताकाञ्चिमारकतकिङ्किणीलिपिम् । आश्रितैः परभृतामितस्ततो मण्डलैर्मुखरतान्वबध्यत ॥ ३५ ॥
column5: nartitoḍḍamaramṛtyudevatākāñcimārakatakiṅkiṇīlipim | āśritaiḥ parabhṛtāmitastato maṇḍalairmukharatānvabadhyata || 35 ||
column6: नर्तिता उड्डमरा मृत्युदेवता तस्याः काञ्चौ मारकतीनां मरकतमयीनां किङ्किणीनां लिपिं सादृश्यं प्राप्तैः कोकिलानां कुलैर्मुखरत्वमितस्ततो धृतम् । स्वाभाविकमुखरशब्दपरिहारेण मुखरतानुबन्धनमशुभसूचकम् ॥
column7: Resembling the emerald bells strung to the girdle of the ferocious, dancing Goddess of death, circles of cuckoos shrieked nonstop.
column8: The uncommon, continuous shrieking of cuckoos is regarded as an evil omen (JR).

column4: काकघूकमविमूकतां तथा गाढमापदधिदैत्यवाहिनि । येन नैव पिहिताम्बरोदरः सान्द्रतूर्यनिनदोऽपि पप्रथे ॥ ३६ ॥
column5: kākaghūkamavimūkatāṃ tathā gāḍhamāpadadhidaityavāhini | yena naiva pihitāmbarodaraḥ sāndratūryaninado'pi paprathe || 36 ||
column6: दैत्यसेनायां काकघूकं कर्तृ अविमूकतां मौखर्यं तथापत् , यथाकाशव्याप्यपि पटहशब्दो न प्रथितः । काकघूकमिति 'येषां च विरोधः शाश्वतिकः' इति रूपम् । अपिर्भिन्नक्रमः ॥
column7: Thus did flocks of crows and owls cry shrilly over the Asura army that even the blaring trumpet calls, pervading the celestial vault, could scarcely be made out.
column8: The Dvandva compound ‘kākaghūkam’, whose elements, ‘kāka’ (‘crow’) and ‘ghūka’ (‘owl’), represent animals that have permanent enmity, takes the singular number according to the rule ‘yeṣāṃ ca virodhaḥ śaśvatikaḥ’ (JR).

column4: व्योमपट्टकतले निरर्गलाः पङ्क्तयो बलिभुजां विरेजिरे । उद्यदन्तकनिदेशशंसनं कल्पयन्त्य इव वर्णराजयः ॥ ३७ ॥
column5: vyomapaṭṭakatale nirargalāḥ paṅktayo balibhujāṃ virejire | udyadantakanideśaśaṃsanaṃ kalpayantya iva varṇarājayaḥ || 37 ||
column6: उद्यन्विजयाय कृतोद्योगो योऽन्तकस्तस्य निदेश इत्थं सेवा कार्या इत्याज्ञा तस्याः शंसनं प्रतिपादनं कल्पयन्त्योऽक्षरमाला इव बलिभुजां काकानां पङ्क्तयो व्योमैव पट्टकं तस्य तले विरेजिरे रेजुः। आज्ञा च पट्टकतले लिखिता भवति ॥
column7: On the surface of the sky, which resembled a plaque, confused rows of ravens appeared like series of letters proclaiming the decree of Death as he rose to victory.
column8: N/A

column4: हेमचक्रसचिवासितोल्लसद्वारवाणघटनेन ते बभुः । आवहन्त इव दुष्प्रवृत्तये भूरिचण्डकरमण्डलं नभः ॥ ३८ ॥
column5: hemacakrasacivāsitollasadvāravāṇaghaṭanena te babhuḥ | āvahanta iva duṣpravṛttaye bhūricaṇḍakaramaṇḍalaṃ nabhaḥ || 38 ||
column6: हेममयानि चक्राणि वारवाणेषु शोभार्थं क्रियन्ते । तत्सचिवानामुल्लसतां वारवाणानां कञ्चुकानां घटनेन ते दैत्या बभुः । अमङ्गलवार्तासूचनार्थं भूरयश्चण्डकरमण्डलाः सूर्यबिम्बा यस्य तन्नभः कुर्वन्त इव । संहारकाले बहूनामर्काणामुदयो युगपद्भवति ॥
column7: It seemed as if the Asuras, fitted with blazing, black armours marked with ornamental golden wheels, were donning the sky, dotted with several orbs of the fierce-rayed sun, to announce their misfortune.
column8: The simultaneous rise of several suns heralds universal destruction (cf. ‘dagdhuṃ viśvaṃ dahanakiraṇairnoditā dvādaśārkāḥ’, Veṇīsaṃhāra, 3.61). The armours and the ornamental golden wheels stand for the sky and  the several suns dotting it respectively.

column4: आत्तमण्डलितचण्डकार्मुकाः कामुका दितिजवामचक्षुषाम् । कङ्कणानि रविजाङ्गनोपदाकल्पनाय बहुशोऽवहन्निव ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: āttamaṇḍalitacaṇḍakārmukāḥ kāmukā ditijavāmacakṣuṣām | kaṅkaṇāni ravijāṅganopadākalpanāya bahuśo'vahanniva || 39 ||
column6: गृहीतमण्डलाकारधनुषो दैत्यस्त्रीणां कामुका दैत्या यमस्त्रीणां कोशलिकाः कल्पयितुं कङ्कणानि दधुरिव । धनुषामाकर्षणेन मण्डलाकारत्वात्कङ्कणत्वसम्भावनम् ॥
column7: Thanks to their fearsome bows that were bent into a circle, it seemed as if the paramours of the pretty-eyed Asura damsels were fetching so many bangles as gifts for Yama’s womenfolk.
column8: JR explains 'upadā​' as 'kośalikā' (?bribe)

column4: श्यामचर्मफलकाब्जिनीदलव्याकुलोद्यदसिशेवलच्छटा । सा दधौ शमनकेलिदीर्घिकादीर्घतामसुरलोकवाहिनी ॥ ४० ॥
column5: śyāmacarmaphalakābjinīdalavyākulodyadasiśevalacchaṭā | sā dadhau śamanakelidīrghikādīrghatāmasuralokavāhinī || 40 ||
column6: श्यामाश्चर्मफलका उद्यमनपट्टा एवाब्जिनीदलानि तैर्व्याकुला असय एव शेवलच्छटा यस्याः सा दैत्यानां वाहिनी सेनैव नदी शमनस्य यमस्य केलिदीर्घिका लीलापुष्करिणी तद्वद्दीर्घतां दधौ ॥
column7: In the Asura army that resembled Death’s pleasure pond by its vastness, swords tossed about dark hide-shields like mossy creepers about lotus leaves.
column8: Swords are likened to mossy creepers and shields to lotus leaves.

column4: ते कुकर्मनिधयो जगाहिरे स्वैर्वपुर्भिरसिपत्रयोगिताम् । सम्मुखं तदपि निर्जरद्विषश्चक्रिरे चिरमरौरवग्रहम् ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: te kukarmanidhayo jagāhire svairvapurbhirasipatrayogitām | sammukhaṃ tadapi nirjaradviṣaścakrire ciramarauravagraham || 41 ||
column6: ते दैत्याः खैः शरीरैरसिपत्रस्य खड्गस्य नरकविशेषस्य च सङ्ग्रहं चक्रुः ।......॥
column7: Though the Asuras - rich repositories of evil actions - were endowed with bodies befitting consignment to the Asipatra hell/carried swords on their persons, they never faced the Raurava hell/yelled at the foe continuously. How strange!
column8: JR’s commentary for the second half of the verse is not available. ‘Asipattra’ and ‘’Raurava’ are two types of hells – Narakas - among many. ‘Asipatravana’ is a forest whose leaves are blades of swords and which is populated by fierce dogs. People who are left to suffer in this hell are cut to pieces by the swords that fall on them from the trees above when a heavy wind blows across the place. Their limbs are then eaten up by the dogs (‘patrāṇi tatra khaḍgānāṃ phalāni - - - || śvānaśca tatra sabalāḥ - - - vyāghrā iva bhayānakāḥ || - - - teṣāṃ gatānāṃ tatrāsipattrapātī samīraṇaṃ | pravāti tena pātyante teṣāṃ khaḍgānyathopari || - - - sārameyāstataḥ śīghraṃ ghātayanti śarīrataḥ | teṣāmaṅgāni rudatāmanekānyatibhīṣaṇāḥ || asipattravanaṃ tāta mayaitatparikīrtitam ||’ Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa, 12.27-33). Raurava is a Naraka in which people who have committed evil acts are left to suffer in a pit filled with burning embers (‘tataḥ śvabhraḥ sudustaraḥ || tatrāṅgāracayo - - - | - - - tanmadhye pāpakarmāṇaṃ vimuñcanti yamānugāḥ ||, Mārkaṇḍeya Purāṇa, 10.80-83). The word ‘arauravagraham’ must be split in two ways – ‘arau, rava+graham’ and ‘a+raurava+graham’ – in order to appreciate the apparent contradiction in the verse and resolve it. The contradiction is due to the description of the Asuras as meriting punishment in Asipatra but not in Raurava when there is no logical reason why it must be so.

column4: पङ्कटङ्कशितिकङ्कटाङ्कितैर्वर्ष्मभिर्विवृतवैकृतोर्मयः । तेऽथ जग्मुरधिखड्गमण्डलीवारिधारमवगाहनेप्सवः ॥ ४२ ॥
column5: paṅkaṭaṅkaśitikaṅkaṭāṅkitairvarṣmabhirvivṛtavaikṛtormayaḥ | te'tha jagmuradhikhaḍgamaṇḍalīvāridhāramavagāhanepsavaḥ || 42 ||
column6: अथ ते जग्मुः । रणभूमिमित्यस्य सकर्मणो व्यभिचाराभावान्न ग्रहणम् । खड्गमण्डलीवारिधारं खड्गधारानैर्मल्यं तत्सम्मुखं स्नातुकामाः । अतिशयोक्त्या कवयो जलशब्देन खड्गधारानैर्मल्यव्यवहारिणः। यतः पङ्कटङ्काः कर्दमाकारा: शितयो नीला ये कङ्कटास्तैरङ्कितैर्वर्ष्मभिर्देहैर्हेतुभिर्विवृताः प्रकाशिता वैकृतोर्मयो विकृत्युल्लासा यैः । सपङ्कस्य च स्नानमुचितम् ॥
column7: Displaying wave after wave of odd mannerisms with their bodies that were covered in slush-like black armours, they marched forth, keen to take a plunge in the shimmering, stream-like edges of the enemy's circular array of swords.
column8: It is appropriate for those covered in slush to take a plunge in water; poets describe the shimmering edge of swords as containing water (JR).

column4: गाढपाटलविलोचनाञ्चिता सा चमूररुचदग्रयायिनी । बिभ्रती तुलितलोहया त्विषा कोपपावकहसन्तिकालिपिम् ॥ ४३ ॥
column5: gāḍhapāṭalavilocanāñcitā sā camūrarucadagrayāyinī | bibhratī tulitalohayā tviṣā kopapāvakahasantikālipim || 43 ||
column6: रोषवशाद्गाढपाटलैर्विलोचनैः सा चमूररुचद्दिदीपे । अतः सम्भाव्यते- विडम्बितशस्त्रया भासा हेतुभूतया कोपाग्नेरङ्गारशकटिकासाम्यं दधती। सा हि लोहमयी सच्छिद्रा च भवति । लिपिः सादृश्यम्॥
column7: Due to its iron-black lustre, the marching Asura army, interspersed with bloodshot eyes, put on the semblance of a Hasantika basket pregnant with the fire of anger.
column8: See footnote under 3.29 for 'hasantikā'

column4: पृष्ठनिष्ठबहुतूणपङ्क्त​यस्तेऽरयो मखलिहां चकाशिरे । प्रस्थितौ यमपुरे पुरः पुरामुद्गता दुरितभारिका इव ॥ ४४ ॥
column5: pṛṣṭhaniṣṭhabahutūṇapatayaste'rayo makhalihāṃ cakāśire | prasthitau yamapure puraḥ purāmudgatā duritabhārikā iva || 44 ||
column6: पृष्ठे निष्ठा यासां ता बहवस्तूणपङ्क्तयो निषङ्गमाला येषां ते दैत्या दिदीपिरे । अतः सम्भाव्यते - पुरां यमपुरे विषये प्रस्थितौ पुरः पूर्वं निर्गताः पापभारिका इव ॥
column7: As the Puras marched towards Death’s Capital, the Asuras in the vanguard, with many rows of quivers strapped to their backs, looked like porters carrying the baggage of (their own) wicked actions.
column8: N/A

column4: चित्ररत्नवलयांशुशारितैः कार्मुकैर्ददृशिरेऽमरद्रुहः । भीतितो दितिजभावनिह्नवं कर्तुमात्तविविधायुधा इव ॥ ४५ ॥
column5: citraratnavalayāṃśuśāritaiḥ kārmukairdadṛśire'maradruhaḥ | bhītito ditijabhāvanihnavaṃ kartumāttavividhāyudhā iva || 45 ||
column6: मारणभीत्या दैत्यभावच्छादनं कर्तुं गृहीतनानाविधायुधा इव दैत्या जनेन दृष्टाः । के: करणैः । मणिकङ्कणकिरणैश्चित्रितैश्चापैः ॥
column7: The Asuras, whose bows were overspread with the rays of their multihued gem-studded armlets, seemed to be carrying different kinds of weapons so as to conceal their identity as Diti’s sons out of fear.
column8: The colourful bows appeared like different kinds of strange weapons, thus masking the real identity of the Asuras carrying them.

column4: ते परस्परविमर्दनिर्दयत्रुट्यदङ्गदमणीरितैः कणैः । सैन्यरेणुजलदच्छटोदये ज्योतिरिङ्गणगणानदीदृशन् ॥ ४६ ॥
column5: te parasparavimardanirdayatruṭyadaṅgadamaṇīritaiḥ kaṇaiḥ | sainyareṇujaladacchaṭodaye jyotiriṅgaṇagaṇānadīdṛśan || 46 ||
column6: रणरसेनाहंपूर्विकयान्योन्यं यो विमर्दस्तेन निर्दयं त्रुट्यद्भयो बाहुभूषणमणिभ्य ईरितैर्नि:सृतैः कणैर्हेतुभिस्ते दैत्या ज्योतिरिङ्गणगणान्खद्योतानिवादर्शयन् । कदा । सैन्यरेणुमेघमालोदये । प्रावृष्येव हि खद्योतैर्भाव्यम् । अदीदृशन्निति 'उरत्' इत्यकारः ॥
column7: Due to the glistening powder rained down by the gems of their armlets, which broke asunder when they jostled against one another, the Asuras seemed to conjure up a spectacle of glow worms to mark the advent of the army’s dust clouds.
column8: Glow worms are seen in the rainy season (JR).

column4: उपनतवति मृत्युनोपरोधे कटकरजोजवजन्यमानबाष्पैः । प्रतिपदमविदूरवंशनाशैः स्वयमिव तैरवशं भयादरोदि ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: upanatavati mṛtyunoparodhe kaṭakarajojavajanyamānabāṣpaiḥ | pratipadamavidūravaṃśanāśaiḥ svayamiva tairavaśaṃ bhayādarodi || 47 ||
column6: सैन्यरजसा जवेन जन्यमानमुत्पाद्यमानं बाष्पमस्रं येषां तैः । स्वयमप्रेरितैरिव तैररोदि । जनितेऽजनितत्वमुत्प्रेक्ष्यते । अत्र हेतु: - यमेन कर्त्रा उपरोधे प्राप्तवति सति । प्रतिस्थानमविदूरेऽचिरेण वंशनाशो येषां तैः ॥
column7: As the dust that was shaken up by the army brought a gush of tears to their eyes, the Asuras seemed to be crying spontaneously and without control at each and every step in anticipation of their race’s utter ruin, to be wrought soon by Death’s impending assault.
column8: N/A

column4: ते गाढगाढघटमानपटुप्रकोप-रज्यद्विलोचनरुचो दिविषद्विपक्षाः । हृष्यत्कृतान्तपुरनिर्भरकीर्यमाण-सिन्दूररेणुसचिवा इव चक्रुराशाः ॥ ४८ ॥
column5: te gāḍhagāḍhaghaṭamānapaṭuprakopa-rajyadvilocanaruco diviṣadvipakṣāḥ | hṛṣyatkṛtāntapuranirbharakīryamāṇa-sindūrareṇusacivā iva cakrurāśāḥ || 48 ||
column6: गाढगाढं भृशं घटमानेन रोषेण रज्यन्ती रक्ता सम्पद्यमाना नेत्रकान्तिर्येषां ते सुरद्विषो दिशो भाविसंहारोत्सववशाद्धृष्यद्यत्कृतान्तपुरं तेन निर्भरं कीर्यमाणेन सिन्दूररजसा सहिता इव व्यधुः । हर्षे सिन्दूरप्रक्षेप आचारः ॥
column7: Thanks to the Asuras, whose eyes were glowing red due to their association with an ever-deepening rage, the directions appeared to be bathed in the vermillion powder that was strewn around in large quantities by Yama’s jubilant city.
column8: Vermillion powder is strewn around in joyous occasions (JR).

column4: चञ्चच्चमूभररजोहठलिप्यमान-धुर्याक्षकूबरयुगा युगपत्तदानीम् । ते स्यन्दनीकृतधरं गिरिशं विजेतुं दैत्या रथं स्वमिव पार्थिवतामनेषुः ॥ ४९ ॥
column5: cañcaccamūbhararajohaṭhalipyamāna-dhuryākṣakūbarayugā yugapattadānīm | te syandanīkṛtadharaṃ giriśaṃ vijetuṃ daityā rathaṃ svamiva pārthivatāmaneṣuḥ || 49 ||
column6: स्फुरत्कटकरेणुना हठेन लिप्यमाना धुर्या वाजिनः, अक्षा नाभिकाष्ठम् , कूबरो युगधरः, युगं च येषां ते दैत्या निजरथं पृथिवीमयतामिवानैषुः । अत्र हेतु: - रथीकृतभूमिं गिरिशं जेतुम् ॥
column7: Presently, the Asuras’ horses, axles, draught poles, and yokes were thickly smeared with the army’s dust, so it seemed they were simultaneously endowing their own chariots with an earth-like quality for gaining victory over Shiva, who had made the earth his chariot.
column8: N/A

column4: निर्गच्छतो निजपुराद्दितिजव्रजस्य काकावली ककुभमभ्यचिनोदुदीचीम् । तस्य प्रवेशविधये स्वदिशो यमेन प्रोत्सारिता विवृतमार्गमयोर्गलेव ॥ ५० ॥
column5: nirgacchato nijapurādditijavrajasya kākāvalī kakubhamabhyacinodudīcīm | tasya praveśavidhaye svadiśo yamena protsāritā vivṛtamārgamayorgaleva || 50 ||
column6: निजपुरात्प्रस्थानसञ्जस्य दैत्यकुलस्य वामां दिशं काकपङ्क्तिरर्थाद्वाशितैरव्यथयत् । तस्य दैत्यकुलस्य विस्तीर्णमार्गं कृत्वा दक्षिणदिशि प्रवेशार्थं यमेन वारिता शस्त्रार्गलेव ॥
column7: As the Asura horde emerged out of its city, a row of crows gathered in the northern direction as if Death had thrown open the iron bolt of his direction (i.e., the South) and cleared the way for its (i.e., the horde’s) entry.
column8: The row of black crows is likened to an iron bolt. Yama, the god of death, presides over the southern direction.

column4: चक्रन्द दुन्दुभिरवैरवशं रुरोद विस्तारिभिः करटिनां करसीकरौघैः । तेषां चमूरभिनवोपनतक्षयानां(णां) दुःखोचितं किमिव नासकृदाचचार ॥ ५१ ॥
column5: cakranda dundubhiravairavaśaṃ ruroda vistāribhiḥ karaṭināṃ karasīkaraughaiḥ | teṣāṃ camūrabhinavopanatakṣayāṇāṃ duḥkhocitaṃ kimiva nāsakṛdācacāra || 51 ||
column6: अपूर्वोपनतमरणानां तेषां सेना शोकयोग्यं किमिव न चकार । सा पटहशब्दैः क्रन्दितवती । हस्तिनां करजलकणै रोदितवती । अमङ्गलपरम्परादर्शनात् । स्वकृतं मङ्गलावहमप्यमङ्गलावहमेव सम्भावितमित्यर्थः ॥
column7: It wailed aloud by way of drumbeats and shed tears through long jets of water ejected from the trunks of elephants; close to death as never before, the Army of the Asuras repeatedly expressed its sorrow in every possible way.
column8: N/A

column4: किञ्चिन्निमीलदलसालसनेत्रतन्द्रागर्वाद्वपुश्च शिथिलाकुलमावहन्तः । मध्येऽरिशस्त्रशयनीयमदूरदीर्घ-निद्रारसत्वमिव ते बहुशः शशंसुः ॥ ५२ ॥
column5: kiñcinnimīladalasālasanetratandrāgarvādvapuśca śithilākulamāvahantaḥ | madhye'riśastraśayanīyamadūradīrgha-nidrārasatvamiva te bahuśaḥ śaśaṃsuḥ || 52 ||
column6: गर्वान्निमीलन्नेत्रत्वाच्छरीरं शिथिलं चात एव वहन्तो दैत्या रिपुशस्त्रशय्यायां विषयभूतायां दीर्घनिद्रायां रसो यस्य तद्भावमिव सूचितवन्तः । गर्वनिद्रयोर्ध​र्मसाम्यादुत्प्रेक्षोत्थानम् । निद्रावसरे च नेत्रसङ्कोचशैथिल्यादयो भवन्ति ॥
column7: Their heavily languid eyes closing partially and slackened bodies assuming awkward postures in pride, the Asuras seemed to indicate their preparedness for the long-drawn sleep of death, which they would enjoy shortly on a bed of the enemy’s missiles.
column8: One shuts one’s eyes and assumes awkward postures in pride and drowsiness alike (JR).

column4: हन्मश्चेत्समरेऽमर​व्रजमथो हन्यामहे तेन वा द्यामासाद्य पदं रतेरुभयथाप्येतद्वधूराप्नुमः । ध्यायं ध्यायमिति प्रकामविकसच्छृङ्गारवीरोर्मयः केचित्तत्र सुरारयो बहुरयोत्साहोदयं निर्ययुः ॥ ५३ ॥
column5: hanmaścetsamare'maravrajamatho hanyāmahe tena vā dyāmāsādya padaṃ raterubhayathāpyetadvadhūrāpnumaḥ | dhyāyaṃ dhyāyamiti prakāmavikasacchṛṅgāravīrormayaḥ kecittatra surārayo bahurayotsāhodayaṃ niryayuḥ || 53 ||
column6: मारणमरणयोरन्यतरदवश्यं भावि भटानामिति निश्चयः । अतो रणे वयं देवसमूहं चेन्मारयामस्तदा जीवन्त एव स्वर्गं प्राप्य रतिस्थानमप्सरसः प्राप्नुमः । अथ तेन देवसमूहेन वयं मार्यामहे तदाप्यप्सरस एव वयं प्राप्नुम इति च स्मृत्वा विकसन्तः शृङ्गाररसोर्मयो येषां ते केचिद्दैत्याः शीघ्रं गृहान्निर्जग्मुः ॥
column7: 'Either we exterminate the army of the Devas in battle or are exterminated by it. Either way, we will reach heaven and make our enemy’s beloved women ours” - thinking repeatedly in this manner, some Asuras rushed out of their abode with redoubled energy, ripples of lustful desire and martial spirit surging strongly within.
column8: It is believed that warriors killed in battle reach heaven (see footnote under 21.24)

column4: उद्यद्भिर्विषसीकरैर्वृतमुखास्तद्वाहिनीदन्तिना-माक्रान्तेऽम्बरवर्त्मनि प्रकटितावर्ताः करा रेजिरे । दैत्याकर्षणकेलिसम्भ्रमरुषां मृत्योर्भटानामिव व्यक्ताः पाशमहोरगास्तत इतो व्यावल्गितुं प्रस्तुताः ॥ ५४ ॥
column5: udyadbhirviṣasīkarairvṛtamukhāstadvāhinīdantinā-mākrānte'mbaravartmani prakaṭitāvartāḥ karā rejire | daityākarṣaṇakelisambhramaruṣāṃ mṛtyorbhaṭānāmiva vyaktāḥ pāśamahoragāstata ito vyāvalgituṃ prastutāḥ || 54 ||
column6: विषं जलं च । तत्कणैर्वृतमुखाः, तथा व्यक्तावर्ताः, तत्सेनाहस्तिनां हस्ताः शुशुभिरे । अत: सम्भाव्यते - दैत्याकर्षिणां पाशसर्पा इव । तेऽपि सविषाः सावर्ताश्च भवन्ति ।
column7: Their tips/mouths spattered with drops of water/venom, the trunks of elephants whirled around in mid-air like the large, striped serpents in the nooses of Yama’s warrior servants, who were intent on the sport of ensnaring the Asuras
column8: Elephants let out jets of water with the tips of their trunks.

column4: योद्धुं सार्धमधिज्यकार्मुकगणग्रामाण्यनीकैर्हठा-त्तान्निर्गन्तुमुदञ्चितोद्यमरसान्नाकेसदां वैरिणः । सम्भाव्यापुनरागमं परिणतौत्सुक्याज्जवोद्गत्वरैः स्वाः पुर्यः परिरेभिरे मणिदृषद्भित्तिप्रभाबाहुभिः ॥ ५४ ॥
column5: yoddhuṃ sārdhamadhijyakārmukagaṇagrāmāṇyanīkairhaṭhā-ttānnirgantumudañcitodyamarasānnākesadāṃ vairiṇaḥ | sambhāvyāpunarāgamaṃ pariṇatautsukyājjavodgatvaraiḥ svāḥ puryaḥ parirebhire maṇidṛṣadbhittiprabhābāhubhiḥ || 54 ||
column6: कटकैः सार्धं युद्धाय निर्गन्तुं सरसानसुरान्निजनगर्यो रत्नभित्तिप्रभाभुजैः करणैरालिलिङ्गिरे । यतोऽपुनरागमं मत्वा सोत्कण्ठाः ॥
column7: As the enemies of the heaven-dwelling gods marched out in the spirit of preparedness to wage a war with the armies of the Lord of the Ganas (i.e., Shiva), whose bow had been strung up, the Cities, apprehending that they may not return back, gave them a quick, nostalgic hug with the outstretched arms of the rays radiating from their bejewelled walls.
column8: N/A

column4: निर्गच्छत्सु प्रियेषु प्रधनविधिधिया दानवेन्दीवराक्ष्य-स्त्रासस्वेदापनीतैः कुचमुकुलतटास्कन्दिबाह्लीकपङ्कैः । उत्तंसैः स्रंसमानैरथ पृथुविकसद्वेपथूद्वेगयोगा-दूहुः प्रागेव गात्रं दधदिव नियतादूरवैधव्यचिह्नम् ॥ ५६ ॥
column5: nirgacchatsu priyeṣu pradhanavidhidhiyā dānavendīvarākṣya-strāsasvedāpanītaiḥ kucamukulataṭāskandibāhlīkapaṅkaiḥ | uttaṃsaiḥ sraṃsamānairatha pṛthuvikasadvepathūdvegayogā-dūhuḥ prāgeva gātraṃ dadhadiva niyatādūravaidhavyacihnam || 56 ||
column6: विधवत्वलक्षणं दधदिव शरीरं दानवस्त्रियो भर्तृवधात्पूर्वमेव दधुः। रणचिकीर्षया वल्लभेषु निष्क्रामत्सु भयजातस्वेदगलितैः स्तनकुङ्कुमैस्तथा कम्पवशात्पतितैर्भूषणैश्च हेतुभिः ॥
column7: The saffron designs over their budded breasts washed away by the sweat of trepidation and their ear ornaments slipping away due to the ever-increasing tremors of anxiety, the dark-eyed Danava damsels seemed to already exhibit the signs of an imminent, fast-approaching widowhood on their limbs the moment their lovers set out with an intent to fight in the battle.
column8: Similar to the idea expressed in 21.50.

column4: दर्शं दर्शं सुराणां कटकमभिविशत्ताः पुरीर्मुक्तशङ्कं सातङ्कान्तःपुरस्त्रीजनजनितघनाक्रन्दवाचालशालाः । गीर्वाणद्वेषिणस्ते हठकठिननवक्रोधदष्टौष्ठरक्तै-र्वक्त्रैरापीतपूर्वं नियतमुदवमन्वैरिवीरप्रतापम् ॥ ५७ ॥
column5: darśaṃ darśaṃ surāṇāṃ kaṭakamabhiviśattāḥ purīrmuktaśaṅkaṃ sātaṅkāntaḥpurastrījanajanitaghanākrandavācālaśālāḥ | gīrvāṇadveṣiṇaste haṭhakaṭhinanavakrodhadaṣṭauṣṭharaktai-rvaktrairāpītapūrvaṃ niyatamudavamanvairivīrapratāpam || 57 ||
column6: निःशङ्कं ता नगरीः प्रविशमानं देवसैन्यं दृष्ट्वा दृष्ट्वा सदुःखाभिः पुरस्त्रीभिः कृतेन क्रुष्टेन सशब्दगृहास्ते दैत्या रोषदष्टौष्ठारुणैर्मुखैर्हेतुभिर्नूनं पीतपूर्वं शत्रुप्रतापमुदगिरन् । वमनं च सशब्दं भवति॥
column7: Their mansions resounding with the loud cries of distressed harem ladies, the Asuras seemed to vomit out of their mouths the enemy’s fiery energy, which they had drunk in previously, through the blood dripping from their lips that were bitten by them in exceptional and unrelentingly intense anger as they continuously watched the army of the Devas enter the Cities without apprehension.
column8: Vomiting is accompanied by sound (here, the louds cries of womenfolk) (JR).

column4: अन्योन्यं ते ध्वजिन्यावथ सुरदनुजाधिष्ठिते सौष्ठवेन श्लिष्यन्त्यौ फेनपिण्डोपमविधृतसितच्छत्रपालीकराले । स्वीचक्राते प्रसर्पत्पटुपटहरवारभ्यमाणोर्मिघोष-स्फारेणानल्पकल्पात्ययसमयमिलत्सागरद्वन्द्वलीलाम् ॥ ५८ ॥
column5: anyonyaṃ te dhvajinyāvatha suradanujādhiṣṭhite sauṣṭhavena śliṣyantyau phenapiṇḍopamavidhṛtasitacchatrapālīkarāle | svīcakrāte prasarpatpaṭupaṭaharavārabhyamāṇormighoṣa-sphāreṇānalpakalpātyayasamayamilatsāgaradvandvalīlām || 58 ||
column6: फेनपिण्डसदृशश्वेतच्छत्रपङ्क्तिसहिते तथा बलेन मिलन्त्यौ ते सेने भेरीशङ्खशब्दभरेण हेतुना कल्पान्तकालमिलत्सागरद्वयशोभां जगृहतुरिति भद्रम् ॥
column7: As they mutually collided, the armies of the Devas and the Asuras, interspersed with rows of upraised umbrellas standing for balls of foam and resonating with the loud din of drums as with the roar of waves, put on the semblance of  two vast oceans mingling with one another at the time of universal annihilation.
column8: N/A

column4: इति श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराजमहाराजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये दैत्यपुरीक्षोभवर्णनं नाम द्वाविंशः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirājamahārājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye daityapurīkṣobhavarṇanaṃ nāma dvāviṃśaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Twenty-second Canto, named 'Description of the Commotion in the Cities of the Asuras', in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja.

column4: त्रयोविंशः सर्गः ॥
column7: Twenty-third Canto
column8: N/A

column4: समघटत पताकिनीयुगं तदथ मिथः प्रथमानय(म​)त्सरैः। द्युसदसुरभटैर्मदोत्कटैः प्रकटितदुर्धरसङ्गरक्रियम् ॥ १ ॥
column5: samaghaṭata patākinīyugaṃ tadatha mithaḥ prathamānaya(ma)tsaraiḥ| dyusadasurabhaṭairmadotkaṭaiḥ prakaṭitadurdharasaṅgarakriyam || 1 ||
column6: मदोत्कटैः सुरासुरभटैरन्योन्यं प्रकटिता दुर्धरा सङ्गरक्रिया करणं यत्र एवं कृत्वा तत्सेनाद्वयं समगंस्त ॥
column7: And so, as the two armies clashed with one another, a fierce battle ensued between the wildly excited Deva and Asura warriors, whose intolerance for one another kept growing by the moment.
column8: N/A

column4: मणिसखयमपाशपन्नगस्फुटफणविभ्रमसख्यचञ्चवः । परिणमदहिमांशुमण्डला विबभुरकोषकृपाणयष्टयः ॥ २ ॥
column5: maṇisakhayamapāśapannagasphuṭaphaṇavibhramasakhyacañcavaḥ | pariṇamadahimāṃśumaṇḍalā vibabhurakoṣakṛpāṇayaṣṭayaḥ || 2 ||
column6: परिणमत्प्रतिबिम्बसङ्क्रान्तमहिमांशोरादित्यस्य मण्डलं यासु ता विकोषाः कोषाकृष्टा: खड्गलता विबभुः । अत उत्प्रेक्षते - मणिसखा मणिसहिता यमपाशसर्पफणा इति विभ्रमो विशिष्टो भ्रमस्तत्सख्येन ख्याताः । अथवा फणाविलाससादृश्येन ख्याताः । 'कालपन्नग' इति वा पाठः । कालाः कृष्णाः ॥
column7: Unsheathed sword blades, which mirrored the sun’s orb, looked like the bejewelled, expanded hoods of Death’s serpent noose.
column8: The reflection of the sun’s orb is likened to the gem adorning the serpent’s hood. JR suggests ‘kālapannaga’ (‘black cobra’) as an alternative reading for ‘pāśapannaga’ (‘serpent noose’).

column4: अशुभपिशुननिःसरद्घ​नश्रमजलसिक्तशराः सुरद्रुहः । हरमनलशरं जिगीषवो दधुरिव कल्पितवारुणेषुताम् ॥ ३ ॥
column5: aśubhapiśunaniḥsaradghanaśramajalasiktaśarāḥ suradruhaḥ | haramanalaśaraṃ jigīṣavo dadhuriva kalpitavāruṇeṣutām || 3 ||
column6: वीरैर्विजितश्रमैर्भवितव्यमित्यशुभस्यामङ्गलस्य पिशुनं सूचकं निःसरद्घ​नं यच्छ्रमजलं तेन सिक्ताः शरा येषां ते दैत्याः कल्पितो वारुणो वरुणमन्त्रसंस्कृत इषुः शरो यैस्तद्भावमिव दधुः । वरुणस्य जलदैवतत्वाज्जलशरतामिव दधुरित्यर्थः । किं कर्तुम् । अग्निशरं हरं जेतुम् । जलं ह्यग्रेर्विपक्षः ॥
column7: The Asuras, whose arrows were drenched with profusely pouring sweat, foreboding of the evil to come, seemed to wield arrows that were consecrated with Varuna’s divine chant for defeating the fire-arrowed Shiva.
column8: Since warriors are expected to overcome exertion, it is an evil omen if they are drenched in profuse sweat (‘śramajala’, literally ‘the water of exertion’). Since Varuna is the lord of waters and water puts out fire, a weapon consecrated with his chant could help the Asuras counter Shiva’s fire-laden missile (JR).

column4: शिखिमयवपुयो(षो)ऽग्रभाविनो विधृतभया विशिखापिनाकिनः । दिविषदसिसखे श्रियः पुरामचरममेव ममज्जुरम्भसि ॥ ४ ॥
column5: śikhimayavapuyo(ṣo)'grabhāvino vidhṛtabhayā viśikhāpinākinaḥ | diviṣadasisakhe śriyaḥ purāmacaramameva mamajjurambhasi || 4 ||
column6: भविष्यतोऽग्निरूपाद्धरस्य शराद्भीता इव त्रिपुरलक्ष्म्यः सुरखड्गधारावर्तिनि जले पूर्वमेव ममञ्जुः। भीतानां जले मज्जनं युक्तम् । विशेषतो वह्नेः॥
column7: Fearing Shiva’s fiery arrow that was blazing before them, the Fortunes of the Cities plunged beforehand, as it were, into the watery sheen of the gods’ swords.
column8: The purport is that the cities of the Asuras were deprived of their fortune; it is appropriate for someone running away from fire to jump into water (JR).

column4: अमरकटककिङ्करा मुखश्वसनविपूरिततूर्यचर्यया । अथ दधुरभिसृत्य मृत्यवे पुरबलभोजनकाहलामिव ॥ ५ ॥
column5: amarakaṭakakiṅkarā mukhaśvasanavipūritatūryacaryayā | atha dadhurabhisṛtya mṛtyave purabalabhojanakāhalāmiva || 5 ||
column6: अमरसेनादासा नि:श्वासपूरिततूर्यचरित्रेण यमायैत्य पू(पु)रकटकभक्षणे काहला भोजनाह्वनार्थस्तूर्यशब्दस्तामिव दधुः ॥
column7: By blowing the war trumpets with their breaths, the attendants in the celestial army invited Yama, or so it seemed, with a clarion call to feast on the forces of the Tripuras.
column8: N/A

column4: उपगतवति शङ्करे ततो भुवनगुरावुभयोरनीकयोः। धनुरनमदवाप मुक्ततामथ तु बताविनतोऽपि सायकः ॥ ६ ॥
column5: upagatavati śaṅkare tato bhuvanagurāvubhayoranīkayoḥ| dhanuranamadavāpa muktatāmatha tu batāvinato'pi sāyakaḥ || 6 ||
column6: भुवनेषु मध्ये गुरौ हरे समीपप्राप्ते सति देवासुरकटकयोर्धनुराकर्षणादनमत् । अनतस्तु शरो मोक्षं प्राप । महतो दृष्ट्वा सर्वो नमति । भयसम्भ्रमादनमंस्तु महतां प्रसादान्मुक्तिं लभते । गुरावाचार्ये च समीपप्राप्ते लोको नमति । आचार्यशक्तिपातात्कश्चिदनमन्नपि मोक्षं लभेत ॥
column7: When Shiva, the Master of the universe, arrived, the bows of both warring groups bowed down. Surprisingly though, the unyieldingly stiff arrows were the ones to get released.
column8: When a master arrives, people bow down to him in respect. The master, though, might not bestow ‘śaktipāta’ (‘divine grace’) on them but, surprisingly, on someone who doesn’t bow down before him. The word ‘muktatā’ (‘release’) is used in the dual senses of ‘release from the bow’ and ‘release from the cycle of birth and death’.

column4: सुरशरनिकरोऽम्बरेऽरुचज्जवचटुलोभयपक्षति भ्रमन् । उपनमदसुरास्रपारणामद इव दर्शितनृत्तविभ्रमः ॥ ७ ॥
column5: suraśaranikaro'mbare'rucajjavacaṭulobhayapakṣati bhraman | upanamadasurāsrapāraṇāmada iva darśitanṛttavibhramaḥ || 7 ||
column6: जवेन चटुले उभे पक्षती यत्र एवं कृत्वाम्बरे भ्रमन्नमरशरव्रातोऽरुचत् । अत उत्प्रेक्ष्यते - उपनमदसुररक्तपारणया मदो यस्य अत एव दर्शितनृत्यविलास इव । मत्तश्च नृत्यति । पक्षती बाहुस्थानीये । 'मुद' इति वा पाठः । हेतौ पञ्चमी । 'पक्षतिक्रमम्' इति वा पाठः ॥
column7: Their feathers rustling on both sides, the arrows of the gods whooshed through the sky, dancing, as it were, in joyous intoxication at the prospect of feasting on Asura blood.
column8: Intoxication may be accompanied by dancing; the feathers on either sides of the arrows stand for arms (JR). JR gives 'mudaḥ' ('due to the joy' - resulting from the anticipation of a feast) and 'pakṣatikramam' (forming part of an adverbial compound meaning 'with feathers rustling on both sides') as alternative readings for 'madaḥ' and 'pakṣati bhraman' respectively.

column4: समरतरुरनङ्कुशाङ्कुरः पुलकितमूर्तिरशेषदिक्ततिः। चिरमजनि शरैरितस्ततः प्रविसृमरैरमरेन्द्रवर्त्मनि ॥ ८ ॥
column5: samarataruranaṅkuśāṅkuraḥ pulakitamūrtiraśeṣadiktatiḥ| ciramajani śarairitastataḥ pravisṛmarairamarendravartmani || 8 ||
column6: दिवि प्रसरणशीलैः शरैरनङ्कुशा निर्निरोधा अङ्कुरा यस्य स रणद्रुमो जातः । सर्वदिपङ्क्ती रोमाञ्चितमूर्तिर्जाता । दिशां स्त्रीलिङ्गत्वात्स्त्रीत्वे रोमाञ्चितत्वोक्तिर्युक्ता ॥
column7: The tree of battle seemed to continuously put forth an exuberance of fresh leaves and the Directions appeared to be covered in bristles due to the arrows darting here and there through the air.
column8: Since the word ‘dik’ (‘direction’) is in the feminine gender, it is not improper to describe the directions as covered in bristles (JR).

column4: अपि कटकयुगे धनुष्मतामघटि परस्परमीरितैः शरैः । उरसि विवृतवीप्स​मप्सरःकुचमुकुलप्रणयाग्रदूतता ॥ ९ ॥
column5: api kaṭakayuge dhanuṣmatāmaghaṭi parasparamīritaiḥ śaraiḥ | urasi vivṛtavīpsamapsaraḥkucamukulapraṇayāgradūtatā || 9 ||
column6: अन्योन्यं प्रेरितैः शरैः सेनाद्वयवर्तिनां धानुष्काणां वक्षसि विवृता वीप्सा पौन:पुन्यं यत्र एवं कृत्वाप्सरसः स्तनकुड्म​लानां प्रणये परिचयेऽग्रदूतता पुरोदूत्यमघटि सम्पादिता । हृदि शरप्रवेशेन मरणाद्ध्रुवमप्सरसः प्राप्तिः । सैन्ययोर्मध्ये कोऽपि नापलायतेत्यर्थः॥
column7: The arrows that were directed at one another by the bowmen on both sides became messengers dispatched in advance to facilitate the union of their chests with the budding breasts of divine damsels.
column8: Since the arrows piercing the chests of warriors will kill them and since those killed in battle are believed to reach heaven and enjoy the company of celestial damsels, the poet likens them to messengers; the simple purport of the verse is that no one on either side of the warring factions ran away in fear (JR).

column4: मुखमकृत तथा परो रिपोर्विपुलविसारितमार्गणार्गलम् । श्वसितमरुदवाप नो यथा पुनरपि तत्र किल प्रवेशनम् ॥ १० ॥
column5: mukhamakṛta tathā paro riporvipulavisāritamārgaṇārgalam | śvasitamarudavāpa no yathā punarapi tatra kila praveśanam || 10 ||
column6: परो वैरी रिपोर्मुखं विपुला विसारिता मार्गण एवार्गला यस्य तत्तथाकरोद्यथा श्वसितमरुत्प्राणवायुस्तत्र पुनः प्रवेशनं नावाप । मरणं प्रापेत्यर्थः । पृथोरर्गलाया दाने च वायोरपि प्रवेशाभावः ॥
column7: Thus did one soldier latch the mouth of his opponent with an elongated arrow that his vital breaths couldn’t get in once again.
column8: A strong latch prevents the entry of even the wind; the expression ‘his vital breaths couldn’t get in once again’ is a roundabout way of saying ‘he died’ (JR).

column4: शरपटलविघट्टनोच्छलद्दहनशिखाकपटेन शस्त्रिणाम् । द्विषदसुविघसाय कङ्कटा अपि विकसद्रसना इवाबभुः ॥ ११ ॥
column5: śarapaṭalavighaṭṭanocchaladdahanaśikhākapaṭena śastriṇām | dviṣadasuvighasāya kaṅkaṭā api vikasadrasanā ivābabhuḥ || 11 ||
column6: शरभरेण विघट्टनयोल्लसन्तीनामग्निज्वालानां व्याजेन शस्त्रिणां कवचा अपि द्विषत्प्राणभक्षणार्थे [अपि] लोलमानजिह्वा इवाबभुः ॥
column7: Under the guise of the sparks emanating from them when they were hit by a volley of arrows, even the armours of the soldiers seemed to sport tongues stretched out for devouring the lives of enemies.
column8: N/A

column4: प्रवसदसुरथापरो रयादुरसि निमग्नमुखे शिलीमुखे । अजनि किल मुहूर्तविघ्नितत्रिदशवधूनिबिडावगूहनः ॥ १२ ॥
column5: pravasadasurathāparo rayādurasi nimagnamukhe śilīmukhe | ajani kila muhūrtavighnitatridaśavadhūnibiḍāvagūhanaḥ || 12 ||
column6: वेगाच्छरे वक्षसि प्रविष्टाग्रे सति प्रवसन्तो निर्यान्तोऽसवः प्राणा यस्य सोऽपि परो मुहूर्तं विघ्नितं जातविघ्नं त्रिदशवध्वा निबिडं कृत्वावगूहनमालिङ्गनं यस्य तथाजनि सम्पन्नः। वक्षसः शरान्तरितत्वात्क्षणमालिङ्गनविघ्नः ॥
column7: His chest pierced all of a sudden by the tip of an arrow, a certain dying soldier was momentarily prevented from enjoying the tight embrace of a celestial lady.
column8: The arrow sticking out from the warrior’s chest came in the way of a free embrace (JR).

column4: चतुरमसुरसायको मुखे गजवदनस्य कृतावरोहणः । पुनरपररदाङ्कुरोद्गमभ्रममपुषन्मुहुरीशचक्षुषाम् ॥ १३ ॥
column5: caturamasurasāyako mukhe gajavadanasya kṛtāvarohaṇaḥ | punarapararadāṅkurodgamabhramamapuṣanmuhurīśacakṣuṣām || 13 ||
column6: चतुरं कौशलवशादलक्षितं कृत्वा गणपतेर्मुखे शत्रुणा कृतमधिरोहणं प्रवेशनं यस्य सोऽसुरबाण ईशस्य दृष्टीनां भूयो द्वितीयस्य दशनाङ्कुरस्योत्पत्तिभ्रान्तिमकरोत् । ईशस्येश्वरस्यापि बहूनामपि दृष्टीनामितीशचक्षुषामित्यस्य ग्रहणम् ॥
column7: The arrow of an Asura alighted agilely on the face of Ganesha, fooling (even) Shiva’s (many) eyes into believing that his other tusk had sprouted once again.
column8: Īśacakṣuṣām’ is a poetically significant usage; since Ganesha fooled even the Supreme Lord's (‘īṣasya’) many eyes (‘cakṣuṣām’) into believing that his another tusk had sprouted once again (JR), it is obvious he would have easily fooled others.

column4: क्षणमसुरचमूमतङ्गजा द्विरदमुखस्य मदं विषेहिरे । वहनहरिमवेक्ष्य तस्य तु त्रुटितधृति त्वरितं विदुद्रुवुः ॥ १४ ॥
column5: kṣaṇamasuracamūmataṅgajā dviradamukhasya madaṃ viṣehire | vahanaharimavekṣya tasya tu truṭitadhṛti tvaritaṃ vidudruvuḥ || 14 ||
column6: दैत्यदन्तिनो दन्तिवदनस्य मदं क्षणं सोढवन्तः । मुखमात्रसाम्येन तत्पराक्रमसाम्यसम्भावनयेति भावः । अथ तस्य गणपतेर्वाहसिंहं दृष्ट्वा ते पलायिताः । सिंहस्य गजान्तकत्वात् ॥
column7: The elephants in the Asura army briefly put up with the elephant-headed God’s rut but ran helter-skelter, their confidence shattered, on seeing his lion mount.
column8: A rather unusual description of Ganesha riding a lion (One of the names of Ganesha given in the Ganeśasahasranāma, verse 12, is ‘siṃhavāhana’, with the commentary of Bhaskararaya mentioning that the lion is also the vehicle of Ganesha just as the mouse and peacock are – ‘mayūramūṣakau yadvattathā siṃho’pi vāhanam’); the elephants ran helter-skelter in fear because they saw an elephant riding a lion, whereas in the normal case lions are known to kill elephants (JR).

column4: उपनतसमरोत्सवग्रहादिव दधतः पटुचीनपिष्टताम् । विधृतनिबिडताण्डवः करे परशुरशोभत विघ्नविद्विषः ॥ १९ ॥
column5: upanatasamarotsavagrahādiva dadhataḥ paṭucīnapiṣṭatām | vidhṛtanibiḍatāṇḍavaḥ kare paraśuraśobhata vighnavidviṣaḥ || 19 ||
column6: उपनतः प्राप्तो यः सङ्ग्रामोत्सवस्तद्ग्रहाद्धेतोरिव पटु बहुलं चीनपिष्टं सिन्दूरो यस्य तद्भावं दधतो गणपतेः करे परशुरायुधविशेषो विधृतं निबिडं ताण्डवं नानाविधं स्फुरणं येन सोऽशोभत । उत्सवे सिन्दूरस्ताण्डवं चोचितम् ॥
column7: A wildly dancing battle axe shone in the hand of Ganesha, the remover of obstacles, who was smeared with vermillion to commemorate, as it were, the festive occasion of war.
column8: Festivities are accompanied by dance (here, of the battle axe) and the smearing of vermillion (JR).

column4: विशिखकुसुमवृष्टिभिः पुरः करिवदनोऽञ्चितचर्चमर्चताम् । मिहिरसुतपुरप्रवेशने व्यतनुत विघ्नहतिं धनुष्मताम् ॥ १६ ॥
column5: viśikhakusumavṛṣṭibhiḥ puraḥ karivadano'ñcitacarcamarcatām | mihirasutapurapraveśane vyatanuta vighnahatiṃ dhanuṣmatām || 16 ||
column6: विशिखाः शरा एव कुसुमवृष्टयस्ताभिरर्चतां पूजतां धानुष्काणां मिहिरसुतपुरप्रवेशने यमनगरप्रवेशे विघ्नानां हतिं हननं गणपतिरकरोत् । निर्विलम्बं शत्रूनवधीदित्यर्थः॥
column7: Ganesha granted the bowmen in front of him a hurdle-free entry into Death’s metropolis when they worshipped him with a shower of arrows, standing for flowers, and smeared him (with blood).
column8: Ganesha removes the hurdles of those who worship him.

column4: द्विरदनवदने जिगीषया विषमतमात्तबृहन्मदोद्गमाः। उपरि करटसङ्कटानना दितिजभटाः सहसैव जझिरे ॥ १७ ॥
column5: dviradanavadane jigīṣayā viṣamatamāttabṛhanmadodgamāḥ| upari karaṭasaṅkaṭānanā ditijabhaṭāḥ sahasaiva jajhire || 17 ||
column6: गणपतौ जिगीषया दैत्यभटा विषमतमोऽनन्यसामान्य आत्तो गृहीतो मदोद्गमो दर्पोत्पत्तिर्यैः । अतोऽमङ्गलसूचनार्थमुपरि करटैः काकैः सङ्कटमुखा जाताः। महद्भिः सह विरोधेऽन्येषामवश्यपराभवनीयत्वात् । अथवा जिगीषयेति प्रतीयमानहेतूत्प्रेक्षा । गणपतेर्हि मदो दानम्। करटो गजगण्डः । गणपतिं प्रति प्रतिपक्षतया तद्रूपाभावापत्त्यध्यवसायः॥
column7: Exuding excessive, unprecedented pride/ichor and thronged by crows/endowed with bulky frontal globes overhead, the Asura warriors seemed intent on challenging the elephant-faced Ganesha.
column8: The Asuras challenged Ganesha by mimicking his appearance.

column4: हठकठिनविटङ्ककीकसस्खलितनिशातविपक्षसायकम् । कवचपरिचयानपेक्षतामभजत भृङ्गिरिटेरहो वपुः ॥ १८ ॥
column5: haṭhakaṭhinaviṭaṅkakīkasaskhalitaniśātavipakṣasāyakam | kavacaparicayānapekṣatāmabhajata bhṛṅgiriṭeraho vapuḥ || 18 ||
column6: भृङ्गिरिटेर्गणविशेषस्य वपुर्देहः कवचग्रहणानपेक्षतामपेक्षारहितत्वमभजत । यतो हठेनातिमात्रं कठिनानि विटङ्कान्युन्नतानि कीकसान्यस्थीनि तेभ्यः स्खलिता निशितास्तीक्ष्णा अपि शत्रुशरा यत्र तत् । कीकसैरेव कङ्कटकृत्यस्य शरनिवारणस्य सम्पादनात् । देव्यवगणनाद्धि भृङ्गिरिटिरस्थिमात्रशरीरः ॥
column7: Surprisingly, Bhrngiriti’s body needed no armour since the enemy’s sharp arrows fell off after hitting his unrelentingly hard and protruding bones.
column8: Bhrngiriti (also known as Bhrngi) lost all his flesh and was reduced to bones as a result of disrespecting Parvati (JR) by creating a false dichotomy between Shiva and her (‘bhedabuddhyā bravīṣi me | - - - bhṛṅgiṇoktaṃ tiraskṛtya tadā śāpaṃ dadau satī | nirmāṃso bhava re manda re bhṛṅgin - - - || (Skanda Purāṇa, Māheśvarakhaṇḍa, Kedārakhaṇḍa, 34.19-21)

column4: प्रतिकटकभटान्विशङ्कटप्रविसरदायुधमुक्तियुक्तिभिः । चतुरमुपनयन्कबन्धतामतनुत तण्डुरखण्डताण्डवम् ॥ १९ ॥
column5: pratikaṭakabhaṭānviśaṅkaṭapravisaradāyudhamuktiyuktibhiḥ | caturamupanayankabandhatāmatanuta taṇḍurakhaṇḍatāṇḍavam || 19 ||
column6: विशङ्कटानि विशृङ्खलानि प्रविसरन्ति स्फुरन्ति यान्यायुधानि तन्मुक्तौ युक्तिभिः शत्रुसेनाभटान्कबन्धतामपशिरस्त्वं नयंस्तण्डुर्गणविशेषोऽखण्डमविकलं ताण्डवं विस्तारितवान् ॥
column7: With his skilful discharge of wildly flying missiles, Tandu reduced the enemy’s soldiers to headless trunks and orchestrated their uninterrupted Tandava dance.
column8: The Tāṇḍava dance owes its name to Tandu, who taught it first (‘taṇḍunā proktaṃ tāṇḍavam’, Kshirasvami’s , quotation in Vācaspatya).

column4: चलकरयुगलक्रमाहतद्विपकरटद्वितयेन नन्दिना । किमु मुरजमवाद्यताग्रतः शशिशिरसो रणरङ्गनर्तने ॥ २० ॥
column5: calakarayugalakramāhatadvipakaraṭadvitayena nandinā | kimu murajamavādyatāgrataḥ śaśiśiraso raṇaraṅganartane || 20 ||
column6: हर्षवशात्करतलद्वयेन क्रमेणाहतं द्विपसम्बन्धि करटद्वितयं गण्डद्वयं येन तेन नन्दिना हरस्य रणरङ्गे यन्नर्तनं नानाक्रियाकरणं तत्र मुरजं किं वादितम् । नर्तने हि मुरजवादनमुचितम् ॥
column7: By striking the frontal globes of elephants with his lively hands, did Nandi play the drum before Shiva as the latter danced spiritedly on the battlefield’s playhouse?
column8: Nandi beats the drum in Shiva’s dance (see footnote under 18.52).

column4: चतुरतरतया निरस्य तानरिविशिखानखिलानितस्ततः । प्रकटिततनुरग्निभूरभूच्छरवणतः पुनरुद्भवन्निव ॥ २१ ॥
column5: caturataratayā nirasya tānariviśikhānakhilānitastataḥ | prakaṭitatanuragnibhūrabhūccharavaṇataḥ punarudbhavanniva || 21 ||
column6: इतस्ततः शत्रुशरांश्चातुर्येण निवार्य प्रकटितमूर्तिः कुमारः शरवणात्पुनरुद्भवन्निवासीत् । शरजन्मा हि कुमारः ॥
column7: Cleverly scattering away all of the enemy’s arrows in different directions, Kumara seemed to arise once again from the forest of reeds as his body emerged into view.
column8: Skanda was born from a forest of reeds (śara), wherefore he is also known as ‘Śarajanmā’ (‘etasminnantare devyaḥ kṛttikāḥ ṣaṭsutejasaH | dadṛśuḥ svecchayā yantyo bālaṃ śaravaṇe sthitam || - - - yatra skandaḥ sthito’bhavat |, Vāmana Purāṇa, 57.22,23)

column4: पतितमधिकबन्धमुच्छ(?त्फ​)लच्छकलितदन्तितनूद्गतं शिरः । अधिदितिजबलं प्रनर्तनैरपरगणाधिपसंशयं दधौ ॥ २२ ॥
column5: patitamadhikabandhamuccha(?tpha)lacchakalitadantitanūdgataṃ śiraḥ | adhiditijabalaṃ pranartanairaparagaṇādhipasaṃśayaṃ dadhau || 22 ||
column6: पतितं ततो दैत्यसेनायामधिकबन्धं कबन्धोपरि उत्फलत्सत् कृत्तहस्तिशरीरोत्थितं शिरो द्वितीयगजमुखभ्रान्तिमधात् ॥
column7: The head of an elephant, whose body was cut off, bounced up and landed on a headless trunk in the Asura army, thus creating the illusion of a second Ganesha with its wobbling movements.
column8: N/A

column4: श्रवणपुटविवर्तनानिलक्रममुखरश्रुतिकम्बुचुम्बितः । द्विरदनवदनस्य पप्रथे स्वयमसकृज्जयशङ्खवादनम् ॥ २३ ॥
column5: śravaṇapuṭavivartanānilakramamukharaśrutikambucumbitaḥ | dviradanavadanasya paprathe svayamasakṛjjayaśaṅkhavādanam || 23 ||
column6: श्रवणपुटयोर्विवर्तनं धूननं तेनानिलस्तेन करणेन क्रमेण मुखराश्च ये श्रुतिशङ्खास्तच्चुम्बिनः शङ्खधारिणो गजमुखस्य बहुशः स्वयं जयशङ्खवादनं सिद्धम् । जये सति शङ्खो वाद्यत इत्याचारः ॥
column7: Ganesha effortlessly accomplished the continuous blowing of his victory conch since he wore for his ear ornaments conches that were made sequentially noisy by the gush of wind resulting from the flapping of his ears.
column8: Conches are blown to communicate victory (JR). Elephants are adorned with conches (see footnote under 10.50).

column4: प्रतिमिततनुरग्निजन्मनो व्यरुचदसौ तडिदुज्ज्वलासृजि । नवमुदिरधिया ससम्भ्रमं कृतपरिरम्भ इवाङ्कबर्हिणः ॥ २४ ॥
column5: pratimitatanuragnijanmano vyarucadasau taḍidujjvalāsṛji | navamudiradhiyā sasambhramaṃ kṛtaparirambha ivāṅkabarhiṇaḥ || 24 ||
column6: तडिद्वदुज्ज्वलं सशोभमसृग्यस्य तस्मिन्नसौ खड्गे प्रतिबिम्बितोऽङ्कबर्हिणो लाञ्छनमयूरो व्यरुचत् । नवो मुदिरो मेघ इति बुद्ध्या कृतालिङ्गन इव । मेघश्च श्यामो विद्युत्वांश्च ॥
column7: Kumara’s peacock emblem, reflected in his sword, which was streaked with blood the colour of a lightning flash, seemed to zealously embrace it by mistaking it for a fresh cloud.
column8: The sword and the blood streaking it resemble a cloud and its lightning flash respectively.

column4: झटिति विरचितेऽसिलेखया पुलकभृता हठतो गलग्रहे । असमशरनिपीडनाकुलः सुभटजनो दृढरक्ततामगात् ॥ २५ ॥
column5: jhaṭiti viracite'silekhayā pulakabhṛtā haṭhato galagrahe | asamaśaranipīḍanākulaḥ subhaṭajano dṛḍharaktatāmagāt || 25 ||
column6: पुलकं गुणविशेषं रोमाञ्चं च बिभर्ति तया खड्गलतया नायिकास्थानीयया मारणनिमित्ते रागप्रयुक्ते च गलग्रहे सति सुभटलोकोऽसमैः शरैरसमशरेण कामेन च पीडितः सन् दृढरक्ततां घनरुधिरत्वमभिषङ्गवत्त्वं चागमत् ॥
column7: As soon as a slender Sword, characterized by the purity of its metal/horripilation, closely clasped the neck of a warrior, the latter, tormented by unmatched arrows/the odd-arrowed Kama, was thoroughly soaked in blood/overcome with intense love.
column8: JR explains ‘pulaka’ as ‘a special feature of a sword’ (‘guṇaviśeṣa’). ‘Pulaka’ refers to the purity/sheen/excellence of a metal (‘pulakastu sārapratipādano varṇātiśayaḥ, sa ca lohe’pyasti, yata eva bruvanti – ‘ramaṇīyo’sya khaḍgasya pulaka utthita’, - - - apara āha kaṇagapulagaśabdaḥ śreṣṭhavācī’, Avacūri commentary on the word ‘kanagapulaga’ in Bhagavatīsūtra, 1.3). ‘Asilekhā’ (‘slender sword’), which is in the feminine gender, is likened to a maiden hugging her lover’s neck.

column4: व्यसुरसुरभटोऽधिरूढवान्दिवमुपयु(भु)ज्य सुरैणचक्षुषः । अगमयदितरोऽथ पश्यतो द्विगुणितमत्सरतां सुधान्धसः ॥ २६ ॥
column5: vyasurasurabhaṭo'dhirūḍhavāndivamupayu(bhu)jya suraiṇacakṣuṣaḥ | agamayaditaro'tha paśyato dviguṇitamatsaratāṃ sudhāndhasaḥ || 26 ||
column6: युद्धे व्यसुर्विगतप्राणः, अतो दिवमारूढवान् , अन्यो दैत्यभटोऽप्सरसो भुक्त्वा तद्भोगं पश्यतो देवान्द्विगुणरोषत्वमप्रापयत् । कथमयमस्माभिर्जित्वा हतोऽस्मद्रूपं प्राप्यास्मन्नारीभोगं कुरुत इति भावः॥
column7: A certain Asura warrior, having ascended to heaven after his death, made love to the doe-eyed divine damsels, arousing redoubled jealousy in the onlooker gods.
column8: The jealous gods think thus: “How can this Asura, whom we overpowered and killed, enjoy the company of our women by assuming our form?” (JR).

column4: समिदभिमुखमुज्झितासुषु त्रिदशदशामुपलब्धवत्स्वहो । अपि सुररिपुषु स्वबान्धवैर्विनिदधिरे स्थिरमत्सरा दृशः ॥ २७ ॥
column5: samidabhimukhamujjhitāsuṣu tridaśadaśāmupalabdhavatsvaho | api suraripuṣu svabāndhavairvinidadhire sthiramatsarā dṛśaḥ || 27 ||
column6: समिति सङ्ग्रामेऽभिमुखं कृत्वा त्यक्तप्राणेषु, अतो देवत्वं प्राप्तवत्सु, असुरेषु स्वैरपि स्थिररोषा दृष्टयो निक्षिप्ताः। कथमेतेऽस्मज्ज्ञातयोऽपि सन्तो देवत्वं गृहीतवन्त इति भावः॥
column7: Even those Asuras, who, having given up their lives facing their enemies in war had attained godhood, were looked at with steadily furious eyes by their own kith and kin (i.e., by other Asuras).
column8: The kith and kin of such Asuras think thus: “How did they attain the status of Devas in spite of being our relatives?” (JR).

column4: समिदुपगमदुःसहोच्छ्वसन्महसि धृतोष्मभरः स्ववर्ष्मणि । निजजनयितुरापदग्निभूरसृगरुणोल्बणहेतिकस्तुलाम् ॥ २८ ॥
column5: samidupagamaduḥsahocchvasanmahasi dhṛtoṣmabharaḥ svavarṣmaṇi | nijajanayiturāpadagnibhūrasṛgaruṇolbaṇahetikastulām || 28 ||
column6: समितः सङ्ग्रामस्योपगमेनोल्लसत्तेजसि शरीरे धृतदर्पभावः तथासृजा रुधिरेणारुणायुधः कुमारो निजजनयितुरग्नेस्तुलां स्पर्धामापत् । अग्निर्हि समिधामुपगमेनोल्लसति शरीरे धृततापोऽसृग्वच्च रक्तज्वाल:॥
column7: Richly possessed of weapons reddened by blood/blood-red flames, the fire-born Kumara, whose fiery form blazed brightly as it approached the battle/fuelwood, attained similitude with his source (i.e., fire).
column8: Skanda is regarded as the son of the Fire God, whence his name ‘Agnibhūḥ’

column4: धृतवति शमने सपाशतामनुसृतशारिभरेषु दन्तिषु । समजनि सुरविद्विषामसुग्लहहरणाय दुरोदरक्रिया ॥ २९ ॥
column5: dhṛtavati śamane sapāśatāmanusṛtaśāribhareṣu dantiṣu | samajani suravidviṣāmasuglahaharaṇāya durodarakriyā || 29 ||
column6: शमने यमे सपाशतां पाशाख्यायुधविशेषवत्त्वं साक्षतां च धृतवति तथा हस्तिषु प्राप्तः शारीणां हस्तिपर्याणानां द्यूतक्रीडाफलकानां च भरो यैस्तेषु सत्सु दुरोदरक्रिया जयपराजयविषयं युद्धं द्यूतं च प्राणपणहरणाय प्रादुर्भूता ॥
column7: The elephants appeared like pawns as Death grabbed the noose/dice and engaged in a game of gambling to secure the wager, namely, the life of the Asuras.
column8: N/A

column4: सकलदिगनुबद्धसैनिकस्फुरदसिसंहतिबिम्बिताननः । दशमुखपदवीमिवासुरो हरबलकम्पकृतो(ते) परोऽगमत् ॥ ३० ॥
column5: sakaladiganubaddhasainikasphuradasisaṃhatibimbitānanaḥ | daśamukhapadavīmivāsuro harabalakampakṛto(te) paro'gamat || 30 ||
column6: सकला दश या दिशस्त​त्स्थितानां सैनिकानां स्फुरत्सु खड्गेषु प्रतिबिम्बितमुखोऽन्योऽसुरो हरकटककम्पकरणार्थमिव दशमुखदशामगात् । दशमुखेन रावणेन हि पूर्वं कैलासं चालयता गणानां कम्प उत्पादितः ॥
column7: His face mirrored by a multitude of swords in every direction, a certain Asura seemed to attain Ravana-hood to make Shiva’s forces tremble in fear.
column8: The ten-headed Ravana had made the Gaṇas tremble in fear by trying to uproot Mt. Kailasa (See footnote under 4.21).

column4: मुहुररिविशिखान्प्रतीच्छता चतुरगतागतकेलिशालिना । श्रवणपुटयुगेन खेटकक्रममपुषद्वदने विनायकः ॥ ३१ ॥
column5: muhurariviśikhānpratīcchatā caturagatāgatakeliśālinā | śravaṇapuṭayugena kheṭakakramamapuṣadvadane vināyakaḥ || 31 ||
column6: शत्रुबाणान्प्रतीच्छता चतुरं गतागतकेल्या शोभमानेन कर्णद्वयेन गणपतिः खेटकस्योद्यमनस्य क्रमं भङ्गिमपुषत् । खेटकस्य हि मुखरक्षा मुख्यो व्यापारः ॥
column7: Ganesha’s deftly flapping ears bore the brunt of arrows and served the purpose of shields protecting his face.
column8: The main purpose of a shield is to protect the face (from weapons hitting it) (JR).

column4: गजवदनरदाग्रघट्टनाशकलितमूर्तिषु नाकवैरिषु । कुपितशमनदन्तसन्ततिप्रहृतिरसः पुनरुक्ततामगात् ॥ ३२ ॥
column5: gajavadanaradāgraghaṭṭanāśakalitamūrtiṣu nākavairiṣu | kupitaśamanadantasantatiprahṛtirasaḥ punaruktatāmagāt || 32 ||
column6: गजमुखस्य दन्ताग्रैर्घटनया खण्डिततनुष्वसुरेषु कुपितस्य यमस्य दन्तपङ्क्त्याप्र(ङ्क्त्या प्र​)हरणरसः पुनरुक्ततामापत् । गजमुखदन्ताग्रघट्टनेनैव तत्कार्यकरणात् ॥
column7: The mauling impact of the angry Death’s row of fangs was rendered superfluous on the Asuras' bodies that were already pulverized by the onslaught of Ganesha’s sharp tusk.
column8: N/A

column4: सकलवपुरुपोढसायकव्यतिकरकण्टकभग्नतालुना। वदनत इव मृत्युनोज्झितः पुनरभजद्व्रणितोऽपि कोऽप्यसून् ॥ ३३ ॥
column5: sakalavapurupoḍhasāyakavyatikarakaṇṭakabhagnatālunā| vadanata iva mṛtyunojjhitaḥ punarabhajadvraṇito'pi ko'pyasūn || 33 ||
column6: व्रणितोऽपि व्रणवान्कृतोऽपि कश्चित्पुनः प्राणानभजत् । अत उत्प्रेक्ष्यते - मुखाद्यमेन त्यक्त इव । कुत इत्याह - सकले वपुषि धृता ये सायकास्तेषां व्यतिकरः समूहः स एव कण्टकास्तैर्भग्नं पाटितं तालु यस्य तेन । तालुनि पाट्य​माने हि मुखगतमपि भोज्यं त्यज्यते ॥
column7: Spit out, as it were, from the mouth of Death, whose palate was shattered by an array of sharp arrows sticking out from his limbs, a certain Asura was restored back to life in spite of being wounded.
column8: A certain Asura, who was restored back to life, is imagined by the poet as having been spit off by Death because the latter's palate was shattered by the sharp arrows sticking out from from that Asura's body.

column4: प्रथमगलदुपोढकुङ्कुमश्रमसलिले वपुषि द्युसद्द्विषः । द्विषदिषुघटनासु कस्यचिद्विसृतमसृङ् न झगित्यलक्ष्यत ॥ ३४ ॥
column5: prathamagaladupoḍhakuṅkumaśramasalile vapuṣi dyusaddviṣaḥ | dviṣadiṣughaṭanāsu kasyacidvisṛtamasṛṅ na jhagityalakṣyata || 34 ||
column6: शत्रुशरप्रवेशात्प्रथमं गलत्सकुङ्कुमं श्रमजलं यस्य तस्मिन्नसुरस्य शरीरे द्विषत्सम्बन्धिनीषु शरघटनासु सतीषु निर्गतं रक्तं न लक्षितम् । वर्णसन्निवेशयोः सादृश्यादिति भावः॥
column7: Yet another Asura’s body was already dripping with saffron-tinged sweat, wherefore one could not readily notice the blood gushing forth from it when the enemy’s arrows struck him.
column8: N/A

column4: रचयितुमिव दूततां मिथः कथमपि सन्धिकृते जयश्रिया । दिविषदसुरसैन्ययोश्चिरं विवृतगतागतता व्यतन्यत ॥ ३५ ॥
column5: racayitumiva dūtatāṃ mithaḥ kathamapi sandhikṛte jayaśriyā | diviṣadasurasainyayościraṃ vivṛtagatāgatatā vyatanyata || 35 ||
column6: कथमपि कृच्छ्रेण सन्धिकृते दूत्यं कर्तुमिव जयलक्ष्म्या सुरासुरकटकयोर्विषयभूतयोर्विवृतं गतागतं येन तद्भावः कृतः । दूतो हि गतागतानि चिरं करोति । क्षणं जयलक्ष्मीर्देवेषु क्षणं चासुरेष्वासीदित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Lady Victory went back and forth between the armies of the Devas and the Asuras as if she were an envoy trying to somehow negotiate a truce between them.
column8: N/A

column4: बहुशरकरसीकरावलीमुचि करवालमदच्छटातिथौ । रणकरिणि गलद्भटासृजा परिममृषे मुखधातुविभ्रमः ॥ ३६ ॥
column5: bahuśarakarasīkarāvalīmuci karavālamadacchaṭātithau | raṇakariṇi galadbhaṭāsṛjā parimamṛṣe mukhadhātuvibhramaḥ || 36 ||
column6: बहवः शरा एव करसीकरावली तां मुञ्चति तस्मिन् , तथा करवालाः खड्गा लक्षणया खड्गधारा एव मदाम्बुच्छटा तदतिथौ तत्प्रणयिनि रण एव करी तस्मिन्, मुखधातोः सिन्दूरस्य विभ्रमः शोभा गलता भटासृजा प्राप्तः ॥
column7: The blood oozing from warriors became the vermillion decoration of the battle, standing for an elephant; a shower of plentiful arrows resembled the jet of water emitted from its trunk and a row of dark swords, its streaming ichor.
column8: N/A

column4: धूमो ममज्ज करवालरुचिच्छटासु भेदोऽप्यलम्भि रुधिरोर्मिषु नो शिखाभिः । आग्नेयमस्त्रमिति नाकिभटैः प्रयुक्त-मप्याससाद न कथञ्चिदपि स्फुटत्वम् ॥ ३७ ॥
column5: dhūmo mamajja karavālarucicchaṭāsu bhedo'pyalambhi rudhirormiṣu no śikhābhiḥ | āgneyamastramiti nākibhaṭaiḥ prayukta-mapyāsasāda na kathañcidapi sphuṭatvam || 37 ||
column6: खड्गेषु धूमो ममज्ज न प्रतिबभौ, तथा रक्ततरङ्गेषु ज्वालाभिर्भेदो न प्राप्तः । इत्यतो देवयोधैः प्रयुक्तमप्याग्नेयमस्त्रं कथञ्चिदपि प्रकटत्वं नापत् ॥
column7: The fire-laden missiles discharged by the celestial warriors could not be made out at all because their smoke was lost in the radiant lustre of dark swords and their flaming tongues were barely distinguishable from streams of blood.
column8: N/A

column4: अस्रं पलं च सममेव पचञ्शवानां यस्तत्क्षणं प्रयुयुजे सु(जेऽस्त्र​)हुताशनोऽन्यैः । हृष्यत्पिशाचरजनीचरपूतनाना-मूरीचकार स महानसवह्निकृत्यम् ॥ ३८ ॥
column5: asraṃ palaṃ ca samameva pacañśavānāṃ yastatkṣaṇaṃ prayuyuje su(je'stra)hutāśano'nyaiḥ | hṛṣyatpiśācarajanīcarapūtanānā-mūrīcakāra sa mahānasavahnikṛtyam || 38 ||
column6: अन्यैः सुरैर्योऽस्त्राग्निः प्रयुक्तः स तत्क्षणमस्रं रक्तं पलं मांसं च सद्यः पचन्, पिशाचानां सूदशालाग्निकरणीयमङ्गीचकार । 'महानसः सूदशाला' इति मालाकोषः ॥
column7: The fire emanating from the missiles that were employed by the gods boiled the blood and roasted the flesh (of the enemies) together that very instant, thus functioning as the kitchen fire of overjoyed goblins, demons, and female fiends.
column8: N/A

column4: वरुणदहनजिष्णुब्रह्मविष्ण्वादिभिर्यै-र्जगति विवृतमोजो दैवतैरस्त्रजातेः । स्वयमकृषत तस्यां यत्र तेऽपि प्रयोगं कथमिव विजयाशा तत्र संशीतिपात्रम् ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: varuṇadahanajiṣṇubrahmaviṣṇvādibhiryai-rjagati vivṛtamojo daivatairastrajāteḥ | svayamakṛṣata tasyāṃ yatra te'pi prayogaṃ kathamiva vijayāśā tatra saṃśītipātram || 39 ||
column6: यैर्वरुणादिभिर्देवतैरस्त्रजातेरोजो वीर्यं विवृतं प्रकाशितं तेऽपि वरुणादयोऽस्यामस्त्रजातौ स्वयं प्रयोगमकार्षुः, तत्र जयसम्भावना कथं संशीतेः संशयस्य पात्रम् । येषां वरुणादीनां सन्निधापनमात्रादस्त्रा​णां वीर्यवत्त्वं ते यत्र प्रेरिताः सन्निदधते तत्र को जयसन्देह इत्यर्थः । दैवतशब्दः पुल्लिङ्गो न प्रसिद्धः ॥
column7: When the class of weapons, whose power is made manifest by gods such as Varuna, Agni, Indra, Brahma, Vishnu, and so on, was employed by those very gods, how could the possibility of victory be a matter of doubt?
