column4: पञ्चविंशः सर्गः ॥
column7: Twenty-fifth Canto

column4: इति स श्रवणोत्तंसं मांसलं भक्तिविभ्रमैः । जगन्नाथस्य जग्रन्थ मङ्खकः सूक्तिलीलया ॥ १ ॥
column5: iti sa śravaṇottaṃsaṃ māṃsalaṃ । bhaktivibhramaiḥ jagannāthasya jagrantha maṅkhakaḥ sūktilīlayā || 1 ||
column6: जगन्नाथस्य महेश्वरस्य भक्तिर्दृढा भावना रचना च । तद्विभ्रमैर्बहुलं कर्णभूषणं सूक्तिलीलया स मङ्खको बबन्ध । त्रिपुरदाहवर्णनलक्षणसूक्तिं भगवतः कर्णभूषणमकरोत् । श्रावितवानित्यर्थः॥
column7: In this way, Mankha fashioned an ear-ornament - disguised as beautiful poetry and rich in devotional fervour/charming craftsmanship – for the Lord of the Universe
column8: Beautiful poetry’ = ‘the poetic description of the burning down of the Tripuras’; ‘Mankha fashioned an ear-ornament’ is a roundabout way of saying Mankha made Shiva listen to his poem (JR).

column4: तिग्मानलदृशः खण्डपरशोः प्रणयग्रहात् । तस्य सूक्तिलता व्यक्तं बत साफल्यमग्रहीत् ॥ २ ॥
column5: tigmānaladṛśaḥ khaṇḍaparaśoḥ praṇayagrahāt | tasya sūktilatā vyaktaṃ bata sāphalyamagrahīt || 2 ||
column6: तिग्मस्तीव्रोऽनलोऽग्निर्दृशि यस्य तस्य खण्डपरशोर्भगवतः प्रार्थनाहेवाकात्तस्य मङ्खकस्य सूक्तिलता कृतार्थत्वमग्रहीत् । बतेत्याश्चर्यद्योतकम् । दीप्तोऽग्निर्दृशि यस्य तथा हस्ते च खण्डपरशुस्तस्य प्रणयाल्लताया दाहच्छेदौ मा भूतां प्रत्युत सफलत्वमित्याश्चर्यम्॥
column7: How strange that the creeper of his poetry visibly attained fruitfulness because of its association with the one whose eye blazes fiercely and who holds a cleaving hatchet!
column8: Not just did the creeper not get burnt down or chopped off as a consequence of its association with the fire-eyed, hatchet-bearing Shiva but it also attained fruitfulness, wherefore the poet expresses surprise (JR).

column4: स्वयं मौलीन्दुपीयूषपूरैः सिक्तेव शम्भुना । सरसत्वं च दार्ढ्यं च वाक्तस्याव्यग्रमग्रहीत् ॥ ३ ॥
column5: svayaṃ maulīndupīyūṣapūraiḥ sikteva śambhunā | sarasatvaṃ ca dārḍhyaṃ ca vāktasyāvyagramagrahīt || 3 ||
column6: तस्य वागनाकुलं सरसत्वं शृङ्गारादिरसयुक्तत्वं चर्वणीयत्वं च, दार्ढ्यमश्लथ​त्वमविनश्वरत्वं चाग्रहीत् । स्वयं मुकुटचन्द्रामृतपूरसिक्तेवेत्युत्प्रेक्षणम् ॥
column7: His speech attained aesthetic flavour/fluidity and compactness/immortal fame because, or so it seemed, Shiva had himself drenched it with streams of ambrosia from the moon on his crest.
column8: N/A

column4: प्रबन्धेन जगद्वन्धुमुपश्लोक्य पिनाकिनम् । आक्रान्तानन्तसन्तोष इति सोऽन्तरचिन्तयत् ॥ ४ ॥
column5: prabandhena jagadvandhumupaślokya pinākinam | ākrāntānantasantoṣa iti so'ntaracintayat || 4 ||
column6: प्रबन्धेन भगवन्तमुपश्लोक्य स्तुत्वा प्राप्तप्रविततप्रमोदमित्यन्तः सोऽचिन्तयत् ॥
column7: Having praised Shiva, the sole ally of the world, through his work and overcome with boundless joy, he thought thus within himself.
column8: N/A

column4: अहो धन्योऽस्मि यस्येयं स्वच्छन्दापि सरस्वती । विना श्रीकण्ठमन्यत्र नाचरच्चाटुकारिताम् ॥ ५ ॥
column5: aho dhanyo'smi yasyeyaṃ svacchandāpi sarasvatī | vinā śrīkaṇṭhamanyatra nācaraccāṭukāritām || 5 ||
column6: अहो अस्मि धन्यः । यस्य सरस्वती श्रीकण्ठं विनान्यत्र चाटुकारितां नाचरत् । श्रीकण्ठस्यैव स्तुतिमकार्षीदित्यर्थः । अन्यस्तुतिकरणे हेतुमाह - स्वच्छन्दापि। उद्दामवाचो हि कवयः । सरस्वती नाम नदी च श्रीकण्ठाख्यजनपदविशेषमेव सेवते । सरस्वतीनदीपक्षे स्वच्छन्दा । स्वेच्छया स्थानान्तरेषु सापह्नवप्रकाशेत्यर्थः ॥
column7: “How lucky I am, whose Speech/River Sarasvati, though unrestrained in her flow, flattered/took recourse to no one else/place other than Shiva/the Shrikantha province!
column8: River Sarasvati flows through the Śrīrkaṇṭha province (JR)

column4: महत्कष्टमहो हित्वा यच्छर्वं सर्वतः श्रुतिम्(सर्वतःश्रुतिम्) । गर्वानवधिबाधिर्यो नरेण स्तूयते नरः ॥ ६ ॥

column6: नित्यं नृत्यन्त्या वाग्देव्याः सम्बन्धिनो मञ्जीरस्य पटुभी रवैरिव हेतुभिर्यस्य शास्त्रविमर्शेषु सत्सु वैनिद्र्यं जायते । रवैरिति हेतूत्प्रेक्षा । तथाहं जाने स यत्र भूतसर्गे पञ्चापि पृथिव्यादीनि महाभूतानि विमुञ्चता । अपाञ्चभौतिकं सर्गं कुर्वतेत्यर्थः । विधिना यो वाङ्मयैरेव परमाणुभिर्निर्मितः । शास्त्रमयपरमाणुनिर्माणमध्ये साधनमुपन्यस्यति क्वेति । क्व नु कुत्रस्वित्कानिस्वित्कियत्कालंस्विद्यस्तपांसि तेपे । कीदृशानि । वैदुष्ये पाण्डित्ये लग्नकानि प्रतिभूभूतानि । कीदृशे । अन्ययोगव्यावृत्तिसाक्षिणि । अन्यस्य नन्दनपण्डितादपरस्य योगव्यावृत्तिरेतादृशेनेव पाण्डित्येन योगस्य व्यावृत्तिर्व्यवच्छेदस्तत्साक्षिणि। सेव साक्षी यस्येति वा । प्रतिभूसाक्षिणोर्द्वयोरपि सन्निधाने सत्ययत्नेन वस्तु घटते । तस्य श्रीलङ्गकस्य समीपं पवित्रयन्तं ब्रह्मवादिनां प्रधानं पण्डितेन्द्रं नन्दनं स तत्र दृष्टवान्॥
column7: 22. to 25. Sanctifying Lankaka’s vicinity by his presence was Nandana - chief among scholars and foremost among the expounders of the Vedas – who barely slept while being engrossed in contemplating about the Shastras, kept continuously awake, as it were, by the loud jingle of Sarasvati’s anklets when she danced around; who, I believe, was created by the Creator solely with the atoms of eloquence without taking recourse to the five great elements; and who performed, I don’t know, what kinds of austerities and for how long, (austerities) that stood surety for the attainment of such scholarship as was evidently beyond the reach of anyone else. To him Mankha paid homage.
column8: Verses 22-25 constitute a Chakkalaka.

column6: जनेन यस्य मुखं सरस्वत्याः श्वेतपटवस्त्रान्तमाकर्षदिवालक्ष्यते। कैः । शास्त्रव्याख्यासु सतीषु दन्तांशुभिः । सरस्वती तन्मुखे कृतसन्निधानेत्यर्थः । यत्पटप्रान्तं चाकृष्यते स तत्रैवावतिष्ठते । सारस्वतस्य धाम्नो तेजसो भूः स्थानम् । तथा अत एव तस्यैव धाम्नः कमपि लोकोत्तरं स्पन्दं शिष्यमुखे सञ्चारमर्पयन्य एव रुय्यक: सर्वशास्त्राणां मूर्तं जीवितमिव भवति । जीवितं च स्पन्दमर्पयति, तेजसश्च स्थानं भवति । तथा आत्ता गृहीता लेखनी लेखनकाण्डं येन तादृगङ्गुलीतलं यस्य शास्त्राणां विवृतीर्विवरणानि लिखति । करोतीत्यर्थः । अत उत्प्रेक्ष्यते - ग्रन्थेभ्यः शास्त्रेभ्योऽर्थस्य वाच्यस्य धनस्य च विश्रान्त्यर्थं सूत्रिका वस्त्रदशालेशं दददिव । तथा यस्य कृतिषु विमर्शेन कस्य न शिरश्चेष्टते विवलते । अत्रोत्प्रेक्षा - सारस्वतो यो रसो जलं च तच्चर्वणवलनेनेवेति । आवर्तस्य जलभ्रमस्य च वलनेन वस्तु विवल्यते, तं श्रीरुय्यकं दृष्ट्वा मङ्खकविः सौहार्दरसस्य प्रश्रयरसस्य च स्रोतसोः सम्भेदे मज्जनमग्रहीत् । अत्रैव हेतुद्वयम् - गुरुं प्रियमिति॥
column7: 26. to 30. Mankha plunged into a confluence formed by the streams of love and respect when he saw his favourite teacher, the esteemed Ruyyaka, whose mouth, during his expositions (of the Shastras), appears to pull at the hem of Sarasvati’s silken robe by way of the radiant glow of its (bright) teeth; who seems like the embodied life force of all the Shastras since he is the ground for the thriving spirit of knowledge and imparts an indescribable pulsation (of that very spirit to his students); who, while writing commentaries with a stylus held in his finger, appears to spread out the edge of a cloth in which he can gather the wealth of meanings offered by the textual corpus; and during the careful study of whose works, the head of every person shakes repeatedly (in appreciation) as if it (i.e., the head) is caught in an eddy of his surging genius.
column8: Verses 26-30 constitute a Kulaka set. Ruyyaka (Rajanaka Ruyyaka), the Kashmiri aesthetician, is the author of Alaṅkārasarvasva and Sahṛdayalīlā; The words ‘priyaṃ’ (‘favourite’) and ‘guruṃ’ (‘teacher’) indicate the reason for Mankha’s love and respect towards Ruyyaka.

column6: यस्याधरः कषायं रक्तवस्त्रग्रहणमिव प्रकटयति । कया । आरक्तया रुचा । नित्यं सन्न्यासेन प्रतिपादनेन सङ्क्रान्तः सञ्चरितो वेदान्तार्थो यस्य । वेदान्तवादिनो हि काषायग्रहणमुचितम् । येन शिष्यविषये कल्पद्रुमायितं कल्पवृक्षवदाचरितमिति भावे क्तः । कुत्र । श्रुतीनां वेदान्तानां पथि । तत्र हेतु:- वल्ली: कठवल्लीलक्षणान्वेदान्तविशेषान्सफलतां कृतार्थतां नीत्वा, इष्टसिद्धिं वेदान्तार्थप्रतिपादकशास्त्रविशेषं विवृण्वता विवरणेन प्रकाशयता । कल्पद्रुमाणां वल्लीसफलत्वादिकरणमुचितम् । स्मयमात्सर्ययोः संहरणान्निर्दोषीकृतपाण्डित्यं तथा धृतं प्रणतो पारम्यं प्रसङ्गो येन तं रम्यदेवं तत्रापश्यत् ॥
column7: 31.to 33. And there he (also) saw Ramyadeva, supremely worthy of salutation on that occasion, (Ramyadeva) whose lower lip is dark red, as if, imbued by the philosophy of Vedanta that he preaches regularly, it has donned ochre robes; who, to his students, is a veritable Tree of plenty on the Vedic path since he renders the Vallis (of Kathopanishad)/creepers (clinging for support) fruitful and expounds the text ‘Ishtasiddhi’/makes wishes come true; and who has rid his scholarship of the chaff that is pride and envy
column8: Verses 31-33 form a Kulaka set. The Iṣṭasiddhi of Vumuktatman is a famous text on Advaita Vedanta.

column7: 34. to 36. Then he heard a few words, full of glorious praise directed at Lankaka, from Loshtadeva, in whose lotus-like mouth the six languages put on the clever semblance of the fluttering of wings by the queen bee that is the Goddess of speech; and in relation to whose writings, shielded by unshakable scholarship, the questions thrown by wicked opponents are rendered ineffective like blunt arrows.
column8: Verses 34-36 make up a Tilaka. The six languages are Saṃskṛta, Prākṛta (Mahārāṣṭrī), Śūrasenī, Māgadhī, Paiśācī, and Deśajā (regional language)  (‘saṃskṛtaṃ prākṛtaṃ caiva śūrasenī tadudbhavā | tato:'pi māgadhī prāgvatpaiśācī deśajeti ṣaṭ ||’, quoted by JR). The footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition quotes the following verse, ascribed to Loshtadeva, from Sūktimuktāvalī – ‘prakṛtyaivātivakreṇa guṇadairghyaṃ vitanvatā | mayā śarāsaneneva bāṇo dūraṃ nirasyate ||’ (‘I am naturally very oblique in my expressions/curved and exhibit poetic qualities in no small measure/an elongatedness of my string; I am akin to a bow and have flung the poet Bana/arrow far away’).

column6: हे लङ्कक विभो, विधिस्तावकमुखमहारमर्पयति स्मेति मन्ये । कस्मै । सत्याय । दाने हेतुमुपन्यस्यति - कलिकाले निराश्रयत्वं दर्शितवते । कीदृशम् । शुभ्रस्य निर्मलस्य रसस्य शृङ्गारादेरेका सूतिर्याभ्यस्ताभिर्गोभिर्वाग्भिरनुस्यूतम् । तथा ज्यायस्याः शुद्धेर्नैर्मल्यस्य सखायो ये द्विजा विप्रास्तेषामुच्छ्वासन्ती या अनिर्वेदप्रथा दुःखाभावकारणं तया पावनम् । वाग्देवीसहिताय । अन्यश्च दुग्धदाभिर्गोभिः सहितं निराश्रयाय कस्मैचिदग्रहारं ददाति । यद्वा द्विजा दन्ताः । अनिर्वेदा वेदसहिताः॥
column7: 'Master Lankaka! Seeing that Truthfulness, accompanied by Goddess Speech, was rendered homeless in the age of Kali, the Creator, I believe, gifted the Agrahara land of your mouth to it, (your mouth) which is rich in words/cows that yield nothing but pure aesthetic bliss/milk and is sancfified by Vedic chants emanating from amidst glowing white teeth/an unbroken tradition of the  Vedas, brought to life by supremely pure Brahmins  (or 'a sorrow-free state of supremely pure Brahmins')
column8: Agrahāra is a piece of land that is granted by Kings to Brahmins for their maintenance. ‘Anirveda’ is both ‘sorrow-free’ and ‘never Veda-less’ (JR). The close relationship between 'satya' ('truthfulness') and 'Sarasvatī' ('Goddess Speech') was alluded to by Mankha in verse 3.45 too. 'Satya' may also stand for the 'Satya Yuga' that is the antithesis of 'Kali Yuga'.

column6: यस्य मतिर्धर्म एव पटच्चरं जीर्णवासस्तं द्रढयति दृढं करोति । यतस्तीक्ष्णा । तथा पृथुलो य ऊहस्तत्प्रकृतिः । गुरुतराणां गुणनिकराणामौदार्यादिगुणगणानां सङ्ग्रहे व्यग्रा। तीक्ष्णत्वादिविशेषणसाम्यात्सूचीव तीक्ष्णा । तथा पृथु यल्लोहं तन्मयी गुणानां सूत्राणां सङ्ग्रहे व्यग्रा जीर्णवस्त्रं द्रढयति॥
column7: Sharp, stong in reasoning/fashioned from strong iron, and ready to gather a multitude of magnificent qualities/threads, Lankaka’s intellect repairs the tattered rag of Dharma in an instant.
column8: The adjectives used to describe Lankaka’s intellect suggest its semblance with a sewing needle (JR).

column4: मूर्तिर्यस्य सभानुताद्भुतलिपेः पुष्णाति गाढामृत-प्रादुर्भावविसृत्वरीं परिणतिं पङ्केरुहद्रोहिणः । तस्य त्वन्मुखशीतगोः प्रणयतोऽलङ्कार वाग्देवता गल्वर्कोपलपुत्रिका गुरुपरिस्यन्दं रसं स्यन्दते ॥ ३९ ॥
column5: mūrtiryasya sabhānutādbhutalipeḥ puṣṇāti gāḍhāmṛta-prādurbhāvavisṛtvarīṃ pariṇatiṃ paṅkeruhadrohiṇaḥ | tasya tvanmukhaśītagoḥ praṇayato'laṅkāra vāgdevatā galvarkopalaputrikā guruparisyandaṃ rasaṃ syandate || 39 ||
column6: सभासु नुता स्तुता अद्भुता लिपिर्यस्य तथा पङ्केरुहेभ्यः पापेभ्यो द्रुह्यति तच्छीलस्तथाविधस्य यस्य मूर्तिः ऋतप्रादुर्भावे सत्यप्रकाशने विमृत्वरीं परिणति रसं पुष्णाति तस्य त्वन्मुखचन्द्रस्य प्रणयतः सरखती चन्द्रकान्तपुत्रिका महाप्रवाहं रसं प्रसूते। सह भानुतया सूर्यभावेन वर्तते या सा । अत एवाद्भुता लिपिर्यस्य चन्द्रस्य तथा पद्मद्रोहिणो मूर्तिर्गाढेऽमृते पीयूषे विसृत्वरीं परिणति पुष्णाति तस्य प्रणयाच्चन्द्रकान्तपुत्रिका रसं सूते । मुखपक्षे पङ्केरुहेभ्य: पद्मभ्यो द्रुह्यति । कान्त्याधिकीभवतीति वा ॥
column7: Alankara! Your face is the moon since it has the remarkable distinction of associating with the sun/is praised in the assembly for its remarkable features; is a rival of lotuses; and possesses a form which, when full-grown, sprinkles ample ambrosia/inherently supports a sustained state of perfection as regards the revelation of truth. And the Goddess of speech, like a figurine carved from moonstone, emits copious amounts of fluid/aesthetic bliss by forging friendship with it.
column8: The word 'sabhānutādbhutalipeḥ' must be split in two different ways: 'sa-bhānu-tā-adbhutalipeḥ' and 'sabhā-nuta-adbhutalipeḥ' (JR). The moon is regarded as a receptacle of ambrosia. The word 'galvarkopala' is used here as a synonym of 'candrakānta' ('moonstone'); it is also used by Mankha in the sense of 'sphaṭika' (see footnote under 17.4).

column4: यः सामन्तशिखामणेऽत्रभवतालङ्कार नित्यं सता- मानीतोऽनवकाशतां हृदि हृताशेषाद्भुतापद्भियि । तेषां श्रोत्रविलिह्यमानगहनत्वत्सूक्तिचर्वोत्सवे राशीभूत इवाधिशीर्षमधुना कम्पः स सम्पद्यते ॥ ४० ॥
column5: yaḥ sāmantaśikhāmaṇe'trabhavatālaṅkāra nityaṃ satā-mānīto'navakāśatāṃ hṛdi hṛtāśeṣādbhutāpadbhiyi | teṣāṃ śrotravilihyamānagahanatvatsūkticarvotsave rāśībhūta ivādhiśīrṣamadhunā kampaḥ sa sampadyate || 40 ||
column6: हे सामन्तानां मौलिरत्न, सतां हृदयकम्पस्त्वयावकाशरहितत्वं नीतः । अत्र हेतु: हृदयेऽस्तविपद्भये । सकम्पस्तेषां साधूनां शिरसि राशीभूत इव सम्पन्नः । श्रोत्रपीयमानत्वदीयकाव्यरसोत्सवे ॥
column7: Alankara! Crest jewel among governing officers! The shaking that you continuously deprive the hearts of virtuous men by freeing it of all unexplained perilous fears seems to have accumulated in their heads at present when they participate in the festive savouring of your profoundly beautiful poetry with their ears.
column8: Virtuous men, their hearts free of worries, appreciate Lankaka's poetry by shaking their heads.

column4: सामन्तभद्रनयमपि भजसे पदमनुसरन्नसामान्यम् । विश्वमपापोऽहमिति श्रीलङ्कक तदपि बोधयसि ॥ ४१ ॥
column5: sāmantabhadranayamapi bhajase padamanusarannasāmānyam | viśvamapāpo'hamiti śrīlaṅkaka tadapi bodhayasi || 41 ||
column6: असामान्यं विशिष्टं पदम् । सामन्तेषु मण्डलेश्वरेषु भद्राः प्रधानानि तेषां नयं त्वं भजसे । यद्यप्यसामान्यमसदृशं पदमनुसरन् । तदपि तथाप्यहमपापः पापरहित इति विश्वं बोधयसि । असामान्यजातिरहितं पदमनुसरन्यः सामन्तभद्रं बुद्धसम्बन्धिनं नयं भजते सोऽपगतान्यावच्छेदमिति कथं बोधयतीति विरोधाभासः ॥
column7: Revered Lankaka! (How strange!) Though you conduct yourself in the manner of the foremost of ministers/follow Buddhist philosophy and occupy a special position/take a stance that does not recognize the category of genus, you still declare to the world that you are sinless/that the Apoha principle of exclusion does not operate in the world.
column8: Buddhism does not recognize the category of ‘jāti’ (‘genus’); it accepts the Apoha theory of exclusion (‘anyāvaccheda’, JR). 'Sāmantabhadra' is both ‘related to Samantabhadra (Buddha)' and ‘foremost among ministers’. The word ‘apāpoham’ must be split in two ways – ‘apa+apoham’ (‘not affected by the Apoha principle’) and ‘a+pāpaḥ, aham’ (‘I am sinless’) (JR).

column4: यापूर्वा कविगर्वहृत्पदगतिर्यस्या विपर्येति नो स्पष्टं या परपुष्टसौष्ठवहरं वाक्यक्रमं पुष्यति । सा श्रीलङ्कक मानमार्गमजहत्यप्यात्तकण्ठा हठा-द्विद्वत्ता तव चित्रमुज्झितरजाः सूते यशःसन्ततिम् ॥ ४२ ॥
column5: yāpūrvā kavigarvahṛtpadagatiryasyā viparyeti no spaṣṭaṃ yā parapuṣṭasauṣṭhavaharaṃ vākyakramaṃ puṣyati | sā śrīlaṅkaka mānamārgamajahatyapyāttakaṇṭhā haṭhā-dvidvattā tava citramujjhitarajāḥ sūte yaśaḥsantatim || 42 ||
column6: यस्या विद्वत्तायाः पदगतिः सुप्तिङन्तादिरचना न विपर्येति । यतोऽपूर्वात एव कवीनां गर्वं हरन्ती। तथा परेषां पण्डितानां पुष्टं सौष्ठ​वं हरन्तं वाक्यक्रमं या पुष्यति सा तव विद्वत्ता मानमादरं दधाना गृहीतकण्ठा । सादरमधीतेत्यर्थः । यतस्त्यक्तरजोदोषा यश:प्रसरणं सूते इति समाधिः । विरोधस्तु के जले वीनां पक्षिणां हंसानां मदं हरन्ती यस्या नायिकायाः पदगतिः पादन्यासो न विपर्येति। तथा परपुष्टानां कोकिलानां सौष्ठवहरं वाक्यक्रमं या पुष्यति सा मानिन्यप्यालिङ्गन्ती विगतार्तवापि सा नायिका सन्ततिं प्रसूते । यद्वा विद्वत्तापक्षे मानं प्रत्यक्षादि ॥
column7: Honourable Lankaka! Your Erudition is unprecedented, with a felicity/gait that puts poets/geese to shame and never falters; It/she cultivates a manner of speech that evidently surpasses the eloquence possessed by others/koel’s sweet voice. Strangely, however, it/she passionately clasps your throat in spite of not abandoning the valid means of knowledge/love-anger and gives birth to Fame even though it is free of the agitation caused by the quality of rajas/her menses has stopped.
column8: The poet likens erudition to Lankaka’s beloved, who is described (by a clever use of pun) as clasping his throat (JR explains ‘gṛhītakaṇṭhā’ as ‘sādaramadhītā’, i.e., 'practised diligently') though she is overcome by love-anger and as begetting fame in spite of her menses having stopped.

column4: मार्गे पदस्य पथि वाक्यकथाप्रथानां मानस्य वर्त्मनि च कन्दलिताभिषेकः । राज्ञेव मन्त्रिवर लङ्कक सूक्तिदेव्या सर्वाधिपत्यपदवीमधिरोपितोऽसि ॥ ४३ ॥
column5: mārge padasya pathi vākyakathāprathānāṃ mānasya vartmani ca kandalitābhiṣekaḥ | rājñeva mantrivara laṅkaka sūktidevyā sarvādhipatyapadavīmadhiropito'si || 43 ||
column6: पदस्य सुप्तिङन्तादेर्मार्गे तथा वाक्यानां तर्काद्यलङ्कारप्रथानां पथि तथा मानस्य प्रत्यक्षादेर्मार्गे विहिताभिषेको भवान्यथा राज्ञा सकलाधिपत्यमधिरोपितस्तथा सरस्वत्या चाधिरोपितः । राजपक्षे मान आदेशः । पदमधिकारः । वाक्यमालापः ॥
column7: Lankaka! Minister par excellence!  The Goddess of poetry, Sarasvati, like the Emperor himself, has raised you to the level of a sovereign master with a ceremonial coronation in the realm of words/official power, the path of poetic tropes and narrative/logical argumentation and debate, and the domain of epistemology/dignified command.
column8: The idea is that Lankaka excels both as a scholar and as a royal official. In the domain of scholarship, the words 'pada', 'vākya, and 'māna' ('pramāṇa') stand respectively for the fields of Vyākaraṇa, 'Tarka', and 'Mīmāṃsā'.

column4: श्रीमल्लङ्कक यद्विशङ्कमुरगाधीशस्य हालाहल-ज्वालाडम्बरडामराद्वदनतस्तात्पर्यतो निर्ययौ । वाग्देवीकरकुम्भनिर्यदमृतोद्रिक्तेन सिक्ते महा-भाष्यं काव्यरसेन तत्तव चिरं वक्त्रेऽद्य विश्राम्यति ॥ ४४ ॥
column5: śrīmallaṅkaka yadviśaṅkamuragādhīśasya hālāhala-jvālāḍambaraḍāmarādvadanatastātparyato niryayau | vāgdevīkarakumbhaniryadamṛtodriktena sikte mahā-bhāṣyaṃ kāvyarasena tattava ciraṃ vaktre'dya viśrāmyati || 44 ||
column6: विषज्वालादुरीक्ष्याच्छेषस्य मुखाद्यनिर्ययौ तन्महाभाष्यं सरस्वतीहस्तस्थकलशगलदमृतार्द्रेण काव्यरसेन सिक्ते तव मुखे विश्रान्तिमेति विषदिग्धशेषमुखान्महाभाष्यं सरस्वतीसुधासिक्तकाव्यसिक्ते तव मुखे सुखं लभते । त्वया महाभाष्यं सुबोधं कृतमित्यर्थः ॥
column7: Esteemed Lankaka! The Mahabhashya that emanated in its essentially cryptic form from the mouth of the Lord of Serpents, made ferocious by a mass of venomous flames, finds eternal repose in your mouth, drenched by the stream of poetry, which Sarasvati has generously sprinkled with the ambrosia in her hand-held pitcher.
column8: The purport is that Lankaka made the grammar text Mahābhāṣya easily understandable through his expositions (JR); Patanjali, the author of Mahābhāṣya, is regarded as an incarnation of the Serpent Lord .

column4: स्वान्ताक्रान्तसरस्वतीगृहबृहद्राजीवनालोन्नत-श्लिष्यत्कण्टकशिक्षयेव शतशः पुष्णाति या तीक्ष्णताम् । तस्यां भिन्नसमग्रशास्त्रगहनग्रन्थ्युद्गतौ त्वद्धियि श्रीमल्लङ्कक किं कलिः किल पदं स्वप्नेऽपि दातुं क्षमः ॥ ४५ ॥
column5: svāntākrāntasarasvatīgṛhabṛhadrājīvanālonnata-śliṣyatkaṇṭakaśikṣayeva śataśaḥ puṣṇāti yā tīkṣṇatām | tasyāṃ bhinnasamagraśāstragahanagranthyudgatau tvaddhiyi śrīmallaṅkaka kiṃ kaliḥ kila padaṃ svapne'pi dātuṃ kṣamaḥ || 45 ||
column6: या त्वन्मतिस्तीक्ष्णतां विचारकौशलं पुष्णाति । अत्रोत्प्रेक्षा- स्वान्तेनाक्रान्ता या सरस्वती तस्या गृहं यद्राजीवं तन्नाले उल्लसन्त उदग्रा ये कण्टकास्तेभ्यः शिक्षया उपदेशेन शतशस्तस्यां त्वन्मतौ तीक्ष्णत्ववशाद्भिन्नाः समस्तशास्त्राणां ग्रन्थ्युद्गतयः संशयस्थानानि यया एवम्भूतायां पदं दातुं कलिः स्वप्नेऽपि न समर्थः । यच्च तीक्ष्णं तत्र पदं दातुं न शक्यते ॥
column7: Blessed Lankaka! Can (evil) Kali gain a foothold in your wise intellect even in his dream, (an intellect) which has attained sharpness in a hundred different ways, due, as if, to being trained by the long thorns sticking out from the stem of the large lotus which Goddess Sarasvati, trapped in your heart, has made her abode; (an intellect) which penetrates its way through the tangled web of knots presented by all the domains of knowledge put together?
column8: Evil thoughts, triggered by Kali, did not find a place in Lankaka’s intellect. One cannot gain a foothold on a sharp surface (JR).

column4: बाणोपमः प्रबन्धो लङ्कक तव पत्रलब्धदूरगतिः । विध्यति कस्य न हृदयं विविधसमज्यानिवेशेन ॥ ४६ ॥
column5: bāṇopamaḥ prabandho laṅkaka tava patralabdhadūragatiḥ | vidhyati kasya na hṛdayaṃ vividhasamajyāniveśena || 46 ||
column6: बाणः कविस्तत्कृतः प्रबन्ध उपचाराद्बा​णः, तत्समस्तव प्रबन्धो दूरं लब्धा पत्रेषु ग्रन्थाधारेषु गतिर्येर्नैवंविधो विविधासु समज्यासु सभासु निवेशेन प्रतिष्ठ​या कस्य न हृदयं विध्यति रसज्ञं करोति । बाणः शरश्च दूरं लब्धा पत्रैः पक्षैर्गतिर्गमनं येन स विचित्रा समा या ज्या तस्यां निवेशेन कस्य न हृदयं भिनत्ति ॥
column7: Lankaka! Your literary work, like that of the poet Bana/an arrow, has travelled quite far, thanks to the copies of its manuscript/its feathers. Whose heart does it not penetrate after finding its way into many a scholarly assembly/being fixed to many a bowstring stretched straight?
column8: N/A

column4: आरूढाः शुभमेधसां परिचयात्तं पावकोपक्रमं श्रीमल्लङ्कक पाकमाकलयितुं व्यग्रा वचोवर्त्मनि । स्निह्यत्पात्रसहस्रपूरणभरादुन्मीलयन्तो मुदं भावत्काः प्रगुणा गुणा बहुरसाभिज्ञं जगत्कुर्वते ॥ ४७ ॥
column5: ārūḍhāḥ śubhamedhasāṃ paricayāttaṃ pāvakopakramaṃ śrīmallaṅkaka pākamākalayituṃ vyagrā vacovartmani | snihyatpātrasahasrapūraṇabharādunmīlayanto mudaṃ bhāvatkāḥ praguṇā guṇā bahurasābhijñaṃ jagatkurvate || 47 ||
column6: भावत्कास्त्वत्सम्बन्धिनः प्रगुणा निःसङ्ख्या गुणाः पाण्डित्यादयो जगद्बहूनां रसानां शृङ्गारादीनामभिज्ञं कुर्वते । कीदृशाः । शुभा मेधा धारणबुद्धिर्येषां तेषां परिचयात्तं प्रसिद्धं पावकोपक्रमं पवित्रीकरणहेतुं क्रियारम्भमारूढाः । वचोवर्त्मनि काव्ये पाकं विस्रष्टुं व्यग्राः । स्निह्यन्ति यानि पात्राणि योजनास्तेषां सहस्रपूरणभराद्धर्षं जनयन्तः । गुणाः सूदाश्च जगद्रसानां मधुरादीनामभिज्ञं कुर्वते । ते चैधसां समिधां परिचयात्पावकोपक्रमं ज्वलनारम्भमारोपयन्तः । तथा पक्वतां सम्पादयितुं व्यग्राः । स्निह्यतां पात्राणां भाजनानां सहस्रस्य पूरणाद्धर्षं कुर्वन्तः ॥ इत्येते लोष्टकश्लोकाः ॥
column7: Revered Lankaka! Your numerous traits/chefs make the world conversant with plentiful joy/tastes; attain blessedness by being known to the pure-minded/initiate the proper process of kindling fire after collecting firewood; eagerly impart perfection to poetic expressions/chat busily while preparing a dish and spread happiness by tirelessly fulfilling the desires of thousands of friendly supplicants/filling thousands of oily containers”.
column8: Loshtadeva’s 11 verses end with this one.

column4: आक्रान्ता यस्य वक्रिम्णा दीर्घदीर्घगुणा गिरः। वाग्देवीकरवल्लक्या इव पुष्णन्ति माधुरीम् ॥ ४८ ॥
column5: ākrāntā yasya vakrimṇā dīrghadīrghaguṇā giraḥ| vāgdevīkaravallakyā iva puṣṇanti mādhurīm || 48 ||
column6: See below under verse 25.50
column7: See below under verse 25.50
column8: See below under verse 25.50

column4: द्विजराजेन भजता प्रभाकररुचिग्रहम् । पावकेन श्रिता येन धामत्रयमयी स्थितिः ॥ ४९ ॥
column5: dvijarājena bhajatā prabhākararucigraham | pāvakena śritā yena dhāmatrayamayī sthitiḥ || 49 ||
column6: See below under verse 25.50
column7: See below under verse 25.50

column7: 55 and 56. And then he (i.e., Mankha), who treaded the path of the virtuous, offered his respects at length to Garga, the old sire; (Garga) who is the foremost among poets like Drona is among bowmen; in whose lucid words (i.e., poetic compositions), the many instances of Cheka alliteration – that infuse ambrosia into the ears and are effected cleverly by various means – find unique expression
column8: Verses 55,56 constitute a Yugma. Cheka is a type of alliteration (‘anuprāsa’) in which a group of consonants repeats once (‘cheko vyañjanasaṅghānāṃ sakṛtsāmyamanekadhā’, Sāhityadarpaṇa, 10.3). Mankha has cleverly interwoven this type of alliteration into the present verse, where the conjoint consonant ‘cche’, followed by ‘kā’, are repeated (‘vacasicchekāḥ svacche kāmapi’). JR's comment 'pradīparucītyādi tilakam' refers to the three verses that follow

column7: 57. to 59. Thus did the esteemed Devadhara – who, having taken recourse to the treatise called Mandira/temple through which he could make his way with relative ease, aided by the illumining light of Pradipa (‘The Lamp’, commentary on Mandira)/the lamp (i.e., the lamp lit within the temple), instantly had a vision of Vishnu’s very own supreme form; and the utterances of whom, known to have one single refuge (in the form of Vishnu), and who, therefore, is akin to the Ekayana path, were characterized by ingenuity/fourfoldness of form and boasted of an artistry that was made praiseworthy by the unstoppable and unswerving flow accompanying them/exhibited the insignia of Pradyumna, in the blessed company of Aniruddha, Krishna, and Balarama - delight his (i.e., Mankha’s) ears with a couple of nectarine verses in praise of Lankaka
column8: Verses 57-59 constitute a Tilaka set. The poet, through the use of pun, compares the technical treatise called Mandira to a temple through which Devadhara made his way aided by the lamp of the Pradīpa commentary. Verse 58 is an example for ‘word-based suggestion’ (‘śabdaśaktimūladhvani’); a simile is suggested here through the dual meanings of the words ‘aniruddhācyutabalaślāghyadarpakalāñcitāḥ’, ‘cāturātmyāñjitāḥ’, and ‘ekāyanasya’. On the one hand, the poet likens Devadhara to the Ekāyana system (of devotion towards Vishnu) and on the other, likens his utterances to the scriptural sayings of that system. The word ‘Ekāyana’, used as a noun (‘the sole path’ – ‘ekamayanam’), refers to a specific path of devotion to Vishnu that is defined as ‘‘the (branch of) Veda that is the sole path for attaining freedom from the cycle of birth and death’ (‘vedamekāyanābhidham | mokṣāyanāya vai panthā etadanyo na vidyate’, Īśvarasaṃhitā, 1.18); the same word, used as an adjective (‘he, who has Vishnu alone as his refuge’ – ‘ekaḥ ayanaṃ yasya saḥ’) qualifies Devadhara. The  Ekāyana scripture of the Pāñcarātra tradition repeatedly alludes to the fourfold manifestation (‘cāturātmya’) of Vishnu as Vasudeva, Sankarshana, Pradyumna, and Aniruddha (‘vāsudevaḥ saṅkarṣaṇaḥ pradyumnaḥ puruṣaḥ svayam | aniruddha iti brahmanmūrtivyūho:'bhidhīyate ||, Bhāgavata Purāṇa, 12.11.21). In Mankha’s verse, these four manifestations are denoted by the words ‘Acyuta’, ‘Bala’, ‘Darpaka’, and ‘Aniruddha’ respectively. The compound ‘aniruddhācyutabalaślāghyadarpakalāñcitāḥ’ must be split in two different ways - ‘aniruddhācyutabalaślāghyadarpakalā-añcitāḥ’ and ‘aniruddhācyutabalaślāghyadarpaka-lāñcitāḥ’ - depending on whether it qualifies Devadhara’s utterances or the sayings of the Ekāyana scripture respectively; likewise, the word ‘cāturātmya’ takes the meanings of ‘ingenuity’ (‘catura ātmā yasya sa caturātmā, tasya bhāvaḥ cāturātmyam’) and ‘fourfoldness’ (‘catvāra ātmānaḥ yasya sa caturātmā, tasya bhāvaḥ cāturātmyam’) depending on the context. Note that the poet exercises some freedom in using ‘lāñcitāḥ’ instead of ‘lāñchitāḥ’ so as to meet the purpose of pun.

column7: “O Alankara! The primeval poet (i.e., Valmiki) pierced the deer of my heart with three Kandas (of the Ramayana)/arrows and subsequently, the poet Bana/(another) arrow hit it hard; Yet it continued to dart around. However, it has finally settled down after listening to a small portion of the suggestive poetry that permeates your every word/sweet music that you create every moment.
column8: Alankara’s poetry is superior to Valmiki's and Bana's; Deer are attracted to music (JR). JR does not offer any explanation for the expression 'tribhiḥ kāṇḍaiḥ' - Why does Devadhara say 'with three Kāṇḍas (of Ramayana)' instead of saying 'with the seven kāṇḍas'? One possible explanation is this: It is in the third Kāṇḍa (the Araṇya Kāṇḍa) of the Ramayana that Rama is described as hitting an arrow at the demon Maricha, who came disguised as a deer; to put it differently, Valmiki had to wait for the third Kāṇḍa before he could make Rama hit the deer. A simpler explanation is that some three Kāṇḍas of the Ramayana were specially appealing to Devadhara.

column7: 62. to 64. Mankha beheld Naga, the chamberlain of Lady Literature; (Naga) who, though middle-aged, seemed much older and more mature because of his noble traits; who possesses a strong desire to study/hear a lot and exhibits a rich vocabulary of hundreds of words/is richly endowed with hundreds of feet, thus making his name (that means ‘semi-divine serpent’) true to its meaning; and to whose blessed state, the discipline of grammar stands proof like a bracelet (of honour) for, like the latter, it is established by Panini/tied around the hand and attains grandeur through (the work of) Vararuci/with its excellent glow.
column8: The semi-divine Nāgas are many-headed and many-footed (JR). ‘Pāṇinibaddha’ must be split in two ways: ‘pāṇini-baddha’ ('established by Panini’) and ‘pāṇi-nibaddha’ (‘tied around the hand’)  (JR). Verses 62-64 constitute a Tilaka.

column6: तर्काणां कार्कश्ये दृढपरिचयोऽपि कविकर्मणि शृङ्गारादिरसकोमले काव्ये प्रगल्भो यः श्रीतुतातितस्य पुनर्जन्मान्तरग्रह इव भवति । तुतातितः कुमारिलः । स हि तार्किकः कविश्वासीत्। महतां सम्यङ्नामग्रहणमयुक्तमिति तुतातितशब्दः प्रयुक्तः । विवरणावसरे युक्तः । अन्यथा विवरणत्वाभावप्रसङ्गात् (?) । सत्कर्मिणां सदाचाराणां धुरि गण्यं तं श्रीत्रैलोक्यं दृष्ट्वाधिज्यस्य धनुषः सधर्मतां सादृश्यं ययौ । प्रणामं चकारेत्यर्थः । 'षट्कर्मिणाम्' इति पाठः ॥
column7: 65. and 66. Having beheld the venerable Trailokya – counted at the head of virtuous men; esteemed Tutatita’s after-life as it were; and adept in composing poetry despite being firmly established in rigorous logic – Mankha repeatedly assumed the nature of a stringed bow (i.e., he bent down in supplication)
column8: Tutatita is the famed Mīmāṃsaka Kumarila (JR). An alternate reading for ‘satkarmiṇām’ is ‘ṣaṭkarmiṇām’ (‘of those who perform the six activities’); the six activities prescribed for a Brahmin include studying, teaching, performing Vedic sacrifices, officiating Vedic sacrifices, donating in charity, and acceptance of gifts (‘ adhyāpanamadhyayanaṃ yajanaṃ yājanaṃ tathā | dānaṃ pratigrahaścaiva ṣaṭkarmāṇyagrajanmanaḥ ||, Manusmṛti, 10.75). Verses 65 and 66 constitute a Yugalaka/Yugmaka pair (JR).

column6: सर्वेभ्यो मानेनाहङ्कारेणातिरिक्तं तथा विवृतमपूर्वं गुणवत्त्वाल्लोकोत्तरं जन्म येन तेन चेतसाधिकार्यस्थितिर्म​र्यादा यस्य स भाति । सर्वेभ्यो मानेभ्यः प्रत्यक्षादिभ्योऽतिरिक्तेन । तथा विवृतं प्रकाशितं पूर्वशास्त्रानुष्ठानजनितस्य फलस्य जन्म येन तेन नियोगेन प्रवर्तककर्तव्यतारूपेण शास्त्रार्थेनाधिकार्येषु नियोज्येषु विषयभूतेषु स्थितिर्यस्य तम् । तथा सूक्तेर्भूरिगुणैरनर्घं दामोदरं बहुशः स्तुतवान् । तस्मिन्समये आसीदता आदरेण नतग्रीवः ॥
column7: 67. and 68. Bending his head respectfully before Damodara, he repeatedly praised the latter, who is a rich repository of poetry’s numerous merits and whose mind, like the Vedic injunction, has relinquished pride completely/is beyond the grasp of all means of knowledge, betrays its singularly remarkable nature/the genesis of unseen result, and is responsible for his (i.e., Damodara’s) highly noble demeanour/enjoins him (i.e., Damodara) to perform actions.
column8: The verse plays on the dual meanings of the words ‘māna’, ‘apūrva’, ‘adhikārya’, and ‘niyoga’; ‘apūrva’ and ‘niyoga’ are both technical terms in Pūrvamīmāṃsā. (See verse 17.30 and its footnote). JR has not explained the word ‘adhikārya’ in two ways - ‘adhika+ārya’/‘adhi+kārya’- as done in this translation. The purport of ‘niyogena adhikāryasthitiḥ’ is that Damodara was regulated by the Vedic injunction in the performance of his actions. Verses 67 and 68 constitute a Yugma pair.

column6: भट्टस्याचार्यस्य तथा प्रभाकरस्याचार्यस्य यन्नयद्वयं तदेव स्रोतसी तत्र नदीष्णता कुशलता येन व्यज्यते । अत एव निर्मृष्टाः शोधिता निःशेषाः कलिपांसवो येन । अथ च नदीस्नायिनश्च पांसुनिर्मार्जनमुचितम् । तथा सुवृत्तं शोभनाचारम् । तथा क्रमेण लब्धमूर्ध्वपदमुच्चपदं येन । तथा सरस्वतीकेलिकन्दुकाख्यक्रीडनकं जिन्दुकनामानं दृष्टिगोचरं चकार । कन्दुकस्य च सुष्ठु वृत्तता वर्तुलत्वं क्रमलब्धोर्ध्वपदता च भवति ॥ पथा चरतीति तिलकम् -
column7: 71. & 72. He let his eyes fall on Jinduka, who, like the sportive ball of Goddess Speech, is neatly spherical/well-behaved and has attained a lofty position bit by bit and who, the dust of evil Kali washed off completely from his person, evinces the fact that he has immersed himself in the river formed by the two streams of Kumarila Bhatta’s and Prabhakara’s doctrines.
column8: One is freed of dust by plunging in a river. Kumarila Bhatta and Prabhakara founded two schools of Pūrvamīmāṃsā. The footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition notes that the verse ‘etannarendravṛṣabha kṣapayā vrajantyā’ in Subhāṣitāvalī is ascribed to Jenduka. The complete verse (numbered 2166) is as follows: ‘etannarendravṛṣabha kṣapayā vrajantyā saṃropaṇārthamiva gopitamambujeṣu | udghāṭayatyayamaśītakaraḥ karaoghaiḥ padmākarāttimirabījamivālivṛndam || (‘O Great King! With his many ray-hands, the Moon pulls out a swarm of bees from the lotus pond as if it were the seed of darkness, which Lady Night had hidden within lotuses before she left for sowing in the future’). Verses 71 and 72 constitute a Yugma.

column7: 73. to 75. And then he honored Jalhana with words that were characterized by humility, (Jalhana) who was the minister of war and truce at the prosperous city of Rajapuri; whose Speech traverses a circuitous (poetic) path with clever words/quick steps as if eager to circumambulate Sarasvati; who imitates/chases poet Murari through his uncompromisingly oblique (poetic) works/stubbornly sinuous passages; and whose wealth of poetry has the poet Rajashekhara’s writings as its capital sum (i.e., whose poetry is inspired by the writings of Rajashekhara)
column8: The footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition mentions ‘Rājaverī’ and ‘Rajaurī’ in modern Kashmir as corresponding to ‘Rājapurī’; on the basis of the verse ‘rājapuryāmākulatvaṃ nītāyāmāsasāda tat | tadbhartuḥ somapālasya dūrasthasyāntikaṃ cirāt ||’ (Rājataraṅgiṇī, 8.1467), it also observes that Jalhana was the minister of war and truce under king Somapala and adds that the Mahākāvya ‘Somapālavilāsa’, which was composed by him and which has a commentary by name ‘Alaṅkārānusāriṇī‘ (by Rajanaka Ruchaka) was widely read in Kashmira. Verses 73-75 constitute a Tilaka set.

column7: 78. to 80. Mankha paid his most humble respects to Kalyana, who was unrivalled in his ability to entertain (others) with many an interesting story (or “who was unbeatable in his ability to joyfully engage with many a narrative text”); whom the honourable Alakadatta regarded as a suitable candidate for entrusting his entire poetic corpus since he (i.e., Kalyana) was the best among those who sculpt poetry; and who had thus polished the mirror of his diction that it was rendered capable of reflecting Bilhana’s expressive brilliance.
column8: The purport of verse 79 is that Kalyana imitated the grand style of Bilhana. JR defines ‘prauḍhi’ as the ability to express the meaning of a sentence in a word or the meaning of a word in a sentence (‘prauḍhiḥ padārthe vākyaracanā vākye ca padārthābhidhānam’); Alakadatta was a minister of war and truce (JR). Verses 78 to 80 constitute a Tilaka set.

column7: 89. to 91. Lakshmideva – who, being pious in nature, nourishes the Triple Fire in the manner of Vishwamitra; who sanctifies his study and understanding (of the Vedas) with the perfection of practice; whose handsome mouth, that naturally expresses affection towards the virtuous/Danu and abstains from wine/is an Asura, never ceases from sporting the Saman hymns/participating in battles involving the Devas; and who, foremost among the Soma-drinkers, freely traverses the Shastric paths - honoured him (i.e., Mankha) profusely with his blessings.
column8: To arrive at the punned meanings, ‘sadanuraktatām’ must be split in two ways – ‘sa, danu-raktatām’ and ‘sat+anuratatām’; likewise ‘sāmarāji’ must be split as ‘sa+amara+āji’ and ‘sāma+rāji’. Danu is the mother of the Asuras. Verses 89-91 constitute a Tilaka.

column7: 96. and 97. Afterwards, he paid obeisance to Ananda, foremost among all physicians, a refuge to the Shastric path, and the son of the great poet Shambhu; (Ananda) who had tided over (the fever of) evil Kali – causing excessive trembling due to the troublesome disruption of all (pious) activities/painful chills and manifesting endless agony/a continuous rise in bodily heat.

According to the footnote in the Kāvyamālā edition, Shambhu is the acclaimed author of  Anyoktimuktālatā and Rājendrakarṇapūra

column7: 100. to 102. Thereafter, he greeted yet another Suhala, a scholar who was the messenger of Govindachadra, the king of Kanyakubja; whose face, sheltered by the umbrella of Panini’s grammar, is never defiled by the dust of faulty speech even in dreams; and who, enriching his master’s realm through his counsels/consecrating Shiva’s Mandala with mantras occupies the foremost position among ambassadors/spiritual masters, rejoicing at the arrival of virtuous men/in the perpetual practice of the Agamas.
column8: The words ‘īśvara’ (king/Shiva), ‘maṇḍala’ (realm of a kingdom/a Mandala diagram), ‘mantra’ (counsel/holy chants), ‘āgama’ (arrival/the Āgama philosophy), and ‘daiśika’ (ambassador/spiritual master) each have dual meanings, one relating to polity and other to spiritual practice; ‘sadāgama’ must be split in two ways: ‘sat+āgama’ and ‘sadā+āgama’. ‘Daiśika’ is explained by JR as ‘deśāntarīya’ (‘an official staying in a different country’, i.e., ‘ambassador’); ‘daiśika’ is also ‘spiritual master’ (Cf  ‘sa ca daiśiko guruḥ’, Tantrasāra, 11.19). According to the footnote in the Kāvyamāla edition, Govindachandra is known to have lived in the first half of the 12th century AD. Verses 100-102 constitute a Tilaka.

column7: “And, having followed her lord (i.e., the Day) by jumping into the fire of the evening red that blazes up wildly from the directions/pyre, sky’s Lady Splendour is now reduced to mere bones, masquerading as stars” (This is the solution to the riddle).
column8: Moon = king; day = king’s enemy; sun’s orb = decapitated head of the king’s enemy; rays = tawny hair; sky’s splendour = wife of the king’s enemy; directions = pyre; evening red = fire; stars = bones. It is interesting to note that a similar idea has been explored by other Sanskrit poets (‘visraṃsamānakapilāṃśuśikhā(?śirā)sahasra-viṣpandisāndrarudhirasruti sūryabimbam | chinnaṃ javājjalanidhau nipapāta kālakhaḍgena visphuritamahna ivottamāṅgam ||’ Haravijaya, 19.25; ‘kṛtavikarālakālakaravālavilūnaviyadvikaṭaśiro:'nukāriravimaṇḍala-niḥsṛtayā | asulabharodhayā rudhiradhārikayeva samaṃ samajani sandhyayā ghaṭitapāṭalima dyutaṭam ||’, kapphiṇābhyudaya, 11.16; ‘kharakālakhaḍgadalitasya nirdayaṃ praśamaṃ dinasya sahasā gamiṣyataḥ | rudhirāruṇaṃ śira ivārkamaṇḍalaṃ nyapatatpayaḥsu caramasya nīradheḥ ||’, Surjanacarita, 14.37)

column7: 108. to 111. Thus did Tejakantha – whom learned men in every place crowned the emperor of gentlemen with the spreading radiance of their teeth as they exclaimed “Bravo! Well done!”; who, in Shurparaka’s alleys had quelled the heat of the opponent’s argumentative arrogance with his speech, whitened by the sandal paste of his teeth’s glow; and whom the glorious and highly acclaimed Aparaditya, lord of the Konkanas, had dispatched (to Kashmira) in the capacity of a messenger – speak to him entreatingly in faultless words that were characterized by clarity of the highest order.
column8: The footnote given in the Kāvyamāla edition notes that one Aparaditya wrote a Tīkā commentary on Yājñavalkyasmṛti and lived in the first half of the 12th century AD but maintains that the identity of this Aparaditya with the one mentioned by Mankha is doubtful. The idea in verse 109 is based on the ability of sandalwood paste to quell heat. JR identifies ‘Śūrpāraka’ with ‘kuṅkuṇa’ (the Kāvyamālā edition gives ‘Koṅkaṇa’ as an alternative reading). It corresponds to modern-day Nala Sopara in Maharashtra. Verses 108-111 constitute a Chakkalaka.

column6: सर्वे भिक्षितुं राजस्तुत्यादिना भिक्षापालनार्थं शिक्षन्ते । त्वया पुनरेकेन समस्तपण्डितानां भिक्षाकत्वं निवारयितुं शिक्षितम् । त्वत्काव्यं श्रीकण्ठचरितलक्षणं दृष्ट्वान्येऽपि कवयः श्रीकण्ठस्तुत्यैव वाणी पुनन्तीत्यर्थः ॥
column7: To fill their stomachs by begging do all of them train in knowledge. But you alone did not train so, desirous as you were to ward off the beggarhood of the scholarly community as a whole.
column8: The purport is that after seeing Mankha, other poets too started singing the praise of Shiva and stopped begging before mere mortals (JR). It seems the verse before JR did not have 'na' since he does not comment on that word; rather, from his use of the word 'punaḥ' ('tvayā punarekena'), it is possible to guess that his version had 'tu' (synonymous with 'punaḥ') in the place of 'na'. In that case, the translation of the verse would be this: 'Everyone learns to beg. But you alone learnt how to ward off the beggarhood of scholars'

column4: सम्भेदः श्रीसरस्वत्योः केवलं न विपन्मयम् । त्वं मोहमयमप्याशु मलं कस्य न लुम्पसि ॥ ११४ ॥
column5: sambhedaḥ śrīsarasvatyoḥ kevalaṃ na vipanmayam | tvaṃ mohamayamapyāśu malaṃ kasya na lumpasi || 114 ||
column6: त्वं कस्य न, अपि तु सर्वस्य विपद्रूपं मलं केवलं न नाशयसि, मोहमयमपि मलं सर्वेषां नाशयसि । अत्र हेतुमाह- लक्ष्मीसरस्वत्योः सम्भेदः सङ्गमः । 'सम्भेदः सिन्धुसङ्गमः' । तस्य च मलविलोपनमुचितम् । पापभीतस्य च संस्कारधारणमुचितम् ॥
column7: You are a confluence of (the dual streams of) affluence and erudition and therefore instantly wash away every man’s dirt, not merely of indigence but also of ignorance
column8: Bathing in a confluence of rivers is believed to wash away the dirt of sins (JR).

column4: सा वैदुषी फलं यस्या न परोपकृतेः परम् । शिक्षन्ते जीवनोपायमन्ये वाङ्मयशिल्पिनः ॥ ११५ ॥
column5: sā vaiduṣī phalaṃ yasyā na paropakṛteḥ param | śikṣante jīvanopāyamanye vāṅmayaśilpinaḥ || 115 ||
column6: यस्याः परोपकारादन्यत्फलं नास्ति सा वैदुषी भवति । अन्ये ये परोपकारं न कुर्वन्ति ते शास्त्रकर्मकरा जीवितोपायं शिक्षन्ते ॥
column7: That indeed is scholarship whose sole purpose is to help others. Others (i.e., those other than you, the purpose of whose scholarship is not to help others), however, are mere craftsmen with words, whose training is for eking out a living.
column8: N/A

column4: नृपचाटुकपाप्मभ्यस्तदित्थं तव यद्यपि । सरस्वती बिभेत्येव दधती शुद्धिसंस्क्रियाम् ॥ ११६ ॥
column5: nṛpacāṭukapāpmabhyastaditthaṃ tava yadyapi | sarasvatī bibhetyeva dadhatī śuddhisaṃskriyām || 116 ||
column6: See under verse 25.117 below
column7: See under verse 25.117 below
column8: See under verse 25.117 below

column4: तथापि मां गुणनिधे भज क्ष्मापचटूक्तिभिः । पञ्चषाभिः पठित्वा याः सभासूद्रिक्ततामियात् ॥ ११७ ॥
column5: tathāpi māṃ guṇanidhe bhaja kṣmāpacaṭūktibhiḥ | pañcaṣābhiḥ paṭhitvā yāḥ sabhāsūdriktatāmiyāt || 117 ||
column6: राजस्तुतिपापेभ्यस्तव सरस्वत्येवं यद्यपि भीता अत एव शुद्धिसंस्कारं दधती । तथापि हे गुणनिधे, पञ्च वा षड्वा पञ्चषाः ताभी राजस्तुतिकथाभिर्मामनुग्रहाण । याः पठित्वाहं सभासूद्रेकं प्राप्नुयाम्॥
column7: 116. and 117. Mine of merits! Though your Speech, purified by a process of refinement, shies away from the filthy sin of royal flattery, do honour me with a couple of kingly eulogies so I can read them out in assemblies and feel elated.
column8: Verses 116, 117 constitute a Yugma pair.

column4: असावध्यवसायोऽस्मदनुग्रहधिया च ते । न दुष्येत्प्रार्थिताः सन्तः किं न दद्युर्हि याचते ॥ ११८ ॥
column5: asāvadhyavasāyo'smadanugrahadhiyā ca te | na duṣyetprārthitāḥ santaḥ kiṃ na dadyurhi yācate || 118 ||
column6: अस्मास्वनुग्रहधिया हेतुभूतया तेऽयमध्यवसायो राजस्तुतिलक्षणो न दुष्येत् । अर्थान्तरन्यास:- कृतयाच्ञा सज्जनाः प्रार्थयमानाय किं नादेयं दद्युः ॥
column7: Such an act needn’t be faulted if it is regarded as a favour done (to me) by you. Is there anything the good do not grant when requested?
column8: Verses 112-118 were recited by Tejakantha.

column4: श्रोत्रशुक्तिपुटेनेति पीत्वा तद्वाक्यविप्रुषः । इमामुदगिरत्सोऽथ सूक्तिमुक्ताफलस्रजम् ॥ ११९ ॥
column5: śrotraśuktipuṭeneti pītvā tadvākyavipruṣaḥ | imāmudagiratso'tha sūktimuktāphalasrajam || 119 ||
column6: श्रुतिशष्कुलीमार्गेण तद्वचनबिन्दून्पीत्वा सूक्तान्येव मुक्ताफलानि तेषां मालां स उदवमत् । शुक्तिमार्गेण च जलकणान्पीत्वा समुद्रो मुक्ताफलान्युद्वमतीति मङ्खकविना स्वस्य समुद्रवद्गाम्भीर्यं प्रकाशितम् ॥
column7: Having sipped in droplets of his (i.e., Tejakantha’s) utterances with the cavity of his ear, akin to an oyster shell, he (i.e., Mankha) emitted this string of poetic pearls
column8: The poet indirectly suggests that he is similar to the ocean in the depth of his personality since it is the ocean that sips water droplets with oyster shells and emits pearls (JR).

column4: यद्वक्रेण पथा प्रयासि सततं यद्वासि विद्वन्मन-श्चौरी यच्च करोषि पूर्वसुकविप्रौढिप्रथोत्पुंसनम् । तस्माद्भारति सद्भिरत्र भवती तीक्ष्णेति सम्भाविता तूर्णं पार्श्वममुष्य पार्थिवमुनेरभ्येहि शुद्ध्यर्थिनी ॥ १२० ॥
column5: yadvakreṇa pathā prayāsi satataṃ yadvāsi vidvanmana-ścaurī yacca karoṣi pūrvasukaviprauḍhiprathotpuṃsanam | tasmādbhārati sadbhiratra bhavatī tīkṣṇeti sambhāvitā tūrṇaṃ pārśvamamuṣya pārthivamunerabhyehi śuddhyarthinī || 120 ||
column6: वक्रेण प्रसिद्धप्रस्थानातिरेकेण पथा यत्प्रयासि, नित्यं पण्डितचित्तावर्जका यच्चासि, यच्च पूर्वेषां सुकवीनां प्रौढा या प्रथा तस्या उत्पुंसनं बाधनं करोषि, ततः सद्भिस्तीक्ष्णा कुशाग्रीया सम्भाविता त्वम्। अतः शुद्ध्यर्थिनी त्वमस्य राजर्षेः समीपमभिगच्छ । यो हि वक्रेण परवञ्चकेन पथा नित्यं प्रयाति नित्यं च चौरः पटच्चरः परबाधनं करोति स हिंस्रः सम्भावितः शुद्ध्यर्थी शुद्धिकरसमीपं याति । पार्थिवमुनेरिति शुद्ध्यनुगुणम् ॥
column7: “Sarasvati! Since you take a deviant path, are frequently given to stealing the hearts of the learned, and thwart the glory of great poets from the past, good men think of you as cruel. Come, therefore, quickly to the side of this saintly king if you seek purification.
column8: One who has committed evil actions (such as taking a deviant path, stealing, and thwarting other’s glory) approaches a saintly person for redemption from the effects of such actions (JR). ‘Deviant path’ is explained by JR as ‘prasiddhaprasthānātirekeṇa pathā’, i.e., ‘a path that deviates from the norm’; it refers to the unconventional ways in which poets employ speech

column4: त्वत्खड्गेन जगत्त्रयैकगुरुणा राजन्गणो विद्विषां सङ्ग्रामेषु पलायनोपनिषदां सिद्धान्तमध्यापितः । उन्मुक्तासमसर्वशास्त्रसरणिः सन्त्यक्तपत्रक्रम-श्चित्रं चिन्तयितुं विविक्तविपिनासङ्गं समाश्लिष्यति ॥ १२१ ॥
column5: tvatkhaḍgena jagattrayaikaguruṇā rājangaṇo vidviṣāṃ saṅgrāmeṣu palāyanopaniṣadāṃ siddhāntamadhyāpitaḥ | unmuktāsamasarvaśāstrasaraṇiḥ santyaktapatrakrama-ścitraṃ cintayituṃ viviktavipināsaṅgaṃ samāśliṣyati || 121 ||
column6: जगत्त्रये एकेन गुरुणा गौरववता त्वत्खड्गेन पलायनोपनिषदामदर्शनरहस्यानां निश्चयं शत्रुवर्गोऽध्यापितः । अत उन्मुक्ता त्यक्ता असमा सर्वा समस्तशास्त्री शस्त्रसम्बन्धिनी सरणिर्येन तथा सन्त्यक्तः पत्रक्रमो वाहनक्रमो येन स तव वैरिवर्गो विजनवनासङ्गं चिन्तयितुं समाश्लिष्यति । यश्च गुरुणा उपनिषदां मोक्षोपायशास्त्राणां सिद्धान्तमध्यापितः स सन्त्यक्तसमग्रकुमार्गः तथा सन्त्यक्तः पत्रक्र​​मो ग्रन्थाधारक्रमो येन स विजनं चिन्तयितुं गच्छतीति चित्रम् ॥
column7: O King! The enemy’s troops, instructed in wars about the mystical tenet of the art of fleeing by your sword – the triple world’s sole object of worth/ master - completely abandon the ill-suited path of weapons/perverted doctrines, bring their chariots/scrutiny of texts to a halt, and retire, most strangely so, to the deserted woods for contemplation.
column8: Mankha likens Tejakantha’s sword to a spiritual master. One who has been instructed by his master in the mystical tenets of the Upanishads, has abandoned the path of perverted doctrines, and no longer engages with texts needn’t retire to the forest for contemplation. Since the enemies are described as retiring to the forest in spite of being instructed etc., the poet is justified in exclaiming ‘citram!’ (‘How strange!’). Contemplation, in the case of the enemies, refers to brooding over their sad predicament.

column4: व्यथोद्रेकादेका घनरुदितशोणे नृपदृशौ वहन्ते वैराग्यादिव विधृतकाषायवसने । अरण्यान्यामन्यास्त्वदरिवनिता यान्ति विपदं लतानां संसर्गादिव नवजटावल्कलभृतः ॥ १२२ ॥
column5: vyathodrekādekā ghanaruditaśoṇe nṛpadṛśau vahante vairāgyādiva vidhṛtakāṣāyavasane | araṇyānyāmanyāstvadarivanitā yānti vipadaṃ latānāṃ saṃsargādiva navajaṭāvalkalabhṛtaḥ || 122 ||
column6: अतिभयाद्यद्घ​नं रुदितमश्रु तेन रक्ते । अतः सम्भाव्यते - वैराग्याद्धृतं काषायं काषायरक्तं वसनं याभ्यां ते दृशावेकाः काश्चिद्वैरिरामा वहन्ते । अन्याः काश्चित्त्वद्वैरिरामा अरण्यान्यां महत्यरण्ये विपदं यान्ति। कीदृश्यः । जटा: संयताः कचास्तथा वल्कलं भूर्जादिकृतं वस्त्रं बिभ्रत्यः। अतः सम्भाव्यते - लतानां परिचयादिव । लता हि जटा मूलानि, वल्कलं त्वचं च बिभ्रति ॥
column7: O Protector of people! Some of your enemy’s wives exhibit eyes that have turned red on account of crying incessantly in extreme despair as if they (i.e., the eyes) had donned ochre robes due to disenchantment with the world while others – possessed of matted hair/hanging roots and bark garments/barks, due, as it were, to their association with wild creepers – face perils in the forest.
column8: N/A

column4: वैधव्योपहताः प्रतापतपनप्लुष्यद्वपुष्कान्तयः कान्ताराध्वसु लब्धसाध्वसभुवः प्रत्यर्थिवामभ्रवः । राजन्निर्भरबाष्पवारिविवलन्नेत्रालवालावली-सन्दोहैस्तव वर्धयन्ति विशदस्पन्दां यशःकन्दलीम् ॥ १२३ ॥
column5: vaidhavyopahatāḥ pratāpatapanapluṣyadvapuṣkāntayaḥ kāntārādhvasu labdhasādhvasabhuvaḥ pratyarthivāmabhravaḥ | rājannirbharabāṣpavārivivalannetrālavālāvalī-sandohaistava vardhayanti viśadaspandāṃ yaśaḥkandalīm || 123 ||
column6: वैधव्येन [पति]मारणोपहताः, प्रताप एव तपनः सूर्यस्तेन लुप्य​न्ती वपुष्कान्तिर्यासां ताः, कान्ताराध्वसु दुर्गममार्गेष्वपि, तथा लब्धं यत्साध्वसं तस्य भुवो भूमयः, प्रत्यर्थिनां वैरिणां वामभ्रुवस्तव निर्मलोल्लासां कीर्तिलतां वर्धयन्ति । कैः । निर्भरेण बाप्पवारिणा हेतुना विवलन्ति यानि नेत्राणि तान्येवालवालावल्यस्तत्समूहैः । आदित्यतापिताश्च भुवो ग्रीष्महताः सेकाधारैर्लतां वर्धयन्ति ॥
column7: O King! Your enemies’ pretty-browed wives – who are devastated by widowhood; whose bodily glow is burnt up by the scorching heat of (your) fiery valour; and who find many a ground for fear in the wilderness – nourish the creeper of your fame in a row of basins formed by their eyes that are filled with water up to the brim.
column8: Creepers grow in sun-scorched grounds that are furnished with water-filled basins (JR).

column4: प्रियान्प्रति मरौ लग्नाः कुर्वते त्वदरिस्त्रियः । सास्रधाराः कराश्लिष्टकुचाः पिण्डोदकक्रियाम् ॥ १२४ ॥
column5: priyānprati marau lagnāḥ kurvate tvadaristriyaḥ | sāsradhārāḥ karāśliṣṭakucāḥ piṇḍodakakriyām || 124 ||
column6: मरुभुवि सबाष्पप्रवाहा हस्तरुद्धस्तनाः । हृत्कम्पातिशयवशादिति भावः । त्वद्रिपुरामाः प्रियान्प्रति युद्धहतान्भर्तॄनुद्दिश्य पिण्डोदकक्रियां कुर्वत इत्युत्प्रेक्षा । कुचाः पिण्डस्थानीयाः, अश्रूदकस्थानीयम् ॥
column7: Covering their breasts with their hands and shedding streams of tears, the wives of your enemies, who dwell in the desert, (seem to) offer rice balls along with water to their (dead) husbands.
column8: The breasts stand for rice balls and streams of tears for water (JR).

column4: भिन्नभ्रूवलनाकुले तरलिते वक्त्रोडुपे सान्द्रया निःश्वासक्रमवात्यया किमपरं भर्तर्यरित्रे हते । राजेन्द्र त्वदरातिचन्द्रवदनालोकस्य शोकाचलो-द्भिन्नास्वश्रुतरङ्गिणीपु कुरुते दृङ्मज्जनोन्मजने ॥ १२५ ॥
column5: bhinnabhrūvalanākule taralite vaktroḍupe sāndrayā niḥśvāsakramavātyayā kimaparaṃ bhartaryaritre hate | rājendra tvadarāticandravadanālokasya śokācalo-dbhinnāsvaśrutaraṅgiṇīpu kurute dṛṅmajjanonmajane || 125 ||
column6: अरिभ्यस्त्रायते अरींस्त्रायत इति वा इत्यरित्रे तथाविधे भर्तरि हते अतः सान्द्रया नि:श्वासा एव क्रमवात्या तया करणभूतया छिन्नं भ्रूणां वलनं तेनाकुले मुखप्रवहणे तरलिते सति त्वदरिरामागणस्य दृष्टिः शोकशैलोद्भिन्नासु बाष्पनदीषु मज्ज​नोन्मज्जने कुरुते । वात्यया छिन्नवलने चोडुपे भग्ने अरित्रे केनिपातने हते प्रवहणगामी नद्यां निमज्जति चोन्मज्जति च ॥
column7: King of kings! The moon/raft that is the face of your enemy’s moon-faced maiden is ruffled by the whirling of eyebrows and trembles in the storm of sighing breaths. And what’s more, her husband, who protected her from the enemy is dead/the rudder that supported it (i.e., the raft) has broken. Because of all this, her eyes are tossed up and down in streams of tears arising from the mountain of sorrow.
column8: The eyes of the widows are compared to sailors who are tossed about in a stream of tears owing to their raft (= face) being shaken up by a storm (= sighing breaths) and the rudder (= husband) supporting the raft getting destroyed (JR).

column4: त्वद्यात्रासमवेतदुर्धरगतेः सैन्यस्य सम्मर्दतो द्राक्पिष्टेऽपि शिरोगणे गुणयुगं जज्ञे फणाभृत्पतेः । प्रापद्भूपरमाणुभिस्तरलितैः कालुष्यमक्ष्णां न य-द्धृ​द्भङ्गस्य च कारणं यदशृणोन्नो पत्तिकोलाहलम् ॥ १२६ ॥
column5: tvadyātrāsamavetadurdharaṅgateḥ sainyasya sammardato drākpiṣṭe'pi śirogaṇe guṇayugaṃ jajñe phaṇābhṛtpateḥ | prāpadbhūparamāṇubhistaralitaiḥ kāluṣyamakṣṇāṃ na ya- ddhṛdbhaṅgasya ca kāraṇaṃ yadaśṛṇonno pattikolāhalam || 126 ||
column6: त्वदीययात्रासु समवेतस्य सङ्घटितस्य अत एव दुर्धरगतेर्दुर्वह​​धावनस्य सैन्यस्य मर्दनेन फणगणे क्लेशितेऽपि शेषस्योपकारद्वयं जातम् । सैन्यमर्देनाधः पतितै रजोभिरुचितमपि दृष्टिकालुष्यं शेषो यन्न प्रापत् , तथा हृद्भङ्गहेतुं पदातिसिंहनादं च यन्नाशृणोत् ततः ॥ एते श्रीतेजकण्ठाभ्यर्थनया कृताः श्लोकाः ॥
column7: Though the Serpent Lord’s multitude of heads was crushed instantly under the burden of a densely packed army, assembled during your military expedition and marching forward with an unbearable speed, it still was favourable for him on two accounts – his eyes were not agitated by the specks of dust that were thrown around and he did not hear the heart-rending clamour of the foot soldiers”.
column8: JR doesn’t explain why the Serpent Lord’s eyes were not agitated by the dust or why he didn’t hear the clamour. One possible explanation is that, along with his heads, his ears and eyes too were crushed under the weight of Tejakantha’s army. Verses 120 to 125 were composed by Mankha on the request of Tejakantha.

column4: ततो यथार्थनामानं द्विजं वागीश्वराभिधम् । अस्तोष्ट पठितश्लोकमिति श्रीलङ्ककं प्रति ॥ १२७ ॥

column4: त्वयि प्रसन्ने मम किं गुणेन त्वय्यप्रसन्ने मम किं गुणेन । रक्ते विरक्ते च वरेऽङ्गनानां मिथ्यैव नेपथ्यविशेषभङ्गिः ॥ १२८ ॥
column5: tvayi prasanne mama kiṃ guṇena tvayyaprasanne mama kiṃ guṇena | rakte virakte ca vare'ṅganānāṃ mithyaiva nepathyaviśeṣabhaṅgiḥ || 128 ||
column6: यदि मयि त्वं प्रसन्नः गुणाः किमर्थाः । गुणैः साध्यस्य प्रसादनस्य स्वयं सिद्धत्वात् । अथ त्वमप्रसन्नः गुणाः किमर्थाः । गुणसाध्यस्य प्रसादस्याभावात् । एतद्दृष्टान्तेन स्पष्टीकरोति - भर्तरि रक्ते किमर्थो वेषः, विरक्ते वा किमर्थो वेषः ॥ इति श्रीभट्टवागीश्वरस्य श्लोकः॥
column7: “Of what use is my merit if you are already pleased (with me)? And of what use is it if you are displeased? Useless indeed is the gorgeous makeup worn by women, irrespective of whether their husbands are attracted to them or not”.
column8: Cf. ‘tvayi prasanne mama kiṃ guṇena tvayyaprasanne mama kiṃ guṇena | rakte virakte ca vare vadhūnāṃ nirarthakaḥ kuṅkumapatrabhaṅgaḥ ||’, (Kṛṣṇakarṇāmṛta, 2.99); ‘tvayi prasanne kimihāparairnastvayyaprasanne kimihāparainaḥ ||’ (Kṛṣṇakarṇāmṛta, 1.29)

column4: सकृदाकर्णनघ्रातसमस्तग्रन्थसंसृतेः । इति तस्य पटोः पट्वीं गिरं चिरमचर्चयत् ॥ १३१ ॥ (तिलकम्)
column5: sakṛdākarṇanaghrātasamastagranthasaṃsṛteḥ | iti tasya paṭoḥ paṭvīṃ giraṃ ciramacarcayat || 131 || (tilakam)
column6: अचार्मणे दिव्ये काव्यपाण्डित्यमये नेत्रे दधानो यः सुखेन समस्तं सरस्वतीसम्बन्धिनं मार्गं दृष्टवान् । शास्त्रमार्गे सञ्चरतोऽसच्चर्मचक्षुषोऽप्रशस्तदृशोऽल्पदृष्टेर्यस्य सरस्वतीहस्तावलम्बेन पदैः सुप्तिङन्तादिभिर्न स्खलितम् । अविद्यमानदृष्टेरन्धस्य च हस्तावलम्बेन पदानि न स्खलन्ति । ग्रन्था एवानन्तत्वात्संसृतिः संसारः सकृदाकर्णनेनैकवारं श्रवणेनाघ्राताधीता समग्रा ग्रन्थसंसृतिर्येन तस्य पटुपण्डितस्योक्तिं स चर्चितवान् ।
column7: 129 to 131. He deliberated for long on Patu’s skilled verse (i.e., the verse that follows) – who (i.e., Patu), possessed of the non-corporeal eyes in the form of poetic genius and scholarship, beheld the path of speech in its entirety without any difficulty; who, though devoid of the physical eyes, never faltered in his steps/words while travelling on the road of Shastric knowledge because Goddess Sarasvati held him with her hand; and who had breathed in the fragrance of the entire textual universe (i.e., 'who had learnt by heart the entire corpus of scholarly texts') from merely listening to it once.
column8: Note the contextually clever use of the words 'ghrāta' ('smelled', rendered in the translation by 'breathed in the fragrance') and 'ākarṇana' ('listening'); since Patu is blind, his engagement with texts must involve sense modalities other than vision.

column4: तज्ज्ञसूरिकृतप्रीति चारुमन्दारपुष्पवत् । कदा भवन्महाकाव्यं व्योमेवेक्षे ध्रुवस्थिति ॥ १३२ ॥
column5: tajjñasūrikṛtaprīti cārumandārapuṣpavat | kadā bhavanmahākāvyaṃ vyomevekṣe dhruvasthiti || 132 ||
column6: तज्ज्ञाश्च ते सूरयस्तेषां कृता प्रीतिर्येन । मन्दारपुष्पवत्सुन्दरम् । अविनश्वरप्रकृति । तत्प्रसिद्धत्वात्काव्यं कदा पश्यामि । व्योमेव बुधबृहस्पतिभ्यां कृतप्रीति । चारवो मन्दार पुष्पवन्तः शनिर्भौमार्केन्दवो यत्र । ध्रुवस्य नक्षत्र[विशेष]स्य स्थितिर्यत्र ॥ इति पण्डितपटुश्लोकः ॥
column7: “When shall I behold that epic poem of yours, which, like space, is dear to scholars well-versed with it/Mercury and Jupiter; beautiful like a Mandara blossom/an abode of the beautiful Saturn, Mars, sun, and moon; and everlasting/shelters the Pole Star”.
column8: Verses 129-131 on the blind poet Paṭu constitute a Tilaka. ‘Tajjña’ in one sense (i.e., with respect to the poem) must be taken as a single word meaning ‘scholars well-versed with it’ and in other sense (i.e., with respect to the sky) split as two independent words ‘tat+jña’, of which the ‘tat’ (‘that’) part must be construed with ‘bhavanmahākāvyaṃ’ (‘epic poem of yours’) and the ‘jña’ part must be taken as one of the words in the compound ‘jñasūrikṛtaprīti’. ‘Jña’, ‘sūri’, ‘manda’, ‘ara’, and ‘puṣpavat’ stand respectively for ‘’Mercury’, ‘Jupiter’, ‘Saturn’, ‘Mars’, and ‘sun and moon’ respectively. Paṭu’s question ‘When shall I behold?’ (‘kadā īkṣe?’) rises beyond being a simple rhetorical question by poignantly drawing our attention to his blindness.

column4: ज्यायसो वीक्ष्य विद्वद्भिर्हर्षदामिति पर्षदम् । स तदा सुचिरं दध्रे दृशं कर्णान्तचुम्बिनीम् ॥ १३३ ॥

column7: A scholarly debate among the learned men became a source of intellectual pleasure resulting from an engagement with the six schools of logic. To his (i.e., Mankha’s) ears, it presented a sumptuous meal abounding in the six tastes.
column8: The Kashmiri logician Jayantabhatta includes Sāṅkhya, Ārhata (jaina), Bauddha, Cārvāka, Vaiśeṣika, and Naiyyāyika philosophies among the six schools of logic (‘asyāṃ prasiddhāyāmapi ṣaṭtarkyām’ Nyāyamañjarī, 1.1; the commentary Nyāyasaurabha explains ‘ṣattarkī’ as  ‘tarkāvalambiṣu sāṅkhyārhatabauddhacārvāka-vaiśeṣikanaiyyāyikeṣu ṣaṭsu ṣaṭtarkīti prasiddheṣu’)

column7: “You alone have truly served Sarasvati by observing hundreds of pious vows one after another across several past life-times. For, established effortlessly in poetry, you communicate the plain fact that you are Sarasvati’s son born of her womb.
column8: ‘Yatnaṃ vināpi’ = ‘abhyāsaṃ vinaiva’ = ‘effortlessly’, i.e., ‘even without repeated practice’. Ruyyaka believes Mankha must be the son of Sarasvati herself since he could compose great poetry without putting any effort into practice (inborn creativity, erudition, and repeated practice put together are regarded as the cause of poetry – ‘śaktirnipuṇatā lokaśāstrakāvyādyavekṣaṇāt | kāvyajñaśikṣayābhyāsa iti hetustadudbhave ||’, Kāvyaprakāśa, 1.3)

column6: सौष्ठवे दार्ढ्ये अशैथिल्ये व्यसनि काव्यकलाशरीरं शब्दार्थसन्दर्भो दोषरूपं रोगं न जातु प्राप्नोति। यत्र शक्तिव्युत्पत्त्यभ्यासास्त्रयोऽपि निर्विकाराः समाः । यत्र शरीरे चाविकृतास्त्रयो दोषा वाय्वादयः समास्तच्छरीरं रोगं न प्राप्नोति ॥
column7: The body of poetry, seeking to grow strong, is saved forever from the illness of flawed utterances when the triad beginning with inborn creativity, akin to the triad of humours, is in a state of undisturbed balance.
column8: See footnote under verse 25.136 above for the triad beginning with inborn creativity. Health is attributed to the equilibrium of the three ‘doṣas’ (‘humours’), namely 'vāta', 'pitta', and 'kapha' (‘doṣasāmyamarogatā’, Aṣṭāṅgahṛdaya, 1.20).

column4: धन्यस्त्वं विनिवेशितैर्बहुतिथैरर्थैः स्थितिं बिभ्रती न क्वापि स्ववपुः प्रसारितवती पण्यत्वसंसिद्धये । सालङ्कारपदाधिकध्वनिजुषा मूर्त्या नरीनर्त्य​सौ शम्भोर्येन पुरोऽर्पिता भगवतो वाग्देवतानर्तकी ॥ १३९ ॥

column6: बहुतिथैर्वाच्यलक्ष्यव्यङ्ग्यादिभिरर्थैर्धनैश्च स्थितिं दधाना तथा पवित्रत्वार्थं सर्वत्र स्वरूपं निह्नुवाना । या सालङ्कारैः सोपमोत्प्रेक्षादिभिः सविभूषणैश्च पदैः सुप्तिङन्तादिभिः पदयोश्चरणयोश्च योऽधिको ध्वनिस्तं बिभ्रता रूपेणात्यर्थं नृत्यति सा सरस्वतीनर्तकी येन हरमुद्दिश्य प्रतिपादिता स त्वं धन्यः ॥
column7: You are indeed blessed! The danseuse that is divine Muse, whom you presented before Lord Shambhu, dances superbly with her form – enriched by the music of her feet, which are adorned with anklets/suggestive meanings stemming from her ornate words - never once putting her beauty for sale before others since her existence has been made secure (by you) through a provision of material resources/meanings of various kinds
column8: The words ‘artha’, ‘alaṅkāra’, ‘pada’ and ‘dhvani’ are used in a dual sense, one relating to poetry and other to a danseuse.

column4: यच्छ्रीमङ्खक मुख्यतां गतवता व्युत्पत्तिविच्छित्तिभिः श्रीश्रीकण्ठचरित्रमित्यभिधया काव्यं व्यधायि त्वया । एतस्मिन्सदसि प्रसिद्धविविधोपासीनविद्वद्वरे तत्सन्दर्शय तस्य रोहतुतरां साफल्यतः कल्पता ॥ १४० ॥
column5: yacchrīmaṅkhaka mukhyatāṃ gatavatā vyutpattivicchittibhiḥ śrīśrīkaṇṭhacaritramityabhidhayā kāvyaṃ vyadhāyi tvayā | etasminsadasi prasiddhavividhopāsīnavidvadvare tatsandarśaya tasya rohatutarāṃ sāphalyataḥ kalpatā || 140 ||
column6: व्युत्पत्तिभङ्गिभिः प्राधान्यं प्राप्तवता श्रीकण्ठचरिताख्यं काव्यं यत्त्वया कृतं तदस्यां सभायां सावधानपण्डितायां सन्दर्शय । तस्य काव्यस्य सफलत्वेन स्तुतिरुत्पद्यताम् ॥
column7: Esteemed Mankhaka! Let the poem, called “Shrikanthacharitram”, that was composed by you – who have gained prominence due to your multifaceted scholarship – be unveiled in this assembly, in which are seated several famous stalwarts of knowledge, so its praiseworthiness can reach newer heights through the fulfilment of its purpose.
column8: Śrīkaṇṭhacaritram’ = ‘Śrīkaṇṭhacaritam’. Could ‘kalpatā’ have been ‘kalyatā’, so an alliterative effect is created along with ‘sāphalyataḥ’?

column4: आरूढां परिपाकवर्त्मनि धुरं तत्तद्रसस्यन्दिनीं निःशेषोऽपि सभाजनोऽयमधिकं श्रद्धानुबन्धातिथिः । वीप्सामूर्धविधूननाकुलतरोत्तंसोत्पलाग्रच्छदै-रुन्मीलद्रसनैरिव श्रुतिपुटैस्त्वद्वाचमाचामतु ॥ १४१ ॥
column5: ārūḍhāṃ paripākavartmani dhuraṃ tattadrasasyandinīṃ niḥśeṣo'pi sabhājano'yamadhikaṃ śraddhānubandhātithiḥ | vīpsāmūrdhavidhūnanākulatarottaṃsotpalāgracchadai-runmīladrasanairiva śrutipuṭaistvadvācamācāmatu || 141 ||
column6: परिपक्वां सरसां च त्व​द्वाचं सश्रद्धः सभ्यवर्गः श्रवणैश्चर्वयतु । चमत्कारवशात्पुनः पुन: शिरःकम्पचपलकर्णाभरणोत्पलपत्रैः । अतः सम्भाव्यते- स्फुरज्जिह्वैरिव । चर्वयतां हि रसना स्फुरति॥
column7: May all the men in this assembly dedicatedly savour your speech – which, prepared to perfection, releases myriad flavours – with their ears, sprouting tongues as it were by way of the fresh petals of the (red) lilies worn as ear ornaments, (petals) that flutter when they nod their heads (in appreciation) many times over”.
column8: Ruyyaka likens Mankha’s poetry to a delicacy that is savoured by the pundits in the assembly with their ears that seem to sport tongues through the petals of the red lotuses adorning them. Verses 136-141 are by Ruyyaka

column4: श्रुत्वा वाक्यमुदारमाशयविदस्तत्तस्य सम्यग्गुरोः किञ्चिन्यञ्चितकन्धरेण शिरसा स व्यञ्जितप्रश्रयः । वाग्देवीकरिणीविसृत्वरमदस्रोतःकणस्पर्धता-मारूद्वैरिव गृढमक्षरशतैर्व्यस्तारयत्पुस्तकम् ॥ १४२ ॥
column5: śrutvā vākyamudāramāśayavidastattasya samyagguroḥkiñcinyañcitakandhareṇa śirasā sa vyañjitapraśrayaḥ | vāgdevīkariṇīvisṛtvaramadasrotaḥkaṇaspardhatā-mārūdvairiva gṛḍhamakṣaraśatairvyastārayatpustakam || 142 ||
column6: भावज्ञम्य श्रीरुय्यकस्योदारं तद्वचनं श्रुत्वा किञ्चिन्नम्रेण शिरसा प्रकाशितविनयः स मङ्खकः सरस्वतीहस्तिनीमदजलकणसमैर्वर्णैः सहितं पुस्तकं विस्तारितवान् ॥
column7: Having listened attentively to those gracious words of his master, who had read his mind, he conveyed his respects to him by bending his head a little and then opened his book, the hundreds of letters hidden in it vying, as it were, with droplets in the spreading stream of ichor of the she-elephant that is Sarasvati.
column8: Rarely do Sanskrit poets describe female elephants as oozing ichor. Though rare, musth in cow elephants has been observed and studied (e.g., Swain, Debabrata & Singh, Lalit. (2003). Musth in female Asian Elephant. Zoos' Print Journal. 18. DOI:10.11609/JoTT.ZPJ.18.9.1202.)

column4: तद्विस्तार्य च पुस्तकं परिचितं कीर्णैर्वचोदेवता-भूषामेचकमौक्तिकैरिव हठाक्षिप्तेक्षणैरक्षरैः । व्याहारेण हृदन्तरालविहरद्विद्यावधूनूपुर-ध्वानभ्रान्तिकृता ततस्तदपठत्स्वं काव्यमव्याकुलः ॥ १४३ ॥
column5: tadvistārya ca pustakaṃ paricitaṃ kīrṇairvacodevatā-bhūṣāmecakamauktikairiva haṭhākṣiptekṣaṇairakṣaraiḥ | vyāhāreṇa hṛdantarālaviharadvidyāvadhūnūpura-dhvānabhrāntikṛtā tatastadapaṭhatsvaṃ kāvyamavyākulaḥ || 143 ||
column6: सरस्वतीभूषणभूतसितेतरमुक्ताफलैरिव रभसाकृष्टदृष्टिभिरक्षरैः सहितं पुस्तकं विस्तार्यानाकुलमना मनोमध्यक्रीडत्सरस्वतीपुरन्ध्रिनूपुरशब्दभ्रान्तिकृतोक्त्या श्रीकण्ठचरितं स पठितवान् ॥
column7: And then, having opened that book, whose letters readily captivated the eyes in the manner of black pearls scattered from the necklace of Goddess Speech, he read out his poem with confidence in a voice that sounded like the jingle of Lady Knowledge’s anklets as she strolled around in the innermost recess of his heart.
column8: N/A

column4: तत्काव्ये धृतदिव्यवर्त्मनि विशत्यन्तः ससन्तोषता-मश्रान्ताहितमूर्धधूननविधिव्याप्तेरभिव्यञ्जनात् । तेषां तत्र कपोलमूलपुलकव्याजाद्ववाम श्रुति-स्तत्तत्पीतचरान्यकाव्यनिवहव्यक्ताक्षरालीमिव ॥ १४४ ॥
column5: tatkāvye dhṛtadivyavartmani viśatyantaḥ sasantoṣatā-maśrāntāhitamūrdhadhūnanavidhivyāpterabhivyañjanāt | teṣāṃ tatra kapolamūlapulakavyājādvavāma śruti-stattatpītacarānyakāvyanivahavyaktākṣarālīmiva || 144 ||
column6: धृता लोकिकसरणी तदीयकाव्ये श्रुतेर्मध्यं प्रविशति सति शिरःकम्पेन चमत्कारं प्रकाशयतां सभ्यानां पुलकव्याजेन श्रवणं पूर्वपीतान्यमहाकाव्याक्षरपङ्क्तिमिवावमत्॥
column7: No sooner did his divine poem enter their hearts than the ears of the audience - who were making their joyfulness known through the continuous nodding of their heads – seemed to spit out the (dark) letters of all the other poems, which they had drunk in, under the pretext of the goosebumps sprouting on their cheek margins.
column8: N/A

column4: वाग्देवीपदधूलिविप्रुष इव व्यक्ताक्षरश्रेणय-स्तास्तत्काव्यवशंवदाः प्रतिपदं कौतूहलं तेनिरे । याः सद्यः श्रुतिरन्ध्रवर्त्मनि भृता(निभृता)वाप्तप्रवेशा दृशो-रानन्दानुगुणाकणानजनयंस्तेषां सतामश्रुणः ॥ १४५ ॥
column5: vāgdevīpadadhūlivipruṣa iva vyaktākṣaraśreṇaya- stāstatkāvyavaśaṃvadāḥ pratipadaṃ kautūhalaṃ tenire | yāḥ sadyaḥ śrutirandhravartmani bhṛtā(nibhṛtā)vāptapraveśā dṛśo-rānandānuguṇākaṇānajanayaṃsteṣāṃ satāmaśruṇaḥ || 145 ||
column6: सरस्वतीसूक्तिकणा इव व्यक्तवर्णास्तत्काव्यपुस्तकान्तरपङ्क्तय आश्चर्यं चक्रुः । याः कर्णमार्गप्रविष्टा दृष्टेर्हर्षाश्रुकणानुदपादयन् ॥
column7: The sharply carved rows of letters in the poem’s manuscript, appearing like particles of dust adhering to the feet of Sarasvati, generated continuous curiosity because, having gained full entry into the hollow of the learned men’s ears, they filled their eyes with teardrops of joy
column8: The cause for curiosity is the fact that the letters, standing for dust particles, enter in through the ears and fill the eyes with teardrops.

column4: उद्यद्वैद्युतदीप्तिसोदरसरत्सारस्वतज्योतिषा पूतस्तद्वचसां रसः श्रुतिपुटैः संसत्सदामापपे । तेषामुन्मिषितालसालसगतौ दृक्शुक्तिपङ्क्तौ शनै-रानन्दाश्रुपृषन्मयी तु जघटे मुक्ताफलानां ततिः ॥ १४६ ॥
column5: udyadvaidyutadīptisodarasaratsārasvatajyotiṣā pūtastadvacasāṃ rasaḥ śrutipuṭaiḥ saṃsatsadāmāpape | teṣāmunmiṣitālasālasagatau dṛkśuktipaṅktau śanai-rānandāśrupṛṣanmayī tu jaghaṭe muktāphalānāṃ tatiḥ || 146 ||
column6: विद्युत्समसारस्वततेजसा निर्दोषस्तत्काव्यरसः श्रवणपुटैः श्रुतिमुखैः पीतः, तेषां सभासदामुन्मिषन्त्यां दृष्टिशुक्तिपङ्क्तौ हर्षाश्रुप्रकृतिर्मुक्ताफलपङ्क्तिर्घटिता ॥
column7: The ear cavities of the assembled scholars sipped his poem’s aesthetic essence/water – made pure by the spreading light of knowledge, that is akin to the lightning’s glow/blaze of the oceanic fire, in association with the lightning’s glow – but it was in the row of their eyes, swinging languidly like oyster shells, that a cluster of pearls in the form of joyful teardrops formed gradually.
column8: N/A

column4: सद्वृत्ताश्च सुसूक्ष्मदर्शनकलायोग्याश्च तत्सूक्तय-स्ताः सिद्धार्थतयैव कस्य न मनो निन्युर्घनस्नेहताम् । आसीना वलमानमूर्धनि तदा तस्मिन्वचोदेवता सच्चक्रे व्यतनिष्ट या बहुमुखश्च्योतद्रसस्रोतसः ॥ १४७॥
column5: sadvṛttāśca susūkṣmadarśanakalāyogyāśca tatsūktaya-stāḥ siddhārthatayaiva kasya na mano ninyurghanasnehatām | āsīnā valamānamūrdhani tadā tasminvacodevatā saccakre vyataniṣṭa yā bahumukhaścyotadrasasrotasaḥ || 147 ||
column6: सन्ति वृत्तानि वसन्ततिलकादीनि यासु, सन्तो वृत्ताश्च । सुसूक्ष्मा या दर्शनकला ज्ञानकला च तत्र योग्याः । तीक्ष्णमतिगम्या इत्यर्थः । दर्शने शैवादौ च योग्याः । तत्सूक्तयः सिद्धाभिधेयतयान्यूनातिरिक्ततया सर्षपत्वेन च । सर्वेषां मनो घनप्रीतितां [घनतैलत्वं] च निन्युः । चमत्कारेण कम्पमानशिरसि साधुवर्गे च निविष्टा सरस्व​ती याः स्रवद्रसप्रवाहा व्यतनोत् । चक्रे निवेश्य च सिद्धार्थान्स्रवद्रसान्करोति॥
column7: His well-rounded words, graspable by the power of an extremely subtle vision, infused everyone’s heart with dense delight/oil, thanks to their clarity of meaning/mustardiness. Assigning them (i.e., the words, that resembled mustard seeds) to the circle of (assembled) scholars whose heads nodded (in appreciation)/a sturdy hand mill, equipped with a rotating upper part, the Goddess of speech made them ooze streams of aesthetic juice/oily liquid in all directions.
column8: Siddhārthatā' = 'clarity of meaning'/'mustardiness'.

column4: स प्रक्रान्तविचारसूरिदशनज्योत्स्नात्तभस्माप्लुतिः स्वव्याख्येयधुरां महेश्वरकथाबन्धुः प्रबन्धोऽन्वभूत् । सत्कल्लोलविलोलतां त्रिजगतीशंस्यस्य यस्याग्रही- दग्रे वक्रकलातिथेर्बुधजनानन्दाश्रुमन्दाकिनी ॥ १४८ ॥
column5: sa prakrāntavicārasūridaśanajyotsnāttabhasmāplutiḥ svavyākhyeyadhurāṃ maheśvarakathābandhuḥ prabandho'nvabhūt | satkallolavilolatāṃ trijagatīśaṃsyasya yasyāgrahī-dagre vakrakalātitherbudhajanānandāśrumandākinī || 148 ||
column6: विचारयतां सूरीणां दन्तभासा आत्तभस्मस्नानस्त्रिपुरारिचरितान्तरङ्गः प्रबन्धः काव्यं स्वव्याख्येयस्य महेश्वरस्य साम्यं प्रापत् । त्रिजगत्स्तुत्यस्य तथा वक्रोक्त्या परिचितस्य यस्याग्रे बुधजनहर्षाश्रुगङ्गा तरङ्गितत्वमग्रहीत् । ईश्वरश्चन्द्रगङ्गे धारयति ॥
column7: Bathed in the holy ash, namely, the lustre beaming forth like moonlight from the bright teeth of the thoughtful scholars (in the assembly), the Poetic Composition - narrator of Shiva’s exploit – put on a semblance of the object of its description (i.e., Shiva) since like him, it too is praiseworthy in the three worlds and exhibits the crescent moon/art of obliquity and since the celestial Ganga of the learned connoisseur’s joyous tears surged forth wave after wave in its presence.
column8: N/A

column4: सारस्वतस्य महसः प्रथमा शिखेव सा मङ्खकस्य ववृते धुरि सूक्तिरेका । दग्धुं मनः खलजनस्य कपोलराग-भङ्ग्या व्यधत्त वचनेष्विव या स्व​​​​मोजः ॥ १४९ ॥
column5: sārasvatasya mahasaḥ prathamā śikheva sā maṅkhakasya vavṛte dhuri sūktirekā | dagdhuṃ manaḥ khalajanasya kapolarāga-bhaṅgyā vyadhatta vacaneṣviva yā svamojaḥ || 149 ||
column6: सरस्वतीतेजोभिनवा ज्वालेव सा मङ्खकस्य सूक्तिः । या दुर्जनानां चित्तं दग्धुमिव मत्सरोत्थितगण्डारुणत्वव्याजान्निजं तेज इव व्यधात् ॥
column7: Mankha’s poem, appearing like the first flame of the fire of knowledge, flickered all alone at the very forefront (of all poems), lending its fiery glow to the words constituting it, (a glow) which sought to burn the hearts of wicked men and masqueraded as the (jealous) blush of their cheeks.
column8: N/A

column4: इत्यादिभिः प्रकरणैर्बुधसाधुवादा-नादाय चेतसि दधत्परितोषमुद्राम् । तत्काव्यपुस्तकमथार्पयति स्म तस्मै पूजाक्षणे त्रिजगतीगुरवे हराय ॥ १५० ॥
column5: ityādibhiḥ prakaraṇairbudhasādhuvādā-nādāya cetasi dadhatparitoṣamudrām | tatkāvyapustakamathārpayati sma tasmai pūjākṣaṇe trijagatīgurave harāya || 150 ||
column6: पण्डितकृतं यशः श्रुत्वा परितुष्य स पूजावसरे परमेश्वराय काव्यं न्यवेदयत् ॥
column7: Bearing the stamp of joyful contentment in his heart by listening to the compliments of scholars in the course of interactions such as these, he offered his poem’s manuscript to Shiva, Master of the triple world, on the occasion of worship.
column8: N/A

column4: इक्षुक्षीरसधर्मनिर्मलरसस्रोतःसमुल्लासना-दातन्वान इवाधिकाधिकमहास्नानक्रियाप्रक्रियाम् । तेनाग्रे निहितश्चराचरगुरोर्वक्रीभवन्मूर्तिभिः शब्दैरङ्कुरितप्रणाम इव स प्रौढिप्रबन्धोऽधिनोत् ॥ १५१ ॥
column5: ikṣukṣīrasadharmanirmalarasasrotaḥsamullāsanā-dātanvāna ivādhikādhikamahāsnānakriyāprakriyām | tenāgre nihitaścarācaragurorvakrībhavanmūrtibhiḥ śabdairaṅkuritapraṇāma iva sa prauḍhiprabandho'dhinot || 151 ||
column6: इक्षुमधुरस्य क्षीरनिर्मलस्य रसस्रोतसः स्फुरणान्महास्नानमिव ददत्स प्रबन्धो वक्रीभवद्रूपैः शब्दैर्हेतुभिः कृतप्रणाम इव महेश्वरस्याग्रे निहितोऽप्रीणयत् । अन्योऽपि शर्कराक्षीराभ्यां भगवतो महास्नानं ददत्प्रणमंश्च प्रीणयति ॥
column7: Performing a grand ritual ablution (to Shiva), as it were, by releasing a stream of pure aesthetic bliss/water, akin to sugarcane (in sweetness) and milk (in purity), the dignified Poetic Work, which, when placed before the Lord of the movables and immovables, seemed to bend before him in salutation through its slanting letters, inspired joy (in the audience).
column8: Devotees worship Shiva by pouring sugarcane juice and milk over his image and prostrating before it (JR).

column4: पितुर्बिभ्राणस्य स्मररिपुपुरीपौरपदवीं नियोगेन स्पप्ने पदमुपगतेन श्रवणयोः । प्रबन्धं सन्धायेत्यधिकविबुधश्लाघ्यनिरघ-क्रमं मङ्खः सौख्यं किमपि हृदये कन्दलयति ॥ १५२ ॥
column5: piturbibhrāṇasya smararipupurīpaurapadavīṃ niyogena spapne padamupagatena śravaṇayoḥ | prabandhaṃ sandhāyetyadhikavibudhaślāghyaniragha-kramaṃ maṅkhaḥ saukhyaṃ kimapi hṛdaye kandalayati || 152 ||
column6: महेश्वरलोकस्थस्य पितुराज्ञया स्वप्ने श्रुतया विबुधस्तुतं तच्छ्रीकण्ठचरितं काव्यं भगवते निवेद्य स मङ्खको मनसि कमप्यानन्दं प्रकाशयति ॥
column7: Having thus composed this poem - highly acclaimed by poets and scholars for its faultless execution – by the command of his father - a denizen of Shiva’s divine abode -  who appeared in his dream, Mankha cherishes a rare contentment in his heart.
column8: N/A

column4: इति  श्रीपण्डितलोलतनयपण्डितनोनराजतनय​श्रीजोनराजकृतया टीकया समेतः श्रीराजानकविश्ववर्तसूनोर्महाकविराजराजानकश्रीमङ्खकस्य कृतौ श्रीकण्ठचरिते महाकाव्ये (ग्रन्थकर्तृकविकालीनकविपण्डितादिवर्णनं नाम​) पञ्चविंशः सर्गः ॥
column5: iti śrīpaṇḍitalolatanayapaṇḍitanonarājatanayśrījonarājakṛtayā ṭīkayā sametaḥ śrīrājānakaviśvavartasūnormahākavirājarājānakaśrīmaṅkhakasya kṛtau śrīkaṇṭhacarite mahākāvye (granthakartṛkavikālīnakavipaṇḍitādivarṇanaṃ nāma) pañcaviṃśaḥ sargaḥ ||
column7: Thus ends the Twenty-fifth Canto (named 'Description of the poets and scholars contemporaneous with the poet who composed this work'), in the Mahākāvya 'Śrīkaṇṭhacarita', composed by Shri Rajanaka Mankha, king among great poets, son of Shri Rajanaka Vishvavarta, and provided with a commentary by Shri Jonaraja, son of Pandita Nonaraja, who is the son of Shri Pandita Lola.
